reviews.review: Basilica of San Giovanni. This is certainly worth a visit just to see the internal architecture as well as the beautiful paintings and great sculpture there. We didn't have to queue and just moved through at a steady pace.
worth visiting. The basilica is really beautiful and worth visiting. I was really impressed with all details inside.

Fantastic statues. Free entry and no big queues.
As with most of the large Basilicas in Rome the architecture and decoration is amazing. However, the highlight in this Basilica are the larger than life statues of the 12 apostles - absolutely awe inspiring.
Wonderful!. The structural works really amazes me! This basilica is the oldest of 4 major basilicas so make sure to visit.

The Cathedral of Rome. Incredible beauty both in architecture and in the art work. Stunning. Wonderful to just sit and take it all in. Lots of tours entering so a bit noisy in spite of many trying to be quiet.

A must see Basilica!. This is the first church to be built in Rome and it contains several sacred relics. Popes were crowned here until the 19th century. The artwork is breathtaking. Far less crowded than St. Peter's, you will be be able to thoroughly enjoy this magnificent Basilica.
Do not miss. It is not one of the top recommended churches - and actually i don't know why. I definatelly liked this one the best. Stunning, big with marvellous sculptures - a must-see!

Beautiful Church. In the middle of the city you will find this beautiful church. A must see as it really is spectacular. You will need to line up and have your bag checked and women will need to cover their legs with a wrap that they provide.

Incredible Basilica!. This is my 3rd favorite basilica. That sounds bad but it is hard to measure up to St. Peter's and St. Paul outside the walls. The outside is magnificent and the inside is truly breathtaking. It sounds cliche but it is true. If you are a spiritual person you will feel something inside. The amazing statues, paintings and ceilings inspired the awe they were intended to. Make the trip, it is absolutely worth it!

Great Church to visit. Our trip was a pilgrimage for the Year of Mercy and this is a must see. One of 4 Major Basilicas in Rome. You can't the history and significance of this church and the relics that you will see inside.

Brilliant. I'm coming at this from the perspective of an American tourist. The thing about the US is, there's lots of religious people. Like, really religious Evangelical Christians. And there's churches everywhere. It's sort of how this entire country developed. But since the US is young, there's not really any super old churches. There are cathedrals like St Paul's in NYC and the National Cathedral in DC that are really impressive. But to understand the force of Christianity through the ages, you've got to visit Europe. And this Lateran basilica is a good place to start.

If you like Italianate churches. this one is a monster with extensive paintings, frescos and statues, etc. Other sources will give more detail but it is worth the short diversion from the centre of Rome to see. It is also at the start/end of a number of church/mosaic/Marian trails.

My favorite of all of Italy.... Huge glorious church with wonderful architectural designs. Very large statues and the ceiling is all in gold...Impressive..Love the mosaic stories on the floors and walls. ancient history for sure...Lovely...

A very historic basilica of great importance to the Catholic Churc. The original church was built in 324 AD and was the first Christian Basilica in Rome. Although the original was destroyed by two fires, the church today has numerous parts of historical importance. The Baldachin, which dates to the 14th century, supposedly holds relics of Saint Peter and Saint Paul. For several hundred years, the church was the main place for the Popes to say Mass. The marble interior was the work of Francesco Borromini in the year 1650 and the golden gilt ceiling is an incredible sight to see. Giotto has left his mark on this church with a beautiful fresco. One must include this basilica, which is Rome's official cathedral today, on the list of must see places.

A lovely place to see. This is the church in which my parents got married in 1981 so it was amazing to see it and it's annexes. A lot of deeply religious people were here to see the most important Catholic church in the world and this in itself was moving to see. People praying on the steps of Maria of the stairs, throwing money down the stairs, etc. A good view of traditional culture.
amazing church. amazing church, at the arts are something !! i am glad that i did not miss this attractionthanks trip advisor i never miss out the best of anything anymore
A classic basilica. A significant contributor to Church History, technically still part of the Vatican. Worth visiting, best of a knowledgeable guide.

Grand, serene, historical and amazing. Has so many beautiful sights for Pilgrim/Catholic visitors and also for general tourists.The frescoes are outstanding, as well as the sculptures, relief in siver of the 'Last Supper', plus the main Altar, Papal throne and frescoes above. The exterior facade is unforgettable.This is the Cathedral of the world. Not to be missed!

Fabulous church and artwork. This was our first time to St John Lateran, and we will be back! It is gorgeous and the artwork is breathtaking!This is the oldest of the 4 major basilicas in Rome.We prayed with a group tour inside...no while we don't understand Italian, it was amazing...we felt close to Jesus.

Not to be missed. In past trips to Rome, we did not visit this historical and beautiful church as it is a bit far from all the other attractions. This is one of the most lavish and beautiful basilicas we have been in. The art is of the masters.

Sunday visits. We visited the place on a Sunday. We had an audio guided tour in the court yard but the museum was closed so I think it was not a good for value decision. On Sundays entry is free for everybody only to the church. The church itself is a magnificent masterpiece. Quiet, peaceful and full of art, songs and people praying.
Beautiful . The oldest church , beautiful , you can feel history and God. If you are in Rome you must go there..
Beautiful and magnificent !!. The basilica was the center of the Catholic Church until the Saint Peter got finished. It worth the drive there. Lots of history and art !!!

Under Rated! This will wow you!. From the outside, you might be a little disappointed. Don't let this stop you. Head inside and be amazed. Be sure to either listen to recordings just inside the church or better yet, get the audio guide. The history of this church dates back to about 400 AD. It is a short walk from the San Giovanni Metro B stop. Viewing the art and architecture inside is well worth the time.
Look Closely!. Everything you see has immense detail, don't just follow the crowed round, take your time to look at the walls and ceilings in more detail to really capture what life was like!
Beautiful. We came here to do the Holy Door and ended up staying and admiring the Basilica. There was no line and it was easy to take pictures.

Most impressive basilica interior we saw.. So we saw the Sistine Chapel, St Peter's Basilica and about 12 others. This was our favorite interior by a good margin. The design is just jaw dropping and well worth a visit. It is hard to describe how awe inspiring this inside is and visitor photos don't do it justice. It is massive and beautiful. Also the outside has some very neat statues out on the top of the building. Make sure you see it, but maybe save it for last so you can enjoy the other buildings before this one.

Impressive Another must see. Very cool basilica, insanely impressive just be carfel not to fall over as your eyes are drawn to all of the amazing paintings, sculptures, and gold everywhere around you.

Magnificant. This is a bit off of the usual tourist routes but worth the walk to see. The original Basilica was built in the 4th century and was one of the first Christian churches built in Rome. Although destroyed by fire twice the Basilica more or less retains its original dimensions. All Popes were crowned here until 1870 and the palace next door was the Popes official residence until 1309 when they moved to Avignon. The imposing main entrance has bronze doors which came from Curia (the location of the first Senate or chief council of state). The inside is beautiful with its centrepiece being the very grand Papal Alter. The Gothic baldacchino is decorated with vibrant frescoes from the 14th century. Don't forget to look up at the ceiling which is a masterpiece.
Should not be missed!. We visited thru a tour of basilicas and catacombs. A wonderful experience. Breathtaking beauty and of course, the Holy Stairs, a most wonderful pious devotions for Catholics!

Pomp and a show of Richess that makes you think sad thoughts. The Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano is a huge edifice that reflects the immense power that the catholic church had attained in the world. There is no humility in this building. The size of the building itself and the size of the sculptures that adorn it are meant to impress and awe the believers. Gold and expensive marbles are employed to create a statement of absolute power. If you like such shows of power, you would enjoy it, it is very well done. if you are more like me, you sit there and think sad thoughts about what had happened to a faith that started from the grass roots of suffering people. I could not avoid thinking about Martin Luther who nailed to the door his famous edicts, and I felt myself the need to go out and nail to the door the well-known American saying: "power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely". if you take this visit do not skip the cloister, for 5 euro you see a beautiful early construction that still invites you to a peaceful contemplation without bamboozing your mind without shows of richness and power.

The best. If your only have time to see one more church after St. Peter's this is the one to head to it will not disappoint .I have seen so many and always take people here.you will need to go through security now.it is the oldest basilica in Rome I think please look it up
Simply stunning!!!. Wow! So beautiful. This is a must see. It's worth every minute of your time in Rome to discover this masterpiece!!!

One of the Great Churches of Rome. This is a great basilica both inside and outside, and the main church of Rome. The magnificent ceiling, cloisters and statues of the 12 apostles are features. Make sure to visit the holy stairs across the road in an separate wing of the basilica.

The Roman Cathedral. There are several good reasons not to miss this place, starting from the astonishing architecture and ending with the charming Battistero just behind the main church. But you'll need only a good one: the beauty of the silence you can experience there.
One of the top "other churches" in Rome. We used a Viator guide for 3 unbelievable churches other than St. Peter's. Same excellent rating for Santa Maria Maggiore and St. Paul's.

The Best in Rome. This is the archbasilica. It is steeped in history, it has the most significant meaning to Catholics. It has stories.Do not miss the Holy Stairs across from the basilica. Catholic doctrine says they were transported from Jerusalem. They were taken from the digs of Pontious Pilate. It is said that these stairs were the stairs that Jesus walked up after his arrest. And so is a most holy relic.Do not miss this church if that is what you like.

St John Lateran. This is a church that takes your breath away when you see the facade. The statues are larger than life, and the interior of the church is a sight to behold. This is the mother church of Roma, and the popes lived here for centuries. It is also the site of the holy stairs.
Very Interesting!. Quite an incredible place that is located near to the Colosseum. Very interesting and well worth the entrance fee. It's amazing how it is all still standing.

Church called the mother church of all churches of Christendom, the holiest place. Impressive in dimensions and importance of construction, full of the wonderful paintings and statues of angels, the church of St. John Lateran was for centuries the seat of popes in Rome. Here are actually the papal throne, before they left to Avignon and to Vatican nowaday. It is a beautiful and magnificent holy place and I was proud to visit it.
One of my preferred basillica's in Rome.. Elegant, stylish and a church where art combined with a prayer always provide you with power and a smile.

Awe inspiring. Just so hard to put to words the awe this Church inspired in these Catholic tourists as we entered through the Holy Door to see all of the sites inside. Simply amazing. We were able to light candles inside and sit and contemplate where we were. Very moving experience!

The most beautiful of them all! . Listen guys, i like basilicas and enjoy visiting on them. This one is the most beautiful one so don't miss it.
It even has some small private rooms and if your'e lucky, you might catch a private missa, making this experience even greater!

Better than St. Peter's. This was my favorite basilica in Rome. It felt more sacred then most and way less crowded. It was decorated with amazing sculptures of martyrs and very little gold, which was a really nice change. The Holy Steps are right across the street as well. Definitely worth a visit

Spectacular Cathedral. This is a spectacular cathedral to visit and doesn't have the crowds of St Peters. A little away from the centre but well worth the walk. There is a security check on entry and knees and shoulders must be covered. Beautiful architecture, the statues of the 12 apostles are stunning. This is the year of mercy and you are allowed to walk through the holy door.While here go over the road to La Scala Santa and see the Holy Steps where Jesus was said to have walked. You will see or if you wish you can pray as you ascend the stairs on your knees.

Basilica of St. John Lateran. This Basilica is another of the must see churches in Rome. The architecture is magnificent and the Basilica is well worth a visit. Believe his is still the Pope's church in Rome

Another little gem!! . We had a few hours to spare on the last day do decided to visit after spotting the top of the church from the coliseum...was Defo worth it!! .... Stunning gold ceiling and frescos on the walls! Lovely and cool inside so a nice break from the blaring sun!! You do need to cover your shoulders inside and also have a reasonably long dress/skirt.

Beautiful peaceful basilica. Simple but yet beautiful basilica. There is scala Santa to pray on each of the staircase until you reach the top. There is chapel on the right side and peaceful feeling to pray. Worth to go to especially there is scala Santa.

Amazing. The Basilica is breath taking. So beautiful and Big! There is a lot of art work and beautiful statues and mosaics. The history of the church is awesome also. I would first visit this Basilica with a tour to get all the history or at least read up on it before you visit. We loved visiting all the Basilicas in Rome
Beautiful. Lovely church, really intricate carvings and pictures in the church. Worth seeing. The lines were not as long here making it so much more pleasant.

Good interior, great history. St. John Lateran, not The Vatican, is the most important church in Catholic history. Replaced a few hundred years ago as the Holy See (the seat of the church bureaucracy), St. John Lateran remain to this day the official seat of the Bishop of Rome, and the Bishop of Rome is the Pope
Beautiful Basilica. Officially the Pope's Cathedral this is very much worth a visit. We found it to be a beautiful building but not "over the top" in riche's like some.
stunning. the pictures and the architecture is just stunning I cannot use any other words to describe this venue

Biggest. A beautifull basilic where you can find a lot of Cristian testimoniances. Inside there is one Porta Santa a place that during the Jubilee year you accross and Haba many important fo catholics

Give yourself enough time to have a proper look around. This building is extremely significant in the history of the Roman Catholic Church. The finishes, artistry and sculptures are similar to St Peters in Rome. The alter where the Holy Sacrament is located is reportedly the table used for the Last Supper. Additionally, the chains the were supposedly used to confine St Peter are encased in glass in the centre near the main alter. The security was quite evident during our visit and be prepared to put your personal items through an X-Ray machine before being allowed to enter the Church.
amazing. beautiful and should not be missed-there are so many to see ut dont miss this one as it is easily accessible

Breathtaking. This is not only my favorite Basilica in Rome, it is the very first Italian church I ever saw (back in 1999). I bring almost everyone I meet to this amazing cathedral. Take your time, spend at least an hour.

A must see!. This stunning church was very close to our hotel and our taxi driver told us to visit as he said it is one of the most beautiful churches. We visited on our last day and I have to say I found it more impressive than the Vatican and no queues! We were extremely lucky that a service was taking place when we visited, but even without that it is really beautiful and I would recommend a visit.

beautiful to see! Breathtaking art. Worth the hot weather and crowds to see it.. A lovely church, breath taking art and history very interesting. The history of this Roman church goes back to ancient times. Not to be missed.
Visit. Wonderful and spectacular. Too bad you're so crowded the visit. This implies a lack of respect for what the site

Lovely. Visited San Giovanni as very close to my hotel and pleased I want as very worthwhile. It's a magnificent building with associated cloisters, currently 5 euros entry. In summary it's grand and interesting as the formal papal church while being quiet enough to be pleasant to visit. The cloisters have interesting pieces of cosmati art which make it good to visit but not worth the entry, though It's good the money goes to its upkeep.

Awesome....... We got the metro and walked through the gate and the Basilica just hits you. It is huge and the stunning interior just knocks you for six, the decoration is immense and is so easy to spend hours in there.

must see church. This basilica is the first church in The Roman Catholicism. This is where the pope's seat was for centuries (from 313 AD) before the rebuilding of St Peter's. Together with St Maria Maggiore -these three churches served as papal basilicas over the centuries. The basilica holds extrateritorail status, meaning it belongs to the Vatican.The interior is spacious and open. Supposedly the marble steps near the altar were brought from Holy Land by St Helen (Emperor Constantine's mother) as they were the street onto which Jesus walked to His Passion.

Wow!. Stayed at a B&B nearby and walked past this place everyday. When I finally went in, I was just amazed by the statues. They were also holding service when my husband and I went, so we got to sit for that.

A hidden gem. After the shoulder to shoulder experience of the Vatican, this church is a wonderful change. The quiet atmosphere invites visitors to spend time here, a welcome change from many of the other major attractions in Rome. The church is located about 1 mile from the Colosseum. My wife and I walked the distance which was a mistake on such a hot day. The church is very close to a metro station which makes arrival and departure much more efficient. As for the church itself, its historical significance and architectural beauty make it a must. They have a small gift shop tucked into an unnoticed corner where I bought a guide book that explained more about the history of the church than I can write about in a short posting. After reading that book, I can honestly say it was a privilege to have visited this magnificent and historic structure.

Beautifully Ornate!. This is the Pope's official seat in Rome, which is slightly confusing! However, the cathedral is typical in its beautiful decoration inside, and as with many other catholic buildings, make sure you look up! The ceiling is mostly flat in this cathedral and is beautifully and ornately carved, painted, and covered in gold leaf.It is slightly off the track for most central sights in Rome, but worth the detour (our hop-on hop-off bus stopped there).
Don't bother. A very disappointing visit. Nowhere the grandeur of the other churches of Rome. the attached gift shop is very cramped but a good range of items

Ancient Church Built by Constatine. This church was the original Christian church of Rome built by Constantine in the 4th Century. It contains relics of the body of Peter and Paul and the Bishop's Chair (seat of the Pope) The ancient design is in contrast to the Vatican, built a millenium later.
Moving. Gorgeous architecture, beautiful and truly peaceful - not as many tourists. This Basilica is a must see when in Rome!

Spectacular Cathedral, wonderful Cloister. This is a spectacular Cathedral and you don't have to deal with the crowds that you will see in St. Peter's. In addition to touring the Cathedral itself, there is a wonderful Cloister that you can tour (paid admission). While many cloisters have a similar design, this one is executed very well, and the descriptions of the artifacts in English and Italian are top notch. It is a very peaceful, beautiful, and educational place. The other site that is very close is the Scala Santa, containing the Holy Steps, just across the street. While this might be considered a separate site, it is all in the same Piazza, and it would be a shame to miss the Holy Steps if you were right next door.

GORGEOUS, must-visit major basilica!. This Basilica is a little off the beaten path but well worth the visit! My fiance and I visited many beautiful places of worship in Rome/Vatican City, Barcelona, Paris, and London and this is one of my favorites. Definitely smaller than some of the more well known basilicas, like St. Peter's and Sagrada Familia in Barcelona but for some reason, this place had an even better ambiance, perhaps because there are less tourists here. Beautiful sculptures of the 12 apostles flank the great hall, do yourself a favor and check out the sculptures above each apostle as well. We visited close to closing time; less crowded and such a reverential ambiance visiting in those late afternoon/early evening hours. Well worth the visit!

Beyond HUGE!!!. Huge doesn't quiet fit to describe this place. The statues of the 12 apostles here are colossal. I was taken a back, straddled, and hit my glutts on the hard, cold, and cool marbled floor literally on my first look on one of these statue's stature. Its ceilings are extremely awesome. Angel/cherub figure at the aft of each column seemed ethreal. The mosaic, the throne, and the dome are uplifting. The cloister with those artifacts are unforgettable and educational. This place is a heaven already. There seemed to be a different kind of feel when one visits this place, then the St. Peter's vis a vis visiting St. Peter's Basilica first, then this place. FYI, shorts not allowed and this place is wheelchair accessible as well. There's a.taxi.stop nearby. And if you are a Roman Catholoc like me, then visit the "Holy Stairs" nearby and climb up the stairs on your knees to express some love to the Holy Triune/Trinity.
The history was very informative. I learnt a lot the San Giovanni was one of my favourite the different altars and a place to sit and pray. the floor where other fathers are buried.
Amazing. The place is impressive, beautiful architecture, peaceful place, not as many tourists as usual, a wonderful experience all together.
Magnificent. Great history and a must visit when in Rome. This is a Basilica and inside I was in awe with its magnificence. We took the tour and learned a lot about the history

mazing. We walked form our hotel to this place and found that next to this church there is the Holly Stairs where people pray and do penitence.The church is wonderful as you will see amazing pieces of art.Security check was quick and easy and this si not a crowded place as in the Vatican City.If you walk out of it for 100m you may found the old city walls that are worth to visit.
A must see in Rome!!. Read up on the history of this church before visiting, and make sure to visit the "Sacred Steps" across the street. One of the most beautiful places we visited.

Just WOW !!. For me this has got to be one of the most impressing building's I have seen in my life,I spent a week in Rome taking in as many sight's with my camera as I could but by far the inside of this is breathtaking and how many photo's I had taken I lost count,the roof,amazing! everywhere you look you've just to stand in awe.This is an absolute must see when in Rome

Spectacular. This is a beautiful Basilica. We did this Church in a walking tour of important and historic Churches in the area. There is security to get in and you must go through a metal detector. You also have to be covered up and they enforce this rule. There are plenty of vendors selling scarves out side if you have forgotten one, but it is best to buy one and have it with you throughout Rome. The ceiling in this Church is quite impressive and even the kids were impressed by our visit there. There is a door of Mercy open this year and we took advantage of going through that for a special blessing. They are very strict about what you have on to go through the door here and at the Vatican. We saw them turn people away. We had one in our party that didn't have a shawl so she stayed out, one went in and then went out and gave her the shawl. she thought that she would pass the entrance, but had a sleeveless top on with a small cap sleeve. There was a group of people attending Mass while we were in there, They were from Australia and were going to World Youth Day in Poland. We meet them at the Holy Stairs which was the next place we went quite close to this one. Well worth a visit. Not too crowded even in mid July.
Moving Experience. The Basilica is beautiful and gives time for reflection. Much less crowded than St. Peter's or St. Paul's. Holy Stairs are a short distance and well worth the effort.

Summer 2016 Rome. This Basilica is stunning. The statues of the apostles are absolutely gorgeous (inside and out). As it is the Year of Mercy, the Holy Door is open. Women MUST cover up, please bring a wrap if you plan on going.

Wonderful. Take the time to absorb the special place here. Security was quick, X-ray unit etc. The building is filled with jaw dropping art. Take the time to visit the baptisry around the back, when I was there I was the only person enjoying this special building.

:D. Rome is Rome, simply amazing!
This is nust a small part of what it can offer, be sure to visit the Arcibasilica di San Giovanni in Laterano!
Beautiful Church. It is such a beautiful church, worth the visit. You can also spend time there in prayer and just feel at peace.

Huge, ornate cathedral. This very ornate basilica is Rome's official cathedral and the seat of the Pope in his role as Bishop of Rome. It features huge statues of the 12 apostles on the roof and inside. The interior is stunning but I couldn't help feeling that it was built to glorify the popes and not God. Well worth a visit though and also go to see the nearby baptistery.
A must while in Rome. Absolutely wonderful basilica, a lot larger than I had originally thought, quite near the Metro, so no travel worries,Yet another Rome marvel

Wonderful architectural gem. I keep returning to this basilica with every trip to Rome. Its inspiring architecture, sublime interior decprations, superb statuary and peaceful - when compared to St Peter's- interiors reward the art lover with a fulfilling sentiment of spiritual replenishment.

Magnifcent building in a charming area. “Mother of all churches”and the Seat of the Pope, it is well worth the walk or bus ride. Impressive statutmes of the twelve apostles. It is lovely to explore a quieter part of Roma and wander around in the near vicinity too
Must. Must see when in Rome. Less busy than the Vatican but very beautiful . Make sure you cove knees and shoulders

The Doors and the Stairs. Technically, this church is the home church of the Bishop of Rome [ the Pope]. While the interior is very tastefully done with statutes of the apostles, there are two attractions you must see. First, as you enter the antechamber to the church, look for the two big bronze doors that are the center doors of the church. These are the doors from the Roman Senate in the nearby Forum.Second, across the street from the church, there is a building that used to be the home of the Pope before the Vatican. Now covered with wood are 28 stairs from the palace of Pontius Pilate that Jesus is said to have walked. These stairs were brought to Rome at the behest of Constantine's Christian mother. On any given day you will find pilgrims crawling up the stairs on their knees as a sign of reverence.If for no other reasons than those mentioned above, this is a must see. Additionally, it is one of the four basilicas of Rome along with St. Paul Outside the Walls, St Peter in Chains, and St Maria Maggiore. During holy years, special doors at these churches are open to allow the faithful to pass through. Otherwise the doors are closed.

Beautiful Church- Take a bus!. St. John Lateran is an impressive basilica with beautiful art. Be sure to pick up a bus near St. Mary Major and ride it to get closer. It can be a long walk otherwise. Nice obelisk nearby as well.
Majestic!. It was well worth the line at the inspection section before entering the church. Very solemn. Every corner of the church is filled with majestic beauty.

Beautiful. The Archbasilica of St. John in Lateran is a lavishly decorated and beautiful basilica - more so and also much more quiet than St. Peter's. The giant statues of the twelve apostles are a highlight. My favourite church in Rome!

Mother and mistress of all the churches!. The Lateran is as impressive as it's appellation.
We had a nice time exploring this grandiose and ancient Church. Even bought a memento from their souvenir store.
Close by is the Scala Santa, the Santa Croce en Jerusalem, and am large statue of St Francis of Assisi

After St Peter Basilica and Pantheon, the next church to visit. Rome has a plethora of churches and may not be easy to select which one to go. St Peter basilica and the Pantheon are no brainers. The next one can be debated, but San Giovanni in Laterano should be a major contender. It is the seat of the pope, who is also the bishop of Rome, and, although not as grandiose as St Peter, it is still quite impressive. And beautiful. And not half as crowded as the Vatican. Worth a visit.

Impressive . There are many statues in Rome but even after 3 days of touring around galleries and churches the 12 apostles in this magnificent church were impressive; it was well worth the treck at the end of a long day and we won't forget this visit.

Impressive!. Magnificent Basilica! A little out of the way, but well worth the effort. You can go and visit while in the vicinity of the Coliseum and Baths of Caracalla.Spacious, beautiful and less crowded, so greater chance for peaceful viewing and reflection.And while there, do go and see Sancta Scala across the road.

Beautiful Basilica. The exterior is magnificent with its large columns and statues. This is the oldest church in Italy, I believe, and the official seat of the Pope. Entry to the majority of the Basilica is free. When we visited there was a large service taking place which was great to see but meant we didn't get to explore the interior fully. Don't forget to also visit the Lantern Baptistery while you are in the area.
Basilica to rival St Peters. Amazing decor, allow at least a couple of hours to appreciate this church amazing photo opportunities but flash photography not allowed

Lovely visit. Great interiors, remarkable doors, and make sure to make it to the cloister -- significant, worth the few Euros it costs to get in it. The rest if free and of relatively easy access -- appropriately guarded by armed forces, as unfortunately these days in age it has become necessary to keep everyone safe... Worth the visit!

Stunning!. Unbelievable architecture and art. The larger than life statues are awesome, so detailed and imposing. The beautiful, well kept cloisters were a quiet break from the busy, yet respectful crowds in the basilica. Plenty of quiet areas for reflection and prayer. Just beautiful!

Official seat of the Pope. Enormous and beautiful. As the actual seat of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope), this is an absolutely gorgeous Basilica. After you see St. Peter's make sure you take time to see St. John in Lateran you won't be disappointed.

Amazing Basilica. One of the four major basilicas of Rome. This one, as I recall, also has pictures of all 265(?) Popes with the current Pope illuminated at the end of the two aisles. It is spacious, not crowded and worth visiting.
This is the first (historically) of the major basilicas, although it has been rebuilt and remodeled many times.

stunning architecture, welcome change from overstuffed barocco of roman churches. beautiful. a must while in rome
unlike 99% of roman churches interior is of high taste and quality. no more overwhelming gold and bad paintings.
additionally it's the most important church in rome higher than st. peter

Veneration. The church is beautiful and not too busy because it is out of the way. People unhappy and terrible volunteers, screaming from the topic his lungs to people telling them to be quiet. Incredible in the year of mercy. Not a welcoming space.

Keep the time in mind if you go. The basilica itself is big but not very impressive from the exterior or interior. But it was going up against some of the most beautiful in the world that we already have seen on our trip, so maybe that assessment isn't fair. But to be honest, I think most people come to this church, which is kind of out of the way from other major sites, to see/scale the Holy Stairs. If this is your main motivation for visiting, check when they are open because the church itself stay open longer than the stairs.
Wonderful . Not so crowded compared to most of the other sights in Rome. Wonderful church with a serene ambience. So beautiful and and humbling.

Stunningly beautiful and inspiring. With nearly 1,000 churches in Rome, St. John Lateran should be on your short list. This is the cathedral of the Diocese of Rome, of which the Pope is the reigning bishop. As a result, the Roman Catholic Church has named it "The Mother of All Churches" and it has first place in honor of all churches ever built.

Arch Basilica of all Basilica. This is the Arch Basilica of all the basilicas in Rome and all over the world. This is the Cathedral of Rome. Much less people and not crowded as compared with the St. Peter Basilica in the Vatican. A must see while in Rome.
Worth the trouble to get there!. San Giovanni in Laterano was so wonderful, we came back a week later with our friends. It features art and architecture from a millenium or more of Christianity.

Hidden gem. As we was based near the Basilica San Giovanni we had noticed it on our first day .It took us until the very end of our trip to get there but what a basilica , Beauifully ,ornate a most for anyone who loves looking at beautiful churches .

Ohh yes. If you want to treat yourself to a nice experience then visiting this church will do it. The statues of the 12 disciples (apostles) are really nice and the overall inner architecture is gorgeous. I went there with my girlfriend and the only regret that we have is that the museum of the treasure was closed in that period.You could see part of it through a glass wall, but if there is any possibility of going in please do it.

Historic Papal Palace at St. John Lateran. An awesome and grand Archbasilica, which is actually the Pope's basilica in the city of Rome. So beautiful and historic. What we loved was that there is so much to see, and less people to distract you. We stayed nice and long, and were able to savor the beauty.
Absolute Favorite. The real Church of Rome. And this is the Pope's Church. Wow and awe inspiring. So glad we did not miss this.

Seat of the Pope. Actually enjoyed this one more than St. Peter's. It was stunning, with incredible art and a peaceful atmosphere. We were fortunate to catch part of Mass there, with a Cardinal presiding. Hard to concentrate with all that beauty around us. Definitely worth the trip to get there.
One on the 500 churces in Rome that should be visited. Close to Colloseum this is the Cathedral of Rome. I cannot say much in words but I was impressed. Near metro San Giovanni line A.

Super impressive!. I visit Rome at least once a year and this basilica has become one of my regular stops each time for "renewal." Monumental statues of the apostles, superb paintings, and architecture on a grand scale. Five euros to visit the adjacent cloister not really worth it to me unless you're really into the historical details.

The Bishop of Rome`s cathedral. Bult on the site of a Roman palace of the laterani family, this is my favourite big basilica with its spacious and airy interior, its monumental statues of the apostles, its wonderful apse with mosaics and the Gothic baldinchino. Don`t miss going to a service here if you can when the building comes into its own liturgically with the space for processions and movement during the mass. And don`t miss ther Baptistery round the side to get a flavour of its ancient origins 1,000 years before the Baroque architects gave it a makeover.

I love this place. Having been here a couple of years ago, I deliberately booked a nearby hotel for a stopover this year. I cannot begin to describe the excellence of the art and statues. I don't know why the popes left here in favour of St Peter's, but that's our gain. Worth paying for an audioguide. Worth popping over the road to the scala santa as well
Beautiful Basilica to visit. We did the 4 major Vatican tour with City of Wonders/Discovery tours. Beautiful Basilica with a Holy door for the Jubilee year of Mercy. Worth the visit.

Beautiful . Lovely church with lots of fascinating details and lovely dome cupola. Worth a visit even if your not religious as it's rather beautiful and has a serene welcoming atmosphere. Lovely acoustics and frescos. A free attraction perfect for escaping the sun with no queues to get in. As with many Roman churches there is a dress code and shoulders need to be covered. We did not pay for cloisters or a tour and if going to appreciate the church I wouldn't say you needed to do either to have an interesting visit.

An amazing place. This was the first church we visited in Rome and may have spoiled us. They open earlier than most sites (7am) so we went there first to get a start on the day. There was only one other person in the church when we got there around 7:45am so we got to explore by ourselves. I was amazed at the detail all around but especially in the ceilings.
Amazing?. Even if religion is not your thing just go and look up. The ceilings and architecture is wow! Just go and look!
Beautiful . Beautiful Papal basilica in Rome. Lots of history and great architecture. A must see while visiting the city. It is open to the public.
Lovely basilica recommended by our tour guide. I wouldn't miss this basilica, if you are in the neighborhood especially. It is monumental and cool inside.

Highest Church in Christendom. I entered the church alone because my father only had a tank top on and the peddlers outside told us he wasn't allowed in without covering his shoulders. What I enjoyed most about the churches in Rome was seeing the tombs of important figures, notably in this one Pope Leo XIII (the tomb is on the ceiling!)
Must see.. The marble sculptures of the apostles were my favorites. This one is very peaceful and much less crowded than the others. This is the seat of the pope so PLEASE so not miss this one.
Holy place for quiet prayer.. Relatively quiet and peaceful. Attended a mass there and the singing was wonderful, opera singer quality. Holy door for the year of mercy has detailed carving.

Wow, the best Basilica in Rome.. This is the most important Basillica in Rome as it is the seat of the Pope. It is also an archbasillica.I loved my visit here, it is stunning and less crowded.The sculptures of the 12 apostles, the gilded ceilings and the fresco on the walls just makes in a must if in Rome.Very easy to get to, using the metro.

Old gems, must visit to see the wonder. Basically, one of the most well kept and maintained grand church in Rome. It gives you the nostalgia and goosebumps when entering it. There's that distinct old smell that you could appreciate.Really amazing experience, and you should make an effort to visit.

Very nice. Great tour and a great escape from the mid-day heat. Beautiful church in Rome and worth a visit. Well preserved and amazing architecture. One of the top churches to visit in Rome. Highly recommend stopping here.

Wow!. So beautiful and amazing
It's on the lists of top 10 churches in Rome to visit - for good reason!
Free entrance
Remember a scarf to cover bare shoulders
One of the Keystones of Christian Rome. A must for sightseeing of Christian Rome. Remember to dress respectfully, as dress code is definitely adhered to at this location.
Beautiful!. Walking around Rome and walked in to the Arcibasilica di San Giovanni. It is beautiful! Well worth a visit!
It's worth a visit. It's absolutely magnificent. The architecture is beautiful, whether you are looking up or down the detail is incredible.
Great details. The details of this Basilica are beautiful. You really need to look all around you at the details. Be sure to have knees and shoulders covered, be remain silent while inside.
wow!. amazing place; well worth it. this is rome's official basilica and it's amazing. don't miss the egyptian obelisk around back in the piazza.

A must-visit church in Rome!. San Giovanni in Laterano (St. John in Lateran) is by far my favorite church anywhere!It's not as grand as St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican or as famous as Paris's Notre Dame Cathedral, but St. John Lateran is nonetheless one of the most beautiful churches of all. After all, St John in Lateran is the holiest church of Roman Catholicism - even more so than the more famous St. Peter's Basilica!Although St John in Lateran was one of the first Catholic churches, the archbasilica had a massive Baroque makeover. Behind the grand Baroque facade topped with Christ and his followers welcoming the pilgrims, the interior of the church is a fine example of late Baroque architecture. Walk through the nave lined with beautiful lively sculptures of the twelve apostles. Bask in the glory under the main altar canopy that housed the skulls of Saints Peter and Paul. Admire the beautiful medieval and Renaissance art that surrounds the Cathedra of the Bishop of Rome - AKA the Pope!For me, I enjoyed visiting this church much more than every other because it's much more peaceful and less like a Disneyland than St. Peter's Basilica. The crowd is significantly less and much more respectful because only people who knew of its significance would go out of their way to visit. Nonetheless, St. John in Lateran is right by the S. Giovanni metro station that connects directly to the Vatican stops, so it's really easy to reach! I highly recommend making a visit to St. John in Lateran not only because of its status as one of the most important churches in Christendom but also of its unparalleled Baroque beauty.---tl;dr version:1) Roman Catholicism's most important church - even more than St. Peter's Basilica!2) Grand beautiful Baroque-style church with masterpieces and relics3) Easy to reach via subway from S. Giovanni station - Highly recommend a visit!

One of the big seven. A must. This archbasilica still keeps its ancient form based on the structure of roman temples. rows of columns divided it into aisles. The fron is a peristyle surrounded by colonnades with a fantastic fountain in the middle. The façade had three windows, embellished with magnificent mosaics. One is in awe all the time.
The one of the major. This is one of the major basilica in rome. This is the oldest of the four major basilica. The architecture is one of a kind . If you visit here make please pray for each other.

Interesting and so romantic. I returned after more than 10 years to this place, since I loved it and it stayed in my mind for so long. I found it the same: quiet, romantic, so... special. I feel so good there... I fully recommend the visit.

"Worth taking it in". This is a must see, please book in advance, from a official website, a great piece of history, the art work is fantastic the views are great, make sure you get a guide as you will appreciate the history more.
Beautiful white basilica!. Very interesting site which is a must to visit! Impressive paintings inside and a beautiful door. Really worth a visit, especially at sunset, very romantic!
Gorgeous, ornate and full of History.. A must see, wonderful experience and architecture. 160 photographs later and feeling the cultural overload we ventured outside for an ice-cream.
so interesting.... Definately worth having a guided visit as you find out so much more and pre-book so that you miss out on the long queues.

Not only a Jubilee year destination. If you are in Rome for religious reasons, then you must visit this church. It is one of the four major churches where the Holy door is opened on a Jubilee year. Besides all religious reasons, the church is amazing. I loved the textures of the marble floors. Very beautiful patterns. The statues of the 12 apostles which adorn the main part of the basilica are stunning. Entrance is free. Just go through the security check and you're in.

Don't miss this Basilica!. There is no shortage of churches and basilica's in Rome and they all have their own unique feel and look. This one is no exception. I love the architecture and the beauty that comes with it. The feeling of peace and tranquility when you walk through. And to think how old everything is and how wonderful it all looks, it's just a moment you should stop and enjoy and embrace all that it represents.
Stunning. The Pope's Cathedral and on a large and impressive scale because of that. Also worth crossing the road to the Scala Santa having made the journey out.
Stunning. First Christian church in Rome. Though I am not christian but the church is too beautiful to miss it.
Beautiful Basilica. This was one of the best churches we visited during our stay in Rome. I was amazed at the artwork and architecture of this basilica. The marble floor is beautiful.

Stunning. A really incredible building. It has wonderful statues, carvings, alters etc and the building has a very grand feeling about it. It is well worth a visit even if you are not religious and are simply going to enjoy the architecture.
Stunning and full of wonderful history!. When we visited Rome, we took a taxi to this beautiful Basillica! Absolutely stunning! Love the history.

The First Christian Church in Rome. Built on the order of Constantine, this basilica is the cathedral of Rome. The statues of the Apostles are breathtaking. Don't miss the Sancta Scala (Holy Steps) across the way. These are the stairs of Pilate's house which were brought from Jerusalem.

Go Early!. We went with a tour so we had VIP access. The lines were forming at 7am to get inside and they were hundreds deep. Even if you are not a religious person, it's a must see to admire the amazing structure, paintings, statues and architecture.

Beautiful Church. Bright and open. Beautiful ceilings. Impressive marble statues and carvings. Beautiful art. Make sure your shoulders and knees are covered because they are as strict as at St Peter’s. If you are turned away you can buy a cover-up for 2 Euro in the gift shop of Santa Scala which is across the street.Take the opportunity to enter thru the Holy Door.

Beautiful Archbasilica. It is hard to believe that someone thought there needed to be a greater basilica than this one. The statuary is incredible and the sheer size is breath-taking. Be sure to note the gold chest above the main alter. This contains the skulls of St. Peter and St. John. When we were there, there was a security checkpoint and they were enforcing the "no knees - no shoulders exposed" rule. It is worth the trip. As a bonus, you can see a large section of the Aurelian wall and entrance gate to ancient Rome. Also, across the street is the Scala Sanctum or "Holy Stairs" that Jesus walked when being tried by Pilot. A lot to see.
Amazing. Free church art museum. Don't miss. Fantastic interior architecture. Take your time to appreciate all statues and marble floor

The first chatholic church of the world. The Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is the cathedral church of Rome and the official seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is the Pope. As such, the Basilica contains the papal throne, although the pope rarely visits and lives over at the Vatican.Originally built in the 4th century by Constantine and was the Pope's principal residence until the 14th century when he moved across the city to the Vatican.In the Basilica, the Altar of the Holy Sacrament contains a cedar table that is said to be the one used by Christ at the Last Supper. There are also six papal tombs.The Basilica Di San Giovanni is open all day until around 7:00 p.m. (1 hour earlier in Winter) and is free to enter but there is a fee if you want to visit the cloisters (with Mensura Christi and the red porphyry slab on which it was believed that the Roman soldiers had thrown dice for Christ´s robe).

Beautiful Sacred Space. This Basilica is as important as St. Peter's in many ways and was FAR less crowded. Add it to your list of Musts if you are able to do so. It is very near the Sacred Steps as well. One must walk up steps to the entrance so it is not very handicap accessible.
Beautiful. Take your time discovering this basilica. You will be surprised to see some amazing art, and little nuggets of surprises. For example: Find the Star of David.

Beautiful. Beautiful, so so worth a visit, we did this on the last day - not realising how impressive it would be. We had the good fortune to hear the choir and see a service start (cue incense etc). Such a lovely experience.
St John the Lateren. A marvelous visit to a church which is about as impressive a place as St Peter's. Worth your time and plan to stay and wander it for a while
Stunning. The ceiling and the interior architecture are stunning to behold. We enjoyed our visit to this church.
Beautiful Basilica. In this Year of Mercy I was blessed to have walked through the Holy Door of St John In Lateran. Was given a guided tour of the Basilica really worthwhile to have a guide.

breathtaking. it has been a while since I visited this church but the experience is held very close to my heart. our tour guide brought us there, I had never heard of it before, and surely will return next time I am in Rome.

Look up - The ceilings are fabulous! Then all around ... Perhaps this is not one of the first places to go to on your list..but if you are in the San Giovanni area (not that far from the Coloseum) well worth a visit..steps... Not only is it steeped in history and beauty..it's also free! ..and just over the road there is the 'Scala Santa' ...holy stairs where you can do penance (should you feel the need) walking up them on your knees!! Alternatively just walk up the centre steps..
Great Architecture. A great church rich in architecture. Looking at the marbled flooring, the marble statues and the ceilings it takes your breath away.

Very Nice. We took the time to go after we had already seen more churches that I can recount. There is a church on every corner and if you see one go in-you will not be disappointed. This structure is huge and worth the time.

Beautiful. Well worth the history. You only need 30 minutes to enjoy the first Christian church of Rome. You'll need to pass through security gates. Don't forget to see the Holy Stairs across the street.

Beautiful!. An often overlooked church with history and beautiful design.The ceiling is amazing. Well worth the trip, but make sure you read up on the history of the building so it makes the trip worth it.

Perhaps our Favorite church. Except for the church in Vatican City, this was our favorite church in Rome. It contains these massive statues of the 12 apostles, plus Paul, and a few others. The statues are just beautiful. Wonderful pieces of art. We spent quite a bit of time just admiring them. As a non-Catholic Christian, I appreciated this church so much because it featured the Biblical characters I am so familiar with, whereas many other churches feature Catholic saints, whose stories I am not familiar with. Really glad we went.

Worth the visit!. Finally took the time to visit this church, it's huge! Really beautiful, the art is amazing and I was blown away by the ceiling. Might be nice to get someone to tell you more about the history and all the things you're seeing like, because it's too much to take in!

Better Than St Peter's Basilica - A Must See in Rome. After being "WOWED" by St Peter's Basilica, we decided to visit this Basilica, because our Vatican Guide said that this Basilica was even more breathtaking. Boy, was she right. This Basilica had no crowds at 10 am on a Saturday, and cost nothing to get in. The interior is absolutely spectacular with so much to see and admire,that you could spend hours gazing at the beautiful statues and art work. There was a church service going on in a side chapel and the confessionals were active, so this was a living, breathing active church, but with many photo opportunities. I think this s one of the highlights of my trio to Rome.
Important church . We have been to Rome many times but never visited this masterpiece of a church.The art and architecture is amazing and we could stay here for days.

Great alternative to standing in lines. I highly recommend this cathedral. It is the Popes church and was here before the Vatican.The statues of the 12 apostles are magnificent. Out front there is a obelisk floated up from Egypt. The baptistry next door is worth seeing but do not miss the holy steps across the street. They were brought to Rome from Jerusalem by Constantine for his mother who was converted to Christianity. The story is written on the wall in 4 languages and is very interesting. Nice statues inside this monument also.Best of all there are seldom any lines and wen there are they last maybe 5 minutes. There is no charge to enter and you can visit at your leisure.
My favorite church. This basilica is so beautiful! The Pope's, cardinals and bishop's church! Make sure to pay the extra 5 euro to see the cloister area.

Too much. I entered to this huge church several times. For me, it is too big with too much history and too many details. At first sight it is a cold baroque outfit. A man is like a tinny ant. I can’t feel the sanctity of the inner place. Older and nicer details are hidden, changed in 19. Century and only behind the corner you can enter the baptistery with some very old mosaics.

Don't miss the cloister. We came on pilgrimage with a group that visited the three major basilicas (except St Peter) in one day so it was a little overwhelming and it is hard to separate them out! This is a stunningly beautiful building with so much more to see than we had time for. For me (as a medievalist), the highlights were the tomb of Martin V and the cloister, which had a huge amount of information to take in. We particularly liked the tomb fragments with images of a series of different acolytes. But there is something for all art lovers.

Oldest Church. Beautiful basilica and apparently the oldest church in the world. It is free to get in but allow time to get through security. You may want to check Mass times/special celebrations as they close some of the basilica at these times.
One of the biggest church in the world!. Once you come inside, you cannot believe how big it is: from inside seems more bigger then it seems from outside.A great architectural example

Impressive basilica. An amazing building inside and out. Make sure, as with all sacred buildings in Rome, that you cover your knees and shoulders (especially the women!).
It's only a 15 minute walk from the colosseum and is a bit less touristy than other attractions, so come here!
A MUST-SEE!. Another must see absolutely gorgeous basilica in Rome which is the official seat of the Bishop of Rome - the Pope. Truly a fascinating and overwhelming place!!

Worthwhile. Last year when I came, there was no seating. It felt more like a gallery than a church. This time however, there was seating so it was possible to take time to sit and ponder.
There was also a service being held in a side chapel, so the sound of singing could be heard.

Spectacular. A bit out of the way for the standard tourist track but so, so worth it. Take time approaching so you can take in the magnificent facade and the statues of saints and apostles on the roof. Then walk in and the rest of the spectacle unfolds. Down the center apse are marble statues of each of the 12 apostles leading up to the altar. You have to see it, experience it and it is not crowded!!!

Large building. this is the cathedral of Rome with the large building and lovely internal halls. I loved the big statues which represent all the apostles. It was an impressive attraction and worth to visit
Very beautiful. Very beautiful church, aboslutely worth a visit. The holy door ia open and I was able to walk through it with no line.
Awesome. The best way to get here is to take the metro. The sculptures & paintings is out of the world. There is so much to see here. They also offer guided tours if you are interested.

Incredible, awesome!. By far, the most important Church in Rome! The architecture, the sculptures, the paintings, including the cloister, it's plainly "spectacular"! More important than St. Peter's. Cannot and must not miss this one!
overlooked by travelers. Everyone goes to the Vatican when in Rome, but if you miss this church you are missing the real seat of the Pope as Bishop of Rome...and the Sacred Steps....

Rome's Catherdral. It is the oldest church of the Western World, founded in the 4th century by Constantine. Dedicated to John the Baptist and John the Evangelist, it is located just inside the city walls. Much rebuilt and remodelled since then, it is grand in scale, with superb mosaics and altars.

Don't miss this historical and beautiful basilica. Had some extra time one morning and went to see the home of the Catholic Church. The Vatican is only a temporary home. Every Pope comes here. The inside is beautiful and historical. There is also the first established baptismal building and the holy staircase (climb it on your knees) within a short walk. Great stop right of the metro.

A lovely catheral. Worth visiting, it tends to be much quieter than some of the other major churches in Rome. We found it less interesting than some other sites, impressive yet bland strangely. It is worth visiting to see the relics of Peter and Paul and to see the cathedral for Rome.

A beautifully decorated cathedral. This is so much more enjoyable than the Vatican. It is free, spacious and not as crowded. The marble floors are wonderful and the general atmosphere is restful and holy.

Fantastic. This is worth the walk - the amazing cathedral with such space and decoration. Even allowing for St. Peter's this is a stunning place. Even better to pay the small charge to visit the cloisters: they are truly wonderful.

Don't Miss it!. St John Lateran is one of the four Papal basilicas of Rome and makes for a stunning visit, often without any crowds to spoil your enjoyment of the church. There are some amazing paintings and the relics of St Peter and St Paul held in golden reliquieries either side of the main altar. This is a definite must see in Rome if you are religious or have an interest in religious art.

Must see. This is the Pope's parish church, and the most important church in Rome. However, most tourists go to see St. Peter's, and don't even know about this church, so it has the added advantage of fewer tourists! Beautiful, beautiful historic church, and the Sancta Scala (Holy Steps, from Pontius Pilate's home) and private chapel are next door, so an added plus!

Words cannot describe it's splendor. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome.Family crypt of Bernina is here. Twelve statues of the Apostles line the main isle and are spectacular. There are nice bathrooms here.

Stunning interior. You can visit this very impressive basilica with it's giant statues lining the walls without enduring the long queues that you find at St Peters. Definitely worth a visit when you are in Rome, it's interior is beautiful.

Beautifull and big.. Heavily armed military (like the rest of Rome) and security check here as well. Speedy though and worth a visit although in my opinion not as beautifull as Chiesa di Sant'Ignazio di Loyola. Very good to combine this place with a visit to Cinecitta (use the Metro nearby).

Lovely structure. This is worth a look even if you're not there for the religions experience, but very impressive. Note that if you wish to light a candle, they only allow the electric kind, for some coin.

beautiful church. One of the four main basilicas .It is beautiful,worth seeing,X it's free.There were two souvenir shops in the church.got some presents for family there.Spent a couple of hours there.

We loved it.. The Basilica of St. John is a phenomenal church. It is breath-taking when you walk in. St. John's is almost as powerful as the St. Peter's at the Vatican. It's hard to take it all in because there is just so much to see. Do it though. You won't regret it!
Gorgeous color everywhere you look!. Gorgeous basilica in Roma that should not be missed! Lovely marble floors, baroque style with beautiful artwork over the alter!

Wonderful free visit. The Basilica is a free to visit attraction close to the heart of Rome. The architectural value of this makes it a must see attraction in the city. Only hint would be to dress appropriately as you would be cautioned if you don't.

Stunning church. Until 1873 (if i remember well) the Pope's were "installed" in this Basilica, on Easter Thursday the Pope celebrates the mass here. Absolute brilliant building worthwhile the visit ... LESS crowded than St-Peter's basilica and at least respect and quiet for worshiping here !
Worth a visit. This was our second visit the first 10 years ago beautiful this visit was on a Sunday so there was a service on. Worth a look the floor is amazing.

My favorite Basilica/church in the world!! 20 ft marble statutes of Christ's disciples. This was the 3rd time I've been to this Basilica. It is my favorite basilica/ church in the world. It is located in the Piazza San Giovanni section of Rome. It is one of the 4 major Basilicas in Rome. When you enter, you are immediately met with the stunning 20+ft marbles statues of Christ's 11 disciples and Paul. Judas Iscariot is not represented. The power of these sculptures is incredible. Each disciple is unique in the facial emotion, body positioning, and depiction of their role in the life of Christ. Helpful Hint: when taking photos of these disciple statues, take the photo of the name at the bottom of each one first, then the disciple, in order to keep them straight when you get home.There are multiple additional paintings, sculptures and artwork throughout the Basilica. I was moved with a powerful "Pieta" in a room along the wall to the right. This is a powerful sculpture of Mary holding her son Jesus after He was taken off the cross after His death.The outside of the church is exquisite as well. In order to get a full appreciation and/or photos, you have to walk down the sidewalk to fully get the Basilica in full view. There are statues all across the top of this Basilica as well. Helpful hint: take your time here. Walk slowly and savor this incredible Basilica. There is so much beauty to see and appreciate. .Also note one of the 4 obelisks on the side of this basilica.Restrooms available. No admission fee.

Beautiful, and Serene. This was a very beautiful cathedral. It was even made more beautiful than St. Peters in that it is properly treated with religious reverence, not as an art gallery!Most people do not realize that this is actually the Pope's church, and it is wonderful to see his bishop's chair. Relics such as the skulls of Peter and Paul add to the sanctity of the space.We visited many churches in Rome, and this was one of the best. It is well worth the visit.

Fabulous. A wonderful church ,Basillica , ! With fabulous sculptures of the Apostles and disciples by Bernadini. Huge figures on both sides of the edifice look down on you and the magnificence of it just takes your breath away. It is wise to hire a guide otherwise you miss so much.
Una misa celestialle. Impressive service on Sunday. The place is extraordnary well conserved. I recomend to visit it with a guide to get all the place offers to you

Stunning and unique . This is a really beautiful gem a littleFurther out of the city if your feeling adventurous. It is absolutely stunning S the ceilings are less detailed and graphic than others until you get to the alter areas and then it truly shines. It contains apparently the first ever Baptismal font but you need to pay to see it. It also however is linked to the church across the road which contains the holy steps you ascend on your knees. Which you might be sceptical of but if you do it you will find yourself a lot more thoughtful and respectful and a little holier by the time you reach the summit. Amazing to watch people of all ages do this and respect the silence. At the top is what is thought to be the original painting by I believe st John of our Lord.really worth seeing these two churches and unlike many in Rome it does not feel consumerist

Very impressive church. There are so many churches in Rome that it's impossible to remember them all individually (at least for me) but this church is such a beautiful work of art (and the type of art I enjoy the most) that I remember it still after few months after my trip. I probably wouldn't have visited there if my hostel wasn't nearby. I'm very glad it was so I could see the church everyday from the outside on my way to see the other sights. The last day in Rome I finally went into the church and wasn't disappointed.

This was an amazing experience. Okay, so this is the actual seat of the Papacy, as opposed to St. Peter's. It's a short hop on the Metro. You will also see a huge section of the Aurelian wall, which is quite a site in and of itself, and you'll have to pass through one of its archways to reach the basilica. We went at night, in pouring rain, which added to the mystery of the place. It's on the outskirts, but it's perfectly safe. The locals are friendly. There's some sort of very loud bar/restaurant between the metro station and the basilica, which was comical. Check out my photos of the place. It was an amazing experience! There's nothing else there (just the Wall and the Basilica), so once you've had your fill of those two, get back on the metro and head back to the historical center. Piece of cake.

Magnificent. You do not have to be a Catholic to appreciate this the oldest Papal Basilica.It is a vast clean and light Cathedral that seems more welcoming than many of the dark forbidding Cathedrals around and with its wonderful statues of the Apostles, decorated ceiling and wall paintings it is well worth the visit.This is a relatively short walk from so many of the more famous tourist attractions and yet remains remarkably empty of them. I would imagine that most of its visitors are in fact Catholic visitors so getting in was easy and free and the interior is devoid of crowds.This leaves you free to admire its splendour in calm and quiet.
A must to see. Be sure to visit here, very spiritual and awesome states of the apostles. Also is the Popes special basilica

Perhaps not as visited as other major basilicas, but worth the trip. This may be the redheaded stepchild compared to the other major basilicas, but as such, it is worth your time to check it out. There is not quite as much majesty as St. Peter's, nor is it as grand as St. Paul's, and instead it almost feels cramped (not saying that it is small - it is not by any stretch of the imagination, only by comparison).What you will see here is an amazing collection of artwork, which is certainly not different, but the special touch here is the incredible Baroque statues of the Apostles, so it is well worth the visit for those alone.
beautiful !. not much more than I can say other than it is amazingly beautiful ! definitely go if you have a chance to !
Magnificent. In a city of beautiful and impressive churches, St. John Lateran, one of the four major Basilicas in Rome truly stands out. The sculptures of all the Apostles are impressive.
Masterpiece without mass tourist visitors. You feel that you live in the early recognized christian era. The monument is something you must no miss. But you have to pay to see the museum.
San Giovanni in Laterano. Beautiful church! A great visit if you already did the Vatican and St Peter's Basilica! It is an easy reach by bus or subway.

great visit if you like cathedrals. better than St Peters.It is the oldest and takes precedence among the four Papal Basilicas (all of which are located in Rome), being the oldest church in the West and having the cathedra of the Roman Pontiff
The most beautiful church I ever seen. This church is a little off the beaten path but you can take the subway to it. It is totally incredible, I cannot recommend it enough. Simply beautiful...

Beautiful . Lovely place that was a short walk from our apartment. Not to ornate, but still very breathtaking. Not as busy as other sites but well worth going out of your way. Donation only, security checkpoint.
Thoughtful. A lovely church with impressive statues of all the apostles portraying their mode of death! The cloisters were beautiful.
A must see as a pilgrim. Not only a magnificent cathedral, I was particulary moved by other international pilgrims spending time at teh Holy Door.
Stunning Church. This is an absolutely beautiful church it is slightly outside the center of the city but is easily reachable via the metro and is well worth the trip.

Beautiful . This basilica is just as good as the wonderful churches in Vienna like St Stevens. The architecture is hard to believe and to think this site is only one of many to be found in Rome is unbelievable. A must to visit.

Stunning building. The original home of the Pope before moving to Avignon. (& subsequently moving back to Rome to the Vatican) Wonderful, wonderful painting, architecture, sculpture and sense of history. For me this building at least equals St Peters but I think it is slightly smaller. (just) On the outskirts of ancient Rome and built on land originally owned by the 'Laterans' family. (Hence San Giovanni in Laterano) Close by are the sacred steps, which Christ is supposed to have ascended to be interviewed by Pilate - a site of pilgrimage for the faithful.

Lovely Church off the Beaten Path. San Giovanni was simpliy beautiful! One of the largest basilicas that I have visited, with masterful architecture and some of the most beautiful Holy Doors that I saw this Jubilee Year (and I did see and walk through all four sets) You really have to search through this basilica, as there are many hidden gems that you can find. A quick walk through the main area won't do...go into all the nooks and crannies! You do need to go through a metal detector to get into this basilica, but the wait is well worth it.
Amazing church. The word is majestic, and as many stuff in rome this is huge. It is clear the importance of the church and it can only be compared with vatican's st. Peter

Fabulous. This is a fabulous cathedral
It's big and spacious and its very clean.
There's a cue but it takes only a few minutes and its free and accessible to everyone.
It's easy to access from the metro and it has various facilities on site

Visit the Baptistry at San Giovanni. We stumbled across the Baptistry when looking for the Holy Door at Basilica San Giovanni (St John).
What a gem - worth the walk to Laterno by itself
Home of Bishop of Rome. Breathtaking. Well worth the visit. Having a tour guide helps you see the finer points. Don't forego the sacred steps.

Stunning and, by comparison, minimalistic Basilica. It says something of the scale of St. Peter's that San Giovanni feels intimate, but it does to an extent! This is a glorious church, less highly baroque than many of the other Roman churches, and as result more, to my taste, aesthetically pleasing. It felt something like Durham Cathedral compared to a oYork Minster, for those who know those churches. We enjoyed too that there were seats out in the nave such that it felt more like a live place of worship, and one was able to sit and take it in more. We arrived too late in the day to appreciate the baptistry or other places as they were closed; check the opening times as they are not the same as the basilica itself.

Are we sure it's a church?. Very impressive, I'm not religious but this place was fascinating, you could spend all day here & not see it all, everywhere you look it's packed with paintings, po traits, China, pottery & statues, it's more like a museum. We went with a guide which was good & she knew her stuff however she did skip the less important items which was a bit annoying as the little things are sometimes just as or more interesting so next time I would go without a guide then you can look at what you want & not be hurried.

Peaceful and awesome. I know this may be controversial, but I preferred this to St. Peter's Basilica. It was less showy, but nevertheless contained awesome art work in many forms, but it was peaceful, and made more sense . I still find it hard to find the Jesus I know amongst all the gold, statues, and ostentation. but hope that others find that the depictions of the scriptures in art form, help to point them in the direction of God's son.
Beautiful church . The most important church and the oldest in Rome Again very underrated when compared to st Pieters but well worth a visit
High Security. There are many beautiful churched in Rome but this the cathedral of Rome is fantastic, a sign of the times is the high security to enter, second only to the Vatican

breathtaking. as one of the four Archbasilicas in Rome, the seat of the Bishop or Rome (Pope) is well worth a visit. The bookshop is good but a wee bit pricey. Make sure to check out the sculptures of the 12 apostles which depict their traditional way of martyrdom.

San Giovanni in Laterano. Gorgeous basilica in the heart of Rome. It doesn't feel like a church, maybe like a museum but so beautiful.There's art all over Rome and I never tired of discovering it in the most incredible places, a little plaza, a niche on the wall. If you like art you will not be disappointed.

The Church of Rome. Where St. Peter's Basilica is the Church of the Vatican, this is Rome's church. Very beautiful. It is a good walk away from from main drag but worth it. Beautiful ceilings and statues. Free admission.

a must see. Impressive basilica, the oldest and ranks first among the four Papal Basilicas.
I was particularly impressed by the great work on marble and golden ceiling.
Mass at 10 am on Sunday. Great choir and the organ music is exceptional. It is one of the most beautiful churches in the world.

Mind Blowing in it's sheer scale. Went on a day when there was a lot of tourists queuing but have patience its well worth it.Having been to Notre Dame you think it can't get much better but it does.As you walk around not too crowded in there.I thought I could access the Sistine from there but couldn't.
Grand beyond description!. We went there primarily because we had to pick up our travel passes at office next door. Really impressive and worth seeing.
Awesome . Beautiful, and free for entrance, they have a check in tent on the left side of the building. Nice paintings.

A stunning place to visit.. The cathedral church of the Bishop of Rome - The Pope. A church steeped in history and is quite magnificent. The site of the Lateran Councils. Do visit the Scala Sancta and the very beautiful Baptistry. Taking a reasonable amount of time is recommended,
Impressive. The size of the sculptures of the apostles is breath-taking. There is no way to describe it. Walking down the wide aisle with the apostles on either side is quite awe inspiring.
Not a Catholic. Not a catholic however, I must say this basilica was beautiful. Well worth the visit. The statues were awesome.
San Giovanni church. Nice cathedral , very huge and so beautiful , no matter if you are not christian , it's amazing place to vesit in Roma , I like it

Amazing church! . My boyfriend and I are not really religious people but somehow we were both moved to tears when we came inside this church. It was just so overwhelming and beautyfull. And it wasnt too crowded.

Very Stunning Basilica. This Papal Basilica is a ways to get to if staying in central Rome but worth the walk or bus ride. Admission is free for the stunning art that is held within. You do have to go through metal detectors and have your bags x-rayed but once inside you know why. It is less crowded than St. Peters allowing for a full experience with larger than life carved saints and beautiful paintings.
Worth a Visit. Very close to the San Giovanni metro and therefore easily accessible. Well worth a visit though at the time we were there there was a music festival on and the area was very busy

This is the real cathedral of Bishop of Rome (aka pope). Worth the walk from Coloseo and close to Metro if you don't want the hike. Old church that has suffered Baroque additions. A little Baroque suffices for me. Sheer size and history make it worthwhile, especially oldest parts still very much part of the living church. This and not St. Peter's is the Bishop of Rome's home church even if he lives in the Vatican. That's a quirky bit of trivia for visitors.

The oldest church in the World. I visited this beautiful church last Saturday morning. Originally, we were looking for the Lateran museum, but we were told that all of its collection was transferred to other Vatican museums and the building is currently closed to the public. For that reason, we decided to pay a visit to the neighboring Basilica and we no regret it at all.The church was full of visitors when I arrived. I had to pass through a security checkpoint before entering in it. The church is full of artwork. The paintings decorating its walls are beautiful, but I was impressed the most by the incredible works made on the church ceilings: patterned reliefs, figures of the Virgin, saints and the Vatican coat of arms are just some examples of these magnificent works of art. I think this church is missed by the majority of visitors, but it worth more than one visit.

Maginificent Art, Religeon, Architecture, History under One Roof.
