The stunning Basilica of St John the Lateran is one of the major papal churches in Rome competing in significance with the Vatican St Peter's; filled with wonderful statuary, murals, religious and secular artefacts all housed in the magnificent edifice of the building itself. To be able to sit in quiet contemplation or stroll around viewing the wonders of the church is simply breathtakingly; whether for a brief visit or a longer exploration this is a must for any visitor to the Eternal City
Fantastic to look at. Pre -Vatican head of the Catholic church. Magnificent architecture and a lot less crowded then St Peter's. A bit off the main tourist route but well worth the visit.

The cathedral of Rome. One of the most important churches in Rome, located in the area south-east of the Esquiline Hill, is the city’s cathedral and it was the headquarters of the Catholic Church before the creation of the Vatican state. A church has been here from the 4th century and the present building is the result of Borromini’s reconstruction in the 17th century that evoked Rome’s wealth of history, with features from its different periods. It is a remarkable building, a great architectural work and in its interior you can see the statues of the twelve Apostles, designed by the most famous sculptors of the late Baroque in Rome.

Beautiful church. I visited the church on Tuesday afternoon and it was almost empty, no line to go through the security and no one inside. Spent some time walking around and admiring. Not to be missed.
Magnificent! Emotional! . An architecture and interior decor that are sublime, a very special and spectacular place to visit. Keep a coin handy for the kids to throw!
Amazing church, grand and beautiful. Free entrance, only a little bag check before you enter. The chruch was amazingly grand, with statues of the 12 apostles. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful marble statues! Very gothic style.. I visited San Giovanni on my last day in Rome and it was the highlight of that day (not the trip, mind you!). There are no iconic or famous art pieces (that I know of), but everything about the church was top notch. Dozens of marble statues, a gorgeous entryway, ceilings, and floors, and everything else was nothing but grand. Funny enough, I think the main church doors blew me away the most -- it's a huge iron door that's over 20 feet tall. Standing next to it made me feel tiny in comparison.  A couple things to keep in mind. It's not central to the other major sites, so it will requires a good walk (about 20-30 minutes from central Rome). I enjoyed the walk, but for those that have mobility issues, please look into buses and cabs. The added benefit of being off the center was the lack of crowds compared to the more central churches, but I did notice a few tour buses drop by around 11 or 12, right after I was done.

Pope previous Throne. Before St Peter was built, this Basilica is thr Pope's place. The placards outside mentions about Mater et Caput (mothet and head) of all churches. It has relics of the table that Jesus used for Last Supper. The main church is surrounded by gigantic statues of Jesus' 12 disciples and the chapel in its right and left are still used for adorations and masses. Many confession boxes are open with each priest's language capability ranging from 5-6 languages. Amazing skill.Don't miss Francis Asisi's statues right across the street when he begged for permission to start an order.Also across the street on Basilica's left side , there are stairs believed to be stairs where Jesus was captured and questioned. We have to kneel all the way up to the stairs and there's a relic of Jesus' blood at the top flight.

Breathtaking. This is a wonderful Archbasilica. Internally beautiful and housing many many great works. Wonderful mosaics, huge statues, amazing ceilings. The cloisters require a ticket, but it is worth it. We walked from Piazza Navona - it is a very long way - consider a bus .....
Must in 2016. 2016 is a holly year. all 4 basilica's open the holy door. This Church is as beautiful as the other ones.
Amazing church. Probably one of the top 3 churches/basilicas in Rome, and once visited, it is easy to understand why is it so popular! Beautiful church with stunning interior.
Wow!!!. What an amazing church!So many paintings and frescoes! You have to visit this church to feel what we felt! It is a church of art!
lovely interior. not many peple know that this is the Archbasilica of Rome (the church of the Pope). Although it is away from the main city area, it is worth it ot pay a visit.

An impressive place. This is one of the most impressive churches from Rome, it is a great place for history and architecture lovers, but also for those who seek to find a peaceful place. It is a place that must be visited, if you are in Rome!

Absolutely stunning interior!. This is a beautiful church with a stunning interior, which is well worth seeking out and walking round. All churches are free to enter and this one is well and truly worth a look!

Beautiful. This is the highest ranking church in Rome and once inside it's easy to see why. Not easy to find but well worth the effort. The statuary and grandeur of it's art are amazing and so meaningful even to a non Catholic. I found it's aura greater than St. Peter's basilica and the Vatican and understand why this was exclusively for the bishops of Rome. Go through the holy door you never know if faith will make your dreams come true as the legend promises. Again though get skip the queue tickets.

out of the way, but significant to Roman Catholic history. If you don't have a guide or guidebook, the 2E recorded info is worthwhile. Also, 2 nice small souvenir shops inside & off to the side which have items not found in other church shops.

a rather large, imposing, and atmospherically cold basilica. it might be a famous church, but there are so many more interesting churches to visit in Rome. The mosaics, from the original basilica I believe, are in good condition after being carefully moved in the 1800s, and very good to examine, however I did not like the very large statues of the apostles that line the nave.
Amazing. Rome is filled with beautiful churches and this one is magnificent. Words cannot describe it's grandeur; full of art and magistracy - you will not be disappointed.

St John Lateran. The Cathedral of the Bishop of Rome, (which is the Pope). Yes the Pope has the Vatican, but as the Bishop of Rome, he also needs a Cathedral and this is it. Built by Constantine in 324 to appease the christians. Tour is FREE!
Easter Monday. I visited the Monday after Easter, which is also a national holiday in Italy. This is of course a very solemn, contemplative place to experience.

An Important Papal Church. This is an important Papal Church and was the home for popes at one time before St. Peters. More important than St. Peters actually. St. John is buried here and this is a beautiful church with so many things to see. The Holy doors were open as this is a Jubilee Year and it is said to walk through the Holy Door--your prayers will be answered.

wow.... Amazing. it's really amazing place , while we go into the chapel , we only sound "wow" "wow" 'wow", we came from china, we hv visited many old chapel and buildings in China , beijing, not none of them could compare with this, we had no idea how the people build this in the past
Beautiful church but many visitors. Its one of the 5 churches you need to visit in Rome. Be there before all the tour bus tourists arrive - before 11.00
Amazing place. It is one of the four most beautiful basilicas in the world, a place you must visit in your life. It is so moving.

A must see place in Rome. A visit to Vatican and to Arc Basilica is a must while visiting Rome. We were in a group of 11 friends and we had a lady guide who was very efficient and took us around the place and explained everything very lucidly. An architectural marvel and has many art work to have a life time experience.

If you are on a pilgrimage do not miss.. This was my first time in Rome but several people in our group were very excited about this Basilica. We passed through the Holy Doors to see a beautiful church.
Great. It's really beautiful place and definetely worth to see. Sometimes there are queues to the entrance as there is a security checking your stuff. :)

More impressive than expected. How had we missed this church on five previous trips to Rome? Unfortunately we didn't allocate enough time to see it fully. We primarily wanted to see the cloister, and since acoustiguides came along with the price, we decided to use them and found them helpful. It is a grandly impressive mother of a church!

Better than St Peters! . Wandered down here for an hour before mass. Although not as magnificent as St Peters, smaller crowd, they had confessions due to jubilee celebrations so some reverence, group of tourists began singing a wonderful selection of hymns! Mass being prepared for later despite tourists wandering about. Felt more like a magnificent church. Three christenings being held in baptistery and tourists there were quiet and respectful of this (us too!)

Stunning. Stumbled on to this on our way from The Pantheon to the Spanish steps. So worth a visit. This church is more beautiful that a lot I've seen on the "must do" lists. There was a lady that seemed to be an usher of some sort who just kept smiling at me. When she was pushing people away from the centre of the church, she let me stay. When i started to move away, she came to me and in sign-language (since i don't speak a word of Italian) indicated that i can stay. When i was leaving, she came to me and said something that seemed to be a prayer. My sister who was standing to the side even asked if i knew the lady. I felt really blessed.

Beautiful basilica!. Rome has a few thousand basilicas - but this is one that stands out. So glad I read the tripadvisor reviews and decided to visit this one. One of the best after the St. Peter's basilica at the Vatican.

Beautiful church. Well worth a visit. Also get the audio guide for a few Euro. It will make the visit more interesting. Easy to get to. It has it's own metro stop: San Giovanni. Just come up from the metro and you will see the large church.
Councils. This Church is important for the many Church Councils that took place here. It is very very beautiful and must be visited.
Beautiful . Absolutely stunning, walk in and you will be truly amazed. Every inch of this church is decorated so very beautifully take your time to absorb it all.

Heavenly!. It feels like the churches in this city fell from heaven - the sky opened up and the churches fell to earth. Hard to comprehend the work and the talents that built these churches. Every single church in Rome is a museum.
Good place. Good place to visit, Italy have so many places, you have to have many days to visit this city, i come back

Great Basilica and wonderful neighborhood!. It's a very important basilica and not well known! A must on your list of churches in Rome. And if you go there take a little walk behind the wall, adventure your self outside the walls and go visit the Market in via Sanio and further down go to Via Taranto where you will find the best, I really mean the best pastry shop in Rome called da Ettore e Nena it's an original they make the best coffe and pastries, so if you early in the Am go there have a cappuccino and a danese, enjoy the Roman way of life.
Breathtaking!. Do not miss out on seeing this exceptional basilica - it is full of history and many of the columns were originally used at the Roman Forum!

Beauty with a smaller Q. It's not as vast or totally impressive as St Peter's Basilica but smaller queues (caused only by security checks and we don't mind those!) and therefore quieter and more in line with one's expectations. The 12 sculptures (each over 4 metres high) are true works of art and worth the visit on their own. The gold ceiling, the paintings, etc, etc, etc!Miss this at your peril!

A must to visit when in Rome!. Beautiful Cathedral and one of the oldest historical sites in Rome. While there visit the octagonal Lateran Baptistery which stands on one side of the main basilica. There is a legend that Emperor Constantine I was baptised there and enriched the edifice.

Very important Basilica, a must see. This Church is a very important part of the fabric of the Catholic Church in Rome, founded very early in the Christian Era. It has, of course, been remodeled over the centuries,and may seem somewhat sparse in it's decoration. Nonetheless, it contains many items of interest to the history buff. The bronze doors, for instance, were taken from the Roman Senate building in the Forum. Don't miss the statue of Constantine in the portico, he's the guy that made Christianity possible in Rome! In the transept are some bronze columns that are said to be taken from the Temple of Jupiter on the Capitoline. Lots to see here!
Totally breath-taking experience!. Absolutely beautiful, one of the most well-kept churches I've seen in Rome. Be ready for airport-type security when going in, but it's worth the effort.
excellent. Another must see place in Rome. very nice place. much better then I expected. entrance is free. good for budget travelers also. don't miss it.
The main church. Beside the St. Peter one, this is the main chuech of Rome. It is very beautiful and other important religious attraction are close to this place

Not as amazing as other palaces. I meen churches in Rome. It is more modern than otherones we have seen so it did not quite impressed me to be honest. Statues of saints are worth visiting because they are glorious.
Gorgeous. Bring your camera. It's so beautiful. very beautiful church. Rome becomes a tour of churches, but they all still hold beauty.

wonderful. t is a joy for the eyes and for the soul , enter the Holy Door and be enveloped by austerity and the sacredness of the statues , frescoes , from the altar and apse ... Each centimeter on the ground or in the air tells a story .. hISTORY ! To see absolutely !

Beautiful. Came here after visiting St Peter's and it was a relief to get away from the hoards of visitors who seemed more interested in taking selfies than admiring the building. This church was a haven where people still came to pray and where one could appreciate the architecture and art work. The cloister was our highlight.

Incredible church.. This church may be out of the way for some, but definitely worth the walk or transit trip to see. It's massive with beautiful sculptures including Bernini. Would have liked to tour the gardens/courtyard but didn't have time.

The best church in Rome. This is the cathedral of Rome, and is stuffed to the basilica with great artworks, fabulous architecture, amazing decoration, and there are not enough superlatives to do it justice. A must see part of your Rome visit.
Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano. this is a huge Basilica that worth the time to visit. While its a bit off the main attractions, the large building and its lovely internal halls are a must see.
Wow. I enjoyed very much those big statues representing all 12 apostles, really impressive. Worth visiting, after Basilica San Pietro from Vatican, which is inside Rome, this is the second to see.

Beautiful paintings. Be prepared this is very busy also you need plenty of time to enjoy all the exhibits and paintings. There are lots stairs and only lifts at the beginning so be prepared for going up and down them.

Impressive. Impressive building and awe-inspiring interior. Plan to spend an hour or two here to really get the full experience. Be prepared for a line at security but the church itself has free access.

Must see!. After visiting the Vatican this is a must see. The sheer size takes your breath away. As the cathedral of Rome its as important as St Peters and where the Popes were originslly crowned. If you want to go through a holy door in Rome this year, this one is easier thsn s hslf day queue at St Peters.

One of my favorite Roman churches. We spent about an hour and a half in this beautiful basilica. It contains the beautiful papal altar in which the relics of the heads of Peter and Paul are kept in beautiful silver containers.

very beautiful. It is a very beautiful and interesting church. the basilica of Saint John Lateran was built under pope Melchiade (311-314), it’s the most ancient church in the world. Due to the fact that the pope is also the bishop of Rome, Saint John in Lateran – being seat of the bishop’s residence – is also Rome’s Cathedral.
always amazing like for the first time. After seeing it at least 5-6 times, I have always a pleasure to come back. Pure beauty! It is a must to see it if you are in Rome.

wow!. So much to see from historical paintings to canvases and wall paintings and decorations. A must see when in rome. Beautiful views and does not take up all your day
I recommend getting the bus hop pass as it will take you to nearly all the key spots in rome and if its raining keeps you dry.
Perfect stay in Rome. Try to choose a Sunday to visit churches in Rome! Superb experience even if you are not sure of your let's say religious directions.
Extremely rich. Really worthwhile. Very rich Cathedral. Very beautiful hallway for which you need tot pay entrance. Go around the complex and visit the baptherium too
Best basilica in ROme. is so Elegant and unit. San Giovanni basilica is the most beautiful in ROMe. behind the metro san giovanni very easy to reach
AMAZING SIGHT. You will enjoy this experience and find it very enjoyable. This is a family experience and worth the time to find it.
One of the key churches in Rome. This church is less ornate than St Peter's but that makes it easier to focus on it's main purpose as a place of worship.
Breathtaking. We thought we wouldn't visit every church we came across but we were very glad that we didn't miss this one. It very very ornate inside and out. Just sit and take in everything.
One of the important churches in Rome. This is one of the main churches in Rome. Worth seeing. It is at walking distance (20m) from the Coliseum.

One of the best churches . The mother church of the world. Yoe haven't gone to Rome if you haven't visited this church. Very beautiful from door detail to gold details in ceiling. This is the church of the Pope and reading through some materials, this one ranks above St. Peter's Basilica.

Beautiful Catholic Cathedral Church. I had an excellent tour of the Basilica. This is the Cathedral of the Pope. There is so much art work and beauty within that place. I really enjoy it in the morning when there are less people because of the silence.
Better than expected. This was the first church we visited. Because we had a Rome pass we did not pay and had Audio free. We also had free access to the Cloisters.
Beautiful church!. Great church, lovely experience. The outside was super nice to look at as well as the inside. Definitely check it out!

Sometimes people get angry for a parking violation when cashing in a major lottery ticket. I love reading TripAdvisor reviews where the score is 28,271 plus to 14 minus reviews. Of course I immediately head to the minuses, because it's so much fun to discover what happened to turn people off, or because they intellectualize what they think something should be like as opposed to evaluating what it is. The Eiffel Tower and Memorial to Victor Emmanual II and the Unification of Italy were neither overwhelmingly appreciated in their own time. Sometimes I imagine such people twisting themselves into amazingly awkward positions and then complaining that the sun isn't shining brightly enough in that newfound posture. So who doesn't like San Giovanni in Laterno because he couldn't find parking, or tried to get in wearing questionable garments, or had the wrong schedule? Or it doesn't look old enough? Or it isn't conveniently enough located? Or I never even heard of it?The Archbasilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is simply put, for many the single most important church in Rome, because it belongs to Rome, not the world, because it formally represents Rome and, depending on how one measures such things, can be considered the oldest ongoing major structure in Christendom of its kind.How many never notice the simple Giotto behind Saint Matthew's statue? Or decide the large latter painting behind that is the Giotto? Or never knew it was there? Or never heard of Giotto? It's Ok.Others know and care and nobody is knowledgeable about very much in the universe anyway. None of us.This is a massively impressive and important edifice which can become amazingly engaging to anyone who lets it be. I strongly urge as many as possible to do a little research, then add San Giovanni to their top whatever must see lists while in Rome. it's very easily accessible by Metro.

late morning visit - it's beautiful!. This church is the see (home church) of the Bishop of Rome, who is the pope! It is very beautiful and has lovely side altars- great colors, paintings, and a stunning ceiling and altar. I found little gifts there that I hadn't seen elsewhere, although we'd visited the Vatican 2 yrs. ago and didn't return this time. Mass times and Holy Week options were clearly posted on 3/15.

Worth a vist. A great church and not so crowded. It's enormous full of history and amazing art. Be sure to look at the floor. I did this as part of a tour the guides are really helpful in weaving the history together.

If you like churches you must visit this one. The oldest of Rome's four Papal Basilica (and possibly the oldest extant church in the world) this, together with St Peter's and St Mary Maggiore, is a church you must try to visit. [The fourth baisica, St. Paul Outside the Walls, may well be equally worth visiting but, as the name suggests, it is somewhat out of the way.]The fairly recent (18th century) façade is impressive, if perhaps somewhat showy, but the interior is magnificent. It's a pity that while admission to the basilica is free, there is a charge to enter the cloisters and gardens.Unlike most attractions the basilica is very close to a Metro station (San Giovanni). It is also not far to walk from the Colosseum so if you are visiting that do try to make time for a detour to this church.

Centre of the Catholic Church. This is an amazing Church. It is a major religious centre for the Catholic Church in Rome. An enormous interior that when filled with a congregation is wonderful to experience.
Holy Door Year of Mercy. Great pilgrimage site for Year of Mercy. Beautiful! Security is heightened, so be aware of what you plan to take with you.

stunning church in europ. a stunning church in one of my favorite in Europe so far just u need to make sure to keep a long sleeve shirt and don t wear a short to enter this place but fortunately you can buy a scarf at the entrance i loved the style of this huge church
What's not to like.. This is a big beautiful building. Inside are huge statues of what seems be the Apostles in various poses.

Beautiful, peaceful church. My first trip to Rome was when I was 14. This church is one of my most abiding memories. Having thrown a coin into the Trevi fountain I managed to return to Rome for my second trip when I was 56.It's still an amazing place, whether you are a practising catholic or not this has a very spiritual feel to it, and much more so than St Peters which just felt like a museum.The art work, sculpture etc. is of course amazing.A nice place to sit and have a bit of a contemplate....

St. Peter's Before St. Peter's. The seat of the Bishop of Rome since essentially the beginning of the Church, the Archbasilica di San Giovanni in Laterano ranks as the most important Catholic Church, even higher than St. Peter's Basilica. Beginning with the 4th Century, most Popes have been crowned there and they lived in the nearby Lateran Palace for a thousand years until the Vatican was completed. As impressive as this history is, the Basilica itself is even more impressive. With its monumental entrance doors, columns, and ceiling, the beautiful, expressive, and massive statues of the apostles lining the perimeter of the spacious Nave which itself is crowned by a gloriously decorated ceiling, and the ornate, but in its own way tasteful main altar, the Basilica is one of the most extraordinary sites of Rome. And then you've also got the beautiful Sacred Stairs, lovely mosaics in the apse, and peaceful cloister to round out a very special experience. To top it off, we had a blissful lack of crowds which allowed us to proceed at our leisure and take in the structure in a way that is impossible in St. Peter's.

Excellent to Very Good. First thing first - this is one of the places in Rome where you can expect to sit hours in the queue, and there is no "skipping the line" here. We've spent I don't know how long in line on a rainy day. It was a disaster and very tiring.As for the church itself, or mother church as people of Rome would call it, it IS magnificent and beautiful and full of sculptures, but after Basilica di San Pietro, a level of excitement will be a lot lower here, because nothing compares to it. The cloister of San Giovanni was included in our "pass", so we visited it, but it is under reconstruction and thus not that exciting.
#2 after St.Pete. This is where the POPE HQ use to be. A must see on the east side of Bella Roma. Check out the 12 Apostle statues and the tomb of St. John.

Nice place in Rona if you have enough time. The plaza and the basilica are nice to visit , the art inside us average , the place a little far away from the main touristic area , so visit it if you have enough time

great. lovely surpise around the corner of the ( wedding cake,) the big white building tomb of the unknown soldier is .

Beautiful! . This is a stunning building!! It was just around the corner from our b&b and we nearly skipped it due to time but I'm so glad we didn't, it's truly breathtaking. I did get told off by security for forgetting to put my leggings on under my shorts but he was kind enough to point me to the toilets so I could rectify that! Amazing Craftmanship. An incredible amount of work has gone into creating this amazing structure. Much quieter than St Peters and no queues!
Best church!. It was the most impressive church of Rome. The size, the various rooms, everything. Go there when there is daylight.
Beautiful Basilica. The sight of the church just from the outside almost leaves you speechless and then inside i just becomes more spectacular. A must see
This place is a must. Stunning church with various decoration. It has every style of decoration you can find in a Italian church. After all, it's the mother of churches

Archbasilica of St. John Lateran. We were advised to visit this place and was not prepared when we saw what was inside, we were filled with awe and grandeur. It is a bit out of the way, but definitely worth the trip. Across the street is the Santa Scala, or Holy Stairs, which are also worth a visit!
Mind Blowing. Breathtakingly beautiful. Walking around the basilica just leaves you awestruck. It is an amazing feeling being there, an experience I won't forget.

In Rome before Christmas . The mother of all Churches.On of the most beautiful Church I have ever seen.The Papal Altar is magnificent.Holy Masses and Confessions are very frequent.Do not leave Rome without a visit here!

Beautiful. While the basilica is a bit away from the central tourist spots, it is well worth the trip to see this beautiful building. It's near the San Giovanni metro stop and several bus lines stop almost right in front of the church. A bit of a security line, but worth the wait.

Been walking past this for a few days before we apprecaited its significance.. We had been walking past this before we finally googled it to see what exactly it was. Alerted to its 'importance' by the soldiers and police on duty. We then discovered it had a important history, Unfortunately this was as we returning to our hotel to catch a cab to the airport. Had we not have been staying out of the main city center we would never have seen this and understood the importance. Supposed to house relics from the Last Supper and the Apostles Peter and Paul. On our visit to Rome, my friend and I took a pilgrimage to all four of the major Catholic Basilicas. We started with San Giovanni in Laterno (St. John) because it was within walking distance of our hotel. There were armed guards outside of the basilica searching visitors upon entrance, but we didn't mind the heightened security. It only took a few minutes to get through. Entrance was free as all churches in Rome are. The exterior of the basilica isn't eye-catching, but once we entered the church, I was blown away by its magnificence. I should mention I'm an atheist and could see how non-believers would view it as too much opulence and a waste of resources, but I was traveling with a Catholic friend and looked forward to the pilgrimage for the educational and historical value.Built atop the barracks of Constantine’s pagan enemies and consecrated in 318 after his victory over Maxentius, San Giovanni is the oldest church in the west. The Papal Cathedra (teaching seat) was placed in its interior making it the Cathedral of the Bishop of Rome. As such, it ranks above all other churches including St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City, and is sometimes referred to as the “mother of all churches”. Attractions to San Giovanni include the original bronze doors of the Curia (Roman Senate House) moved here from the Roman Forum in the seventh century. The Pope visited San Giovanni just 3 days after we were there to open The Holy Door for the Jubilee Year of Mercy. For the coming Year of Mercy, Pope Francis has requested a Holy Door be designated available to people for sacred pilgrimage, so visit while you can.Another attraction is the High Altar, which is the only altar made of wood instead of stone and encloses no relics, but is believed to be the actual wooden altar upon which St. Peter celebrated Mass during his residence in Rome. Carefully preserved through the years of persecution, it was brought by Constantine to San Giovanni where it would become the principle altar of the cathedral church of Rome. Above the High Altar is the baldacchino, a Gothic structure resting on four marble columns, and said to house the preserved heads of the Apostles Peter and Paul. Another draw to San Giovanni is the 1000 pound gilded silver bas-relief of the Last Supper enshrined in cedar, said to have been part of the table used at the Last Supper. Finally, the obelisk outside of the basilica is the largest standing Egyptian Obelisk in the world. It was originally designated for Constantinople, but after Constantine died, was brought to Rome where it stands today.Most of Italy's churches include small tour guide listening stations that for 2 euro will give 2 listeners 10-15 minutes of commentary on the history and salient points of a particular site. They're worth the time and small cost to know the significance of what you're looking at. We sought them out everywhere.We visited the small gift shop in the church and purchased better quality crosses and rosaries than I saw displayed at any of the souvenir shops or vendor booths outside. You can pick up cheap rosaries outside, but for the special people in my life, I purchased rosaries from one of the major basilicas because they were more authentic.San Giovanni in Laterno is a must-see if churches are on your agenda for Rome.

amazing architecture makes a beautiful basilica. This basilica has features from a number of architects including Michelangelo and also works by various sculptors and artists.There are so many things to admire as one walks around on incredible mosaic floors.San Giovanni dates back to the 4th century.There are relics of saints Peter and Paul.It is A church in everyday use and is the cathedral of the Pope as Bishop of Rome.This basilica is very accessible as there is a Metro station close by and many buses stop outside.

Best Church in Rome. This one was my favorite and should not be missed. We put this visit together with a trip to the Colosseum and it worked our perfectly. First stop by the Colosseum, Palatine, and the Roman Forum and then cruise down to check out the Arcibasilica.

Simply breathtaking. Beautiful Basilica, the facade and entrance collanade are special but the ceiling is absolutely amazing. Heavily restored c1650 with sculptures added down each side of the nave. Central alter with relics of the saints was a highlight.Recommend going early, it was quite quiet when we arrived (about 10am) so east to get through bag checks and the inside was relatively calm and peaceful

Huge impressive structure, its wealth makes you wonder. It is a huge impressive structure, with amazing exterior and interior. It has lots of paintings and rich, massive gold elements. It's wealth makes you wonder when you are there and ask yourself some questions.

It's free to visit, and if your near the colosseum or able to get metro line a then I'd recommend walking over to this.It's also the official basilica of the pope and has the papal throne - religious or not this is a must see!

The most wonderful basilica in Rome. In my opinion this is the nicest basilica in Rome...yes even more than the Vatican. It is easily accessible by metro which stops really close. The enormity of this place is impressive. Statues huge and artistic. There is also the cloister which is so peaceful. Full of works of art. In front of the basilica there is the sancta sanctorum...sacred steps which is also worth visiting.

Worth the walk.. This is the Cathedral of Rome. It's a bit off the beaten tourist track but definitely worth a visit. We walked to it after the colosseum. What struck me about it was the contrast between it and other churches in Rome. The main nave is very monochrome, back, white and grey with huge white marble statues of the apostles - they were breathtaking. The alter end of the catherdral is very colourful with the usual, gold, marble & paintings found in Roman churches.

Different World. Different world. what a place to visit. It look like that you are 4000 years back. Beautiful buildings and art work.well kept as if they are made yesterday. you feel you are in wonderland.

Unearthly beauty!. Unearthly beauty! There are a lot of sights in Rome, from a small church to such big building. Sculptures that can be seen inside are inestimable! a lot of stories and legends are to relate about these sculptures, and even local guides will not have time in all their born days just to tell it! In this building you can feel how small you are and how great are works made by the same people as you.

A must-see.. Beautiful church. A bit far, but metro takes you close enough.
Worth a visit as it is one of the oldest churches in Rome.
Beautiful. A place you HAVE to see if you are a Catholic or an architecture and art lover, it is truly breath taking even though it is smaller than San Pietro.

best church in Rome after Vatican San Peter church. A very big church just near ancient Rome wall of 2000 years ago. Just on the back of this church there is not Italian country but a small part of Vatican territory.
The oldest Basilica in Rome. Unique Church, with an interesting clauster and small museum. We used the audio/visual guide offered by the Omnia card, it was useful.

A local told me this is our church as opposed to st. Peter's Basilica. We had time before our Colosseum tour so we walked here after visiting San P{intro in Vincoli. A spectacular church. My wife really enjoyed it. Another must see.

Beautiful. This church is huge and very beautiful. Very light inside and when it's sunny outside the sun shines through the church windows and lights part of the church. It's gates are huge and about three storeys high. The architecture is great.Entrance is free.

A magnificent church. This should not be missed. It is free entry although there may be some extra bits for which payment is necessary.It is easy to get to being easy walking distance from a Metro station.

This basilica, in my opinion rivals St Peter's in detail, architectural beauty, artwork and statuary. There are many side chapels that could each qualify as churches in their own right. The sheer size of the interior apse, nave altar,and statues of the apostles are awe inspiring. My neck ached the next day and it took my a while to remember that I had been looking up for quite a long time. Thank goodness for digital cameras.

Great. Buses in Rome take long, but if you are going to Calixto´s Catacumbs, once you get off the Metro at St. Giovanni, spend a few minutes a the Basilica. It has incredible marble statues of the Apostles, and its of colossal size.

Heavenly Place!!!. been here on Christmas day! its a great experience to be there. Great Architecture and paintings inside the church stunning...

Amazing. Really amazing to see it from outside but even more inside.
You can take photo.
Really nice architecture and arts

Stunning. Nothing prepares you for the impression you get coming towards this stunning basilica. It is huge yet elegant in it's architecture. Inside you see beautiful architecture. It is simply beautiful and a visit more than worth it
Not to Miss. So beautiful and being a previous papal seat very notable. 600 churches in Rome. Don't miss this one. right across the street are the holy steps. Easy to miss.

The Four Churches of Rome. Have long had a desire to see the 4 Churches of Rome. Visited St. John Lateran, St. Maria Maggiore. St. Peter and St. Paul. Marveled at the beautiful art work and construction design. It was breathtaking.
Spirituality and Amazing Beauty. The Basilica is one of the major Basilicas of Rome and seat of the Bishop of Rome; the Pope. It is a remarkable place to visit for Christians and non alike.

Stunning basilica.... My family and I visited the 4 major basilicas in Rome. Very beautiful. The inside art work and architecture in each are so amazing. All worth a visit... truly most beautiful churches in the world.
Gorgeous. Whether your off a spiritual nature or not the sheer grandness off design and decadence in architecture and art is something else , you will be blown away by it its really stunning .

Fantastic Church. San Giovanni in Laterno or St John in the Latern as it would be in english is a brilliant church and one of the four big churches in Roma. A true sight for all art and architecture lovers and a deeply spiritual sight for people of faith. A must visit sight for the traveller to Rome for its sophisiticated interior and exterior which are equally impressive for their design and history. Recommended.

it was just okay after visited vatican city. when we were there, it was a long queue in the rain and cold. There was even security check but the process was quick which was good. but it was not as impressive as expected if you have visited vatican musuems.

Shame about security... 1 entrance security gate to get in and 100 people ahead of me.. we spent 1hr in line and 15 mins inside :-) I guess this is the fault of our friends from the East necessitating this however more staff / gates should open to accommodate.Inside very nice and well worth a visit to the official Papal Basilica.

Yet at the same time is interesting to see the craftsmanship. Wide open space outside, makes the appearance walking up to the church seem more impressive, despite the street sellers outside.

Absolutely stunning!. If you are in Rome this is an absolute must. Don't be put off by the que, it looks long but moves pretty quickly. It took us 30-40 minutes to get in but was really incredible. One of the top places I have "ever" seen.

This is Roman history at it's best. I read the other reviews of this place, and i would have to agree with them. You need to come to this Basilica while in Rome. Not only is it massive, it is full of Roman church history. Get the audio tour for the true experience of this place. Also, make sure you walk around to the front of this building for access. It is easy to approach from the back, thinking that is the front and that it is closed, but keep persisting until you see the massive columned front facade.Well worth it!

Huge Archbasilica with huge and magnificent statues and papal tombs. It is the official episcopal seat of the Bishop of Rome, meaning that it only looses in size to the Vatican's Saint Peter's Church's.If you go to Rome it is a must, not only from a distant, close and near view, but also from inside and detailed view.Enjoy
Ah yes!. Calm, serene, contemplative and just beautiful. A most magnificent building along with an interesting collection of ancient carvings, statues, grave covers etc. A must see.

Wonderful Church with a Rich History. An excellent church with wonderful pieces of art. More important is the character of the church. Try and attend a mass there if time permits to make your visit a truly fruitful one.

Not to be missed. Beautiful and breathtaking! The sacred stairway next-door was also very moving. All of the artwork, architecture and sculptures were well maintained. So much better than a cold museum.
