Spectacular. All of the churches outside the Vatican walls were stunningly beautiful. Even if you don't spend a ton of time, take a walk through and look at the beauty
Fantastic Place. After Vatican, a place that must be visited. There is a subway station nearby so, it is very easy to get there.
Marvelous . A must see place, long line because of the security, but the architecture and the museum is free across the church is the holy stairs

Stunning. This is a little off the beaten track compared to a lot of the other attractions but well worth a visit. We used the hop on hop off bus to visit, which is a great way to see the city, but there is also a Metro stop a few minutes away. It is just absolutely beautiful here, inside and out. It was not busy at all and it was a privilege to be able to see it.

Official Episcopal Seat of the Bishop of Rome. My favorite church in all of Rome. It is the oldest of the five Papal Basilicas of the world. There is something about it that makes it feel fresh and new. It is colossal inside. Every place you look, there is something to absorb. A highlight for me were the spectacular greater than life size statues of the Apostles that now fill the twelve niches that line the interior. Twelve papal tombs were here but were consumed by fire. Six papal tombs remain, with Pope Leo XIII buried in 1907, being the last Pope not buried in St Peters Basilica.

Amazing and Beautiful Basilica. This is an amazingly beautiful church. My gf and I both went to confession here after entering thru the Holy Door and praying the Apostle's Creed. I wish I had the priest's name.

The very first Christian church in Rome. This is the first and oldest Christian church in Rome and it oozes history. Much older than St Peters, it forms part of the Vatican and is the Parish church of the Pope, even though it sits well outside Vatican city. The property was given to the Bishop of Rome in the 4th century by Constantine the Great, who is commemorated by a statue at the entrance. It has been rebuilt and updated at various stages and once housed a Benedictine monastery - the cloisters of which date from the 13th century and which can still be visited. The church was built before the tradition of facing to the east was established so that this one faces to the west - very unusual. It also (allegedly) houses various relics including the heads of Saints Peter & Paul - although rumour has it that the French removed those in the 18th century. The central altar baldacchino (gilded cage) is the supposed location of those relics. Entry to the church is free but there is a charge for entry to the cloisters (free or reduced with an Omnia pass - the Omnia office is handily located in the building next to the church). The church decoration is beautiful - frescoes, gilding, statuary all of highest quality. Due to it's position as a Papal church there are some oddities such as that the central altar can only be used by the Pope and mail sent from here will go via the Vatican postal service - a Vatican mailbox is located next to the shop which sells postcards and Vatican city stamps. Outside the church another beautiful mosaic is located across the road. That dates from the 8th century and is all that remains of the first Papal palace on that site.

This is a must in Rome. This is an astonishing roman catholic papal church just 20 minutes walking away from the Colosseum. We enjoyed visiting this architectural masterpiece as part of our tour going through all four major basilicas in Rome. Don't forget to pass through the holy door of mercy!

Awesome I love this place. My advice to you, especially during the Jubilee of Mercy is visit this before you visit St Peter's. You will be stunned by this building but if you see it after St. Peter's you won't appreciate its size or St. Peter's San Giovanni - or the Lateran Basilica - is the head and mother church of all churches in the World. It is grand and big and thankfully not all of the Romanesque and mediaeval bits have been baroqued up. But the scale of San Pietro dwarfs this. They've opened the cloisters and while in need of much love it has a few pieces of brilliant stonework including paleochristian examples The basilica di San Clemente is ten minutes walk away, the Scalia Sancta across the road and the basilica of Santa Croce in gerusalemme ten minutes walk away. They are ALL must visits for pilgrims I think, and for different reasons. The walk from San Giovanni in Laterano to Santa Maria Maggiore along the via Americana is thirty minutes or you can get buses from Piazza San Giovanni I posted elsewhere my review of the Porta Santa at St Peter's and there is a holy door at every one of the four papal basilicas in Rome. Here, quoted from my review of the holy door, is my take on pilgrimage tips for the year of mercy: "There is a Holy Door at each of the four papal basilicas - and you can buy models of them as souvenirs. You'll find them and any Jubilee of Mercy souvenirs much cheaper in the shops around Borgo Pio shops than in via Conciliazione, where the shops seem to add a markup to pious souvenirs and gifts. But the holy door for St John Lateran is one I have only found on sale in the Lateran.And the same goes for cafes in via Conciliazione - it's tourist packed and expensive. If you want books try the shops but also don't forget the good Libreria Leoniana in Borgo Sant Angelo parallel to Conciliazione which has good English selectionsAlso the bookshop run by the Pauline nuns on via del mascherino (running parallel to the street which runs alongside the Vatican walks towards the museum, the via do pray Angelico). Soprani's in via del Mascherino is good for cheap religious goods There is a great jubilee of mercy guide for dummies in the typical yellow cover for €1,99 which is great for first time pilgrims and is in multiple languagesThe security is much tighter than usual, for the Jubilee of mercy, and this means queues take longer than usual. I'm constantly surprised by how poorly people prepare for security - leaving jewellery and coins on and in pockets for example just slows everyone down.You will notice much tighter security in Rome - you will even notice the Army (esercito) on the streets - armed. This is nothing to be alarmed about, they've been doing Operazione Strade Sicure - Operation Safe Streets - for months now and it's as much about general crime reduction as anything else. The best thing you can do if you are visiting the major basilicas is to expect security, prepare your party by putting belts, watches and jewellery etc into bags to go quickly through screening and don't attempt to carry liquids through security. Do not buy any tickets for tours or the Vatican museums from touts on the street. They will rip you off. The best thing to do is go to the OPR office (opera romana pellegrinagi) the Vatican pilgrim office in the piazza Pio XIII - what looks like the end of via Conciliazione directly in front of at peters square itself - or even better book online using the Vatican museums website. My key tips for RomeA) prepare to walk and queue B) buy NOTHING from touts in the street, no matter how charming C) shop around for souvenirs especially religious ones there are a dozen religious shops in the Borgo Pio and more in via do Porto Angelico - the further you go from St. Peter's the cheaper it tends to beD) restaurants in the via Conciliazione are pricey tourist traps, go a few streets in "

BEAUTIFUL, not too crowded, cool obelisk from Egypt. I wanted to visit this church because I had read about it and the square contains the oldest egyptian obelisk in Italy, and the tallest standing ancient egyptian obelisk in the world.It claims to be the mother church of the whole world, and is the main church of Rome (NOT St. Peter's over in Vatican City). It was absolutely beautiful. We went late morning on a Wednesday. You can see the old city walls outside - very cool. There were lots of peddlers hassling us on our walk up to the church. Very persistent and annoying.The church is a palace - it's gorgeous. Don't forget to look up at all the statues. As I said, we went on a Wednesday, so mass was ongoing all day. You could still go in and take non-flash photos of the other areas as long as you were respectful and quiet. Remember to wear clothes that cover your shoulders and knees as when visiting all churches in Rome...it is both respectful and REQUIRED. The mass was beautiful. I am Christian but not catholic but I do love hearing their songs. I don't understand a lot of it but I think their mass processions are beautiful. There is a bookstore at the back of the church - has souveniers too. I wish i would have purchased a crucifix but I didn't want to wait in line (boo - when in Rome, buy that crucifix! LOL). The doors at front are huge and way cool - look at the handles - they are little naked cherubs. It was real neat seeing the very old confessionals. There were lots of separate rooms (chapels) all decorated lavishly. A pope crown was in the first chapel to the left after walking in - pretty neat - kind of tucked away to the side but you can see it through the glass. The whole altar area of the church was gold, and i'm pretty sure it's real gold. very lavish. Basically all you see up there is red and gold. Okay I'm babbling - beautiful church. Don't forget to go see the holy steps across the street in San Lorenzo - but note they do shut down for a 2 hour lunch mid-day.

A Must See in Rome!. Even if your'e not that much into Religious and Churches, You just can't skip that one. Amazing and Beautiful.Easy to reach by metro - 2 minutes by foot from the San Giovanni metro station
One of must see churches in Rome. The church is beautiful and calm. We went on a holiday and were happy to see the services being offered.
Beautiful basilica. We decided to visit this basilica and We did not regret it. There are many places dévotes to saints, beautiful ceilings and a decent treasure. Do not miss it once visiting Rome.

One of the oldest churches in Rome. Across the street from where luther climbed the steps on his knees. You must be covered to your knees and no shoulders showing. Watch out for the street venders, they will try to put scarves on your shoulders and charge you for them if your shoulders are bare. Always take a scarf with you if you wear tank tops. If you do buy anything from the street vendors, never pay what they ask. They expect haggling, esp. from Americans.
Artwork. The peaceful atmosphere and the breathtaking artwork warrants a visit and is walking distance to many of the attractions

great visit. on my recent visit to rome i visited st.john laterna again.tight security at the entrance,similar to the airport security.Due to Jubilee celebration the door of pardon was opened by Pope in december & i was able to enter through it.

Lovely!. Quiet and peaceful the day we were there. Free to walk around inside. Look at the gorgeous mosaics and the beautiful ceiling. Not crowded as St Peter's but just as spectacular on the inside. We would go back again, just to soak up the atmosphere.
Beautiful Basilica. This is an amazing Church, the art work breath taking so many statues. It is not far from the Colosseum.

really nice mosaic. one of the beautiful church in Rome
It0s free entrance but you can purchase an additional ticket to access part of the Basilic
Top church to visit. Remarkable, beautiful church. Arcibasilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is definitly worth of multiple visits!
Beautiful. Beautiful! If you love European churches, this will be one of your favorites. The architecture, the lighting through the windows. Would love to go back again!
Not well known. This is a place a bit off the bitten track but as this was the first basilica in Rome you must see it. Great ceiling and the sculptures.

One of the top 4 or 5 churches in Rome. This church, along with St. Peters and Santa Maria Maggiore would be the top churches to visit in Rome in my opinion, although there are many more that are remarkable as well. It's worth multiple visits.

As impressive as St Peter's Basilica. Remember that St Peters is the Vatican Basilica so a completely different state, this is the Basilica for the Arch Bishop of Rome and it will not disappoint you, the interior is as beautiful as St Peters with out the enormous crowds and security screening, so no lines ! This is therefor a much more peaceful place. We visited the St Clements Basilica on the way here, both places are very near the Colosseum, so an easy walk. The photos of the interior don't do this place justice.

An outstanding testimony to European Catholic Church exquisite architecture and art. Next to St Peter's and Sta Maria Maggiore this basilica is the quintessential architectural gem testifying to the exquisite taste, artistic sophistication, historic significance and sheer endurance of the catholic church and its determination to preserve and enhance its centuries-old humanistic message. Just getting lost in its nave and transepts is an experience not to be missed. Acoustics are also remarkable. Plus is a free -like most catholic churches - opportunity to just stay, reflect and if inclined, pray in one of Christianity's most revered churches.

A little out of the way but...... We stayed near the Borghese/Via Veneto. This was the one spot during our week's stay that was a little farther out and we almost put off going since we had decided to walk everywhere.. Just go visit this lovely church - the Bishop of Rome's church. If a Catholic, go during one of the Sunday masses. Read about the church, it's art, it's history (it's doors!). Go across the street to the Holy Stairs for an incredible piece of history.Walk back through the magical "village" area of the Monti district.

Spectacular and pretty much ignored. Like Santa Maria Maggiore and St Paul, this basilica is pretty much ignored by the public and believe me, it stands comparison with St Peter, which is crowded and now partially closed to public access (at least last time I was there).I would warmly recommend the visit as the place is spectacular and you really can enjoy it without being walked over by hordes of tourists.There, you can feel you're in Rome and not in Disneyland.
A beautiful space of peace in a busy city. The churches of Rome are all fantastic, but this one gives you a feeling of peace and being humble - very nice.

Spectacular. The Archbasilica is the seat of the Bishop of Rome and the church of the Pope. It is truly and totally magnificent, and worth a visit under any condition when in Rome. Even though it is very large, it has a much warmer and religious sensitivity than St Peters--for me. When visiting, take some time to explore throughout.

Amazing statues. Another Roman basilica with a larger-than-life feel. Huge statues line the nave, and a statue of St. John stands beneath the main altar. Tip: go early - we were kicked out around 7pm after the last Mass of the day.
Ageless Beauty!. This was my favorite of the 4 papal basilicas in Rome. Everywhere you look you are awed by the beauty. I would be a regular churchgoer if I had a place like this in my neighborhood.
Wonderful!. This church was absolutely worth the visit! It is huge with beautiful interiors laden with statues and stunning carvings and paintings on the ceilings! A visual treat!

The Pope's Church in Rome. Take the time to walk a few blocks from the Colosseum to visit San Giovanni Laterano church. While grand, the church's size can be appreciated (it's not overwhelming). Check out the "optical illusion" flooring. Be sure that shoulders and legs are covered (security while not unreasonable, was a bit stricter than at other churches).

Couple with 1 year old. We had a stroll through lateran on the way to the colosseum from where we were staying near the termini! Great decision made as this church is out of this world.Simply stunning. Outside is glorious all in white. Golden interior with some great paintings.Pay a little and you can walk around brick courtyard which is beautiful. And see lots of artefacts. Great toilets in this bit too. So much history to take in. The pope takes a service here each year.
Nice,,. A nice place to visit. Women will have to wear a full sleeves and shorts are not allowed. A worthy place to visit

Interior Super. We enjoyed the vastness of this church and the twelve statues of saints that are mounted on the walls. This is a very scenic church, a little out of the center of the city but easily accessible via the metro and a block or so of walking.

Arcibasilica alright!!!. Me and my wife went on honeymoon at Rome.We booked a hotel at San Giovanni in Laterano region, in the historical center of the city.We arrived at night and as we were walking from metro station tomthe hotel we crossed the Church of San Giovanni.We got shocked from the beautybof the front side of it, were gigantic collumns of Corinthian rythm were holding the forehead that had some magnificent statues on its top.Since our programme would be dense, filled with visits in museums and archaeological grounds, we left the visit here for the we left.So, we did.As you get closer to the Church you begin to realise why it's been called Mother of all churches and you understand why it was made like this, since it was the Popal Residence for centuries, before moving into the Vatican. As you enter, it is natural to feel so very small (try to compare your size with the main door...)Fabulous paintings, carvings, statues of holy men full of splendor.But here you can also find 2-3 holy artifacts, which will thrill you, especially if you go to Rome for religion tourism;-The very first wooden statue of Saint John Baptist.-The very same steps that Jesus ascended from Pontious Pilatus mansion, for His trial.Don't miss it; this church is a museum. Art is everywhere, totally besides faith and religion.You'll be thrilled with the beauty of it.

stunning! great detail!. With my husband and I not being religious we had reservations about visiting here but it was stunning, beautiful detail literally from ceiling to floor. Just next to this is a small lane way where you can pay a few Euros to go to the roof of the adjacent building and the view from up there of Rome is excellent.
Take a look. Not my favorite church by any means, but still one of the more interesting and beautiful ones you'll find. Normally not too crowded either.
a beautiful Church. Another amazing church, among so many in Rome. No wonder its called the eternal city. The details on the ceiling are fantastic.
Worth a visit . Many people head straight for St Peter's Basilica but really this place is amazing, and lot less crowded too. A truly beautiful church.

Stunning Cloister offers quiet relief.. Beautiful and fascinating church. Sometimes the majesty and grandeur of these places can be overwhelming - so make sure to pay a small fee to get out to the Cloister. Peaceful and stunningly beautiful. Not to be missed.
Extraordinary Basilica. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome. The entrance is free of charge. The square besides the church hosts the largest Egyptian obelisk in the world
St. John Lateran. A perfect place to attend Mass. Also, get a photo of the St. Francis statue across the street. Try to get a white dove in your photo. They're all around.

The Most Beautiful Church. I think this is the most beautiful church we saw in Rome. Many are dark and gloomy but San Giovanni is bright and sunny. The artwork inside is as impressive as anything in the Vatican and the grounds are very impressive. It is a bit off the beaten path but is a must see when in Rome.
Some Wonderful Statues !!. This is a very impressive church attached to a monestary. Some of the statues and altars are incredibly beautiful. Well worth a visit!!
Look up!!. This old church is just beautiful, but be sure to look up at the ceiling. Not just here but in all church's.

The highest ranked Catholic Church. Never know that there is a higher ranked Catholic church than St. Peter's Basilica and this is it! Compared to St. Peter's, this is not as big but the interior is so luxury.

One of the 4 papal Churches!. If you are a visit to Rome, Amongst the 1000s of the churches and chapels in the city, San Giovanni is one of the four main papal churches. I loved visiting all the four papal churches. San Giovanni was one of the least crowded and quieter of the four.
A French Basilica in Rome !. Loved the paintings inside the Basilica . Also learnt that this is a Basilica built by the French in Rome
Beautiful. I love going to old churches and this was beautiful as they all are in Rome! Do they need that many churches to support?

Grand, imposing. One clearly needs to see these places in order to gain an understanding of what a basilica is. A must if you appreaciate churches, this is the first and foremost church of the Cristianity, the church of the Pope, the first built just after Emperor Constantine the Great lifted the ban on practising Christian religion.One can find a whole lot of awe-inspiring things in a place like this, just mentioning a couple that impressed me more:- The grand beautiful mosaics in the vault of the apse, that unfortunately can't be well appreciated unless you are allowed access up to the papal throne behind the altar.- The elegant small gilded Last Supper, located on the top of the altar of Santissimo Sacramento in the south-side transetto, on the left-hand as you are in front of the main altar.There are quite a few sacred relics in this place, probably more than in any other church of the Christianity, among them the heads of Saints Peter and Paul, as well as parts of the wooden table above which the first Popes celebrated Mass (when Christians had still to hide in catacombs).The tour of the four papal basilicas is really worthwhile, they are open-air art museums as well as places of worship, like so many other smaller churches in Rome, only these probably provide clearer glimpses of how important, in any sense, the Catholic church has been, and still is, for Rome and Italy.
Great!. Rome, has full range of Basilica's together with its history to tell. This is simply one of them. Always, learn its history.
Awesome. Overcome by the sheer scale and splendour of this historic church. Would like to have stayed for the cnncert by visiting Germans.

A surprise at every corner. We ended up going to the Basilica twice as we found it quite intriguing, the scale is out of this world, it made me feel ant sized. We particularly liked the statues of the Apostels carved by well known artists. I'm not pretending to understand art history but they were pretty amazing to look at.The rest of the church is a mixture of styles and eras which makes the visit quite interesting, little side chapels, some open some closed, confessionals going on all around, guided tourist groups being ushered through all added to the lively atmosphere of the main Basilica of Rome.

A must for sculpture lovers. It is a place for worship and well designed for it. Nothing very glamours or fanciful, and certainly not tacky. The beauty lies in the two lines of sculptures leading to the altar. They are majestic, beautiful, inspiring and impressive. No sculpture or art lovers should miss the opportunity to admire these beauties.

Put this Church on your List. Most people only know St Peters before they come to Rome. I did not know about this church but this is one of the top three churches in Rome because this was the main church before the pope moved the papal seat to St Peters. The place is ornately decorated and it is a must see. You can also see the chair that the pope sits on.
Wonderful. You have to visite Basilica San Giovanni in Laterano !!! Amusing statuses of 12 apostols! Beautiful pantings !

Look Around and Look Up. Astonishing collection of art. The fact that they have a Francis Bacon painting of the Pope says they have a sense of humor. The Sistine Chapel comes as a slight disappointment as you have already traveled through 45 minutes of great art and the chapel is rather small.

A hidden gem. The church wasn't quite as easy to find as I expected. It's right in front of you but doesn't leap out as there are other building built onto it. However, once you push open the door and step inside it doesn't disappoint. The ceilings, floors and walls were spectacular.If my understanding is correct this is the Pope's Church in Rome, as the Bishop of Rome this is his seat and the decor certainly lives up to that billing.We had an Omnia pass which as well as giving access to various areas of the Vatican also allowed gave us an audio guide for the church and entry to the cloisters area.The cloisters is an oasis of calm after the main church and has a several interesting pieces in it, in particular the (alleged) stone slab that the soldiers rolled dice on to decide who got Jesus' clothes after he was crucified.

Beautiful church - amazing... look up, look around - everywhere you see art.. This huge church is near the old city walls, the St Francis Monument, and Santa Scala and chapel. It is amazing. Beautiful art everywhere. Just beware of the beggars and hawkers between it all.

One of Rome’s seven main (pilgrims’) churches …. … which you will understand when visiting. It is also (or mainly ?) the bishop of Rome's church (i.e. the Pope). However not only the very impressive cathedral, but also the Lateran palace including adjacent buildings and Rome’s largest obelisk should not be missed, so be sure to plan sufficient time. The ensemble can easily be reached by public transport, however better by foot e.g. on a tour from the Colosseum or in conjunction of a visit of Santa Croce in Gerusalemme.

Christians and Catholics have to "visit" her once in their lives. Most of my life I have wanted to visit Vatican City, the head quarters of the Roman Catholic Church and the home of the Pope. Get your tickets at least a day ahead of time as you can not really get tickets ahead of time… unless you are a "dignitary" of some sort. Then you get to use the elevators that are hidden from view from the public. Yes, I have a "map" of the place yet it i worthless. You just have to follow the throng, and heaven help you if you have to ask for directions. The uniformed people, not police, just point you to the crowd leaving the area of the exit and that is all the information you will get. Be willing to take this tour by yourself without a paid guide. I heard so many varied stories about the place I was standing in, I actually wondered if anyone really knew the real story that was being told. When the crowd finally got to the various eating establishments, the "guards" were willing to point you to the nearest open restaurant. Do not expect more than that. Okay, I sound disappointed. I am more than disappointed. I am angry that the Vatican looks upon as the unwashed, yet willing to pay their outrageous entry fee and tram our way through this place, the supposed center of Christendom and are willing to to be treated like cattle and eventually ushered out the door. As I was at the EXIt I was taking pictures of the area showing the empty line rail guiding us into the place, I was approached by a tall man dressed well in a nice suit. He asked me "where I was from" with an attitude that was supposed to intimidate me. I answered and when I informed him I was from California, he basically walked away without any regards to my answer. So I whipped out my press pass and as I approached him showing him my press pass, his attitude seemed to change towards civility. I asked him how many people are guides and guards, not the Swiss guards for the Pope, He answered about two thousand on a daily basis. We spoke for a few seconds and he then excused himself as he was busy overseeing the crowds leaving the entrance/ exit area, I want back to taking images. It was another very long walk back too the Red Bus area.

official cathedral of Rome. This church is right inside the city walls so we enjoyed seeing the location of the church as well as seeing the church. It was consecrated in 324AD and is the first Christian Church in Rome
A pleasant surprise, worth a visit. Right at the metro stop, this huge Basilica, of San Giovanni is very beautiful. Check out the Baptistry too. Some beautiful works of art in this building of grand

Absolutely gorgeous!. This amazing basilica was about a 10 minute walk from the hostel I was staying at in Rome. From the outside, it's looks huge, with plenty of Saint's decorating the top of the structure, but seems pretty common. The real beauty lies on the inside.The huge statues, colorful ceiling and magnificent paintings are a sight for sore eyes and will take the breath away. I caught mass on a sunny Sunday morning, and the colored glass in the church is even more vibrant with the sun shining through it. If you're in Rome, you should definitely stop by this beauty.

San Giovani in Laterano. I was blown away when I entered in the "mother" of all churches in Rome.It's amazing how beautiful and well kept this church is!This church is a must visit for anyone coming to Rome.

Surprised by the beauty. When in Rome, be sure to visit this gem!! It's a quiet (when you get there early) and wonderful place For a small entry fee (5€) you can visit the garden and they're beautiful We've visited St Peters Basilica but this was more impressive!
Holiday visit. As with many buildings in Rome this is no exception, so lovely a must to visit the interior is typical of the architecture found in Rome. Amazing
Great place to visit. Interesting and very worthwhile. Tons of things to see. easy entry and walk around.Put it on your list

Beautiful. We stumbled upon this church while trying to find something else and it turned out to be a wonderful find. The inside will take your breath away. I took so many photos, but they did not capture the beauty. The ceilings were gorgeous.

A Splendid Relic of a Bygone Day. This was the seat of the Popes until the 14th Century. It is situated in a large piazza with impressive wide steps leading up to it. One can certainly imagine it as the predecessor to the Vatican. I have a personal history with San Giovanni so was happy to return more than 40 years after my first visit here and relive my experiences. It is very much a working church with many side altars for celebration of Mass.

Very beautiful "mother"church. One of the many churches we visited on our trip and one that stands out to us for beauty and cheer awe-factor. Especially the ceiling is impressive, metro stops across the street, no excuse to not visit this beauty.
Pilgrimage basilica. One of the pilgrimage basilicas in Rome. Very important in historical way. Easy accessible by public transport.

The beauty found in Rome is endless. Everywhere you turn there is beautiful artwork to take your breath away and here it is another must see. Like the Vatican the art here is awesome and inspiring. I recommend taking the time to see and enjoy it here
Good. Obviously not quite the same scale as St Peters Church but still quite impressive. It is best to go whilst there is a service on.
Beautiful, tranquil, amazing. I was staying just over the road from here and I am so glad I popped in. It is so incredibly beautiful inside. I could have looked all the ceiling all day! A must visit!
A lovely place if you like Imperial Roman-feeling church architecture. I don't.. If you like Santa Croce in Florence, you will probably like this barn too. (E. M. Forster's word.) Huge, ornate, dull.
Worth the walk to get there. Another beauty and as it is a bit out of the way up the hill there are far fewer tourists admiring the lovely altar and ceilings

Very underrated church. The Church of the popes is extremely underrated in my opinion. The beautiful ceiling and artwork is better than other more popular churches in Italy (Duomo in Florence, for one). Was lucky enough to hear the organ during our visit.

The Pope's Church. Everyone knows that the Pope is the head of the Catholic church, but less known is that he is also the Bishop of Rome. As such, this is his cathedral, or his seat in the diocese of Rome. Once inside you will be struck by the elegant ceiling, the beautiful altar area, and the wonderful statues of the apostles. It is a little out of the way, but very well worth a metro ride to visit. It is about a block from the Metro station.

Not just another church. The art, sculpture and dignity of this Basilica are well worth the walk up the hill. It is cavernous and full of detail, like most of the other churches, but it radiates a special quality of calm and grandeur.

A bit smaller version of St. Peter's with much less crowd. Nice place to visit during your stay at Rome. Arcibasilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is offering almost the same amount of sights as St. Peter's but is much less crowded and quiet.

A nice change from the Centrl Rome hoards. Spent a couple hours here today, and it's an awe inspiring space that has some of the most incredible paintings and sculptures I've seen in Rome. I even stayed for mass even though I haven't been in years.If your looking for a church to visit, don't miss this one. Easy access from the Metro. San Giovanni stop.

Another impressive and ostentatious Cathloic church.. In four days in Rome we saw so many beautiful and impressive churches that inevitably you become confused but suffice it to say that this like the others is very impressive in size, architecture and contents highlighting the incredible wealth of the Catholic church.

Beautiful Basilica. As the mother cathedral of Rome my party were surprised that there were so few people in this beautiful, monumental church which is many ways is no poor substitute to St. Peter's. Well worth a visit.

Original seat of Papacy. This is called the mother church as it was the main church of the Roman Catholic Church before St Peters was built. It is a beautiful church, open to public and free of charge as places of worship should be. Across the road is the Holy Stairs, another place you must visit.St John Lateran is probably a nicer church to visit than St Peters.

Better than the Vatican. The hotel suggested this place and what a suggestion. Truly magnificent. There are no crowds of people, no massive long queues, nobody telling me I can skip the line, nobody shouting at me to be quiet and no feeling like you are being herded like sheep. You just relax and admire.

A must-visit not only for Christians, but for anyone who loves sculpture!. We went on a tour, so I'm not sure whether admittance is free or not if you get there on your own. This is the site of the first seat of the Pope, which is actually in Rome, as opposed to where it is now in Vatican City. I loved the arch basilica for its history, but most especially for the statues within. All of the statues were baroque. My favorite one was of Michelangelo's St. Bartholomew holding his skin. (St. Bartholomew was skinned alive). While that is a gruesome thought, what made this sculpture special for me was that Michelangelo created a self-portrait on the "skin" that the statue was holding. The bronze Jubilee doors at this church are amazing to behold, and as a bonus, Scala Sancta is located within the same small piazza.

Rome tour . Beautiful church, am so glad we took the time to go check it out on our tour of Rome. It was not so busy as most other places since it's a little off the beaten track. But well worth seeing.

One of the great Cathedrals of Catholicism. This church was magnificent. The church contains 12 massive statues of the apostles with the stations of the cross above them.Across the street is the Scala Sancta which are the stairs taken from the palace of Pontius Pilate that Jesus walked on. Worshipers scale the steps in their knees. At the top is the Sancta Sanctorum which is the chapel for the earliest Popes.

A working church. A large service in French was in progress in the centre of the nave following the beatification of the parent of St Theresa of Lisieux. Also other services and confessions. This is a beautiful ornate church but a working one unlike St Peters. Many languages are catered for too

Beautiful. We got so confused to reach the Basilica, especially using the bus in Rome, but at the end of the day we got there and we were amazed by the Basilica beauty.Wonderful interior, majestic & at the same time holly.One of 5 Must see basilicas in rome.
Choir was outstanding and the basilica beautiful . Just amazing - free to get in. We went on a Sunday and it was great as the choir/ band were playing. No queues if you go later in the day too
Amazing. A lesser known attraction with amazing sculptures on the rooftops, and breathtaking interior. One of the more beautiful churches in Rome.

Not To Be Missed!. In a city with so many amazing churches, it is easy to become complacent and think its only another church. However, it's size, architecture and historical importance demand a careful examination. The magnitude of the statues, the glorious paintings and the fact that this was once the first church of Roman Catholicism make it one of the top churches to visit.
Amazing. While not as large as St Peters, it is a very beautiful cathedral. It is worth the trip to this part of town to see it.

Very Impressive. We were staying in the San Giovanni area and so walked past this amazing church every day. The outside facade is ornately decorated with huge statues making the roof line unique and the church immediately recognizable. The vast and elaborate interior is simply awe-inspiring.

Hidden gem. This is a lesser known tourist attraction which is well worth a visit. If you go in the morning you can enjoy a nice quiet and peaceful experience while reflecting on the extravagant interior art. The sculpted Angels are most fascinating.

Beautiful but out of the way.. We stayed at a B&B near the Colosseum so this church was walking distance for first day while waiting to check in. Absolutely gorgeous. Second only to St. Paul's at the Vatican. Free admission.
Wow. This church is Amazing it was well worth a visit, it is huge and fantastic murals and statues…………...

Lovely church. . Nothing out of the ordinary by Rome's standards but it was a beautiful church. Not worth going out of your way to visit. We were staying nearby so popped in but there are more impressive churches in central Rome.
Really Nice. As with most Italian churches this one is massive and extremely highly decorated, Only a short walk from the coliseum a must if you go there first then take a quick look at San Giovanni

Definitely worth a visit, it contains several world-famous paintings and sculptures, especially the cloister is beautiful. Stunning ! ! ! !. We were in a group of 6 with a ship excursion and this site had been selected by the organizer of our group. So glad this was a stop. Just a beautiful church and NOT crowded like some of the other sites. Truly had an amazing experience at this basilica.

So beautiful.. Loved this basilica -- the statues of the saints were probably my favorite -- each sculpted with the means of their martyrdom. Rome's basilica primus inter pares. The first among Christian churches (yes ahead of St Peter's) is an impressive structure. Though constructed originally in the fourth century, the church has been redesigned several times and suffered catastrophic fires in the fourteenth century. The impressive and enormous statues of the apostles are by different artists. Detailed inspection of them indicates the different styles of the artists and provides distinctive context and symbols for each of the apostles.

Wonderful art, architesture and history. This is one of Rome's greatest basilicas.The art is stunning. Great marble statues and ceiling paitings.It's easy to locate, near the red brick wall and gate from San Giovanni Piazza.Good for a rainy day, also.

beautiful place. If you want to see something special this place is for you. you can find there tomb of Saint Paul Apostole and more great things but you need to read before you go there to be well inform about this place.
Part of Vatican tour. As with all of the Vatican Basilicas, it was absolutely spectacular. A guided tour is highly recommended as you get far more out of it.
The perfect peaceful and serene atmosphere. Its structure.Its work. Don't know what is bad .Its a place of importance so visit it.the paintings are good and there is nothing I dislike
Really worth to go. I found this place on tripadvisor , good recommendation. Great church, worth to put into trip plan, and not difficult to find.
The popes church . The artwork is amazing. Like all the churches in Rome it is beautiful. A must to see for all visitors to Rome.The church is huge and when you enter you will feel dwarfed.
St John Lateran Basilica. Fantastic place to visit for religious and non religious visitors. Wonderful art, architecture and history.
Amazing!!!. Words cannot describe this place! No trip to Rome is complete without this! Michaelangelo was a genius & this place has to be seen to believe this!

One of Rome's Best Churches. A beautiful on the lines of St.Peter's. It the second biggest church in the world and was the seat of the Pope before St. Peter's was built. It is currently the seat of the Bishop of Rome. BTW, the Pope is the Bishop of Rome. So I assume any Bishop affairs are conducted there.

During the mass we had time to see and hear the church itself in a "big picture".We're not catholic so mass structure wasn't familiar. People were ok with us being there and we stood up and sat down when others did. Otherwise we just listened. Of course we didn't go to Eucharist when others did. People shake hands in middle of mass and they wish blessing or something. Do the same :)Bravely walk in and enjoy a silent, sacred moment in a city that offers it all around. Fabulous interior by Borromini. San Giovanni in Laterano is considered to have one of the most beautiful Baroque interiors of the churches in Rome and they were designed by Borromini. Absolutely amazing!. For my point of view, attraction #1 in Rome and the most beautiful basilica in Rome and Vatican. Architecture, painting and statues are worth to see and no know their history.Inside, it is possible to rent audioguide just for donation (no fixed fee).

Beautiful. . San Giovanni one of the highlight in Rome. If you're a woman dress correctly or you'll end up looking like Sarah. Overall, very nice.

San Giovanni - The Mother Church of the Roman Catholic World. Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is one of the most important churches in the world and a wonderful place to visit in Rome. It is the official Cathedral of Rome and a place that you will certainly want to include on your itinerary if you enjoy spending time in historical churches during your travels. Opening Hours 7am to 6.30pm daily. Historically, San Giovanni was constructed by Emperor Constantine in the early 4th century upon the lands previously owned by the Laterano family. The church was officially dedicated by Pope Sylvester in 324AD, beginning its reign as the Mother Church for Roman Catholic World. Interestingly, this was the papal residency for nearly a thousand years until Pope Clement V, a Frenchman, elected to have the papal court moved to Avignon in 1309. It was also where all Popes were crowned until 1870. What to see at Basilica di San Giovanni? San Giovanni is a massive church and takes some time to explore thoroughly. The exterior facade, designed by Alessandro Galilei in 1735 is of huge proportion, featuring stacked porticos, topped with colossal figures of Christ, apostles and various saints. You'll need to step back some distance to capture all within the lens of your camera. Before you enter the cathedral, take note of the huge bronze door. Take a picture next to it to help remember its jaw-dropping size when looking over photos after your trip to Rome. Once inside San Giovanni you encounter a 70 meter long nave, lined with large wall niches. Each niche is occupied by an apostle figure, sculpted by the best of Italian Baroque sculptors during the early 18th century. Each is beautiful to look at and all are highly photogenic. The nave also features marble flooring that is Cosmatesque in style, providing elegant geometric shapes and patterns typical of the Medieval period. Look up and you see a long ceiling, delicately panelled and gilded, rounding out a most pleasant church setting. as you proceed down the nave, you will encounter a delightful 14th century baldachino, resting above the high altar. This is elegantly designed with Gothic features and lovely frescos found midway up the structure. Behind the high altar is the Papal Cathedra that remarkably beautiful to see. This area is roped off, which is actually nice as it allows you to stand before it and take unobstructed photos. The apse mosaics, Cosmatesque marble flooring, wall columns and general design of this section of San Giovanni are really nice to see. There are late 16th century porticos and facade of the North church entrance designed by Domenico Fontana that I always enjoy seeing. Have a look at the ceiling frescos here. If you step into the piazza and look up into the upper portico, there are real gems. These are more difficult to see from ground level. If you have binoculars, you're in for a treat. Beyond this North entrance, you can also see the standing 15th-century BC obelisk originally from Karnak in Egypt. To your left, you can enter the Laterano Baptistry which is part of San Giovanni but with a separate entrance. Here you will see several beautiful rooms. Further, across the piazza, you can also see the Holy Staircase of 28 steps used by Jesus just prior to to crucifixion, located in the Santa Scala building. These are all worth making time for as part of your visit to Basilica di San Giovanni. In the end, I find Basilica di San Giovanni to be a remarkable place to visit in Rome. This historically important church is not just an institutional place to visit, it is genuinely beautiful with quite a bit to see. Interestingly, it is never crowded at San Giovanni compared to the more popular places around Rome, this helps make for more peaceful and enjoyable visits.

Amazing basilica. I loved this church and would have liked to have spent much longer exploring here. Not as crowded as St Peters of course, but just as beautiful, I think. Only bad point was the toilet facilities, which were dreadful, and the fact that when we went there were no cafes in the close vicinity at which to recharge our energy. Well worth the effort to find this and if I get to return to Rome one day I would definitely revisit.

Beautiful. We were there fairly early before all the guided tours came so we had a lot of time to just walk about and look. The church is beautiful even if youre not interested in religion. Stunning!. Wow! What a place to see in Rome, not at the top of any tourist list, but magnificent and very well worth a visit. Breathtakingly beautiful, a must see.

Amazing statues. The church is filled with statutes to the right and left as well as in surrounding chapels. They depict scenes from the Bible as the artist perceived them. Very interesting. We were on a 4 basilicas tour and by the time we got here were quite tired and worn out from the heat. We filled our water bottles many times from Roman fountains around the streets.
Beautifyl!. We absolutely loved it here! Very beautiful. Loads of tourists so please be patient as it is worth it!
A great place to visit. A great church, with many frescoes. Worth visiting. Be carefull what you wear if you are a lady. Very nice

Don't miss this!. Once you get past all the selfie stick and water sellers outside, you are greeted to a fantastic church. You don't want to miss this if you're going to Rome. I don't believe in religion but this is so beautiful and there's amazing attention to details.
Immersed in architecture. Great architecture of Rome. It is a sight to see and get immersed in the architecture of the building.

Impressive sculptures. This was both an impressive and spiritual place, compared to St Peter's and the Pantheon which have become too crowded to be able to be reflective of the beauty within these spaces. It was worth the taxi fare.
Beautiful surprise. We walked past this every day and finally decided to pop in on our last day. So glad we did, absolutely stunning interior, recommend a visit.

Amazing. It's a huge and beautiful church, very close from S. Giovani metro station. Remember to avoid short skirts ou bermudas and to have a coat with you if you are wearing a sleeveless shirt or dress, otherwise you won't be allowed to enter any church.

The Vatican Church of St. John Lateran. Visiting this church is just a very moving experience. It is visually breathtaking and very profound. St. John Lateran was for centuries the place in which the popes were crowned, and the church here was as important as St. Peter's in the Middle Ages. Many people don't even know it exists, since they only know St. Peter's and the Vatican Museums, but this is also a complex of buildings and it is still a papal church. Also, it incorporates the "Scala Sancta", or "sacred steps" in the church across the street, which also houses medieval papal apartments. People have come on pilgrimage for centuries to climb the scala sancta on their knees, and the day we visited there were many people doing just that. The interior of St. John's is vast and hugely impressive; along the sides of the walls of the nave there are enormous carvings of all of the apostles, and the Stations of the Cross are carved into the walls above the figures of the apostles. Then, as the viewer continues looking up, he or she is greeted with one of the most fabulous ceilings that I have ever seen in any church in Rome, and that's saying something. The papal seal with the keys and the tiara are in the center of the ceiling, and the detail is just exceptional. Then there's the high altar. The initial colors of the church are gray and white, which makes the explosion of color on the high altar even more impressive. The high altar is really magnificent, and the relics are some of the most important in the Church. Even though it is a massive building, it feels more warm than St. Peter's, and the cloisters are not to be missed. There is no charge for the church, which is the same in all of the churches in Rome, but there is a charge for admission to the cloister. Go see it; it's worth it. The cost is 5 euro. Also, this is where you should buy any rosaries or holy medals in Rome. The prices and the quality are the best in Rome, and the rosaries will still say "Vatican" because it still is. There are also no lines, because people don't know about it, so you can really take your time to explore the church without thousands of people pushing you everywhere. Even though it is a massive building, it still feels like a place where there is time for quiet reflection. This was one of the churches that I had to see on my first trip to Rome, and I was much rewarded by the experience.

Next Best Thing to St. Peters. All of the architectural pagentry and history of St. Peters without the lines. A very interesting and attractive neighborhood with many monuments. Be sure to see the Scala Sacra across the street.

The Pope's "Home" Church Does Not Disappoint. The ceiling in this Basilica is simply breathtaking. Went to mass here while in Italy. Lovely choir. Beautiful setting. After mass there is time to wander before the next mass begins.

Heads of Apostle Peter and Paul above alter. This is a holy pilgrimage for all Christians. There was no line and an easy walk from the metro. Take your time and reflect on their sacrifices for us as God/Jesus planned with the Holy Spirit. This was the First Vatican Basilllica.

The Most Beautiful Church in Rome. With a historical background dating back to 312 AD, with the defeat of the Roman Emperor Maxentius by Emperor Constantine I, and a first-class pedigree (headquarters of the Roman Church and site of the Papal Palace until St. Peter's was built), one could spend all day learning about this church. Audioguides were available from a small, sweet nun for a donation. She also gave us a very good map of Rome.  The archbasilica is packed with historical artifacts, like the tall bronze doors in the portico originally from the Roman Senate House, or the statue of Constantine found in the Diocletion bath; with relics of deep religious significance, such as the cedar table below the high altar used during the Last Supper; and also with art works of great beauty, like the larger-than-life statues of the 12 apostles, or the ornately coffered ceiling. Yet the grand proportions create an atmosphere of harmony and peace.  There is an additional fee to see the cloister, but it is worthwhile to see the artifacts displayed there, the beautiful columns, and the modern restrooms. The tomb of Pope Martin V lies in front of the high altar. At least 16 other popes are entombed there as well, but are not accessible. Every Maunday Thursday the pope delivers an address from the balcony situated on the second story of the portico.

Mind blowing. Absolutely stunning, art work just amazing,
No flashing cameras allowed as they will ruin the artwork.
Remember this point tho--
When inside , take a seat and time to admire the works of Michael Angelo,
Honestly,
Great place to really relax and admire.

Amazing basilica, but don't overlook beautiful and peaceful adoration chapel inside. The Cathedral church of St. John Lateran (San Giovanni Laterano) gets a 5 star review from me on the strength of its architectural, artistic, ecclesiastical and historical patrimony. I have been to Rome 4 times and missed San Giovanni Laterano the first two times, which was a mistake. The church is truly magnificent. If you are in Rome on a pilgrimage, I advise beforehand to do the Scala Sancta (across from this cathedral), then to visit here, then on to the Santa Croce in Gerusalemme which is only 10 minutes away by foot. But we never made it to Santa Croce, because I visited the Blessed Sacrament chapel in San Giovanni Laterano and ended up staying there for over two hours, and then the Holy Mass started then and I could not miss this chance to hear Mass in the Pope's own church. This adoration chapel is incredibly peaceful but note it is not accessible to tourists, unless you switch off your camera and are willing to pray in silence for some minutes (recommended). Of course it would be better to have a good look around the main part of the basilica before the chapel.
Beautiful church!. Beautiful church but a bit far out of the city center and make sure you are properly dressed, because otherwise you will not get in.

Roma Cristiana. The best Basilica. Tremendous. I also enjoyed seeing the Sacret Door. Needs time to see this Basilica. It is better to go in a tour like Christian Roma, for example, so a guide will explain everything to you about the construction and the history. If you go by yourself , you might come in and come out..
Beautiful. not a fantastic looking building from the outside, but once you're inside, its stunning.its well worth a visit

Almost as nice as St Peters but without the queue.. This is a gem of a church close to the San Giovanni Metro station. By passing through part of the ancient Roman wall you come to this huge church with its beautiful paintings, sculptures and carvings. There are many confessionals in the church and each one contains a priest who will listen to your confession in one of three languages.

AMAZING. Probably one of the most beautiful churches I have been to, certainly the most opulent. The gold work on the ceiling left us stunned in awe. Truly a must visit place in Rome!Be careful to bring along something to cover your shoulders and legs (if you are wearing shorts), though!

The Archbasilica. Impressive! If you pay a visit to San Giovanni don t miss the holy stairs that are located on the left side of the church, across the street. The tradition wants you to climb the stairs, step by step, on your knees, while praying the Rosary.San Giovanni is an Archbasilica, meaning that it is above all other churches, the oldest and the first among the five Papal Basilicas of the world

Part of the Vatican, though accros town.. Among the many churches I visited this one is still memorable for it's grandeur and the fact that it is the Cathedral of Rome or seat of the Bishop of Rome otherwise know as the Pope. Definitely worth a visit.
The most amazing statues. This basilica's got the most beautiful statues, they sand out from the other basilicas in Rome. Truly worth a visit !

A must see when in Rome. Off the beaten path about 15 min leisurely walk from the Colloseo, this massive church is less frequented by tourists. Superb carved ceilings, huge organ and very bright interior to show off several side chapels. This is the place where the pope gives its first mass as archbishop of Rome... Just to give an idea about how rich that church is!
San Giovanni. The popes little cathedral as bishop of Rome wonderful church and they say that the gated steps in the quarantine are from the way of the cross at Calvary
Beautiful outside. Didn't go in but saw it from the outside and it's an amazing piece of work. I'm sure the inside would've spectacular too..

Church with loads of History. This is a must see for people with young children. There are so many points of interest within this church that both young and old minds will appreciate. And the best thing was that his church was just one block from our hotel so we got a glimpse of this place every time we went out.

Unexpected surprise. We were headed to the stairs across the street that Constantine brought over from Jerusalem that Jesus walked on to see Pilate. We thought we would start here first since we didn't really know where we were going and we knew someone would be able to speak English inside to help us find it (it was across the street). The basilica has very pretty statues and what I really remembered were the beautiful paintings in the oval frames. There is a gift shop and what looked like another part that you can visit but we were only in Rome for a few hours so unfortunately we were in a hurry.

Beautiful Basilica. This is a lovely Church. Great art! And the Main church of Rome... not the Vatican! It is a must on my list of places to visit when in Rome. Go across the street and see the Holy Stairs- brought by Emperor Constantine's mother- Helena from the Holy land to Rome. You can climbs these only on your knees. Even if you don't want to...go and see this prayerful place,

Wonderful Papal church. This is the cathedral church of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of thr Bishop of Rome (Pope). Very intresting and less known important church in Rome. Near Colosseum.
Great visit to San Giovanni. Really enjoyed the very large statues in this cathedral. That's one of the features that makes this church stand out from so many other great ones in Rome.
Amazing basilica. Amazing space with many beutiful statues and nice painting ceiling,magical atmoshere inside, two souvenirs shop

Far from everything, but worth it!. What makes me in awe is the statues of the twelve apostles in the columns that are beautifully carved. The video guide is very cheap but very informative! Did you know that Handel played on of the organs in this church? #funfact

Got kicked out but still my favorite. This was my favorite Basilica in Rome (despite the fact that I got kicked out). When we wentthere, there was singing, which was absolutely beautiful. They even had a bathroom with door carved right into the wall.

Highlight of Rome trip. Booked a tour with Roma Pass for the first full day that I was in Rome, whilst the tour was average the actual venue itself was breathtaking the scope of the basilica and the remainder of the building was far more than expected and the detail in each and every sculpture and piece of artwork was mindblowing, if you visit this be prepared to take lots of photos as there is much too see and admire.
When in rome. Spectacular . A long wait in line though. Very busy. But to be expected. Lived up to expectations. Intricate art work.

Impressive. Almost everything in Rome is impressive but especially this beautiful church kept attracting me to a second visit in short time. A must place to see in Rome. Close to the San Clemente which is another interesting church to visit. Try to combine these two.

One of the most impressive in Rome. Visited this first as was near our hotel. Absolutely beautiful Basilica and one not to be missed in Rome. Easy to get to and a great Sandwich shop across road as well for afterwards. Also near Holy Stairs.

Long way to get to the chapel. Unfortunately it took about 30 minutes from the guide shop to the chapel ( by then we were exhausted walking in 35 degrees sun) When we got in we realised we had to keep walking and walking as it was very busy and after about 3/4 hour you eventually realise you are in the chapel being told to keep moving like sheep be quiet and don't take pictures. If you stopped you got stood on so we kept walking and it felt like we couldn't take it all in. Then another big walk to get out. Didn't do it for me I'm afraid

Great to visit - recommend a guide. Visited here on a tour and it was fantastic. The guide provides expert knowledge that takes the visit to more than that of observing the ancient architecture. The church itself is fascinating and an amazing experience. And the legends and history of the church take the visit to another dimension. Really enjoyed visiting this place

A must visit in Rome free and no lines. Location of one of the four holy doors for the jubilee and an absolute must visit in Rome. We actually saw this after the Vatican and while not as massive it truly is comparable in many ways.

Excellent. Full of art, cloister has gone up to 5 euro each which is a bit on the expensive side since there isn't anything amazing to see. The rest of the church is amazing though - definitely worth visiting - spend an approx 1.5 hours! No crowds, tourist seem to completely miss it.Afterwords walk down to Giardini di via Carlo Felice and have a drink at the kiosk there!

Impressive. A place of tranquility and personal thoughts. You need to be there to understand what I mean by that. Beautiful place that fills your heart with positive energy, happiness and peace. Both my husband and i were very impressed and we would recommend it to everybody

Uauuuu Amazing !!. I strongly recommend to visit , its a work of art full of history , you dont need to be catholic to feel the greatness and the power of this Arcibasilica.outstanding, definitively a place to visit!!!
Gorgeous architecture. This place has the wow factor written all over it. Together with no crowds this is a winner. One of the absolute must sees in Rome!

Amazing Basilica.... I wish I had seen this before going to the Vatican City as nothing can compare to St. Peter's Basilica. Nonetheless, this Basilica was very amazing as this is the Basilica popes used prior to the Basilica in the Vatican City. I recommend seeing this if you are in Rome and have the time to. Please do make sure to not wear shorts (men seemed to be able to but women could not) and if wearing a tank top, bring something to cover up your shoulders.
Chair of the pope. When staying in Rome you should visit this. Historically it is a very important building and this can be sensed when visiting.
Beautiful. Towards the city wall, the "Popes Church" is full of beautiful artwork and historical significance. About a 15 minute walk from the Colosseum, - don't miss it

Beautiful, amazing scuptures, and no crowds. The San Giovanni Basilica is amazing. Although massive, it has a light, airy feel. The highlights are the centerpiece and the sculptures of the 12 Apostles. Definitely it is worth visiting.As a small side note, the metro stop is nearby so it is easy to reach.

Worth the walk past the Colloseum and the more touristy places. Amazing architecture, large sculptures of the apostles and saints, Byzantine mosaic in apse ceiling, and paintings. The massive archbasilica doors taken from the old Roman Senate building are impressive. For good measure, the Scala Sancta is located just across the street. We even got to see a wedding taking place in a side chapel. Plus, the whole place was basically barren of tourists compared to other spots. This should be a required tour stop for students and art lovers.

Statues of 12 Apostles are HUGE. Centrally located in Rome, adjacent to the ancient entrance to Rome, Porta San Giovanni, the Basilica is an architecturally and artistic marvel. Huge statues of the 12 Apostles line both sides. The ceiling, floor, columns and side alters are a artistic joy to behold. Certainly not as large as St. Peters, however one cannot call it a miniature but one that allows one to explore and marvel because of much smaller crowds. The Santa Scala (Holy Stairs), transportation, restaurants and a large park are directly across the street. The front lawn and park are excellent for children to stretch their legs.

More important that St. Peters. It might not command the presence that St. Peter's does, but as the ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, AKA the Pope, this Basilica is a must see. Once inside you are dwarfed by statues of the Saints. The artwork of the apse is breathtaking. I was surprised by how modest the papal chair seemed amidst all the other décor.

One of 3 Must See Churches in Rome. Rome has over 400 churches, I'm informed. Can't see them all & probably don't wish to see them all, unless you're in the Priesthood - so which one's to visit? The 3 "must see" are St. Peter's, Santa Maria Maggiore & San Giovanni in Laterano.San Giovanni has more history & significance than even "big brother" St. Peter's. Plus the Lateran Treaty between Mussolini & the church was signed here, of interest to 20th century scholars. Magnificent in all regards...

The 'Mother Church'. One of the four Major Basilicas in Rome (along with St. Peter's, St. Paul's Outside the Walls, and Santa Maria Maggiore). This is the first publicly tolerated church in Rome, and in Christianity, and is called 'The Mother Church'.. It is the seat cathedral/cathedral) of the Bishop of Rome - the Pope. It was the site of his residence from the dawn of public Christianity in 13 until the Papacy withdrew to Avignon, France in 1309. It started out very differently, as a cavalry barracks for the Roman Emperor Maxentius, who opposed the first 'Christian' emperor, Constantine's attempt to seize power. This land belonged to Maxentius' daughter Fausta, who Constantine later married. After coming to power, Constantine immediately disbanded this cavalry, then donated the land to the Pope, who had previously resided at the former home of Senator Pudens, at the church of St. Pudenziana (see my review). The Cathedral stands in the middle of a series of very holy and noteworthy monuments, acting as a sort of hub. The tallest free standing obelisk in the world stands right around the corner (32 meters tall, from the reign of Thutmosis III). The 4th century main Baptistery of Rome is within a few feet of the obelisk. The 4th century church of San Stefano in Rotundo is just 10 minute to the west past the hospital (keep it on your left as you walk). The Holy Stairs and Chapel of San Lorenzo is across the street. Santa Croce Basilica is a 10 minute walk to the east on Viale Carlo Felice. The Cathedralral is a five minute walk from San Giovanni subway station (line A), but beware of the traffic enroute. The exterior of the cathedral is massive and stunning, reflecting the power of the medieval Popes, temporal as well as spiritual. The doors at the west front are taken from the Curia in the forum - the ancient chambers of the Roman Senate. The interior is bright, open and airy. It is also significantly less crowded than St. Peter's. The golden ceiling adds to the splendour, as do the floor, mosaics, frescoes, different colour marbles and statues - including massive sculptures of the Twelve Apostles done by seven of the most famous 18th century sculptors. The tomb of the medieval Papcy's most powerful Pope, Innocent III is within the Cathedral. Audio and pod-based tours are available and must be taken for a true appreciation of both the historical and artistic significance of the place. A must! Enjoy!

Beautiful Basilica!!!. The Archbasilica of St. John in the Lateran is considered to be both the main basilica and the oldest Cathedral of the Catholic Church in the west and is the official seat of the Pope as Bishop of Rome! It is a truly magnificent building, full of opulence and charm! It really is a very beautiful Cathedral and well worth a trip whilst sightseeing in Rome!

2nd to St Peters. First time we visited this Basilica. We walked here from the Colosseum in 100 degree weather but it was surely worth it. What a fantastic church. What an enormous surprise. This is a must see in Rome.

Beautiful. I had read this was as good as St Peter's and it did not disappoint. Sadly it was the only time my daughter was underdressed and had forgotten her shawl so she was not allowed in and they had nothing to offer her, like we saw them doing in other churches. I went in on my own and it was well worth the visit.
Unforgetable. I can recommend the visit. The church is really very beautiful and there you have a chance to see a Papal door, it is openned just during the holy year.

Wow, a beautiful spiritual place. We had the good fortune to arrive in time for confessions and then mass began, it is a beautiful place, very spiritual and very moving. We were told that many great people had walked through here. St Francis and St Anthony. It is just across from the Santa Scala (holy stairs)

a beautiful church. a very grand, beautiful church with surrounding buildings, the church is vast and gives an atmosphere of serenity. i loved the building, and found its position was outstanding ,plaza at front was grassed in areas and the back with the obelisk was resplendent

A highlight in Rome. I've visited many churches in Rome and this was one of the most beautiful I've seen. No, it doesn't quite compare with St. Peter's (what does?). But unlike St. Peter's there was no line to get in and it wasn't so crowded, giving you time and peace during your visit.

The Basilica to SEE!. I went to San Giovanni in Laterano after reading the reviews and was NOT dissapointed. The "Mother Church" is, without a doubt, the most impressive church I have ever seen- even more moving than St. Peter's and withour the crowds! Take the time to find this church- it is worth the effort!

A different experience. San Giovanni is an impressive Church. I have visited may times. It is a magnificent building full of wonderful works of art. Cool refuge on a hot day.This time I visited with a friend who suggested we should attend mass.I am not particularly religious, yet sitting and taking part in the celebration of Sunday mass did change my perception of the church.The focus changed from seeing everything from a historic - or art lovers point of view, to perceving it as a backdrop for a... well... religious event.

Gorgeous. And don't miss the cloister audio tour. You can walk here from the Colosseum (about 15 minutes). Beautiful church. We also did the cloister audio tour, which included interesting religious artifacts. You get to this area from the back left corner of the Basilica.

Viist to San Giovanni. The viist to San Giovanni was most enjoyable. I took lots of pictures of the statues of the apostles and marytrs as well. The chapels invited a spirit of meditation and prayer. The opulence of the altars was sad and almost shocking

Breathtaking. Absolute must see while visiting Rome. I stumbled upon this Basilica when searching for places to visit close to the apartment I was staying in Esquilino. After having read reviews on google, I quickly realized this is a "must see". Note to travellers - ensure you are dressed appropriately to enter. For women - make sure your knees are covered, and you take a shawl to cover your shoulders, similar to the expectations for visiting the Vatican. We walked over in 40 degree temps one evening only to realize we had not brought shawls, fortunately we were close enough to walk back the next day and go inside.This place is larger than life, the size of the statues will take your breath away, and the intricacy of the the artwork and all the monuments literally leaves you in awe. This is without question in my top 5 for places visited when travelling, definitely go visit!!

Gorgeous & Historic Church. The oldest Church in Rome it was dedicated to Constantine. They do not allow men in sleeveless shirts or women in sleeveless, mid rift or shorts. There is a large brutish, mean bouncer at the door to stop them. I don't understand if Jesus is love and accepting of all, why the people who run his Church don't subscribe to the same principals? Catholic Church is run by a bunch of old white guys making rules. Silly rules. What would Jesus do?
Very beautiful. An amazing church but you must be aware of the dress code. One of the few churches where they do enforce the shoulders covered and no short, shorts.

Sacred place to see. Beautiful cathedral. A bit far from the traditional places to see in Rome, but taking the metro (station St Giovani) you will get right there in about 20 minutes. If you are a believer, visit the holy steps just next to the cathedral!

Amazing Cathedral - has to be seen. What an amazing place - the decoration is beyond belief. So detailed and impressive. We were lucky enough to get there for a big commemoration service that had to have somewhere near 100 priests attending. The place was full with congregation. Amazing.

Normal visiting place. The solemn mass was at 10am and was truly magnificent. It was the modern liturgy but most of the chants such as the Kyrie, Gloria, etc were sung In Latin. The church itself is stunning, as it should be considering it's the popes cathedral (St. Peter's is not the cathedral of the diocese of Rome)

A place to get lost in.. This church was one of the stops on the Roma Cristiana bus tour and on the Vatican pass and although it's quite a bit out of the way it's well worth the visit. Whilst St. Peters is beautiful I much preferred this church, not too many people inside, quite, more respectful. It really is a stunning building with lots to see, everything is a treat, the floor, ceilings, walls, statues, sanctuary. It's was lovely to just sit down and soak it all in. The Vatican pass gets you a little extra tour which is nice.. and has nicer toilets. The gift shop is not too expensive and has some lovely things in. Just beautiful.

Stunning. Well worth the effort to go past the Coliseum and experience this beautiful and peaceful Cathedral Church of Rome. The papal residence in Rome until the 14th century before the popes moved to the Vatican, it remains impressive and ornate. A delight - and there were no queues!

CENTER OF OUR WALKING TOURS. Were ever we want to go somewhere and we are lost we ended in front of this church. First time we was trying to find a marketplace and we so the church and didn't have a time to go inside. Next time we was lost and we come in front of it and yes smile we new it where we are, and yes next time we go inside. It was a breathaking all full of art and you are surroundid by angels. Such nice fealing I wanted to stay forever...
One of the four great basilicas--great mosaics. Definitely worth a visit--a great basilica with spectacular mosaics. The design is interesting as the church was remodeled over the centuries.
Loved it!. Unique and breathtaking place with a remarkable architecture! I definitely reccommend it as a TOP place in Rome!

Be impressed by the size and scale. Warm to the lovely quiet harmonious little cloisters. This is an important Basilica and on an enormous and impressive scale though I found it a bit like an enormous Municipal building in places. The best bit is the cloisters which are from an earlier date and more intimate and pretty with rose bushes and so many little pillars with intricate and different patterns
Small but breathtaking. One of the most beautiful churches I have visited in Rome. Absolutely breathtaking baroque architecture. Definitely worth seeing.
Another "WOW" Church. A most impressive building with wonderful statues and fantastic ceilings. The stations of the cross were beautifully carved. High Mass was fantastic.
Awesome. It is nice place to visit with your friends or family, if you will go to Italy then this is must see place.
Mother of churches. Beautiful, huge, magic mother of churches. Beware of appropriate clothing! (Fortunatly, there are many guys who sell some shawls :) ) There is no etrance fee.

Magnificent church!. Here is a beautiful basilica, the first place of public worship built specifically for that use by Constantine. Relics of St. Peter and Paul reside there, and the mosaics in the apse are magnificent.
Wow. Wonderful.. giantic.. great.. all you can say. The first thing to see..first residence of pope.. perfect.. (dress code)
Lovely Cathedral. Beautiful cathedral, lovely frescos originally the basilica of the pope before the Vatican well worth a visit.

Must See Church after St. Peters. I didn't know about this church before we arrived to Rome. Our hotel staff recommended we see it. It is as beautiful as St. Peters only not as large, with 3 amazingly beautiful pipe organs. It is considered the most important Catholic church in Rome. It is the catheral for Rome and the oldest christian church in Rome. I believe the Pope live here for over 1000 years. This is where all the official work of the church gets done; where all the Cardinals and Bishops do their work to manage the church. In the piazza there is the tallest obelisk in Rome. There are 3 other interesting churches nearby. Plus a short walk away you can see some remaining ancient aqueducts made my Nero and the old roman city walls. You can take Tram 3 from the Colosseum area to get to the church or you could walk.

Serene and fascinating. Although Vatican City and St Peter's Basilica appear to be a must on most tourists' itinerary in Rome, I found the Basilica of San Giovanni(St John) in Laterano to be absolutely fascinating as this is the mother of all churches in Rome having been consecrated before St Peter's Basilica. It is a short walk from the Coliseum and does not seem to draw a huge crowd so there is time to admire the architecture of this beautiful church and reflect in silence or prayer within the church.
Wow. Amazing architecture and a must see for anyone. The ceiling alone is worth the trip to see this basilica. I am also pretty sure dinosaurs went there to confess their sins.
Amazing church. The outside belies the lavish interior. Amazing paintings and decoration. I love that it is still a living church with services going on in the side chapels.

Not as famous but better. St. Peter''s might be the number one place to go when in Rome but St. John Lateran -- completely across town -- is equally impressive. Each Cardinal -- the Pope included -- has a cathedral in Rome for which they are the bishop. St. John Lateran is the Cathedral seat of the Bishop of Rome, i.e., the Pope. This is a magnificent church. Completely unassuming from the outside but absolutely magnificent inside.
