And, don't miss the Bishop's chair behind the alter.Additionally, St. John Lateran is the oldest church in Rome dating to 324 AD.About halfway between the Coloseum and St. John Lateran is a small shrine -- at the intersection of Via del SS Quattro & Via deal Querceti -- in honor of the mythical Pope Joan. It is at this intersection that the mystical Papessa was through from her horse while traveling from the Vatican area to St. John Lateran. Falling from her horse caused a miscarriage.
Site to see. The art in this cathedral rivals those of other cathedrals in Rome. The interesting fact is how detailed the sculptures using such primitive tools.

Absolutely Amazing. This is a beautiful Basilica. It has an amazing history, incredible architechture, stunning sculptures and more. The gift shop is very well stocked and all items are blessed. Be sure to take in the beauty of each alcove, ceilings and the spectacular alter area. Don't miss out on the exterior architecture and foyer. Well worth the walk.
Sense the History.. Stunning building worth the long walk uphill to see, simply magnificent. Don't forget the cloister, it to is very interesting.

Better than St Peters?. One of the best Basilica’s in Rome and if you go early in the morning you may find you have it almost all to yourself. While the outside is not as dramatic as, say, St Peters it does have a spectacular interior which will take your breath away. It is an Archibasilica which means it’s a Papal Basilica and several Popes are interned here.It’s a bit out of the way, but well worth the trip.
Worth visiting , given the crowds at St Peter's. This basilica is grand and well worth a visit. Unlike St Peter's it is not overcrowded and can be enjoyed at a leisurely pace.
Breathtaking Basilica. Beautiful with fantastic giant statues, very inspiring with wonderful mosaics. For pilgrims a great experience to be at the church where the Pope celebrates Easter mass.

Much better than the Vatican!. This is the Pope's Church in Rome. It is a 4th century Basilica and it serves the Diocese of Rome as the Cathedral. Many Americans will refer to this church as St John Lateran.
Take your time and look at this wonderful place of worship with very little crowds. A stop here is highly recommended!

Beautiful. free to enter with a huge amount of statues and other carved items
Photos allowed
Cover shoulders and knees
Beautiful church. This beautiful church is well worth a visit. We arrived in time for the 9:00 a.m. Mass, then spent the hour afterward exploring the entire place.

Churches and more churches!. Yes, you need to tour MANY churches to really see the best of Italy. The beautiful churches are definitely part of the experience. This was another beautiful church in the heart of Rome. Many great pictures...no flash inside and pics still come out beautiful.

Beautiful church. Did a 'Pilgrim's Rome' tour on my own by visiting the churches from Sta Maria Maggiore until the San Giovanni in Laterano and was thoroughly awed by the beauty of the churches. San Giovanni in Laterano was so beautiful to see inside and out. I would say not to be missed on the visit to Rome.

The Cathedral. Despite what you might think, this is actually the Cathedral of Rome - and a cracking one it is too! There aren't many churches in Rome that aren't worth a visit, to be honest! Choose wisely or, like me, you will be run ragged! Plan ahead and plan routes! I loved every second, but I was totally exhausted!

Check to Make Sure It's Open!. We walked here after touring the Colosseum because a friend said we MUST see it. Got all the way there and discovered it was closed for an international priest conference. Wore ourselves out walking through unattractive and uninteresting neighborhoods all the way back to Trevi Fountain area and were glad to get back to the "old city" but frustrated we had wasted so much time walking out of our way (and not through cool areas of interest). If you're gonna go, make sure it's open and take a cab!
Spectacular Church!. Without a doubt our favourite Church to tour during our Italian Vacation.It was a pleasure to spend a few hours observing the remarkable architecture.

Beautiful Basilica. This is a beautiful basilica, built by Constantine the Great in the 4th century, San Giovanni in Laterano was the first church to be built in Rome. It is the cathedral of the bishop of Rome, the Pope. We were fortunate to be in Rome at a time that the Pope would be celebrating the Feast of Corpus Christi here at the basilica. The mass took place outside on the steps of the basilica, with a one mile procession to the Basilica of Saint Mary Major following the ceremony. The procession was a candlelit walk with hymns being sung - it was an incredible experience!! I highly recommend checking the Pope's schedule if you are visiting Rome, you may get lucky as we did and have a similar opportunity.The central bronze doors of the Basilica are Roman originals from the Curia (Senate House) in the Imperial Forum. Remember to dress appropriately for this visit, no shorts or shoulders bared for women.

Dont walk past this!. Shoulders covered no hats and long skirts/ shorts to the knee. Respectful clothing they say and if you dont have clothing with you, you can buy sarongs (haggle!!) Off the men outside the basilicas! I paid 3euro to cover my legs as i was asked to leave because my dress was too short. A must-see and when youre in,dont forget to look up!! :-)

Beautiful Basilica within the Roman Walls.. Its always amazing to see the beauty inside many of Rome's churches. The artworks and Papal tombs inside are beautiful to see. Great photo op for those interested in photography. Remains of the Roman Wall opposite the basilica.

Stunning. This is a breath taking basilica, so beautiful. Most of us non - catholics think St. Peter's is the pope's church but actually this is his church. Very well kept, beautiful piazza in front, stunning architecture. A must see when in Rome!
impressive church. ancient, bronce doors at the outside, beautiful medieval cloisterst the side, look at the baptisterium outside the church
Beautiful place. This was a quiet place to reflect and think of what it would have been like when it had just open. Great place to visit and a must when visiting Rome.

Beautiful basilica. Wonderful big basilica , very well kept, located in a beautiful big piazza close to the former ancient city walls. All in all I have seen many much more beautiful and really charming cities in Italy than Rome: Firenze, Venice, Trieste. Rome is big, has big buildings and large streets and no charm wharsoever. It is also dirty, covered in grafitti and full of asian and.african inhabitants and it is also too expensive for what it offers.

Spectacular. If travelling to Rome you must make a point of visiting this Basilica, the church of the bishop of Rome - the Pope. It is so unimposing from outside you could possibly pass it if you were not interested but once through the doors you are met with an array of absolute beauty. From the incredible painted ceilings to the ever imposing statues of the saints, it is just spectacular. However, there is one little piece of paradise you could so easily miss. It will cost you 5 euro but you must go through to the garden where you will find a spectacular amount of achitectural gems and the peace, even though you are in a very busy part of the city is unbelieveable. Do not miss this gem which is so easily missed with all the other sites of Rome - also there are no silly queue's

One of the four major cathedrals. . Rome is about history and years of history. And as well the marvelous architects that built these wonders. This cathedral has no second and you will always be amazed visiting praying and admiring.

A very spiritual experience. A beautiful basilica with a very rich history. Many feel that it is more important to visit this basilica rather than St. Peter's. Don't miss either. The Sacred Steps and the Sancta Santorum are very nearby but not well marked. Another must see that will stay with you long after you leave Rome.

"A Must See". I had read about the church and the steps of Jesus when planning our trip, but it wasn't included in any of our tours. On one of our tour days we had some spare time and I asked our guide if he could take us to the church and he did. I am so thankful and feel blessed it worked out for us to go. I truly do believe it is a must see. It is spectacular, beautiful, and impressive. The steps of Jesus are in a smaller church right across the street. If you have the opportunity to go visit I don't think you'll be disappointed.
Beautiful . Lovely visit- worth the trip out if you have a bit of time in Rome, even though it's a little out of the way. Really beautiful and quiet- a welcome change from much of Rome!
cathedral of Rome. Fabulous cathedral and no crowds. Very ornate alter only used by the Pope. Lovely cloister (charge to get in). Well worth a visit.
Spectacular church. Beautiful church to walk around. Impressive statues and alcoves. Also outside across the piazza there is a beautiful statue of St. Francis of Assissi

The Pope's Church!. The Pope i also the Bishop of Rome and San Giovanni/Laterano is the seat of the Bishop. There are over 600 churches in Rome but this has to be in the top 10 if not 5 of "must sees"

Impressive Basilica even for Rome standards. St. John in Lateran is the seat of the Bishop of Rome, i.e. the Pope. The current building is certainly not one of the oldest in Rome as is dates to early 19th century. But is an impressive building with significant art.

Very much worth a visit. Obviously, St. Peter's is the most dramatic and beautiful of Rome's churches; but San Giovanni has a style and a history quite as compelling. The statues of the apostles alone are well worth the visit. Much quieter and perhaps more reverent than St. Peter's, this should be high on your Rome-sights list.

Definitely Worth Seeing. Huge basilica... definitely worth seeing! We walked from the Colosseum, so our first rather disappointing view of the church was from the back side. After we got our act together and realized the front faces towards the San Giovanni metro (not the Colosseum), we were back in business. Once you're done, it's a short walk downhill to the metro (A line).

Beautiful landmark without the crowds. As mentioned in the reviews this church is a longer walk after the colosseum but it was well worth the extra effort. The inside was just spectacular and it was relatively cool on a hot day. There were no long lines or crowds so we spent time to really enjoy the architecture. There is a very valid reason that this was #1 on the TA Rome list when we visited.

Awe-inspiring. We loved visiting this basilica. Everything about it is beautiful and amazing that it was all built for God! We saw confessions being offered (none in English when we were there), as well as masses and Eucharistic adoration. It was really an incredible experience- Catholic or not!

Beautiful. I walked from Santa Maria Maggiore, to here, to Santa Croce in Jerusalem. It was less than 2 miles and really a nice walk between 3 beautiful churches. St. John Lateran was gorgeous and definitely worth your visit. There is nobody checking at the door, but make sure knees and shoulders are covered, as is the rule for many Roman churches. Also, they do have bathrooms on site that you can use.

How do you begin? . Unbelievable! Free for just the basilica. If you are Christian you must see the holy steps. A little out of the way but it has its own bus stop. Plan some time there if you are a pilgrim. We experienced Eucharistic Adoration and the rosary in Italian.

crème de la crème of cathedrals. This is the main cathedral of the city of Rome and the official seat of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope). The exterior is grand but does not prepare you for its incredible interior which is lavish with each inch covered in amazing detail. To see the cathedral properly, you will need about an hour. As you enter, you see the papal alter on your right (where only the Pope may celebrate a mass) – in fact the guide books and pamphlets will tell you that until 1929, the main papal residence was adjacent to the cathedral in the Lateran palace. The papal alter is richly decorated with the highest artistic tools and techniques of the time. The nave is decorated by marble statues of apostles leading to the alter. Whilst the ceiling is a feast for the eyes, don’t forget to look underneath your feet as the floor is also decorated in style. There isn't much in terms of cafes in the immediate vicinity but the avenue opposite the cathedral (Via Merulana) and in most of the streets leading to the church, you can find plenty of cafes, restaurants and pizzarias. Within 20 to 30 minutes walk, at the top of Via Merulana, you will see the cathedral of Santa Maria Maggiore (another amazing church) with good cafes and bars in its vicinity but you will pay for the prime location.

Basicilia of San Giovanni in Laterano & Le Sacre Scalle. Many , Many times visiting here. San Giovanni in Laterano should be a must for 1st, 2nd & even 3rd time travelers to Rome. This is the Pope's church. In addition to seeing San Giovanni in all it's splendor , directly across the street to the right of this most magnificent basilica are the Sacred Steps in the church of the same. Governed by the Jesuits, these steps were donated to Rome by St. Helena the mother of Constantine. These steps were the steps that Christ walked up to Pilate. They are covered with the blood of Christ and now covered in wood. You can only go up these steps (28) of them on your knees. Extremely Moveing.

Beautiful inside and out!. Our highschoolers really enjoyed this site on our trip to Rome. It is just beautful and filled with historic artwork and biblical history. Our tour guide did a fabulous job explainting the history behind the church. We liked it as much as St. Peter's Bascillica.Well worth the trip to this beautiful church!

A pleasure to visit. Having visited other basilicas in Rome I enjoyed this one the most as there was less tourists so I was less distracted and therefore I could really appreciate where I was. This is a beautiful and well preserved basilica and brighter due to the white stone/marble than some of the others. Highly recommend visiting it
Great architecture and history. Beautiful architecture and history. It is a bit further out of the usual Rome tourist circuit but worth the trip

The Mother of the churches. This monumental huge church is the mother of the churches all around the world. This is the title of it and it deserves this name. It is beautiful and breathtaking with its sizes. The history of this building can be found in the guiding books but what is important that security guards stand in the door and they request the proper clothes to enter in the church. Short, mini skirt and top without sleeves is forbidden. The internal part is amazing, the richness captures your eyes.
St Peter's without the crowd. If you can't make it to the Vatican, this is the next best thing. A bit out of the main part of Rome, but worth the hike

Another Gem in the City. Beautiful Cathedral, the oldest Papal Basilica and free! Rome is full of beauty but I feel this place is overlooked. Wonderfully preserved and not at all busy. Remarkable larger than life statues of the apostles and many papal tombs.

I'd choose this over St Peter's any day. Amazing. Not quite as big as St Peter's, but much more comfortable to get around, as it's no where near as crowded. The interior is wonderful, with the gilt ceilings and altar piece. This is the catholic cathedral in Rome (St Peter's isn't). There are beautiful mosaic floors as well. It has a tranquillity that you won't find in St Peters. Don't miss this out of your trip.

Awe inspiring building . Another building that has to be seen as pictures don't do its size and beauty justice. I now appreciate that these churches were designed to wow people into, basically, being converted to the religion. I still can't comprehend how they built and decorated this!

It is better than the exterior. They have renamed the Piazza in front of the church for Pope John Paul II. The exterior of the basilica is rather unimpressive, but the interior is quite splendid with huge statues of the saints and gorgeous paintings and mosaics.

Superb. Breathtakingly beautiful. Quiet and , fortunately, not too crowded. Gorgeous pieces of art, sculptures, paintings including probably the greatest ceiling. Great place to just sit back and meditate! I am happy my 18year old daughter pushed us to visit this basilica.

Extraordinary. Breathtaking basilica! This is a do not miss site in Rome. We went in the early evening and there were perhaps a dozen other people there. It was absolutely beautiful and the carvings, pipe organ, high alter and ceilings were just unbelievable. I thought it every bit as fabulous as St Peters, and much less crowded.
Breathtaking.... One of the most impressive places in Rome. The Cathedral of Rome is full of impressive sculptures and wall paintings. Don't miss this....

a must see place. If you enjoy visiting old churches you must see this place. In many respects we enjoyed this more than St. Peter's Basilica; less crowds and more beautiful. Be sure to pay the small fee - no fee for the church - to visit the cloisters, accessed from inside the church.

Vast, grand, somewhat oppressive!. A little from the major sights but worth the effort if you have time. Has interesting history in relation to Catholic Rome, and site of pilgrimage owing to its relics (the heads of St Peter and St Paul - allegedly!). Lacks the intimacy and artistic interest of many smaller Baroque churches. Was surprised San Giovanni was rated so highly on Tripadvisor!!
Amazing interiors. This one is better than St Peters Bassalica for its interiors...........wont find many visitors since St Peters is marketed more

First home of the Popes. St. John Lateran was the original Papal church before St. Peter's was built in the 16th century. Many of the early popes are still buried here. The Cathedra chair is still in this church. Once elected the new pope must say mass here and sit on this chair to assume the bishopric of Rome, which is the title he holds. The building is elegant and full of history. Another must see.

It is the most important catholic church in the world. This was the first catholic church in the world. It is even above the Saint Peter Basilica. At the back of the Archibasilica you can find the stairs that Jesus used to climb to his crusifixion.
It is a must seen site that not many people know about.

So amazing. We had a wonderful time visiting here and marvelling at everything we saw. I highly recommend coming here if you have time. We walked here which took us about 15 or 20 minutes from the Colosseum.

Don't miss it.. Beautiful basilica, located within walking distance from the colosseum. No crowds or waiting like at the Vatican. It would be helpful to get information from a guide book before attending.

Worth a Guided Tour & Visit. This is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and one of the major churches in Rome. Definitely a must see. Filled with a lot of history, the basilica is a catechetical experience in and of itself. I'd take a guided tour just for the historical and architectural information.

Superb Basilica -quite far from the other attractions in Rome but worth it!. Breathtakingly beautiful church. A lot larger than I had anticipated it to be with so many wonderful things to see.Did not queue to get in & had plenty of space to move/see inside.The basilica itself is a work of art & it is easy to see why it is rated Rome's number one attraction.Many street sellers around the outside.Be sure to cover up! No knees or shoulders to be seen inside.

Awesome!!. One of the world's most impressive churches. Saw on tv but nothing like the real thing! Took 100s of photos. It is huge. It needs to be promoted more. The sculptures were beautiful. I bet a Papal Mass is breathtaking.

Magnifico Catedrale. Dropped in on Sunday and coincided with mass. Wonderful space. Magnificent ceilings. Superb acoustics for the organ and choir. It was wonderful to see the service well patronised but still available for tourist visits.
magnificent. To see it in person was awe inspiring. It's huge. I didn't like all the people trying to sell us something which happens all over Rome.

Massive. This basilica is the biggest and most impressive out of many impressive basilicas in Rome. This was my eight and last basilica of the day and my first thought going in was I get why this is #1 on tripadvisor.
Super beautiful!. It's easy to have church overload in Rome, but this church is worth seeing. I found my favorite chapel here. It's beautiful filled with these angelic sculptures...it's breathtaking!

Beautiful. I read the top10 places in Rome to visit, and was curious about this attraction as it was #1. I was relatively close to the Basilica and took a taxi to check it out. Absolutely beautiful, but weird as there was a Mass going on in the center and tourists quietly around the outside. The setting was spectacular for the Mass with the procession of priests and novitiates proceeding through the church in the haze of incense with the most beautiful woman's singing voice echoing throughout. Wow. The ceiling, the sculptures, the whole setting was amazing.

The first church of the Pope. St. John Lateran is the first of the major basilicas of Rome. It is the church of the Bishop of Rome. It has been built and rebuilt many times. One of the four major basilicas, it is magnificent.

Gorgeous place - but make sure to cover up!. We had time to spare on our last day in Rome so we ended up visiting this place, and glad we did. Absolutely beautiful inside, very religious ambience, a sacred place which included prayer rooms being used. However if you want to stay in this place long I suggest covering up! Aware how strict these sacred places are with females covering up, I took a shawl to cover up my shoulders, but that wasn't enough. I had shorts on (baring in mind it was 30 degrees) and was asked to by security to cover my legs, and after not having anything to cover with I was asked to leave! So if you would rather not be embarrassed I suggest being prepared to cover up! There are men outside selling scarves, however they're rather small. The Sistine Chapel is also as strict. Both definitely worth seeing though and respecting as they're out of this world.

Magnificent with no crowds. This is one visit you must make while in Rome. if the queues at St. Peter's defeat you then this is the next best place. Read up about it before you go and be prepared to take your time. Easy walk from the tourist area of the Colosseum but much less crowded. We were overwhelmed by the number of churches and the crowds in Rome but this place is a gem. Don't miss it.
San Giovanni in Laterano. Amazing piece of architecture. You cannot find churches like this in the States. Old world charm and character.
magnificent. The basilicas of Rome are great venues (free and accessible). San Giovanni in Laterno is one of the most grandeur of the lot - massive, ornate and dazzling.

No crowds, a ton of history, and oh, the sculptures!. Nobody told you that this was one of the truly amazing places in Rome? They probably didn't know. This well-kept (but enormous) secret dates back to Constantine, who gave it to the Bishop of Rome in 324AD. It's been reconstructed many times since. Just the massive Borromini relief sculptures of the Apostles are worth the trip, but they're not the whole show. The recorded self-guided tour is excellent. You'll never forget this place.
Great place and a must see. Beautiful Basilica and a must see. Lots of people there. This was our last church to see on our tour and we were tired but worth visitin.

Not to be missed. Easy to get there even by public transport. When visiting, take your time and don't rush. Better if you read about it before the visit, but not necessary. So much to see and find out...

Gold and mosaics. No line for this one! A great find away the usual crowds. Wonderful patterned mosaic floors and overwhelming ceiling art everywhere you look. This place has an interesting history as a Papal Archbasilica but outside the Vatican boundaries. Worth a look!

Catholic Mecca. While out of the way, this is one of four major Basilicas of Rome and is not to be missed. There are significant relics at this church inlcuding those from St. Peter and St. Paul. Aside from it's beauty and art works, there is also the sacred stairs which can be climed by pilgrims on their knees to reach the Sancta Sanctorum - the holiest of holies for the Catholic Church. Tradition indicates that the stairs are the very ones that Jesus climbed on his visit with Pontius Pilate. Constantine's mother, Helen brought the stairs to Rome and placed them in this special site. Climbing these stairs on our knees was a tremendously powerful spiritual and cleansing experience. Incredible!!

Wow. Huge and stunning, almost up there with St Peter's. Sorry we got there just too late to see cloister, partly because we were told we couldn't park our bikes right outside, but then by parking a little further away we discovered Santa Scala - a far smaller church to one side of San Giovanni, but very unusual with staircase that believers climb on their knees and Pope's room at the top.

The 1st Church of Rome before St. Peters Basilica. If you plan for a religious pilgrimage, this is one of 4 main "Papal" Basilicas that the Vatican highly rank. It is a must for all Catholics to be at the place where the pope is the bishop of the church.
God inspired!. This terrific edifice is an architectural and artistic marvel to behold! When in Rome it is a " must see."
Amazing Bascilica. This bascilica is a short walk from the Colosseum and is worth taking the time out to see. It is an extraordinary place which is as fantastic as St Peter's.

Wow !!. A truly beautiful & peaceful place. The basilica is a must see even though it is a little out of the main tourist area. The marble statues of the apostles are fabulous & the ceilings are stunning.

A Church with it's own Feast Day!. This basilica is a "must-see" for many reasons. First, it is the Pope's church and seeing his chair is worth the visit alone. It is such an important church in Catholicism that is has it's own feast day, and of course the beauty and architecture are stunning. We had the opportunity to tour this beautiful church with a local guide and I know that helped us understand and appreciate our visit even more. If you do not have that opportunity, do not worry, the beauty and size of this church will welcome you and delight your senses. Be sure to spend time looking at the amazing statues and spend some time gazing at the ceiling. Enjoy the feeling of being in a breath-taking building that is still very much a living, working, real parish.
Still in awe. This is a must see place. The steps that Jesus walked up to Pontius Pilate are there and you go up on your knees. There are no words to describe this experience

The official cathedra of the Pope. One of the oldest churches in Rome, originally built on the orders of Constantine after his defeat of Maxentius in the 4th century AD. It´s located right next to the Lateran palace, also worth a visit as it used to house the pope. The archbasilica also has several of the popes´ tombs. As it is not in the centre of the city, it´s not too crowded and you can take the time to appreciate it. I like the roman-inspired statues of the 12 apostles.If you have the time, it´s an interesting place

Amazing basilica. As others have said, this church rivals St. Peter's basilica in breathtaking design and decoration. Though we personally preferred the decor of St. Peter's, San Giovanni in Laterano is not to be missed either. The highlight for me were the statues of the apostles. Even if churches are not among your favorite of Rome's attractions, this place, like Vatican city, is worth a visit. It even has its own metro stop on the A line, so visiting is effortless and entry is free.

Even better than the real thing. I planned to visit the Arcibasilica di San Giovanni In Laterno the first day, and boy, I wish I didn't. The Arcibasilica is so beautiful that afterwards Sint Peter's even disappoints. This is a magnificent church (the first catholic cathedral in Rome by the way) with a very nice ceiling, nice statues and very impressive. The metro is close-by and even the surroundings are very nice to see. A must for every Rome visitor.

Awe-inspiring cathedral - worth the trip. Don't miss this extraordinary cathedral - everything from its huge marble sculptures of the Apostles which line the walls to the organ pipes, mural paintings of scenes from the Old and New Testaments and ornate gold ceiling attest to the dedication and wealth of the Roman Catholic Church since the 4th century. It is only a short bus trip from the colosseum and worth the trip even if you are in Rome for a short time. You can see everything in an hour. Pay the €1 for the sit down audio commentary machines around the walls for the background info and a rest! Outside stands the largest obelisk in the world.
Wow ! Just , wow ! . Absolutely unbelievable ! A hidden gem indeed ! While in Rome you must visit this amazing place you will not be disappointed . Breathtaking .

Top 3 To Do in Rome. Missed out when in Rome last year when trying to book late. Advance booking essential even in low periods. A pleasant walk through extensive gardens to Gallery from drop off bus 116. A small café inside to grab a coffee or bite whilst waiting. A fabulous space, something for everyone but Bernini sculptures are awe inspiring, just how did he do it? Genius of course.The audio guide is a must. We used the full 2 hours of the timed visit. Not too busy in May but last minute visitors could not get in. A must visit for anyone interested in power and history of Rome, indeed world, and the wealth of cultural legacy.Could visit again and see something different each time.

A hidden treasure with an amazing history. From the exterior the Archbasilica of St John Lateran looks like just like one of the many churches that can be found in Rome. Located outside the Vatican but within the boundaries of the City of Rome.However it's beauty is evident upon entering and seeing the impressive ornate ceiling, nave and the statues of the apostles.The Archbasilica has a long and fascinating history and is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, (the Pope).It is well worth a visit and across the forecourt are the Holy Stairs or Scala Sancta, said to be the stairs which formed the staircase to the praetorium of Pontius Pilate in Jerusalem and therefore were sanctified by the footsteps of Jesus Christ during his Passion.Amazing history!

Stunning. One of the best churches. Should combine visit with Vatican museum and Sistine chapel. Recommend doing the guided tour. All the three above cost Eur 37 per person. Takes approx 3 hours in all. Do buy the tickets in advance. Either do the tour first up in the morning around 9am or evening. Wednesdays and Sundays can get busy.
Beautiful, easy to reach on the metro. This is such a beautiful space, with lovely cloisters with unbelievable artefacts from early centuries BC. The statues of the apostles were extraordinary
hidden gem. wonderful baroque interior. Take time to learn about the history See also Santa Maria church at the other end of the road,
Amazing church. This Archbasilica is not to be missed in Rome. Absolutely stunning and awe-inspiring, It is simply the most impressive church I've seen in my lifetime.

BREATHTAKING. AND BUSY!. This is undoubtedly one of the three main must see attractions in Rome along with the Coliseum and the Forum. It is a beautiful building both outside and inside; huge, impressive and very gold!! The only downside were the crowds of course; it was extremely busy so - if you can - try to get there first thing in the morning on your own. (We took a "beat the queue" tour around the Vatican, the Sistine Chapel and then the Basilica starting at 8.45am but in fact the "beat the queue" tours only beat the queues and didn't avoid at all the crush inside which was made up of all the other "beat the queue" tours tangling up with each other). So if you want to visit the Sistine chapel (stunning!) I would recommend getting there early and taking the short itinerary route. Same goes for the climb right to the top. Its a lot of stairs so get there early when its cooler and less crowded. The last section is very narrow and slants over the Dome so if you are prone to claustrophobia like me, definitely head straight to do the Dome climb first thing in the morning so you can get through the last section quickly; it is a short section and you are soon out for the views.
Stunning!. Absolutely beautiful basilica. There are 8-ft statues of the disciples and Paul that are amazing, as well as the altar and art. This is not to be missed!

Lovely visit. Lovely visit to the Basilica with beautiful architecture.
As good as, if not better that St Peters Basilica.

Sept 10, 2001: The day after. We went to see the church. But this seat of the Archbishop of Rome was just that on the day after 9/11. The Archbishop appeared at high-noon. "Tre minute silencio con populo estade unite": "The minutes of silence for the people of the United States." Then, starting hear, and throughout the eternal city, every church bell began to ring. Italy stood with America in the aftermath of 9/11. Everywhere: Bruto, molto brute was the response to the suffering at home. We were, in that moment, all Americans; all Italians.
Another great Basillica. Rome has many great basilicas and this is another good example. Unfortunately its a bit out of the way if your pushed for time
Good to visit.. Depending on where you stay in Rome, this is on the Metro so easy to get to.Impressive, worth a short visit.

Huge and Amazing basilica. We went to St. John's after the braving the Colusseum and waiting for San Clemente to open. It was an amazing example of over the top baroque and we happened in while a Dutch school choir was performing which just added to the atmosphere. The cloisters were also lovely.

The reason the Pope is Pope. This is the seat of the Bishop of Rome, which happens to be the head of the Catholic Church. So, this is the position that actually confers the Pope the primacy of the Church. The Basilica is impressive, and I recommend going there first before visiting the Vatican. The Cathedra, or Bishop's seat is behind the altar, and the ceiling and roofs are breath taking. Also, next to the Archbasilica, is the Lateran Palace, which although cannot be visited, is the place where in 1929 the treaties between Italy and the Holy See were signed that created the Vatican State.
Gold Galore. Simply out of this world. Everything is Gold. The first Basillica. Its free. And it's a definite must see.
must visit if you are at rome. the oldest basilica of Rome popes before Vatican. The majesty of this place, baroque decoration, the history of the Basilica

An experience to remember!. I had read about this Basilica in Rick Steeves book so was eager to include a visit in our trip to Rome. Our timing was perfect!We went on a Sunday afternoon and as we entered a choir of nuns were singing. We had hit on a special day and very special service. What we thought was going to be a quick visit, lasted almost two hours, including a visit to the cloisters that does have an entrance fee.Not only is the architecture amazing and well worth a visit but the service that we witnessed was inspiring. We just sat and absorbed. At the end there was a cardinal who spoke. Of course, we didn't understand a word but were so grateful for the experience.

St. Padre Pio. I was especially interested to know more about Padre Pio, This place is phenomenal. The story of this man is very moving. Being in the place where St. Pio preached and lived makes me want to discover more about this man.
Breathtaking.... Amazing basilica with enormous marble statues, artworks, and a very soothing energy. This was the case for us as we went there on a calm day. Recommended.

Fantastic church - perhaps the best in Rome!. Right next to a metro stop (S. Giovanni) so very convenient.
No charge to enter (just like all the churches in Rome).
More impressive than Saint Peter's aesthetically and in terms of grandeur. A must see in Rome.

One can never tire of visiting this Arcibasilica.. The outside of this amazing structure is breath taking. And then one enters & the interior is even more stunning!! The statues depicting the 12 disciples are amazing. Quite frankly, it is difficult to capture the feelings this edifice evokes. I've visited before & if I have the opportunity, I will certainly visit again.

An amazing church. I went to this church having in mind the fact the on TripAdvisor it was the number one recommendation. You can imagine that my expectations were huge.The church didn't disappoint me. It is a great place with amazing statues and paintings. All the 12 apostles have a representative statue realized with great details.There is a place of prayer with a statue donated by the pope Francesco.The tomb of pope Martino V is situated inside this church with the statue of San Giovanni by its side. It's difficult to put in words what it can be seen in there so I also attach some pictures.Although I was impressed by what I found in there I wouldn't really place it as the number one thing to visit in Rome. There are a lot of different impressive places in Rome so it's hard to impossible to create such as top.I recommend visiting it nevertheless as it is an amazing church.

Beautiful Church. This church is a little out of the way from the main sights (Colosseum, Forum), however well worth the visit. A metro stop is nearby, as are the old city walls and steps that Jesus is said to have walked on. Make sure you don't wear shorts and bring a cover-up if wearing a tank top - the guards out front don't joke around. A beautiful obelisk is right behind the church and have a nice walk back to the Colosseum, etc.

Regimented. Visited on a hot day. Its a long walk a long walk from the main part of RomeRegimented in that they have a revolting little jobsworth to shout at anyone sitting on 'his' steps- when asked why, he answered that this was 'Vatican' area. Fair do's but they don't stop people sitting on the steps on any other church properties. Such as St Peters, or the beggars on the steps at any other churches.Anyway, inside is a somewhat scary gothic style of terrifying Angels & cherubs, and lots of madonna/jesus art. You are not allowed to go near the apse dome, and no indication where the stone the centurions gambled over Jesus's clothesThe enormous statues flanking the Nave reminded me of the bank vault 'nave' in 'despicable me'. -tortured male saintsIf this is your "bag" them go for itSmoke your cigarettes & throw the tab on the steps, but for goodness sake DONT sit downAnd as for the angels inside- Just Dont Blink !!! T'is free though, and the toilets are lovely
The best sight in Rome. This is the church of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope). Better than Saint Peters. Stunning in all respects. Spend more time here than at the Vatican. The best church hands down.

Do not overlook this fine church, much more beautiful than St. Peter`s. This is in fact the cathedral of Rome. There is a special altar from the 14th century for the Pope and the first time a new pope leaves the Vatican, this is where he goes to celebrate mass.The interior of the church is impressive though very difficult to describe because even if the oldest part goes bach to the 4th century it has been modified so many times that by now it mostly stands as a baroque church. However, do notice the beautiful mosaic floor from the 13th century and the impressive ceiling made by one of Michelangelo`s pupils. Also, go to the far end of the church where you will find a painting of Bonifacius made by Giotto in the 14th century. The painting is hidden behind a pillar so you have to be a bit insistent to find it.Outside of the church on Piazza San Giovanni in Laterano you will see the highest and oldest Egyptian obelisk in Rome. It is 47 meters high and very impressive. It was brought to Rome in the 4th century but it is of course much much older, in fact from about 1500 BC.It is a short walk from the Colloseum and I strongly suggest you do it. It is well worth the effort. Not least because the throngs of tourists in Rome have not found it. It is quiet, there is no queue at the entrance and there is no fee either.

Amazing Cathedral. Huge basillica used by the Pope for Maunday Thursday mass. Lovely mosaic altar requring 1 euro to power the lights. Well worth it! Beautiful, large white marble statues throughout the church.Atmospheric, historic and significant. Not to be missed.

Well worth a visit to this oldest church in Rome.. This is an unusual church and full of amazing historical significance. After a tour of The Vatican in the morning with crushing crowds it was lovely to spend time in this church and be able to absorb the details without people all around you. Well worth a visit.

A must visit. this is a beautiful basillica, a little off the main tourist track but that is a positive. It's close to metro stop at St Giovanni, although I walked here (it's not far from the colosseum). I visited on a Wednesday morning. The basillica has two entrances and I went through the ''alternative" entrance which means i appeared in the middle of the church. However that didn't matter and the lack of tourists meant my visit was quite serene and we weren't bothered by the usual tourist touts selling selfie sticks.
the oldest church is Rome. This used to be the Rome Cathedral until the XV century. It is quite a small building. It has a wooden ceiling and beautiful mosaics.

very ornate ancient cathedral. If you like to visit ancient cathedrals, Rome is the place for you! The opposite to London, they charge for visiting their museums, but there is no charge for visiting their churches, unless you want to pay for guides, for souveniers, or for skipping the queues, or other such services. The churches are so luxurious that they make our best cathedrals seem really plain and simple!This church is probably the best, outside of the Vatican.

A great basilica and it's also free!. The Arcibasillica di San Giovanni is a great piece of art! It is situated centrally in Rome and is easily accessible on foot. The basilica is open for the public and there is no entrance fee. Inside, you can find numerous works of art and stare at awe at the design of the temple. All in all, a great place to visit.

Awesome. We stumbled on this church in search of the steps that Jesus walked on (another church almost next door on the same square). This was probably the most impressive church we visited, right up there with St. Peter's Basilica. There is a feeling of awe as you walk in, as everything from floor to ceiling is intricately decorated. It was a little out of the way from all the other sites we were visiting, but it was well worth the walk- just south of the Colosseum.

Each basilica is worth examining. If you go from basilica to basilica each person seems to react differently. Having grown up in Catholic schools for 12 years meant my experience was very different from my non Catholic companion. So if one can get past an entirely religious experience and focus on the incredible works of architecture and art the experience might appeal to all. This particular basilica is historically more significant to me because it originates with a decree and gift from Constantine. No other Christian church is older and that alone left me with visions of so many years of people passing through this site with the purpose of expressing their faith. No longer Catholic, I still can appreciate the history and dedication. It is well worth visiting.

amazingly beautiful. We entered from the side door (by mistake) - an unassuming entry that left us completely overwhelmed when we saw what was inside.....even with so many people inside there was a sense of peace that compels you stop and pray. The ceiling, the statues of the Saints and wall paintings are amazing - and make sure you do not miss the cloisters with a vast collection of relics (well worth paying to view them).On exiting through the main doors we were rewarded by the view of the main portico - fantastic!
A must visit building. Just a fantastic place to see, breath taking. The workmanship of the construction and the fine detail of the decoration is mind blowing. The audio guide is worth doing.

Quiet, beautiful church. It's pretty clear why this is such a well rated attraction on TA as it is much more quiet than other tourist locations in Rome, it is free and easy to enter, and most importantly very beautiful inside and out. Thank goodness for the taxi rank out the front for the ride home!
wow factor. wonderful basilica, the original church of the early popes in Rome . the gold mosaics are fantastic . the large statues of the apostles within the basilica are wonderful too.

Best Church in Rome. It is easy to see why the popes have used this church in older times. The scale of everything is enormous. Statues, paintings, and other flourishes make this an ornate place. You could spend hours appreciating the art. Check the ceiling for even more art.
Use the self-guided tour offered at the entrance.

Incredible. St. John's basilica is extraordinary and is a must see when in Rome. It is included as part of the Omnia Roma pass and you can get there on the open top bus also included as part of the package. Make sure you go through to the cloisters (entrance fee included in the pass) for some of the oldest artefacts you will ever see.

Stunning Basilica. Definitely a church worthy to be the seat of the Bishop of Rome aka the Pope. The frescoes and mosaics are simply amazing. The sculptures on the outside and the inside are works of the masters. Another must see while in Rome.

LIKE A SMALLER ST. PETER´S. Was the first "basilica" of the popes in Roma.After being destroyed, was rebuilt having St. Peter´s (Vatican´s church) as model.Beautiful and less crowded than St. Peter´s at vaticano city.

Top notch church to visit while in Rome. If you are a fan of ornate awesome churches, this one is for you. The huge 10 meter statues a top this church are imposing as you draw nearer. Then there are these extremely tall heavy bronze doors made for a giant. Once we got inside there is an information booth that will loan you an audio iPod with wonderful narration and photos that pop up. All the church asks for is a volunteer donation for the use of the iPod. Every corner, every sq foot, of this jam packed cathedral has breathtaking pieces of art. It may not be the #1 Rome site to see in my book but definitely in the top ten.

A must see in Rome. This is the Basilica of Rome and a must see when visiting the city. The statues of the Apostles and the artwork were fabulous and the alter is a must see. Take your time during your visit so you don't miss anything. Then cross the street to visit the Scala Sancti or Holy Staircase.
Truly impressive. The church just keeps getting bigger as you walk towards it until you reach it an realise that it's vast. The statues inside are also some of the most animated in Rome. Wonderful.
One of the "Must sees". The statuary and decoration was magnificent. The majority of the church was open to wander. I found the 1 euro videoguide near the entrance very informative.

Just around the corner: incredible!. We are staying in a B&B just around the corner and saw this building last nights when going out for dinner. This morning we decided to have a look inside and it is amazing! Beautiful floors, beautiful ceilings, lots of gold, incredible altar. Must visit!
The best. i love it. It was perfect painted and very beautiful. Michael angelo it was a hero at the time and this is his masterpise.

Amazing! A must see!. Just visited Rome on March 25th and 26th. This is stunning and you shouldn't miss it. It's a part of Vatican City, I saw it while on a tour of the Vatican Museum and the Basilica

Outside of St Peter's - The Most Beautiful Interior of any Church in Rome. This is a return visit to St John Lateran and we feel just as excited every time we return.This church is the "home church" for the Bishop of Rome i.e. the Pope!At one time, the Pope resided here (but of course has for centuries resided at the Vatican).It is tough to say which is more impressive, the massive main altar with its huge colonnade or the twelve giant reliefs of the Apostles lining the nave.And these just scratch the surface.Get a good guide book so you won't miss anything and plan on spending a couple of hours here.

Churches dont get much more impressive than this. The sheer grandeur of the church is overwhelming but the aspect that sets it apart is the large grand sculptures of the apostles lining the nave and the incredibly ornate ceiling. It is the sheer scale of this church which is overwhelming and surpasses most of the other churches in Rome. Outside it gives no hint of its fabulous interior but it is worth a detour to visit. Its a 15 minute brisk walk from the Colisseum

beautiful one of top churches. A beautiful church definitely worth visiting but not sure it warrants the very top spot.A 10\15 minute walk from the Colosseum but well worth it with basilica San Clemente on the way (careful that closes early afternoon)Tip. Double it up with San clemente.

Don't miss the cloister. This basilica is an elegant ecclesiastical space with sweeping arches and beautiful sculpture at every turn. Take your time walking around the main body of the church -- the large sculptures of the saints that decorate the main aisles might cause you to miss the more delicate friezes of Biblical scenes even farther up the wall -- you can really see how the early church used art to teach the Gospels. The lovely cloister (which will set you back 5 Euro to enter, but has a good audio guide) is also chock-a-block packed with remnants of beauty from the ancient and medieval worlds.

Only for those who love churches...... It is rated number 1 in Trip Advisor and it doesn't even make my top ten. Granted it has history on its side but little else. If time is short you can leave this location out. The audio tour put me to sleep in the first five minutes.

More beautiful than St Peters. St Peters is bigger and of course has the Sistine Chapel, the Pieta, etc. But this church was absolutely stunning, from the Mosaic to the organ, the sculptures of the Apostles, etc. See both, but don't miss this. Plus in the plaza out front is the best of all the obelisks in Rome.

A beauty in every aspect. Rome has some of the best churches that you could see and not one is far behind in terms of its beauty and among one of them is this church. Though to get here you have to travel extensively as it lies a little out of the usual course but at the same time is easily reachable by the metro. The one unique thing about this church is the 12 apostles all together standing right at the entrance itself. A beautiful sight indeed. Seems like each corner of the church was paid strong attention because it is glorious and eye catching from every angle

San Giovanni in Laterano is amazingly lovely!. From the outside this church looks like nothing special. I is on a slight hill and presents as very large. The metro stop of this name is just down the road and across the street. It is the inside that takes your breath away! This is known as Rome's Cathedral and here is where the Pope officiates in his role as bishop of Rome. It dates from 1736 and was modeled after St Peter's. The church was founded in the 4th century on land donated by emperor Constantine. Fires and earthquakes damaged the original church many times. In 1646, Pope Innocent X engaged Borromini to rebuild the church you see today. This is a pilgrimage church, one of four in Rome. It is beautiful in all respects and has a lot of history built into it. Take the time to explore and digest all of its' wonders!
A Gem of a Church. This beautiful basilica is one of the loveliest in Rome. The artwork alone is worth the visit, but it is the ceiling that is truly spectacular. No waiting in line or entry fee.

An amazing Basilica with beautiful Alfresco, Scluptures and paintings. The Lateran Basilica, is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is the Pope. The outside hall is gracefully built and decorated. The rich architecture and history lies inside. It is worth a visit specially for Religious Christians and others in interested in the basilica / church. Get the Audio Guide for 2Eur if you want to know the history. Short trip and should not take more than 30 minutes to go around.

Beautiful. You have to see this basilica if you have any interest in architecture and church history. It is a short walk from the metro, and there happens to be a nice Roman department store right by the metro where you can pick up gifts and pay non-tourist prices.

Another do not miss church in Rome. Full of Art treasure's and sculptures. We were there during a mass which made it extra special. Don't miss the "Holy Staircase" at the "Scala Santa" next door. Caution, the wooden stairs are rough on the knee's but worth it.
Fantastic. Very very beautiful church - the mother of all churches! Remember to see the chapel unless you have been to Sicily and see the one north of Palermo. You must see this.
Stunning!. Absolutely wonderful! From the impressive facade to the amazing interior. And very interesting history too. Don't miss this!
Great church. The spectacular thing here is the 12 sculptures here. Also buy the audio guide to learn more about the church and get entry into the church's courtyard

Really amazing church. I found the church to be more beautiful and more impressive than Sct Peters. Maybe because it's smaller so it's easier to get the full impression and the full "feeling" of the church. It's one of the plazes that is a "must visit" if you are going to Rome

Absolutely worth the visit!. This is a great piece of Roman history and culture - you should not miss it! Easy to reach by Metro on line B. Access is free as it is for all churches and Basilicas in Rome. This used to be the main Papal Basilica before St.Peter's was built.

Not Outstanding - Worth a Visit. This church was not on my original itinerary but was on my way to another that I did wish to visit so I diverted for a visit. It was thunder-plumbing all day that day and it is a good 3/4 mile to the church from the S. Giovanni metro stop across some very busy roads so I was not in best of form on arrival. Entrance is free and photos are allowed even with flash and there are some nice altars/art, but the find of the day was the little shop at the top end of the church selling handmade / other jewellery at very cheap prices which turned out to make excellent presents for my many nieces and myself! I spent e30 here and in hindsight - should have bought more as they were well above the standards found in the markets. I just couldn't face the journey again. All in all, great find.

A display of wealth. The Arcibasilica is another example of what Roman churches have to offer: an amazing display of art in its many forms, but also a display of opulence that leaves the visitor gawking at such riches.It is wonderful, definitely, a display of grandeur that will amaze you. There is also the possibility to visit the cloister and a museum, if you pay for it. The rosaries, medals, and other such souvenirs are cheaper in the Arcibasilica store than in, or near, the Vatican.

So Beautiful!. I know everyone says that St. Peter's in the Vatican is the most impressive church in Rome.. but this has to truly be the most impressive. We spent a few hours wandering around, sitting quietly, and just soaking it all in. If you're going to go to a church in Rome, I'd recommend this be your first stop!
Must see when in Rome. This is one of four churches must see when come to Rome, especially given its importance in Constantine making Christianity the state religion.

Another monument of excess.... We had already visited the Vatican,so this former residency of the popes came as no surprise. Its an imposing and richly decorated edifice,but we had the same feeling about the whole thing as many other churches and palaces...Is this what Jesus had in mind?

Must visit cathedral. Was hesitating shd we especially go this area since we already visited vatican a few days and saw st peter basilica. However, i would say this san giovanni laterano is a must see one. The church history dated back much earlier before pope chose vatican to stay after italian unification. Before 14th century, this was the original vatican for popes. Also, now this church is still very important for the pope. This church is very gorgeous elegant and many amazing scultures and decorations. We like this more than in fact. Really nice ones. Also nearby there is holy stair church plus holy cross church (u can tell how important this area in history for the pope and christians) which makes this area visit very fruitful. We spent the whole afternoon here that was super enjoyable one. No matter u like amazing architecture, decorative arts and history or even religious ones. A must go place

Breathtaking. I wasn't sure about going to see this church after visiting the. Basilica of Saint Peter but I'm glad we did I liked it more than. St Peters. The ceiling is unbelievable. NO crowds or lines to contend with. WELL Worth a visit to this beautiful church.
Amazing place. This basilica is not Saint Peter, but it's huge! Great spaces filled with marble, some popes are buried here, and the work on the ceiling is amazing!
Wow. if you see the entrance from the street. ..you wil say that it is just another church in Rome. Just get inside. You can't do anything wrong.

Should be seen. the oldest and first ranked of the Basilicas in Rome it is still the Pope's church as he is also the Bishop of Rome. The bronze doors in front were once the entry to the Roman senate and it sits atop the remains an even older Roman structure. Like much else in Rome the sheer scale is overwhelming. Remember to look up at the ceiling when there.
Gorgeous church. What a beautiful church with incredible interiors. Second only to St Peters. A must see while in Rome. Bus from Termini Terminal, or a 20 minute walk.
Fantastic Experience. The Pope's own church. Outside the walls of the Vatican but under Papal rule. Marvellously impressive next to the city walls. A must see for all.
Beautiful church.. This is the Pope's church. Fantastic statues of each of the Apostles. Was in a neighborhood convenient to the Coliseum.
Must see!. Stunning, mesmerizing...good gift shop and be sure to cross the road and take in the Holy Stairs. Note: most churches close between 12:30 and 3pm so make sure to plan.
Grand Scale like St Peter's. This was the big deal church before St Peter's so everything is done no a grand scale. Geometric designs and plenty of gold. Spend some time to sit and admire the art.

For non-believers too - if you can spare the time. - The basilica was beautiful from the outside, but really magnificent inside. The gigantic bronze doors btw were "stolen" from a temple on the Roman Forum.- Would this be a must while visiting Rome? I suggest that depends on your time budget. My mate and I are not religious, but still enjoyed the experience much. But then again, we stayed in the Manzoni area, so it was only a short walk. There isn't much else really close-by you would want to visit.- free of charge- take metro San Giovanni on Line A

Beautiful. The church of St johns was included in the places included in our Omnia Pass. We took metro line A to San Giovanni and a short walk through the old city walls and it was in front of you. This used to be the papal palace and inside the sheer beauty stops you in your tracks. With our Omnia Pass we got free audio visual guide which explained so much to us and made the visit even better. This is probably one of the most beautiful churches in Rome This is a must for your visit to Rome

The seat of the pope is a must see in the heart of Rome.. The learned that the Archbasilica ranks first among all the great Basilicas in the Catholic Church, and it is filled with rich art and history as well. The faithful can attend Daily Mass and it is within walking distance of restaurants, bus lines and other sites.

peace and beauty. This was easy to find, catching the metro to San Giovanni on Line A and then walking under the old city walls. Inside, the buzz of life outside was lost and the magnificence of the building worked on all senses. It really is worth a visit. Walk around each place and take a seat to enjoy from different angles.

Amazing. This church is most beautiful in whole Rome. History of it is just amazing . Don't miss it if you ever visit this great city. Tombs of six Popes are very interesting and striking. From outside church looks stunning. Statues are huge and you just wonder how it's done so long time ago. There is no fee charged to enter and it's well worth it.

Second Basilica in Rome. San Giovanni in Laterno is a must see place in Rome. It is the second important basilica that can be visited in Rome after the Saint Peter's Basilica in Vatican City. It has gorgeous sculptures and paintings. The ceiling of the Basilica is another story that everyone should see. If you ever go Rome you should write Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterno to the top of your list.

Church. Definitely worth a visit. After the Basilca Di San Pietro ( the Vatican)which is over powering,
the Basilica is most probably the mos beautiful of them all.

A very, very beautiful basilica. Known as the “Pope’s Church”, it is the oldest and ranks the highest among the Papal Basilicas and is the Cathedral of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope). It is called “The Mother Church” and with good reason, since it is the first western church.
For more info on San Giovanni and other highlights in Rome visit: http://theplanningmonster.gq/Theplanningmonster/English/Entries/2015/3/14_Roma_de_weekend.html

A beautiful place that is sometimes missed on the tourist trail. This church is very striking from the outside and truly beautiful inside. The history of the church is very interesting and the audio guide, which costs only one euro, is definitely worth listening to.There is no cost to enter the church and there is plenty to see.

Amazing place to visit!. It is the oldest and ranks first among the four Papal Basilicas or major basilicas of Rome (having the cathedral of the Bishop of Rome), and the oldest church in the West. It claims the title of ecumenical mother church among Roman Catholics. The current archpriest is Agostino Vallini, Cardinal Vicar General for the Diocese of Rome. The President of the French Republic, currently Francois Holland, is ex officio the "first and only honorary canon" of the basilica, a title held by the heads of the French state since King Henry IV of France.Just check out more at triphobo.com/rome-italyThe large inscription on the façade reads, Clemens XII Pont Max Anno V Christo Salvatori In Hon SS Ioan Bapt et Evang, a highly abbreviated Latin inscription meaning "Pope Clement XII, in the fifth year of his reign, dedicated this building to Christ the Savior, in honour of Saints John the Baptist and John the Evangelist"; this is because the basilica (as shown by its full name, which is given below) was originally dedicated to Christ the Savior, with the co-dedications to the two Saints named John only coming centuries later. As the cathedral of the Bishop of Rome, it ranks above all other churches in the Catholic Church, including St. Peter's Basilica. For that reason, unlike all other Roman Basilicas, it holds the title of Archbasilica.

This building has kept Sculptures in business for centuries. Just look at the marbles.. This is an Archbasilica not your run of the mill bascilica - say - like Saint Peters. It contains the tombs of 6 Popes and has a magnificent, tasteful blue, gold - with touches of red, ceiling. The sanctuary is in the Orthodox Style - with much gilding.There are the over life sized statues, a dozen inside and 13 on the Facade. The facade was built in 1735 and is a true facade in that it does not fully extend into the church itself. Move around to the side of it and you will see what I mean.The first time I saw the front I just could not believe the size of the figures up top. They are huge. I am still trying to find out their actual size. However, if you imagine the building without the figures; I think you will find that it would make a very fine frontage for a Bank.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

The most beautiful basilica and church in rome. Even if churches and buildings are not your cup of tea, you don't want to miss that place. It is so rich with beauty and colors, so many special rooms, paintings and sculptures you can feel the Holiness even if you are no Religious.

Well worth the effort!. A little hard to get to but there is a bus stop a short walk. This is one of the 4 major basilicas in Rome, the others being St. Peter's, St. Mary Major, St. Paul outside the walls. Very different inside. This is the pope's "own" basilica and he is not pope until he formally takes possession of it.

Put this Basilica on your list. I love this Basilica and the Holy Stairs across the road. I visit each time I come to Roma. It's a bit out of the way but there is a metro close by. The Basilica is ornate and fabulous inside its impressive if austere exterior. I was there during a service and I reckon there were at least 20 clergy in attendance. Then there are the stairs which you must climb in silence on your knees. It's excruciating because the pace is slow as the penitent pray on each step. My knees have yet to forgive me. Especially as the elderly italian lady next to me couldn't manage on her own and asked for my assistance. She leant on me (& my poor knees took it with a whimper) then kissed my hand profusely for the assistance. What an experience!

Arcibasilica visit. The most amazing basilica I ever saw. Impressive and quite easy to visit besides being free. you can get by either walking or several means of transportation from downtown or the coliseum. Quite worth the visit and expect to stay at least half an hour at the site due to its size and all the details to see. A must see when in Rome.

Mouth dropping beautiful and free . This church was close to where we stayed in Rome. The first time we went we went in an unassuming side door. Once inside it is opulent, and awe inspiring. After reading that the original bronze door from the Senate is at the front of the church, we went back to see the front. Wow! Just the facade of this church is something to behold!

Complex Basilica - One of the most beautiful. Mark it in your Schedule!. This basilica is a very complex site. But it is one of the most beautiful in Italy. The facade is beautifully simple and elegant and not over stylized. It has an imposing beauty to it.It is actually built on land once owned by a family in ancient Rome - who had their villa in this location. The surrounding area still has that peaceful and secluded feel to it.There are a couple of astonishing finds inside this complex. One being the magnificent bronze doors which were taken from the original ancient forum and placed here. They are a beautiful copper green and very impressive.One of the things I was really looking forward to - is an altar within the basilica which has a bronze pediment and bronze corinthian columns. You can't miss them. They are huge. These were actually taken from the Temple of Jupiter (the most important temple of ancient rome). And where the Spanish steps lead you to - is where this enormous temple and others once stood. Visible for miles around.Believe it or not - this Bronze Altar is from the Temple of Jupiter. Even more amazing - is that the bronze was melted down after the naval battle with Anthony & Cleopatra - from the rendered down rudders of the Egyptian Navy who were defeated. And this luxurious work of ancient art was placed inside the Temple of Jupiter.In the Rennaissance - the temple of Jupiter was still in excellent condition but once again - as is so often the case. It was demolished and all the materials used in constructing the buildings that are now on that acropolis. Some designed by Michelangelo. We can but imagine what the temple complex would have looked like in its and ancient form. But there is a marble relief you can find online - showing what the temple of Jupiter looked like in its magnificence.The bronze pediment and columns from the internal altar to Jupiter where taken from the Temple and placed in the new Basilica. An act of vandalism by the over-decorators of the middle ages. This kind of theft is known as: Spolia. Where ancient art and materials are placed in newer buildings. Hoping to emulate some of the grandeur of ancient rome and usually failing.I really enjoyed the visit to this beautiful building. For a small donation - there is an entrance to an external area of gardens with a collonade on four sides. Be sure to take your seat at the bronze altar and admire it for its complexity and skill.It is free to enter this basilica. I also really enjoyed the beauty of the enormous marble columns in the portico of the basilica. They are so beautifully carved and ice cold to touch. A real achievement on a grand scale. So we have to give the later architects some credit. This building is much more beautiful than St.Peter's in my opinion. Enjoy.

Definately worth a Visit. This Basilica is well worth the time spent. The Basilicas tend to go on and on after a while but if you are trying to narrow down a group of them be sure to incllude this one. Really lovely..... and the Holy Stairs are right accross the road as well :) note. If you want to go up the Holy Stairs don't go over during riposa as they close :(
beautifull. it is a beautiful basilica well worth a look inside and out inside is beautiful as are all the churches in Rome you should look inside ever one they are all so lovely painted
Don't miss this.. If Saint Peter's Basilica is on your list to see then you must see this as well. Photographs do not do justice to the interior of this holy place.

overdecorated but atmospheric.... Loved the early mosaics glittering in the half dark around the floodlit Papal Throne. Contrary to populr belief St. John Lateran is actually the Cathedral of Rome, pre-dating St Peters and the seat of the Pipe's authority as Bishop of Rome.

Almost Missed This Gem. On the last day, we were looking for somewhere to pass time while waiting for the trip to the airport. we had a walk around this area, and completely stumbled across this gem of a Basilica.The front of the building is impressive, and is nothing compared to the internal designs. Absolutely stunning, you cannot miss it.
Amazing. Like almost all Basilica in Rome, Arcibasilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is very interesting with lots of history and especially beautiful! Take your time, look around and be amazed!

Stunning Basilica. Set aside a few hours to visit the original Papal church of Rome. It is quite fascinating (rent the audio for a donation) as well as being beautiful. It is just a short walk past the Colosseum to the square which houses this magnificent building. We also bought a ticket to enter the Cloister which was well worth the very small fee (they will give you the audio tour for free if you purchase this for 5 Euro). The artwork and sculpture is breathtaking & so is the history of the Basilica. There is a small gift shop which sells a large selection of items which are much less 'kitch' than those souvenirs you buy elsewhere. There are also restrooms for those spending time here. We would visit again for the sheer magnificence.

true beauty. amazing, graceful ... every moment I felt that God really was present and gave his blessing to build this wonderful Christian temple ... a large and serene. One of the most beautiful basilicas which I visited

The unexpected highlight of our trip !. Absolutely amazing ! Totally unforgettable, Don't miss this for anything. And pay the extra euro for the cloister and other areas. Well worth it. It's an easy walk with lots to take in on the way. Don't miss the Pope's church ! No lines, and the most beautiful sites. Highly under rated now, go while you can

The original Papal church.. We had chosen a walk from a guide book which led down from Sannta Maria Maggiore to this Basilica. This is a huge building and quite different to Santa Maria Maggiore. There is a long chapel with the Papal Throne in it. The layout seemed quite unusual but very interesting. We parted with 10€ to visit the Cloisters but were not overwhelmed.

Vatican do not miss. Long lines to entre but is the prive to know one of the most importants museums in old world. Take a look specially in the Atenas school. And study previously about this painting and is relación whit the philosopy.

Superb. One of the 4 main basilicas in Rome, this is the official Church of the Bishop of Rome (Pope). Originally built by the Emperor Constantine has being rebuilt many a times, is an impressive structure with a very beautiful interior. The main landmark here is the Gothic structure at the altar which contains relics of St. Peter and Paul. Also a a piece of a wooden table used by St. Peter to celebrate Holy mass in the catacombs is preserved in the altar.Also for the catholic visitors be sure to visit the "Scala Santa" or in English "Holy Stairs" which is in a church just outside this basilica. These steps were brought by Queen Helena, mother of Emperor Constantine from Jerusalem, are a believed to be steps on which Jesus walked during his passion and some of Jesus's blood marks also to be faintly seen which are enclosed in glass.
Superb!!!. the church is simply fascinating! Pity that it is always surrounded by annoying foreigners who keep forcing you to buy their stuff

Speachless. really worth the visit, for me one of the top 5 churches in rome.when you are by the statues, if you are 2 try this is funny:one goes to one side and the other to the other (with the statues in between) try to talk to the wall and see if the other gets your voice on the other side. amazing hein!?!?! :)

A must visit after Saint Peter in the Vatican. A Holy and historical place. it is a must after the Basilica of Saint Peter in the Vatican, Impressive with very interesting architecture, marble statues and and old paintings.we came walking and went back with the Bus 85 that goes to Termini.
Worth seeing. Worth seeing if you're nearby or if you have many days to spend in Rome. It has beautiful architecture with impressive historical value.
Breathtaking. Peaceful, spacious, full of history obviously. Make sure you check the Cloister when you are there. Walking distance from Colosseum. A must to see!

San Gionvanni in Laterano. Great place to visit and next door to the Omnia Card collection point, which is on the right hand side as you look at the front of the church. Just note that the Omnia card office is not always open. Definitely get an audio guide as it really explains everything you need to know about this place. If you have an Omnia card the audio guide is free. Good place to start your sightseeing as it is linked to lots of other places to visit. Two hours is probably enough time to have a good look round.
vetican. its amazing and definitely worth a visit. entry is highly disorganized and there are tour agents outside who arrange a quick tour of the place of course for a fee.
A must visit. Definitely visit this church with its historic importance. We took a taxi there and had the taxi wait for us.

San Giovanni in Laterano. Few people knows that this is the church of Rime. Everybody think to Saint Peter, but this is Vatican while Saint John is the seat of the Pope ad bishop of Rime. Do not lode the possibilità to visit this basilica that is a concentrate of art. Coming out enjoy the square with the obelisk: a variety of styles amalgamated in a wonderful vision.

Must See in Rome. This is the "cathedra" or seat for the Bishop of Rome, The Pope. This is a very important Catholic site which is located outside of Vatican walls. It houses the impressive relics which are the skulls of Peter & Paul. There is much to see here including huge statues of the Apostles and chapels. Just exquisite. Across from the basilica is the Santa Scala, or Sacred Steps. These marble stairs were brought to Rome around 350 A.D. by Constantine's mother from the Palace of Pontius Pilate. It is said these are the stairs Jesus walked on when he was being questioned by Pilate. They are covered with wood to preserve them but pilgrims ascend them on their knees. It's quite a remarkable sight. I highly recommend a visit here. It's one of the 4 major basilicas in Rome and one of the most important .

Beautiful! Agree with other poster, Outranks Vatican. Beautiful architecture and murals. We visited on a gorgeous, sunny, blue sky day in October and the exterior is formidable against the backdrop, and equally awing inside. There was a mass when I attended so could not walk about the entire interior, but the service was roped off to encompass the middle section. Thus, we were able to respectfully view other ares of the church during the mass. I loved the Vatican, but this is a different flavor and visiting in October there were far, far fewer tourists then on my previous visit during June. It is well worth the time, I would loved to have another hour to view and snap photos -- a small image sampling included with my review.
Rated #1 & it isn't a surprise why!. Breathtaking! So much to look at and take in. A MUST visit if in Rome. & while you're here visit the Scala Sancta across the road.
Heavenly. Outranking the Vatican in ecclesiastical hierarchy, this was my first stop after I got settled in my hotel. Amazing architecture.

The Apostles' Church. For me, this Church has the most bombastic display of 12 apostles within its walls for the first time visitor of Rome and well worth the visit. It is a must visit Church for newbies, especially Catholics, in Rome. From the outside, it has an expansive lawn which provides a wonderful foreground to the statues of holy men (didnt notice if there were women) on the pediment of the Basilica's impressve facade. By the way, across that lawn, is a touching monument to St Francis and his first group of followers, commemorating the holy man's visit to the Pope at the time, who is said to have recognized divine inspiration in the beggar so much so that he kissed the saints feet, to the horror of the Church elite around him. Don't miss that monument.Anyway, going to the interior of the Church, one can/should go slowly from the statue of one apostle to the next, both for its artistic value and for Christians, its religious intent and history -- each apostly very beautifully done in stone, but also with some symbol (e.g. Peter and keys, etc.) preserved through 2000 years.

Less crowded and a must see. This cathedral was by my hotel and I was pleasantly surprised at its beauty and history.
