You don't need to wait an hour to go through a metal detector and X-ray your items as at The Vatican Basillica. The atmosphere was lovely and the fold up chairs was a non issue compared to the history, architect and awesomeness of the Basillica .

Beautiful work all around. Rome is not devoid of churches but this one just blew our mind away. There is so much artwork around the place whether it’s the paintings or the interesting statues or the ornate ceilings or wall works. It’s nothing less of a museum in itself. Well being inside the church these all are actually pages from the bible so it is pretty inspiring and informative. Also this is the main and official cathedral of Rome.

Basilica. One of the four major basilicas in Rome. You could walk to it from the Hotel Napoleon. Basilica of St Mary Major is also close by but in the opposite direction. The Lateran was the original residence of the Popes. An internatiional seminary is adjacent. The Scala Sancta, Holy Steps, is just across the piazza from the front of the Lateran Basilica. Well worth a visit.

Impressive church. The cathedral of Rome.there are many things to see.visiting the church is free,but for the stairs nearby there is a fee.
The plastic grey chairs in such an impressive church are terrible.

Wow, wow and super wow. Free, Now crowds, no queues, quiet inside, amazing ceilings and so much history and connection with past Popes and the Vatican5 mins from the Metro Line A. Right by part of the Roman Wall - - - even a Coin Store for some retail therapy for those "Churched out" (Do not miss this one). If I was in this corner of Rome and had a Metro Ticket would also visit Santa Maria Maggiore getting off at Vittorio Emanuel or Termini but of preference leave this one to last or the only one of the two.
is GREAT !!!!!. nothing to tell more. If you did not see it you make a very big mistake. The statues of the Apostoles are manificent. The statue o St. john the Bbaptist is great...

As impressive as St peter's. Another fantastic church. And it's the mother church of catholicism as it's the popes church. Some great pieces of sculpture and an epic ceiling. Easily accessible from San Giovanni station on the blue line.
Great find!. After a visit to the Colosseum we wandered round the neighbourhood and came across this beautiful church. Simply stunning, without the crazy queues you see at the Vatican!

Fantastic super Huge - must see it. the Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano it's a must. you have to see it if you go in Rome. It's super huge and when you get inside you see an incredible cathedral.

Fabulous church. We visited this attraction in October 2013. We had to walk uphill from the Colosseum on via San Giovanni in Laterano to reach the church of the same name at the top of the hill. This is the cathedral of Rome and was founded in early 4th century by Emperor Constantine. It was rebuilt several times, notably in 1646 when Borromini restyled the interior. Note the Scala Sancta (Holy Staircase) which Christ is said to have climbed at his trial. Unfortunately no photos can be taken but we purchased a book on the basilica to get photos as a reminder. Not sure if postcards were available. Certainly worth the visit. Just downhill on the same street heading back towards the Colosseum is another church worth taking time to visit - San Clemente - refer to my review on this church.

Beautiful basilica. Impressive basilica. With the omnia card you get an audio guide witch is very interesting. Beautiful statues. Impressive nave. Huge alther. We can only recommend to visit this site.

Refreshingly beautiful. The more restrained, compact, but no less elegant San Giovanni (St John's) is a refreshing change of pace and style from St. Peter's. In retrospect it makes sense that this is the Pope's actual "mother church": The basilica feels welcoming and accessible rather than imposing and majestic. Highly recommended.

One of my favorite!. After seeing the many basilicas with a lot of colors, this basilica is a refreshing change! The facade of the basilica is simple and elegant. We particularly like the statues of all the apostles. When the sun sets in the area, the facade is a great place for some photo taking.

It's massive. This church is almost as impressive as St Peters. Well worth the visit and only 10 mins walk from the Colleseum. Extremely quiet and peaceful. If you can't be bothered with the massive queues at the Vatican City, just come here and relax
The original papal seat. Breathtakingly beautiful. Fascinating Papal museum next door for which there is a charge. The tours are by guide only.
magnificient. Really huge and beautiful, makes a big impression. Lots of fantastic work of arts, paintings, sculptures etc.
impressing. This is one of the most beautiful things I have ever seen! It is a real must see when you are here!!
magnificent!!. i was ammazed to be found inside such a church!!!amazing,every corner,everything inside was magnificent!!everyone should visit!!!
mother and head of the church. centre of catholic faith, near bus stop and metro line. a few metees from the Scala sancta. A must for every catholi to vist. good bus link to St mary major

what a great cathedral. loved the statues of the apostles
it is worth the trip outside the walls of Rome
incredible to see the place where the first Popes walked

beautiful and important Basilica - Pope Francis' home church!. There is so much to see in this Basilica including a lovely statue that the Pope gave to his congregation for Christmas 2014. The Sacred Stairs were interesting and I really appreciated going into the Sanctum Sanctorum - Holy of Holies. A very special place, especially for Catholics like myself.

Impressive Basilica. I'd read the reviews of the San Giovanni in Laterano and it certainly didn't disappoint. The stature and magnificence of the interior is really impressive. My wife also rated this above all the other cathedrals that we saw in Italy although there were quite a few other impressive ones.

Beautiful Art. We visited many churches in Rome and were awed by the magnificent art - paintings, mosaics, statues. It is like visiting religious art museums; the artwork tells stories from the Old and New Testaments. Our visit was just after Christmas and we saw many lovely nativities. I think my favorite may have been the one in the Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano. San Giovanni is the official cathedral of Rome, originally founded by the Emperor Constantine in the early fourth century. We were able to reach this Basilica easily from the Metro Line A at the San Giovanni stop.
Exceptional Art. Incredible art adorns every part of this church and it is easier to get to than many of the other wonderful churches within the old walls of Rome.

Amazing. Ceiling, walls, glass and so on....everything is just amazing!
It is so big! Everything is so beautiful that you just keep saying WOOOW and I'm not kidding. You need to see it, it's gorgeous!
Remarkable. This majestuous church is worth entering into just because of the ceiling, which is not that far from the beauty of the Sistine Chapel

Quiet and calm in a busy city. The Cathedral Church of the Diocese of Rome and well worth a visit for its quiet and calm compared to the queues and hustle & bustle of St Peters. The over-life size statues of the Apostles are stunning. Terrific architecture and space for quiet and contemplation. Just a few minutes walk from the San Giovanni metro station on lineA and completely free to enter.

Stunning.. Just wow. A fantastic experience. Beautiful artwork, you could spend all day just wandering about taking it all in.

What can you say? One of the most spectacular places on earth. Yes, old, crowded, and in need of repair, but it is the world's greatest religious building and representative of some many great things...the Reconnaissance, art, architecture, religion, people coming together.

beautiful church. you cannot come to Rome and experience its beautiful churches and this is one of its finest offerings with being beautiful from inside and outside and much quieter too. The artworks and the whole layout is impressive. The Altar is picture perfect and elegance. It is truly a worth visiting place
Not to be missed. The sculptures of the 12 apostles are unique - do not miss this Basilica! And this Basilica is so much quieter than San Pietro.
Amazing. I didn't believe churches/cathedral could blow my mind anymore after seeing tons but this one sure did! Simply amazing!
verry nice Basilique. i like the Church Altar.. is Verry Beautiful.. idon't like the souvenir Magazine into the Church.. ana the museum is verryyyyyyyy nice...
FANTASTIC. In a place with churchs everywere this is so special a fantastic peacefull place to visit and to pray

Absolutely STUNNING Church.. San Giovanni was the first stop that my wife and I made in Rome, and talk about starting on a high note, it was spectacular. The pictures here on TA are beautiful, but they don't do it justice one bit. You HAVE to go. I know, I know, a lot of places on here are going to be called 'can't miss,' and for the most part you're going to miss something in Rome if your time there is limited. Do not let this church be on your 'miss' list. Regardless of your religious beliefs or affiliation (or even lack thereof), make sure to stop here for the beautiful artwork and history surrounding this most holy place.
Beautiful artwork. What can i say like all the numerous churches etc in the area the effort, history and architecture is just beautiful. Such a shame we don't take as much pride in our own history.
A special spot. This is a worth while trip.Away from the all the ques and busy tourist groups , this special sight is a must see.We were blown away by the interior of this special place.A must see
Well worth a visit. Absolutely stunning basilica and, amazingly, not nearly as crowded as St. Peters when we visited. A "must see" not only for the beauty but also for the history.
The pope's church. This is astounding and should not be missed! The artistry inside is magnificent! The light inside shows off the statuary and vaulting. Mosaics are amazing.

Worth seeing . San Giovanni is an amazing church and I think it's worth seeing once but there are other churches that I would want to revisit every time I come to Rome. If you're here make sure to go across the street to see the Scala Santa.

Lovely church. This is the place the popes were crowned until the 1800s - so it has a long history. It is lovely. Right near here is the Holy Stairs - the stairs Christ climbed to Pontius Pilate. There is also a nice chapel as part of this church right next to it - go in and see the baptismal font. It is lovely too. Another stop on the "Pilgrim's tour of Rome."
Awesome inside out. Just outside the main travelers' routes, but definitely worth visiting! The interior is as grandeur as St Peter

Great Christian monument. Better than St. Peter's because it is less crowded and closer to human sizes. I don't get excited with churches but this is a monument of Christian art and culture. Definitely a must visit place in Rome.

Old, big and splendid. One of the oldest and the most important churches in Rome - and in the whole Christian world. The cathedral of Rome, part of the Vatican state. Impressive by its dimensions, splendid because of the decoration. You will admire the stunning baldachin over the main altar - this fantastic piece of art comes from the Middle Ages and is a unique example of the composition of the architecture, sculpture and painting. Beside this you will find colorful frescos, mosaics and huge sculpures of the Apostles. The facade is very , very white and looks fantastic on the fond of a blue sky.Remember to go also to the Baptistery, that was originally a part of the church.I
fabulous. just a must to view , take the guided tour bus it was 40 euros for two people all day and the guide told you of the history via er phones on the tour
Huge and...amazing. We all loved it, the magnificent of the basilica was amazing for all of us. and the square...what a wonderfull place
Beautiful gilded basilica. The Arcibasilica is very beautiful and worth a visit. The gold on the ceiling and altar area is gorgeous. I also enjoyed the numerous angels that were throughout.

Stunning. This is located near the old Roman wall so you can see this also. We walked to this location from the back end and saw a huge obelisk which is 'Lateran Obelisk' we walked around and found the facade of the 'San Giovanni in Laterano' this is impressive. There are massive doors and the interior is just beautiful. We did not get to see inside the Vatican museum or Sistine Chapel so this was a nice compensation.
Grandeous! A must see!. It is so massive and grandeous to behold! incredible interior. From sculptures to mosaics. One should find time to visit while in Rome. Just look around...

Rome's Cathedral. If you search St. Peter's for a papal throne, you will not find one -- aside, perhaps, from Bernini's apse sculpture of the Fisherman's Chair. That's because the massive papal basilica is not a cathedral; that is to say, not the seat of a bishop. St. John Lateran is Rome's cathedral church, and as such, houses the only true papal throne in Rome. Although extensively outfitted in the baroque, the church's bones are Roman medieval and predate the current iteration of St. Peter's by centuries. Until the 15th century, St. John Lateran and its nearby palace served as the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church and the home of the papacy. The cathedral features several monumental statues of the 12 apostles, each electric with movement; a gorgeous, Byzantine-style apse mosaic; a medieval baldacchino over the main altar, and one of the most vivid, carved polychrome ceilings in any large building anywhere. Don't miss the nearby, octagonal baptistry and the Scala Sancta -- or holy stairs -- celebrated by generations of Catholic pilgrims and reviled by Martin Luther himself. Art and history lovers should not miss St. John Lateran.
one of the majors. One of the major churches in Rome. Absolutely beautiful. The baptistry is worth walking next door. Also the Holy Stairs are across the street
Awe-inspiring. Pictures simply don't capture the expansiveness of this place. Do not miss this church on your visit to Rome!

A must if you're touring Basilicas. This location doesn't draw the crowds that St. Peter's or the Vatican does, but it is still an impressive basilica, loaded with history. The steps that Jesus walked up are nearby.
Worth a Visit. Most spectacular church in Rome, worth a visit. Photographers do. not go in the morning, Sun light not in favour of nice pictures of the Fresko in courtyard....

Ornate and beautiful. This is one of the most important churches in Rome after St. Peters and has a lot of history attached to it making it a must visit while in Rome. The interiors are a fine masterpiece and truly inspiring. There is so much artworks around that are a treat for eyes. The church is bathed in gilded beauty all throughout. One of the main attractions at the place is the steps that were climbed by Jesus Christ when he was brought in front of Pilates Pontius. Compared to St. Peter’s this is less crowded
San Giovanni di Laterano. beautiful building. visit this place.this place is easily reached by public tranportation. must see in rome if you like their fabulous buildings.
Must see. It is third cathedral after San Peter in Rome. Just go and see. Unforgettable . Does not mater what religion you aret
Amaizing. San Giovanni is the official church of Rome. Don't miss St. Peter's - or the other 2 papal basciallicas - Santa Maria Maggiore and St. Paul Outside the Walls
Beautiful. Beautiful almost as the St. Peters Basilica. Next to it is the largest standing ancient Egyptian obelisk in the world
Amazing. It is an amazing Basilica. Here you can see the steps from the house of Pilat Pontius, the stairs climbed by Jessus Christ.
Another beautiful basilica. This is a beautiful church. It is worth a long visit to see the church and the artwork. The audioguide is free but it seems to jump all over.
Beautiful, Must-see. The beauty in this space is immense. I could sit and look at the ceiling for hours. We went during a Sunday service and didn't feel like we were interrupting.
Amazing church built on an ancient Roman Basilica. A little less popular then the Vatican but what an incredible interior and a church that is still part of the Vatican. Beautiful Church.
Stunning Basilica. Don't miss this magnificent church, which serves as the pope's church. Stunning art and fascinating history! Be sure to see the sacred steps across the street.
The most beautiful church in the world. Need I say more - more intimate and interesting than the Vatican. And not crowded. A very beautiful and spiritual place

One of the more interesting churches. One of the cornerstone churches in all of Christendom, and not to be missed for those looking to get the full experience of the history of the church, especially if you are Catholic. However, if you have already seen St. Peter's and Santa Maria Maggiore (or any of the other dozens of ancient churches in the city) and are feeling "you seen one, you seen them all", then there might not be much more here for you to see. Amazing art and statuary, especially the apostles in the nave. For us, it was unbelievable!

Divine History. Worth spending a few hours in this massive church which was the spot of the first church in christiandom. From the bas relief walls to the solid gold ceilings to the giant statues, this is an impressive testament to Man's faith- or at least what some have perceived is a tribute to show the world they have faith. Kings were crowned there.
Beautiful, historic. One of the many churches in Rome that is worth a visit. Magnificent in size and structure. Beautiful artworks and filled with history.
Beautiful!. The location, the Basilica itself, it's history and the art work was well worth travelling south. It was steeped with paintings and sculptures, you must take your time taking it all in.
wow. It is an amazing huge structure, so luxurious and detailed, if you are into architecture you'll be amazed...!

Amazing place. Huge basilica full of wonder! Beuatiful statues, mosaics, paintings, artwork, floors and ceilings. Difficlut to take everything in in one visit as there are so many outstanding things to see. Holy stairs outside. This is also where the Pope sits as Bishop of Rome
Interesting.. One of the 4 major basilicas of the catholic Church. Interesting. Make sure you cross the street to view the Holy Stairs (it's inside the building NOT the one exposed outside)

Amazed. We stumbled across this Basilica and entered through a side door, crikey did we get a shock, this church is huge and very beautiful.
One of the top 5 churches in Rome!
Amazing place. It's so breathtaking there!!! You should see it with your own eyes to feel its marble-and-gold beauty and calmness.

splendor. This basilica is the 2nd largest in Rome after St. Peter's. It is well worth a visit to see the marble and gold and paintings in the interior, and learn the history of the building within the Roman Catholic hierarchy.
Don't miss it!. San Giovanni is the official church of Rome. Don't miss St. Peter's - or the other 2 papal basciallicas - Santa Maria Maggiore and St. Paul Outside the Walls.
Stunning!!. The church looks absolutely stunning at my first sight. It is very beautiful. There was also a band playing music when I visited, which improves the atmosphere.

Magnificient. This church is the Pope's Official church as the Bishop of Rome. I recommend reading the history of this church before touring as it enhances the experience. The sculptures of the apostles are grandiose. Easy walk from the metro station.

More beautiful than St. Peter's (and also the true seat of the Church). St. John Lateran is technically part of Vatican City (not Rome) and is also the true seat of the Catholic Church - it's the Archbasilica and the church above all other churches, and the Pope's home church. The seat in the apse is where the Pope must sit after he is elected.When we walked in, my breath was taken away. St. Peter's is excellent, but it is a little dark and grey. This church is awash in light and color. The statues of the apostles are amazing, and I loved the paring of the Old and New Testament scene paintings. The red, blue and gold ceilings are gorgeous.There's a beautiful baldaccino over the altar, and a side chapel (with what is said to be a piece from the table of the Last Supper) flanked by the pillars from the old Temple of Saturn. In the entryway is a statue of Constantine, and the old doors to the Roman Curia.And then there's the apse! This is a beautiful mosaic and was one of the first legal images of Christianity in Rome (not sure how much of the mosaic is the original). The basilica was built when Constantine legalized Christianity and so is the first legal church. It's been through a lot - fires, earthquakes, being looted in the fall of the Empire - but is still here, and even more beautiful, and a metaphor for the Church itself in some ways.Next door are the Holy Stairs, also worth a visit for a pilgrim.

Wonderful time. All I must say after visiting this place is just WOW !! It's like many churches into one. It is a very big Basilica and it will take time to explore it all, but is worth it.. must visit

Incredible. The basicilas of Rome (other then St. Peter's ) are too often overlooked.. San Giovanni looks somewhat humble from its exterior in a large piazza. Inside, it's breath-taking. To get there, we walked around the Colosseum and headed down Via di San Giovanni in Laterano. It's a lovely little street, with lots of cafes and stops for lunch.
Amazing. Stunning architecture. I was with a group and we walked into a music recital. Unforgettable to see and hear.

Beautiful church worth seeing. The Holy Seat is here (where the Pope gets the name Holy See). So many churches and you will get churched out easily in Italy but I recommend this one because it is one of the 3 Papal Basilicas in Rome and is important. Also the artwork is lovely.

Breathtakingly Beautiful. This basillica is both huge and beautiful. You should plan a few hours here to enjoy it all. The statues, paintings, altars and more are just amazing to see. We were with a group and had a great tour guide which I would highly recommend. There is so much to learn and hear about.Enjoy this beautiful, holy place when you visit Rome.

Magnificent. Solemn, mejestic Arcibasilica. I wanted to pray, I felt spiritually uplifted, peaceful. It is worth to visit once in a lifetime. This is sacred place, I would not call it attraction. I do not think, is it place to take pictures.
Beautiful. This is one of Rome's most beautiful. The history, the architecture, the art, the many special chapels within make this a must see.

Very beautiful!. It is a very beautiful church and besides, is extremely important from the historical point if view - as our guide explained to us, the first oficial christian church was built on this very spot in the 4th century. in front of the church there is a nice street market.
Stunning. As beautiful as St. Peters. We did it as part of the Christiano Romano ticket which we picked up from the office next door. It was well worth the 2 hours inside.
More than a church. All I have to say is WOW !! It's like many churches into one. It is a very big Basilica and it will take time to explore it all, but is worth it.
nice. wow, what an amazing basilica. you cannot miss it when in rome! the mosaics are stunning!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The "mother of all churches.". It actually ranks in importance above all other churches in the Catholic Church, including St. Peter's Basilica. For that reason, unlike all other Roman Basilicas, it holds the title of Archbasilica. It is absolutely humongous, and there is so much impressive art and architecture to see.

Nice - Omnia office info. This gets very very crowded and you may have a long wait to get in. We gave up.For those of you trying to find the place to pick up your OMNIA pass, Number 6 Piazza di Porti del San Giovanni is the large, arched wooden door to the right of the main portico of the church of San Giovanni, opposite the Basilica. we walked around the square for two hours before finding it, then discovering it was shut, and then going to Piazza Pio XII by taxi, where we were told the San Giovanni OMNIA office is closed on public holidays. We hope this helps someone in the same situation if it comes up on a search.

Stunning!. Many of the churches in Rome seem to blend together by the end of the trip, they are all really incredible, but this one really stood out to me. I felt almost a close connection to God while visiting this church. It is the seat of the Pope and is the highest ranking catholic church. The statues of the apostles are beautiful. Please take a seat and just admire the building while you are there, do not rush out of this one!

Impressive. We visited the Basilica by default. We were picking up our Rome Passes in the adjacent building and were recommended to it by the ticket office. At one stage the Basilica was the most important church in Christendom and it still remains the pope’s seat as the bishop of Rome. Whilst for me this was perhaps not as awe inspiring as St Peter’s Basilica (Rome) or St Mark’s (Venice) it is nevertheless quite magnificent and well worth taking the time to visit, especially if you are in the area. Also in close proximity are the Scala Santa (Holy Stairs) and one of, if not the, largest Egyptian obelisks in Rome so again make sure you take the time to have a look at these.

Impressive. Impressive sight and well worth the trip a bit outside the city. Not much around it though, we went straight back to the centre. (note: you have to put euro coins in machines to switch on the lights inside, so if you travel there make sure to have coins on you if you want to see anything inside !)

Part of Constantine's legacy. The Papal Archbasilica of St. John Lateran (Arcibasilica Papale di San Giovanni in Laterano) is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is the Pope. It is the oldest and ranks first among the four Papal (major) basilicas of Rome, and the oldest church in the West. This church was a gift from Emporer Constantine I to the Bishop of Rome. It is a massive, beautiful basilica that is full of fantastic art. This is a gem that most tourists don't see. It is worth a visit. Time for visit - 1+ hour

Beautiful Basilica. Beautiful Basilica with deep history of the Catholic faith. Don't miss seeing the baptistry alongside the church. There are 2 souveneer shops and both are well stocked with fairly priced items. Bring along a guidebook to help understand the history and significance.
Unmissable. You can find inside the Old Cloistrum, The basilic collect different part from different ages, starting from Roman onward.

Beautiful church. The basilica is beautiful and much less crowded than other famous Roman church attractions. Across the street you will find the Scale Santa, the stairs Jesus carried the cross up when he faced Pontius Pilot.

Not to be missed.. This is the first church of modern Christianity in Rome and is an artistic wonder. One of the doors into this church was confiscated from the Roman Senate and is impressive on it's own. But knowing that the relic heads of St.s Peter and Paul are in the center balustrade is inconcievable. The artwork is priceless and once again, you must look up at the beautiful ceiling.
Beautiful Church. We were in this church for over 2 hours and I must say it was one of the highlights of our 9 day Roman tour. Grandeur at its best!

Awe inspiring. Having seen the Sistine Chapel from time to time on TV, I got a totally different sense of what this place is all about. I was part of an escorted tour group visiting the museum and chapel. We all wore listeners, and a narrator who guided us through the museum and prepared us for the chapel. There is no talking inside the chapel. That said, I was unprepared for the fabulous, colorful painting of the entire inside of the chapel. I could have spent hours studying these glorious works of art. Either tour this site with a guide or read about the paintings before you tour. There are subtle, sometimes hidden aspects to many of the paintings that would easily be missed without learned knowledge.

Stunning and awe-inspiring. No wonder this is the Pope's home church.. St. John Lateran is, simply, awe-inspiring. Without any of the crowds of the Vatican, you'll have the time to be both curious and reverent. The grounds are vast, including a draw-dropping view of Rome front the front plaza down an ancient path. The main doors are from the Roman Senate . . . an unbelievable, humbling start. The church itself is architecturally designed for sunlight to stream thruough windows and highlight altars, statues and chapels . . . it's as if you're in a choreographed heavenly light show. Tip 1: Once here, you'll spend more time than you probably thought . . . allow for it. Tip 2: take one of the audio-guide tours. Just a little background will make understandable what could be overwhelming.
Impressive. Was the main Church in Rome once upon a time and you can easily see the efforts that this period brought forth. A fine Church to visit.
A MUST FOR CHRISTIANS TO SEE. unbelievable art/architecture/ history. . . this Basilica is in fantastic shape and a place of peace for prayer and reflection

A Little More out of the Way. During a recent trip to Rome, we have developed a list of churches to visit. Much of my research led me to recommendations of other travelers. Since this church is away from the center of Rome and many other sights, we rode the Metro out to the San Giovanni Metro station. Between the station and the church and adjacent to the old city walls is the Via Sannio market. We like these type markets, if only just to see if they have something that the others in Rome doesn't. It didn't but it was still a bit of fun to shop. My wife made some purchases. We then walked on to the church. Is is one of very few that has open space around it. At the time of our visit seating, speakers and barriers were being set up. The church is worth the visit with beautiful mosaics. Also a statue of Constantine on the porch, to the left of the entrance. The central entryway has huge bronze doors. Once you've completed your church visit, you can easily turn north, cross the street, and arrive at the Holy Stairs.

The Lateran Obelisk in Rome. #ThetallestobeliskinRome! It is in Piazza San Giovanni in Laterano. Carved in red granite, measuring 32.18 meters high (45.70 meters with the base) and weighs 230 tons. It originally stood in front of the Temple of Amun at Thebes (Karnak, in Egyptian). It was realized by the pharaoh Thutmose III in the fifteenth century BC Over 1,700 years later, in 357 AD, Emperor Constans II, son of Constantine the Great, wanted it as decoration for the Circus Maximus, the largest cirrcus destined for chariot races; he then built a special ship to transport the monument to Rome. Pope Sixtus V will dig it up from the ruins of the Circus Maximus more than twelve centuries later to restore it and place it in front of the old entrance to the basilica of St. John in Lateran in place of the equestrian statue of Marcus Aurelius, formerly believed to belong to Constantine, located now in Capitol Square . At the base, Domenico Fontana, architect of Sixtus V, in charge of the road accommodation in Rome, placed on three steps a fountain topped by a statue of the holy Evangelist.

The Vatican Before the Vatican. St. John of Lateran is probably my favorite church in Rome. Yeah, St. Peter's is THE seat of the Catholic church, and is amazing, but St. John (which was the seat of the church before St. Peter's) is amazing in its own right. The impressive, imposing statues over the front entrance are towering and foreboding. The cloisters outside the church is nice, peaceful, and seemingly an entirely different location. But the inside of the church, with the many statues of all the saints, is truly impressive and DEFINITELY worth a visit if you're in Rome!

Absolutely amazing!. This church is a feast for the senses. The artwork is amazing and it is a busy active living church full of nuns, friars and other pilgrims. The nearby Papal university appears to attract many people of the cloth.

AMAZING!. We stumbled across this amazing church after going up the Scala Santa across the street. I needed to use the restroom and they had one. Little did I know the amazing place I would be visiting. The italian woman cleaning the bathrooms gave us an earful. She was very VERY upset about the lack of cleanliness. I had never heard a woman cuss up a storm like that in a church. But this was an amazing place.
Awesome. The Basilica is such an inspirational and holy place. Knowing that basilica's were built so all people were welcome, makes this such a holy place for all.

Put item the list. This is a must see . When you have visited St peters. Next stop is St john of the laterano. This basilica is every bit as impressive as St peters with less of the opulence and the crowds! This is the bishop of romes church. The bishop of Rome is the pope.
Beautiful!. The architecture was beautiful! The sculptures were extraordinary. It is a huge basilica and awe-inspiring. Make certain it is one of the churches that is on your list to see in Roma!

Major basilica not to be missed. This basilica/cathedral is the actual "home" of the Bishop of Rome, who happens to be the Pope. A very beautiful edifice, with glorious stained glass, magnificent pipe organ, many pieces of art work and architectural craftsmanship. You can take pictures in most areas, but some areas were "off limits" to flash photography. Be sure to note the many members of the Catholic faith who are remembered or buried there; each is different and quite a number will catch your eye. Hard to imagine that churches of this size were built by hard work of many hands, with none of our modern technological advancements. Take a stroll through the basilica and take in the sights and sounds of a sacred place. Worth your time I'd say!

Rome's Cathedral -- a must see. Visit the cloisters (slight extra cost) for its beauty, museum room, and artifacts. After visiting crowded St. Peter's, a visit here is a pleasure. This was my third or fourth visit over the years.

Impressive . When in Rome, you're likely to see churches. Many of them. There's almost 1000 thousand but this one deserves attention! It's beautiful, of course, and the statues in the main nave are of particular interest for those who like sculptures. Also mind the bishop's chair, throne like. A place to see, certainly!
Magnificent. Stumbled across this on our return from the baths of Caracalla. Entered through side entrance which didn't look that impressive but were blown away by the interior. Well worth a look.

Mother Church. Most memorable are the huge life-like statues of the twelve apostles. Every statue shows such detail and beauty. Across from the Archbasillica are Scala Sancta or Holey Steps. These steps were once in Jerussalem and are the steps Jesus Christ walked up to Pilate. The marble steps are encased in wood. Many devout climbs these stairs on their knees.

big surprise for me!. I did not know that this is the most important church in the Vatican, I thought it was that of St. Peter, the great discovery that is worth visiting, EXTRAORDINARY and full of history.

A short walk from the colosseum but worth a visit. One of the Papal basillicas that is very impressive. The facade at the front is so different from the side facade that you need to look at both entrances to the church.The inside of the church is incredible with larger than life statues of the apostles, the papal Cathedra and the 14th century baldacchino.Don't bother with the garden museum which costs extra. For me the only thing that was interesting were several manuscripts of music written by Palestrina.
Must see place. this is a must see place for anyone who is touring or doing a pilgrimage in rome, since this is one of the earliest churches here.
Amazing Bascillica. This was certainly an amazing experience,we enjoyed it thoroughly.The craftsmanship was a visual experience not to be missed we actually preferred this Bascillica to St Paul's.
Huge and impressive. This is the main Catholic church, the church of the Pope as bishop of Rome. Portraits of all the popes, wonderful art

The mother of all churches. The church used to be the home of the Diocese of Rome before the Vatican and it is full of history, per example, some papal tombs.
As in the Vatican, you must go covered.

Stunning.... You need to see it to believe it....fantastic views of the church.Amazing the churches in Rome are so different to the UK. Not being someone that goes to Church that often, except for the usual funerals, weddings, christenings, it was a really pleasant surprise to see the architecture and paintings on the walls and ceilings.You really need to spend some time just walking into some of the beautiful churches and this one is exceptional.
Breathtaking !. Such Beauty on a huge scale.The statues, artwork and frescos are amazing. Do not miss this place!Truly fantastic

Definitely one of the 3 most beautiful churches on the world!!!. This church is just amazing full of details by herself. Is just one if those places to have a sit and admire their beauty. A place that you can't miss in Rome! - Abraham Rojas Chavez, the Mexican traveler.
Great Atmosphere. Mystic place even for my kids, they loved the candles and the big area. The church is easy to reach from the hotel and it is located in the city center.

Experiencing the Pope's Church is a divine encounter. During my visit a traditional Mass occurred with many priests and brothers about. The choir was heavenly with the organ pipes soaring. Though mass participates were of many origins the Universal Catholic church prevailed. Set in a magnificent edifice with gold guilding, statues, paintings, ceiling decor, and an altar from heaven it was difficult to participate and pay attention to the Mass. A must see for everyone to absorb the history and beauty of the Pope's church!
Very interesting church. Very nice and impressive church. Must see when visiting Rome as this one out of 4 papal basilics. Nice job done by Boromini inside the church

We had a great conversation with a nun...... ......who worked there and who came from Wigan. Lovely lady at a fantastic cathedral! I did not realise the importance of the place and the history that it represents.

Holy staircase in the neighboring building. Among the innumerable churches that can be visited in Rome , this is particularly exciting : in addition to all the elements of the richly decorated church itself , you can visit the holy staircase is in the neighboring building . This ladder would have been used by Jesus Christ when he was interrogated by Pontius Pilate . It was transposed into Rome in 326 A.D.

A real divine experience. Of all Basilicas in Rome, San Giovanni in Laterano is definitely the most impressive! First of all, it has amazing statues, a breathtaking ceiling and the most wonderful paitings. Confessions can be hold in so many languages: german, french, spanish, english, polish, czech and so on....At the time of my visit, a Liturgy was held in English by one of the priests and it was absolutely emotional to see that no matter what nationality you are, you can participate at the ceremonies and understand every word. This Basilica is, in my personal opinion, more beautiful than St. Pietro from Vatican, one in which you can admire it's beauties but still remember you are in a church.If you just lay down and take a breath, you can feel the peace that a church is suppose to make you feel!

A church that knows it's a step above the others. You just get the sense that this building is absolutely certain that it is the big brother of all the rest. I think it's the throne that does it. It's sometimes known as the Pope's Church but I'm sure the Pope would be the first to say that actually, it's Christ's Church. I'm not at all sure that Francis would approve of the throne being the focal point of the church and, to be honest, it doesn't thrill me either. But go, have a look, make up your own mind.By the way, get the underground out to ST Giovanni see the church and the Santa Scala and walk back to the city centre via the Basilica of San Clemente, the Colosseum etc.

Our Catholic Roots are here!. This was our second trip to Rome, and the Church of St. John Lateran was a must-see once again. It contains the beauty you will see in many of the Basilicas in Rome, but the history of this Church is what is so inspiring. And, it's "The Pope's Church".

Yes, the most important Catholic church in the world. This basilica is the seat of the Bishop of Rome (Pope) as such it is even more important than St. Peter's itself. Outside of the Vatican but still in Rome this church plays a major role in the history of the Catholic faith. It is the site of several of the Ecumenical councils.IN addition to the religious and historical significance the basilica itself is a beautiful and peaceful place to visit.

One of the Major Basilicas. This basilica is not easy to walk to, we too a cab. Large square surrounding it, much walking involved. If your schedule is tight, this one could be skipped and visit some of the others instead.

The first cathedral of Rome (Constantine's Basilica). This massive and important church (many important councils of the Catholic church took place here) has a beautiful baroque façade (Alessandro Gailei) and a nave that has a dazzling ceiling, with the coat of arms of many popes. Huge statues of the apostles (by Bernini followers) are spaced along the entire nave. Of special interest is the Corsini Chapel on the left side of the church's entrance.

Beautiful. The basilica of San Giovanni Laterano is gorgeous. A beautiful church without the crowds of St Peter's. Well worth the visit. We walked there from the Colosseum which was an easy walk if you've got your walking shoes on.

No Vatican crowds.. worth the distance. We love this church. It's beautiful and you can really enjoy being in church without the crowds in St Peters Basillica. It's in a different area so a taxi or other transportation is needed if you are staying in the Vatican area or in the main tourist areas of Rome. Enjoy you will be so glad you did!
Beauty, History, Peace. Come, drink it in. . . history, beauty, Faith, Truth, the rest is up to you, the saints, angels, God and His Mother
Wow. this was one of the most amazing things I've ever seen in my life and perhaps the most spectacular dont miss it!

Beautiful Church, Great History. We decided to take a walk to visit the Basilica of St. John Lateran, the Pope's church before St. Peter's. It was well worth it. We were able to get individual audio guides which were offered for a donation of our choosing. The audio guides provided a lot of great information and filled us in (2 fifty something year old life long Catholics) on a lot of the history of the Catholic Church. While in the neighborhood, stop and see the Holy Stair which are across the street. Whether you believe they are the real stairs that Jesus climbed or not, the site is very moving. If you get over to the east side of the city a stop here, St. Mary Maggiore and St. Prassede were highlights of our short stay in Rome.

Definitely worth making the effort to visit.. Not as famous as Saint Peters but definitlely worth a visit. Amazing inside with its frescoes and dome. There is a 5 euro entrance fee to the cloister which we thought a bit much really but there are two small museums to see as well.

Magnificent Church & beautiful cloisters. This amazing church and palace - the original Vatican & papal residence - was very close to where we were staying. Our hosts advised it as a must, and we were astonished at how much there was to see and how few people there were (relatively) looking at it. The interior (rebuilt over an older Basilica) is incredibly ornate and beautiful. The 17th Century ceiling is particularly fine. Non-flash photography is allowed and entry is free. You pay a small fee (5 euros I think) to look at the equally beautiful (and much older) cloister. If you go out to the other side of the great facade there is the oldest and tallest Egyptian obelisk in Rome, and the original Baptistery building (not open when we went, as far as we could see). We did fail to find the Holy Steps, owing, we said, to a misleading guidbook, which we are rather annoyed with ourselves about! The Lateran Palace itself is not open to the Public.

Classical Basilica. Beautiful Basilica, watch out for the pickpockets out by the restaurants. You can easily spend a half day taking pictures and attending Masses. You are outside the walls of Ancient Rome, so make sure you have transportation back to city center before you go there. The bus service is spotty at best and never trust the cabs.

Worth a visit. Right in front of metro station San Giovianni. The Archibasiica is one of the oldest papal basilica of Rome. The building is splendid with a very beautiful interior. Not as crowded as St Peter's, which made it nice to take time to admire.

Stunning! Hardly any tourists!. One of the most beautiful places I have seen. I'm not religious but can completely appreciate the stunning work that goes into creating such a beautiful place. It's worth the trip and you don't feel like cattle being pushed around as there are hardly any tourists. It's free to get in and you can take non flash photos.

Imposing. The Basilica of St. John Lateran is imposing in its position at the top of the Celine Hill. The papal altar is lovely and the 5th century mosaics in the baptistry are worth seeing.The cloisters are attractive but those of St. Paul Outside the Wall are more beautiful.
Beautiful. Well worth the drive to see this beautiful cathedral on the outskirts of Rome. Offers both excellent paintings and sculptures.
Wonderful. The Cathedral of Rome, just in case you thought St. Peter's was. Amazing place, very interesting and the audio guide is well worth having.

Wonderful. Came here to view the oldest and the most important of the four major basilicas of Rome and want to say was not disappointed at all. The front of the church may not give you the exact idea of how huge this church is which you get to notice once you get in through the huge doors of the church. Inside the church there are many sculptures dating back to the 18th century but the main eye catchers were the throne of Pope and the wonderful 700 years old baldachino inside the church. Outside the church on the opposite side there is the building named Triclinium Leoninum.
A long weekend in Rome. A beautiful basilica, it is probably second only to St Peter in the Rome area.It is easy to get to with public transit, a bit further then the Colosseum, but well worth it.
Beautifull Basilica. A place that most be visited while in Rome. We went for a beatification of D. Alvaro del Portillo and it was completely full with peregrins
amazing. It was an fantastic visit we ll always remember this church and of course the Holy Stair opposite...

Gigantic edifice lacks elegance. Some cathedrals are beautiful structures from the outside and others have splendid interiors but San Giovanni has neither, it is simply too big! The scale of its columns, its doors and its statuary, is never less than gigantic and it conveys no overall impression of welcome or sanctuary. It is an austere and imposing edifice which invites all but without the accompanying appreciation. The statues of the Christian martyrs which line the nave are huge and frankly disquieting. Above the Papal Throne there are two enormous polished brass statues of Jesus and John (?) uncomfortably clinging to the ceiling, misplaced and far away. Don't waste the trip to the Lateran Hill though, visit the beautiful Baptistery next door for a far more intimate experience.
Peaceful and calming. A beautiful cathedral and much easier to take time to reflect than in the bustling St Peter's. Easy to find as close to Metro station
A suprising gem. We walked here from our hotel and you keep getting glimpses of the roof in the distance.It was amazing, we all stood in awe
It's a pleasure to visit it. If you believe in peace you find it in this place you fin a piece of history pleasure to be in Rome where you can find art and history in every place you visit

So Beautiful!. Huge church! Loved the HUGE statues of the saints along the main aisle of the basilica. Dedicated to Saint Peter and Saint Paul, and they're symbolized everywhere in the church. Bought some rosaries and other souvenirs from the giftshop inside the church too.

Another stunning church in Rome. One of the most stunning churches in Rome and not as busy as St peters. Felt you could walk around and enjoy the surroundings without being swamped by people. The church is huge and there are lots to see. Definately worth seeing :)

Very beautiful and in places peaceful. I have visited this Church on a few occasions and even now I am still stunned by the beauty of its interior and exterior. I visited the Cloisters (small charge) and Holy of Holies at the Scala Santa (a joint ticket offered a discount). I used the audio guide, covering San Giovanni and the Scala Santa, very helpful and informative.
DON'T MISS IT. With a guide or reading up before the visit, you won't be disappointed. I'm not religious, but this was an amazing place to see.
See it for yourself. One of the most special churches in Rome, read any guide book beforehand so you know what to look for. it is certainly worth the visit.
An impressive church. Lots of gold and swirling statues of the Apostles and others. A place fit for the popes! Great PA system.
A must see. A really impressive building in a lovely location. Use the trams to get close and enjoy the walk up to the piazza in front of the Basillica

Table of the Last Supper. A must see if you're coming to Rome. The holy relic of the table from the Last Supper of Christ is high above the back left altar. Don't miss praying the Luminous mysteries of the rosary here.

Awesome Cathedral. This is so huge it needs a day to see all of whats in it, since this is included in our itinerary for our hoho pass we decided to have a look first as our agent told us this is the first church that was ever built in the whole world, the mother of all churches.

The perfect prettiest place to love history and art.. I went here in 2004 because of my daughter's birthday. She loves art and painting even she already graduated form Fine Arts at college and this was an amazing visit.The church is so pretty and quiet that you feel the presence of angels in there. It takes time to see everything you cannot see all in just one visit. I would like to go again it was a magic vacation you cannot miss.You leave the place with a feeling of joy.

Great Attraction to visit. Be sure to see this while in Rome. My husband and I enjoyed learning about the history. The church is beautiful. We had read so much about it prior to our visit but it is so amazing when you actually see it!
The next best thing to St. Peter's, without the crowds. This basilica is simply fabulous. It's the Cathedral of Rome and seems to be about 3/4 scale of St. Peter's. See it.

Often Missed but shouldn't be. One of teh great churches of rome. It is the home church of the Pope. Nearby the Santa Scala or holy stairs are reputed to be from the holy land. Many walk on their knees up each step saying a prayer at each.

St John in Lateran. The arch basilica of the diocese of Rome. This church is amazing. So many side chapels, statues that it is hard to believe. As you walk through the aisle/halls it is incredible that one chapel is more beautiful than the previous one. Awesome..

Attended mass and it was very moving. Attended Sunday mass at this basilica. There were over 12 priests and a bishop on the alter. Even though the mass was said in Latin, it was very moving to attend. We went to mass at 10:00 am and the 11:30 mass only had one priest. Gift shop had beautiful rosaries and necklaces.

St Peters Scaled Down. This is Rome's Cathedral and it did remind me of St Petersboth inside and out, though not quite as overwhelming. There's a Metro Station just beyond the city walls to the east and the large green space in between provides an ideal camera shot. The wide marble floored nave is lined with magnificent statues of the apostles who also feature above the east front portico.The Basilica also has a papal altar enclosed in a colourful grille. Don't miss the peaceful, beautiful cloisters with fine tiled detail which are reached from near the audioguide stand. To the west and outside is the separate baptistry is also well worth seeing, and very reminscent of Florence or Pisa.

Often missed. Just a little away from the centre but just off the Metro, but go must not be missed the pictures and size of the church warrants the visit alone put with this the large doors are said to have belonged to Julius Caesar and statues are fantastic

important to see especially for Catholics. This basilica predates St. Peter's as the seat of the Roman Catholic Church. It is extremely beautiful, and lacks the tourist throngs of St. Peter's. I have sung here with a choir, and the accoustics are impressive too! This is also the place where St. Francis of Assisi came to get permission from Pope Innocent III to found the Francisicans. Innocent III is buried here. The famous liturgical composer Palestrina was Choirmaster here for 6 years in the 1500s, and it is possible to see some of the works he wrote here, although it is not a regular part of tours. Worth the time it takes to get there. If you take the Hop on, Hop off tours of Rome, there is a stop here that makes it very convenient.

Out- and inside, complete opposite. Odd front, however on the inside hugh and a really beautiful church with lot's of paintings ans sculptures. Even the ceiling has been taken care of, do not forget the marble old floor.

Exceptional. The Arcibasilica di San Giovani in Laterano is certainly in the must not miss category. We were advised by the very kind & informative chap in reception at our hotel that it was one of the most ornate & beautiful churches in Rome & he was absolutely right.  Having visited perhaps 7 or 8 churches during our stay we were not disappointed in any of them.However this was the one that really took our breath away. Absolutely stunning. We didn't want to leave & we took many photo's to look back on & remember our visit. We highly recommend it be high on anyone's list of places to see.

Incredibly beautiful mosaics, soaring architecture. Not to be missed - this is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is the Pope. Be sure to bring a travel guide or audio tour to get the insights on this beautiful church.
Great historic basilica to visit. It is a beautiful place to visit. Amazing artwork of the era including statues, pictures, and ceilings.

Snazzy church. Rome is full of exquisite and ornate churches and cathedrals, and the one in discussion does not fail to impress. Free entry, easy enough to get to on Metro line A and maybe a 15 minute walk from The Colosseum, I squeezed the Basilica in before I did The Colosseum/Agora; 'twas a busy but visually and historically pleasing day.

Fantastic. The basilica is wonderful. It is a combination of working church and a museum. The art work is very beautiful and the huge sculptures are breathtaking. The ceilings are painted and the pipe organ in huge. The basilica is very easy to get to via the Metro - the exit is right in front of the church. There are also no big crowds like at the Vatican, and thee is no admission charge so it is very easy to take in the beauty of the church with no rush. This was an excellent surprise and something that shouldn't be missed!

Exceptional and one of the most important places for catholics. Located a bit off the main Rome attractions (15 minute walk from Colosseum) the archbasilica is the oldest church in the West. Interestingly, it has an extraterritorial status, belonging officially to Vatican rather than Italy (though quite a distance from Vatican). That means it is also much less crowded than Vatican - or actually rarely crowded at all. The basilica is huge, though still only about 2/3 the size/length of the St Peters basilica. I particularly liked the statues of the 12 apostles, which are large but very, very detailed.
worth a visit. Probably even more impressive than San Pietro, also you can take the bus 218 outside the chutch afterwards to visit the Catacombs of San Callisto etc.

a must see. A 'must see' during a trip to Rome! As with all the churches we visited amazing interior! We read our guidebook before visiting so we knew what to look out for, eg Pope Sylvesters tomb....his bones are said to rattle before a pope dies!Scala Sancti across the road is said to have 'holy stairs' from Jerusalem which the fsithful climb on their knees, said to have drops of `Christ's blood (?)

Don't miss this church. I don't understand the lack of reviews for this Church. It is famous, important, beautiful, peaceful and not crowded. Hard to find a better and more significant church in Italy.P.S. With the front door at your back, walk diagonally to the right across the piazza and through the arches of the old wall. Then turn sharp right into the first side street for a large on-going flea market.

Awesome. Also visited the Sacred Steps which are next to this site. I will never forget this experience. Helpful to read the history and facts about this site before you go. Wish I had been able to attend Mass there.
Oldest Church in Rome?. Not quite as Awesome as the Vatican but not crowded either. Largest Egyptian obelisk ever hidden behind the church.
wonderful visit to an amazing church. Enjoyed it highly.. Amazing site and church and would recommend it to other travelers and was easy to reach by city bus.

Rome's church. The ceiling alone is worth the visit. A beautiful and quiet place amid the bustle of Roman traffic. Across the street are the miraculous steps which were "transported from Jerusalem." Over 200 steps which pilgrims go up on their knees. Watching is less painful that trying it.
Beautiful church. Love the huge statues in St. John Lateran. A great spot to visit when in Rome. Enjoy the view from the front steps, especially if you come in the side.

Where the Pope becomes Pope. The Basilica of St. John Latern is of great importance in Rome and to the Catholic church. When you enter the Basilica you re-enter the property of the Vatican State. In this Basilica there is a chair called the "Bishop's Chair". When a new Pope is elected he comes here to sit in the chair and officially become Pope. This is a purely ceremonial act, but it is a reminder that this is the home church of the Pope. The church is extremely old. It was the first Christian church in Rome and originally opened in about the early third century. Until St. Peter's was built this was the center of Catholicism. The interior is enormous and along the nave are wonderful huge statues of the Apostles. There is much to see here, and catholic or not this is a place of incredible history. The Basilica is very easy to reach on the Rome Metro line A. Just exit at the stop for San Giovanni. It will be easy to find.

The Most Interesting Church in Town. My wife and I have visited Rome many times and have eventually got round to visiting this venue. I can honestly say that it is the most interesting church I have ever visited. The €5 for the audio commentary really is excellent and provides an informative overview of the church and cloisters. However, I will add that it does have a noticeable bias for the Mother Church, but that will be no surprise to anyone. I found this much more interesting and informative than any visit I have made to the Vatican. Well worth the visit.

One of the highlights. Much to admire here including some of the most beautiful ceilings I have ever seen. The sculptures are magnificent especially the gloves St Bartholomew carries. Beautiful altars and much more a feeling of spiritualism than the fake St. Peter's.

Outstanding Basilica. The approach to the Basilica is wonderful, it immovable on the highest slope of the Piazza. We were delighted to discover a little more of its place in the Catholic faith. It is the diocese church of the Pope, who is the Bishop of Rome. It is the oldest of the predominant Roman basilicas. Before the re-establishment of the papacy in Rome following the Avignon papacy it and its palace were the Pope’s residence. They fell into disrepair so the papacy relocated to the Vatican.The façade is most impressive as are the massive bronze doors. On each side of the central aisle are large statues of the apostles, each in a different manner and appearing with symbols.  The interior is vast and highly decorated. The floor, walls and ceiling are rich in ornamentation. There are many side chapels, each with a distinctive quality.
Beautiful church, in use by locals. Beautiful church, actively In use by locals. Incredible sculptures and gilded ceilings. No crowds so a welcome change from St. Peter's!
Miss this and you miss a lot. The amazing sculptures, the history, and the tiled floor which appeared as 3 D, toy really must make a stop here
Roman Churches. One of the largest churches in Rome outside of the Vatican. A must see if you love to visit churches.
An unexpected visit. A very beautifully detailed church, much bigger and much more depth than it looks from the outside, the artwork is fantastic, a must see when in Roma!
Ohhhh,another truly Yes!. Yes!,another "must see" in Rome.Just walk in and out and around in marvel at the gracious beauty. How great that this is so well preserved for all to appreciate.
Impressive. Massive structure and very tranquil compared to St. Peter's. I liked the statues of the apostles at both sides of the nave
Must see. Beautiful! Free entry! Easy access from metro station. This is a must see. We were at the Arcibasilica around 1pm on Wednesday. Very few people were there, so perfect timing. Loved it.

Unbelievable. So much beautiful art and history to see. I especially liked the very large statues of the Apostles - especially Bartholomew - he was skinned alive when martyred and held a piece of his skin in his hands with the face of Christ.
There was no negative at this beautiful Basilica.

Stunning Cathedral. First of all dress code no bare shoulders for men or women but of course in Rome there are a few guys outside selling shawls for just a few euros. Shorts it seems are whoever is in charge that day. I believe this is the official Church of the Archbishop of Rome. The earliest building began between the1st and 4th century. The statues inside and out are incredible and the ceilings have to be seen. Went on a Thursday hardly any crowd and no charge.
One of my favourite.... This is one of my favourite buildings in Rome - looks pretty spectacular especially when approaching from the San Giovanni Metro station at night! Worth a visit.

Best Church in Rome. We were staying not far from here and this was not mentioned in our AA guide book as a must see nor did the hotel highlight it on the map they gave us! But this is a MUST see church. We went inside when a mass was underway, which was amazing. The architecture is incredible and we found out that this was the Popes main residence before they built the Vatican. No queues, just make sure you cover your shoulders and no very short skirts or shorts!
First thing we saw in Rome.. This is just a stunning basilica. Home to the popes before St. Peter's basilica was built. it's one of the must see's of Rome that's not so touristy.
Fabulous. St John Lateran is the Pope's Church. It is a beautiful church & not to be missed. Beautiful ceilings and an amazing altar. Statues of the apostles. A must see.

The Pope's Church. This is the Popes church! It is well worth the visit. There are no lines here. The architecture is amazing as is the art. We used the rental self use units and enjoyed the tour very much. If you decide to walk from the Coliseum, bring some water. All in all it is not a difficult walk unless heat is a factor.

Beautiful facade in the evening. This church was located near our hotel so we ended up visiting it both during the day and the evening. Though you can't actually go in during late night, I must say that the illuminated facade is really worth seeing. Naturally the interior of the church is beautiful as well. The most interesting piece of art for me were the statues of the 12 apostles. As many have suggested, compared with Saint Peter's this church is calmer, both in the sense that there are less crowds and that the decorations and artwork are not so over the top. Definitely worth a visit.

Grandeur and relative calm. I enjoy attending Catholic mass and visiting churches and find this fulfilling on different levels.
There is a simplistic sense of proportion in the huge buildings in Rome that is not as evident elsewhere - please try it for yourself.

The oldest basilica in Western Europe. St. John in Lateran was founded by Constantine prior to St. Peter's in the Vatican and as the cathedral of the Diocese of Rome is the official seat of the Pope as the bishop of Rome. In contrast to the crowded and ornate St. Peter's, St. John's is tranquil and aesthetically pleasing. An audio tour is an excellent aide to explore this massive and quite beautiful cathedral rebuilt by the flamboyant architect Barromini in the Baroque era. A 16th century ceiling and massive Statues of the Apostles by Bernini are worth noting. The 13th century cloisters are a peaceful retreat and the 4th century baptistery has fine mosaics and frescoes. Metro stop San Giovanni is a short walk away and the neighborhood around the Cathedral has some nice department stores in which to browse.

Better than a day at the Vatican!. We stumbled across this beautiful church on our way back from spending the day at the Vatican. At the Vatican, we were surrounded by hordes of people - to the point where we just wanted to get out and get some fresh air - it was too hot and crowded for our liking. In contrast, when we entered this church, it was completely different; free to enter (optional donation), peaceful, and mostly empty. The size of this church and the decoration are extremely impressive, and we enjoyed spending a short time wandering around inside.Definitely worth a visit if you want to get away from the crowds and off the beaten track.
Steeped in history. This is where the popes were before the Vatican. We were staying within easy walking distance. I am not sure I would have visited it if it had been further away.

Favourite. This church was my favourite church due to the statues. I was totally in awe. Don't miss out on this church if you want to visit. It is so easily accessible and free. Do cover up in respect.

A bit off the beaten path..... The Scala Santa are just next door, so its worth travelling off the beaten path for this. A short walk from the Colosseum takes one into the less touristy part of Rome. There seems to be a market here too where all the tat is!!
Truly a gem. We settled in to rest our feet during Mass while we were there, but were very moved by the service. Jaw dropping gorgeous art everywhere.

Make sure you visit here and not just the Vatican.. A lovely Cathedral within walking distance of the Colosseum. Everyone visits the Vatican, but this Cathedral has bronze doors from ancient room at the front. Hugh inside with statues of the saints on either side of the nave. Free to enter, if you want to visit the Cloisters there is a €5 charge. There are 2 small gift shops on site as well as toilets. You need to cover your legs and bare shoulders. There are street peddlers outsides trying to sell you shawls. Site security keeps them away from the front of the Cathedral.

The seat of the Bishop of Rome. This is the oldest and the first among the four major basilicas of Rome, and the seat of the Bishop of Rome, namely, the Pope. It is also considered the "Mother Church" of Catholicism. The emperor Constantine (his statue stands in the portico) gave the site to the Bishop of Rome. This is a very elaborate church, with decorations from very different times. The apse mosaic, and the beautiful Cosmati floors, are part of the oldest stage; (much) later work was by Borromini, doing the nave in grays and creams. The niches are filled with enormous statues of the apostles. The transept is a riot of color and metals. And, there's that gorgeous gold, red, and blue ceiling. There's almost too much to take everything in at one time. Note that the church is free (although I believe there is a charge for the cloister, which we did not see on this visit), and there is a dress code (knees and shoulders covered), albeit erratically enforced. Nearby is the Baptistry and the Scala Sancta.
Absolutely awesome. nice visit here at the first Christian church in the world. Also, it's free to enter, so do not miss it!

Amazing church. Absolutely stunning, the statues were my favourite part but in general the interior was just perfection. I accidentally arrived during Mass but it was a beautiful experience, really brought the church alive. Beware of closing and opening hours - I think at the moment it shuts at 6:30.
Beautiful. Make sure you cover your knees before you go. Otherwise you will be buying a scarf from the vendors outside for 4euro to 10euro.
The cathedral of Rome. Such a majestic church!!! It's a must visit as it is one of the first Christian churches to be built in Rome. Popes used to be crowned here.

not to be missed. The oldest Church in The World!! Stunning! The Cloisters also hold the actual stone on which 4 Centurions rolled dice for Jesus'clothes before he was crucified! Take the audio tour outside and it will tell you where it is as it is not that obvious!

THE Cathedral of Rome. This basilica, the seat of the Bishop of Rome, is one of the finest historical and religious sites in the City, other than the Vatican, of course. The array of historic art and architecture is awesome, and the moderate crowds a pleasure.

A must. Really imposing structure..... The paintings, statues, even the entrance doors are all of great detail and the little garden within it is a little gem that one would never even imagine it would be there.It was our first stop when we arrived and it was a good start to an amazing few days of culture.We found a little "locals" restaurant just around the corner with very friendly staff and really nice inexpensive food "Le Virtu' in Tavola"

Grand and beyond belief. This Basilica is off the beaten path in Rome and should be included on your list of "must see basilicas" in Rome. It houses the Pope's chapel and is opulent and grand, exceeding all expectations. Mosaics of all the Popes throughout history line the great walls, even featuring a spot light on Pope Francis. It's helpful to understand the history behind this landmark prior to visiting. It even has a gift shop and restaurant with plenty of clean, well-maintained restrooms.

Churches Churches Churches. There is no entrance fee, and both male and female need to be appropriately covered. Visitors here were very respectful that it is a place of worship. Worth they time to sit and mediate.

Beautiful church. Really Beautiful church and free audio guides for a donation. But not worth the 5 euro's each to view the cloister. A beautiful cloister but 20 euro's for 4 of us just not worth the money

Magnificent. This basilica - the Pope's cathedral - is truly magnificent. From the patterns on the floor to the gilded coffered ceiling, this is a wonder. We were especially moved by the wonderful statues of the eleven disciples and of St. Paul. This cathedral is somewhat out of the way in regard to most of the attractions in Rome, but it is definitely worth the effort to make a trip to see it.

Beautiful. It is one of the most important church of Rome and christianity. It is georgeous. It is a pity that you have to pay 5 euro to visit the chiostro and that the square outside the church is not well

mother of all churches!. Arcibasilica or Archbasilica, the only basilica that can be prefixed with an "arch" , being the oldest and thus ranking #1 of the four patriarchal or papal basilicas in the Roman Catholic Church, and also the cathedral of the bishop of the Diocese of Rome that is the Pope himself.
One couldn't afford to miss when visiting Rome!

Monumental. Well, this is the Pope's cathedral, so you know it is going to be mind blowing. Our Airbnb was 5 minutes away, so when we saw it on the map we decided to do a quick visit.once we went inside, we were blown away by the grandiosity of the Cathedral, the opulence and the gold. It's simply beautiful.if you (well, you're in Rome) are into visiting churches to admire the nonsense opulence of the Catholic church, this place is for you!

Spectacular. This site was just beautiful. The statuary was amazing as was the mosaic in the apse. Of course, the history is impressive too. It's simply one of those places that everyone should visit if in Rome.
Beautiful. We stayed in the Hotel attached to this church and WOW, what a beautiful place to visit. Either for spiritual reasons or tourist.

Must do. This was amazing! twelve apostles all standing in a row, lining the main walkway with Jesus. Fantastic. Nothing to dislike here. Just pop off the Metro at San Giovanni and follow the signs. Not far.

The Cathedral of Rome. This is the cathedral and mother church of Rome;it is a huge grandiose Baroque structure,visible from all over Rome.It was the chief papal residence until about 1300.and Popes were crowned here until the 19th century.It also contains the worlds very first baptistry.The 13th century cloisters are also remarkable and well worth visiting.

Amazing!!. My partner and I visited the basilica in July during our 4 night stay in Rome. Although the building was within walking distance from our hotel, we decided to rest our feet and caught the metro to San Giovanni, whereby the basilica is a short five minute walk from the station. Being a religious building, it is essential that shoulders are covered! Once inside, my partner and I were in awe at the scale and size of the building!
Awesome!. Nothing to hate about the place. It was amazing. All I knew about Rome was the Vatican. I never knew that there was an old Vatican and a new Vatican
Spectacular!. Oh my! oh my! this basilica was gorgeous! It is worth the trip to see such spectacular statues and the interior of the basilica!
Incredible. Worth it! Just take a step in and look up the whole time. If intricate art is your thing, then it's totally worth going in to take a look.

Amazing. Apart from the vatican St Peters Basilica, this was truly fantastic, twelve apostles standing metres high lining the main walkway with Jesus. Fantastic organ, everything in gold and mosaics. Overwhelming the detail on the carvings and art work.
Make sure you give your self plenty of time you will need it to truly appreciate it

A must see!. Quiet, out of the way and I may even suggest, better than St Peters! I cannot believe that this is not mentioned in more maps and guides. The most beautiful Basicilla with the best little shop in the back. Much cheaper Catholic souvenirs than anywhere else and they are so much more meaningful!
very ornate. this church was magnificent & very ornate & very large ,also just accross the road from Scala Santa.this is also romes cathedral which the pope uses.
breathtaking. Great place - don't miss the sacred steps. Audio guide excellent and worth the money -you have got leave security.

Serene. I was fortunate enough to stay a walking distance to this Basilica and arrived there first thing in the morning. It is absolutely serene and the atmosphere was so calming ... it felt like a sacred space. And of course it is very beautiful

Very surprising, try not to miss it. When we went here by tube train (just avoided being pick-pocketed) there was a market going on outside and a marriage ceremony had just finished. What a surprise on entry - huge statues all around a huge space inside. Paintings everywhere. It's really a Don't Miss.
wonderful. lots of great pictures, it was great to shoot pictures of,I shot a lot,lots of camera angels it was why I was there

Beautiful!. Lovely art and cloister read up before you go though so that you understand what you are seeing for example, the first papal throne. Close by is Santa Croce and the Santa scala, a must do!
A must. One of the nicest Church I have ever visited. Every corner hides a gem. Just remember, shoulders and knees covered. Gentlemen, no baseball caps.
Bit further away. Have to take metro to get here as it is not in the center. If you are visiting then look for Pompi, a famous tiramisu restaurant. You can just ask around. Everyone knows it.
Absolutely amazing, it's a must visit & it's free!. I can't believe this breath takingly beautiful place has free entrance. I could easily spend hours wandering around!
Great sight to see!. Impressive sight just like Rome is a great city lots of places to see and enjoy the atmosphere and people always busy and vibrant!
beautiful. check your times because it opens and closes throughout the day. We had to venture back to see it all, but it was worth it.
Wonderful.. a must see. check your times because it opens and closes throughout the day. We had to venture back to see it all, but it was worth it.

Wonderful and amazing... But busy like Disney. What an amazing site and one of the best places to see in world. It was just surreal and inspiring to see however it was so rushed by thenl number of people in it. You couldn't get peace to take your time.. It reminded me of the ques in Disney! Go when it's quiet!

Archbasilica of St. John Lateran. You must do your homework in Rome as not to miss the most important church in Western history. This is the official church of Rome, the church of the Pope and one not to miss. Entry is free but you must adhere to a strict dress code but there were men selling scarfs just outside the doors just in case. The crowds don't seem to go here so you can spend a relaxing time in the grandeur and quiet of this place. Statues of the 12 Apostles (not sure why Paul is one of them) line the walls of the main hall. The way they are depicted matches their Biblical character. This is my 2nd trip to Rome and I'm so glad I didn't miss this this time!

The first Vatican. If you are traveling to Rome to learn more about the Catholic Church you must include a visit to this basilica. Build before St. Peter's and with a much more austere style it will move you in ways different from the grandeur of St. Peter's.
Important Basilica. As this is the Pope's own church as Bishop of Rome it is an important building. I is beautiful and well worth a visit.

out of this world. this was out of this world . beautiful windows painting Etc. It was lovely to see however I do think all that gold could be used to help people who are suffering via poverty or war. (just my opinion.) I feel it would be just as wonderful without the glamour.
