Too strict dressing code?. Unfortunately, we didn't have the chance to visit the inside of this otherwise beautiful basilica. There was a man at the door banning people from getting in who were not wearing "proper clothing". After 3 weeks in Italy, we knew the proper way to visit a sacred place, and this was the only place in all of Italy we were banned from. On the same kind of clothing we were even allowed into St. Peter's Basilica! Maybe it's no problem there because they charge for a ticket? I wonder.It seems looks are more important than attitude. It is ok to wear long trousers and then be noisy and disrespectful inside a church, but it's no ok to wear knee-long shorts and be there for religious and artistical admiration.

mindblowing!. I came to Rome on a pilgrimage and this place was by far the best place I visited. Everything about it was spectacular, beautiful and for me, spiritual. I also went to St Peter's and by comparison, that place was loud and overrun with hoardes of photographers...there didnt appear to be any respect for the surroundings. However, San Giovanni in Lateran was quite the opposite, I would definitely recommend. As a little extra note, we purchased go Rome tickets which enabled us to visit lots of places plus use unlimited public transport for 3 days. We would never have gotten around as swiftly without these.
San Giovanni in Laterano. awesome !! It's a short walk from the our hotel Daniela, and it is absolutely beautiful. in the next street you can fin the church of the hoy steps.
Different and beautiful. Just a few meters from the San Giovanni metro station this beautiful churc is different to most others, it is worth the visit when in Rome.

Nice but be aware of pickpockets in San Giovanni area. Nice church but it was all fenced when we got there as they were preparing the area for a massive concert taking place on the 1st May. We visited it again few weeks after the concert. It's nice but quite few pickpockets in the area.
Rome's Cathedral. The church is smaller than St. Peter's Basilica but I lilke it becasues it is quiet and not as busy as St. Peter's Basilica.
Beautiful Basilica. Apart from its obvious attractions visitors might be interested in the Basilica's connection with Artemisia Gentileschi.

Rome's Finest Church!. After you've visited St. Peters, you really need to visit St. John's. It's a short walk from the Colosseum, and it is absolutely beautiful. I hope people just don't go to the Vatican if in Rome, and they do take time to visit not only St. John's .... but some of the other beautiful Roman churches. And you probably should go across the road and see the Sancta Scala, a very sacred site, but one my wife and I found a touch tacky, with a tour group in taking photos of such a spiritual place... but you make up your own mind.

Major Cathedral. If you enjoy the Cathedral architecture or are a Christian, please do not miss this amazing basilica. Tucked down in southern part of the city sits the beginning of the Catholic Church. Here, The heads of St Peter and St Paul are in the altar. The body of St John the Baptist is also here. The architecture is stunning. In the back of the church are phones you can pick up that give you a lot of information about the history of the church for 2 euros. Our family spent a lot of time here admiring, viewing and praying.
Beautiful. This was right on our doorstep and when we first visited I couldn't get in as my shoulders were showing. I'm so glad we went back, it's truly stunning inside. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful Seat of the Pope in Rome. The most important church in Rome! The Pope isn't Pope until he takes his seat HERE. Amazing church, colossal statues of the apostles. Worth a visit!

Definitely a church to see in Rome. After St Peter's Basilica this is about the most spectacular altar in Rome due to the ornate baldiccino that rises over that altar. Add in the ceiling and it is worth the walk. You can reach it walking from several directions either walking southeast from the Colosseum where you will go past St Clement Basilica or south from shopping or eating on Via Nazionale.

The Basilica of St John in Lateran. I started my tour here and it is a great shame (or a good thing?) that the millions of people who visit Rome each year often bypass this stunningly beautiful church. This church has a huge significance in Roman Catholicism and rivals St Peters from my point of view. Beautiful!!

amazing church. When travelling around I really enjoy visiting old churches and I was absolutely amazed by the history it carries and by the beauty of this place I wouldnt miss this point for nothing....

The Original "Vatican" Founded by Empiror Constantine. This is the site of the church of the first Popes of the Catholic church, founded by Emperor Constantine after having a vision of the cross prior to defeating the pagan Romans in the 4th century A.D. It rivals in beauty and grandeur the Vatican itself, and is considered the mother church of Roman Catholicism. This cathedral is often overlooked by tourists but should never be missed based on it's origins, beauty and significance.
Supurb. worth a look, but dont disrespect others, be quiet, we had Londoners talking loud and eating sweets- embarrassing to be British or what!- It is a house of GOD please remember that

Much better than St. Peter's!. Unlike the Vatican, which we visited earlier, St. John in Lateran seems mostly overlooked by the throngs who flock to Rome, which is a great pity. It wears it's history with more dignity I would suggest - not feeling the need to suspend it's modest dressing rule to rake in the cash (as does the Vatican) nor to have a shopping centre (slight exaggeration) of religious rubbish every 20 yards or so like the Vatican Museums! This was the Papal Basilica for a long time before the Vatican and fortunately it is still there!

A Walk through Church History. An idiosyncratic choice for the number 2 attraction in Rome (are a large number of pilgrims using this site?) yet I am grateful to my fellow tripadvisor reviewers for suggesting this basilica. We included it in a self guided walking tour of this part of Rome taking in the Basilica Sante Croce di Gerusalemme, the Basilcia di San Giovanni in Laterano and the Basilica di San Clemente ending at the Colosseo.From our hotel in Via Nazionale it was about a 30 minute walk via Santa Maria Maggiore and the Piazza Vittorio Emanuele II to the Church of the Holy Cross in Jersusalem. From there it is a less than 10 minute walk along the viale Carlo Felice to St John of the Lateran providing an impressive view of the Piazza di Porta San Giovanni and Alessandro Galilei's 1735 facade of the basilica. I believe this walk between St John of the Lateran and the Church of the Holy Cross was undertaken by the popes barefoot as a frequent act of penitence to worship the relics contained in the latter church. Naturally, St John of the Lateran is also easily reached via Metro Line A from the nearby station of San Giovanni.The area of the Basilica and the neighbouring Lateran Palace is highly significant for imperial Roman history as well as church history. The site was from ancient times the Domus Laterani, the home of the distinguished Plautii Laterani family of Rome. Also in this area was the Castra Nova equitum singularium (the new fort built around 193AD for the imperial cavalry). From the time of Constantine the fort was demolished for a cathedral and the Domus was soon gifted to the Bishop of Rome. The Basilica is historically significant as the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome (the pope) and is therefore the principal Roman church in Rome (the archbasilica). It is the prinicipal of the four papal basilicas in Rome (and therefore part of the Holy See) and the neighbouring Lateran Palace was once the main residence of the Popes for a thousand years.At the end of the Giardini di via Carlo Felice overlooking the Piazza di Porta San Giovanni is a seven metre tall bronze monument to St Francis of Assisi completed in 1927 for the 700th anniversary of the saint's death. The statue's hands are outstretched and have been placed to give a visual impression that the saint is holding up the Basilica as a reference to the tradition of Pope Innocent III's dream in 1210 of the saint doing just that which convinced the pope to support the creation of the Franciscan Order when Francis sought an audience with Innocent in Rome.Passing through the 18th century portico of the Basilica one can note an ancient statue of Constantine on the left, which apparently had been found in the ruins of the Baths of Diocletian. The nave is impressively vast dominated by 12 large early 18th century statues of the Apostles and a fine ceiling decked with papal crests. The cosmatesque paving of the nave is also justly praised. At the head of the nave, before one reaches the Transept, is the 1369 baldacchino. The baldacchino is between the nave statues of St Peter and St Paul and below it is a statue of St John the Baptist. The Transept and the Apse are richly decorated with frescoes and fine mosaics are to be seen in the apse. I regretted I did not have more information at the time to appreciate the art works here more.There is plenty to note outside of the basilica as we returned to the piazza and made are way to the right around the Lateran Palace toward the Piazza Giovanni Paolo II. I had read that the Scala Sancta (Holy Stairs) were in this area. These are said to be steps from Pilate's palace in Jerusalem which had been brought back to Rome by Constantine's mother after her pilgrimage to the Holy Land. It was not immediately obvious where these were and I first mistook the Triclinum Leoninum in the open air as the Scala Sancta. The triclinium is all that remains of the state banqueting hall of the old Lateran Palace from the time of Pope Leo III (795-816) and it contains mosaics dating from 1743 which are copies of the original 9th century decorations. The Scala Sancta are actually inside the nearby chapel but it was closed at the time of our visit.We observed the facade of the Lateran Palace from the Piazza Giovanni Paolo II but it did not appear obviously open to tourists. I understand it houses the office of the Vicariate of Rome and is the home of the Cardinal Vicar of the Diocese of Rome. In the piazza is the Lateran obelisk, one of the many impressive Egyptian obelisks dotted around Rome. It is on the sight where the equestrian statue of Marcus Aurelius once stood (it survived as it was once thought to have been of Constantine) before it was moved to the Capitoline Hill (a copy now being in the Campidoglio and the original in the Capitoline Museum). The obelisk dates from around 1390BC and once stood at Karnak. Constantius II brought it down the Nile to Alexandria and then to Rome in the 4th century AD where it stood in the Circus Maximus before falling into ruin and then being re-excavated and re-assembled in 1587 during the time of Pope Sixtus V when that pope destroyed the ruins of the old Lateran Palace to build the present edifice. Such monuments might only take a moment to view but their centuries of history and various locations are fascinating.On the opposite side of the piazza from the palace is the Lateran Baptistry which seems to have been on this site since at least 440AD but now seems separated from the basilica after various constructions over the centuries. It is an interesting octagonal building with many mosiacs and friezes as well as a number of side chapels. I again would have liked more information about it at the time to appreciate the building more. From here it was just a short walk down the via di San Giovanni in Laterano to the Basilica di San Clemente with the Colosseum close by, again showing how much of a walkable city Rome is.

Truly stunning...a fave. The inside of San Giovanni's is absolutely breathtaking. I was in awe of this church and spent two hours here without even realizing it. It was so beautiful to walk around and take in the art and architecture. This is a sight that is not to be missed. I highly also recommend that you listen to the audio tour as well. Its inclusive to the purchase of tickets for the Cloisters but the audio was worth it. Very interesting.

I think they forgot that John served Jesus.... Honestly, it was very difficult to visit any of the basilicas in Rome and look at them objectively. Of course, the exterior and the interior décor of this place was astounding. An absolutely beautiful place with a lot of interesting art inside.The difficult thing that my wife and I struggled with was the fact that those that decorated the church seem to have missed the point that the Apostles served Jesus, not the other way around. Our concern started the moment that our tour guide mentioned something about a holy doorway (fyi - that's NOWHERE in the bible), and it just sort of went downhill from there.Honestly, the whole experience just felt paganistic (that's not a word).

my favorite. aqmazing basilica, 5 minutes from the metro stop. if u go in the morning u can see the market of VIA SAGNA, just between the metro stop and the basilica. the basilica offer a lots of things to see. in front there is a saint stairs church, and not far aways santa croce in gerusalemme. i suggest.

'Amazing'. I'm always impressed when I enter this 'Basilica' due to the impressive oversized statues of the twelve apostles that were added in the 1700's. The Lateran was the ancient seat of the Popes who also lived adjacent to the original building throughout the Middle Ages. Besides the interior make note of the floor patterns. One in particular gives a 3D effect when you change your angle of viewing. Please read up on the history before heading off for a visit. The main entrance faces the towards the San Giovanni metro stop which is reached through Metro Line A. It is a leisurely stroll from the Colosseo Metro stop taking you by the 'Baptistry' built 432-440 and this directions brings you up along the west side. Make sure you go around to the front. Very impressive view! You can also reach via buses and trams. One of my favorite places while currently living in Rome!
Beautiful Church. Loved this church. Was a service on the Wednesday around 4pm. However didn't like the persistent scarf sellers on the steps outside...
San Giovani. The Basilica is worth a visit if you are in the area. Close to the Metro station, there is a vintage/secondhand clothes market nearby which is also worth a look

Beautiful.... We visited in June. We entered through the back left side, the Lateran Palace entrance, not realizing the main façade was around the corner..! No matter, what we saw inside was truly beautiful. The nave, the ceiling and not forgetting the wonderful floor, all worth seeing. You should read up about it's history prior to visiting, it will make your visit more interesting. There is a baptistery next door too, but we didn't visit. It is in my top 3 of the churches/basilica in Rome...beautiful.
Amazing. The seat of the papacy until St. Peter's was built, this cathedral is extraordinary. You can walk quietly through its massive nave and view the impressive art works as well as meditate.
A part of Rome. If you travel to Rome, you have to visit this basilica, together with all the other famous location in Rome. Magnificent witness of a glorious past.
Surprise. From the outside, we didn't expect what we saw on the inside. It was massive, the sculptures were remarkable!

Once of the nicest cloisters ever seen. The Basilica has a great architecture and amazing with and breath for a cathedral. There are not too many tourists which makes a visit a pleasure. The cloister accessible via a small door at the left end of the main basilica room is extremely nice and adds a semi-outside location to the visit. It also features museum-like exhibitions adding to the historic education received by visiting this place. (The Basilica is free but the cloister adds a 5 Euro fee).

Outstanding Cathedral in Rome. Inside the Basilica is absolutely stunning - ceilings, walls, floors and scultptures. You can easily spend half a day here soaking up the magificent works of art in a magnificent building.

Free but may need paid audio tour to understand. We had been in about 100 churches at this point so didn't buy the 5 euro tour. We may have gotten more out of it if we had. Ornate and interesting but we were looking for the Holy stairs across the street.
A must see. Great site for religious pilgrims or architectural enthusiasts. The art and architecture in all of these churches are amazing, and the religious significance will warm you.
Beautiful. stumbled here by accident and it was very breathtaking inside, free to get in and worth a look. The kids enjoyed it, they loved the ceilings and the prayer areas
beutifull!. beutiful church. Medieval and full of paintings that make worth while the visit. free of charge. styles get mixed with colours and sculptures.

Beautiful. A large, really lovely, cathedral, seat of the Pope as Bishop of Rome, with an interesting history (seat of the Popes before the Vatican); with a fine 14th century baldachino, said to contain the heads of SS Peter and Paul, Papal cathedra and altar, beautiful mosaic floors, bronze doors from the curia in the Roman Forum, and a lovely interesting 13th century cloister.
Great architectures.. Breath taking medieval architectures. Brings you back centuries ago. Brings you closer to the ancient people in their times.
impressive. you should visit this basilica. it is impressive, yet not as large as St. Peters, but has a wonderful atmosphere.
Quiet Haven. we enjoy visiting the main churches in rome and san giovanni is good if you just want peace and quite for a while or to take in the archictecture and design

Beautiful!. We got lucky and were there when the Pope said Corpus Christi mass outdoors. Could not go inside that day, so we went back to see the basilica as well as the holy stairs. If your into "all things Pope/Catholic" than it is truly a place to visit.

Unexpected little visit. Came across this church by chance and it was a wonderful little insight of the some of the artwork and beauty of the city of Rome.Well worth visiting as it is not far from the Subway stop and in a nice location.
An amazing church!. We like churches, cathedrals, etc. both for their religious significance and history, but also for their architecture. This amazing church has it all, and is well worth a stop!

A little out of the way, but shouldn't be missed. A beautiful Basillica that was the precursor for St. Peter's. Do not miss visiting the little non-descript building across the street which contain La Scala Santa and the Sanctum Sanctorum, two sites which must be seen and which do not take more than 30 minutes.
Wonderful decorations. Beautiful building, the painted decorations and ornate features are wonderful. Well worth a visit we were not disappointed.

very important visit. Since many years I promess me to visit this monument.
I am very pleased to visit this place and I intend to come next year

Glorious. I just love this church. Magnificent exterior and interior. Moreover the Piazza in fron of the Basilica, Piazza Giovanni Paolo, is also very beautiful. The gem however is the Basilica itself. You cannot but admire its marvellous architecture. Totally recommended!!
Impressive!. Really worth visiting! (if interested in history and art) There could however be more information available...
Basilica di San Giovanni. Magnificent building. Tremendous site in the middle of the city. Great area to walk around, to sit and admire the buildings. Nice restaurants.

Breathtakingly beautiful and so rich with history!. This is one of the four Vatican Basilicas, and if you are interested in ancient Catholic history, it is a must- see. It was the original basilica I. Rome for the Catholic Church prior to the building of Saint Peter's Basilica. Next door are the stairs thought to have been used by Christ when he was going before Pontious Pilot. It is a very moving place to visit as pilgrims comes to climb the stairs on their knees. Make sure that you include this basilica in your tour if the Vatican, as well as the other two major ones- Saint Paul's and Saint Mary Maggiore.

first Christian church. This is the site of the first official Christian church in the world. It is full of history, medieval mosaics and baroque art, and other artistic treasures. It even includes the heads of St Peter and St Paul, and, from what I have read, they have a pretty good chance of being the real ones. It is actually the cathedral of Rome, and so the Pope's cathedral, but, unlike St Peter's you do not have to line up to get in.
Worth the Trip!. Beautiful basilica - indescribable - just have to see it. We were very impressed with the antiquities. Put on your must see list.

Spare an hour on your visit to this Basilica - You'll love it!. Ok, you're in the city of churches, so why bothering about another one? Believe me, this one is not a simple another one. The masterpieces inside this Basilica are simply jawsdropping. The statues are incredibly big and perfect, giving you their feelings on their faces. Besides, it's huge and with a ceiling with lot of details you can spare several minutes appreciating them.Take into account:- As any church, you're not allowed over exposing your body. For girls, is highly recommended to bring that 'summer scarfs' (sorry, as a man I have no idea how to call that) to cover parts of your body- It usually closes at 6:30PM, but worth Googling before planning your trip - going there and seeing only outside is a lost visit- It's a church, so be respectful. If you're going to take pictures, no flash

Home Church of Bishop of Rome, the Pope. Magnificent cathedral! Absolutely breathtaking, like all of the churches of Rome that we visited! Be sure to cross the street to see, and perhaps climb on your knees, the Scala Santa. So thankful to have had the opportunity to see and experience these holy and beautiful places!

Grand. Although I highly recommend, the lines were long, but moved fast. It is so hard to describe all the alters, chapels and sculptures. We hired a car and driver,so getting around was pretty simple and easy for us.
Stunning Cathedral of Rome. This huge cathedral -- where the pope serves, in his role as Bishop of Rome -- has a gorgeous nave and alter, many beautiful chapels, an ornately decorated cloister.

Words can't describe. This fabulous basilica is a "must see" in Rome. Although it's very popular, it's not overrun with tourists in any of the manner of Saint Peter's in the Vatican. I especially love the huge scuptures of the disciples. Superb art all around: scuptures, paintings, mosaics, architecture. Astounding place!

Grand Cathedral. Impressive like most of the churchs in Rome but this one ranks with St Peters inside if not outside. Would recommend a visit. Take the Metro it is a very convenient way to access this and nearby sites.

An Important Basilica that is often missed.. As we approached the Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano and saw the construction for an event out front, we were slightly disappointed, but that completely dissolved upon stepping inside. This is a "Papal Church", like St. Peter's, and some say it is second only to that well known basilica. It is very, very large - one of those places in which you marvel at the abilities of the old world architects and even builders who somehow managed to put such a massive structure together. The walls are covered with frescoes everywhere, precious artefacts of extremely high quality, depicting the lives of Christ and St. Peter.The website led us to believe that a reservation for a tour was necessary, but we did not find that to be the case at all. While a tour would certainly provide further insight, it is possibly to simply walk in and marvel at the wonders. So, there is no excuse for missing this important location, as it is just steps away from the San Giovanni Metro station.

An impressive basilica. First trip to Rome, and visited san Giovanni in Laterano on a Weds. AM. Impressive but not overwhelming. Audio guide and add-on visit to the Sancta Sanctorum are worth it. Not as huge as St. Peter's, but much less crowded or chaotic.

Beautiful Baroque Cathedral. Baroque and therefore beautifully over the top. Like most of Rome's churches, there is no entry fee. It is not closed for siesta hours, open 7am till 7pm. Remember to dress appropriately, no shoulders on show and no short-shorts. It will probably take half an hour to take a good look at the entire cathedral.

Stunning Church. Location: 20-minute walk from the Colosseum. You can visit both San Clemente and San Giovanni in the same day - they're about 10-minutes apart from each other on foot. The place: Because the Pope is also the Bishop of Rome, this church is Rome's 'official' cathedral (this is because this church is the seat of the Bishop's residence). San Giovanni very much resembles St. Peter's basilica. Now, what did I think? WOW! What a beautiful (and HUGE) church! Architecturally and visually stunning - those are the best words I can use to describe it. If you love art, history and architecture, or you are simply devout, then this is a must-see church. I spent about two hours taking photos here, and I probably could have stayed longer because it is that impressive. For the first few minutes after I entered the church, I stood there with my mouth hanging open because I was in awe of the magnificence that was before me. I mean seriously, it's an architectural feat. Price point: Free entry.One of the things that I enjoyed about visiting this church was its size - you can walk freely and at your leisure without anyone invading your space, so it's a nice break from the madness of Centro Storico.

Beautiful Church. We visited in August 2012. Take the time to cross the street, towards the left, by the entrance to the church. There, you will find the Scala Santa. These steps, brought from Jerusalem, are said to be the ones Jesus Christ climbed to meet Pontius Pilate. Climbing the stairs, on your knees, reminds you of the sacrifice Jesus Christ made for us.

Beautifully Stark Church. The church is one of the four papally controlled churches in Rome. It is quite stunning with magnificent super sized statues of the apostles lining the nave. The space is huge, however, and can leave the visitor feeling a bit cold

One of the four Basilicas of Rome. This is one of the major cathedrals in Rome, it is the oldest but it has been destroyed and rebuilt over the years. It is the Cathedral of the Bishop of Rome (The Pope) but it is not as crowded with visitors as the Vatican is. Its design is outstanding and the marble work on the floors is magnificent along with the whole design of the cathedral. Inside it is not as dark and heavy as many ancient cathedrals and with the light streaming in, it highlights the statues in the niches in the walls. I easily spent an hour here enjoying the cathedral.While the Vatican is far better known and has more religious and historical heritage, this cathedral would rank number 2 to see.

Like the TARDIS, it's bigger on the inside. San Giovanni Laterano is a bit off the beaten path (all of the major basilicas are on the fringes of the city), but it's well worth a visit. Honestly, while it's smaller than St. Peter's, in some ways it's even more visually arresting. Polychrome marble everywhere you look--it's both vast and a bit claustrophobic in its ornateness. It's a lovely, quiet place to sit and take a break and let it soak in. It also has a museum (that I didn't get to see) and a wonderfully kitschy gift shop.

Amazing place to visit. We visited the Lateran Basilica during our 4 days stay in Rome. It is not in the very central part of Rome but it is worth to take some extra time and to spend at least an hour here admiring the cultural and historical heritage. From the Basilica you can walk to the Colosseum and further to the Piazza Venezia.

if you like visiting churches. if site seeing churches is what you like , this one should be second on your list when visiting Rome , after St Peters . it was one of the first ( if not the first ) catholic churches ever established , not the original building however . the statues lining the main hall are impressive along with the ceilings

important thing. this is the first real big church ever built. for a christian, this was a magnificent experience and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to be amazed by christian architecture :)

Stunning cathedral. I am an atheist and so churches and cathedrals often disappoint because of the decadence displayed whilst the poor went hungry, and the preponderance of religious art. However, this cathedral is stunning because it is understated but with the contrast of a magnificent nave, wonderful mosaics and amazing sculptures. Of all the religious places in Rome, this is by far the best!

The most amazing thing, you can see at Rome!. I'm not a Basilica-liker person. But this... This is just a game changer! Smaller then St. Peters, but with better atmosphere, without so many tourists. Sometimes it's look like a conference center for a believers :) Must see at Rome!

Beautiful church. Probably our favourite cathedral. One of the four major basilicas in Rome so it's a must see! It's away from the centre but it's definitely worth visiting. You can take the metro or walk it from the Colosseum.

Beautiful and rich history. Amazing sculptures, worth checking out the Cloisters (courtyard) which costs a little extra. If you do visit the Cloisters you can get an audio guide to explain the various historical items found there.

A must see. Beautiful place to visit! You will be transported to the great masters of paintings, sculptors, and many more to browse and appreciate. We visited this place as a personal pilgrimage for my husband and I and we were just awe struck with all the beauty and splendor of the basilica. Close by (which is just across the street) is the Holy Stairs which is the actual stairs that Jesus took when He faced Pontius Pilate.
Beautiful work. When we visited this Church I had not seen so much gold used in any of the other Churches we visited. The work on the ceilings and dome and walls - beautiful
Confess All!. It's a bit out of the way, but it's an awe-inspiring place. Great for a good confession in any one of several languages
must visit place in Rome. visited this as part of the guided tour that we took, one of the significant basilicas, must visit when you are in Rome.

Beautiful and peaceful and quiet. Met someone in Venice who insisted we go visit the church when in Rome and I am glad we listed to them and made this visit.the church is beautiful and just outside the church is another portion where you have a huge baptismal octagonal font and a tiny chapel with mosaics from the 17th century I think. Make sure you visit these if going there. It is not in the church but a one minute walk from there.

Archbasilica. John Lateran's Archbasilica, St. John Lateran's Basilica, and just The Lateran Basilica, is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is the Pope.

lovely basilica. loved the visit to this baroque church--huge interior, lovely mosaics, awesome ceiling. It's the seat of the Pope and exudes such a serene vibe. we got here by taking bus 571 from via castellana where we stayed.
Beautiful. We'll worth a visit,truly magnificent,astonishing architecture.one of the not-to-be-missed sites of Rome

Lovely find off the beaten track. We wanted a quiet period in Rome one day and visited this site. It is lovely, massive church, beautiful inside, good architecture and no-one there! Also free to go in.
Great chrch. at the gates of the Roman Empire you sure have to go here and enjoy the surroundings and after you go out just go on shop LEAM
Unbelievably beautiful inside. The interior of the church is breathtaking. Even the floors are gorgeous with inlaid tiles that have been there for over a thousand years.
Nicer then St Peters. It is a lovely church and we went to mass there on the Sunday morning and it was lovely with a lovely choir at 10oclock

Beautiful Church. All Churches are breathtaking full of beauty,history,amazing reality of the Christian City,they are monuments with very old history,very real.
The serenity and peace of being in this place is life given.
I'm always with architecture and religions figures,the ceilings are of endless Beauty,there is never enough time to see and take in so much.
Good place to be. I visited that place yesterday with my family, it's a great place to visit in rome. You need to go there 1 time in your life at least!
Beautiful Cathedral. The statues and architecture is great, it can be reached by bus from the termini. Plenty of restaurants around the area too.

Splendid. I visited here with my husband, for me this was by far the best Basilica we visited in Rome. It was so beautiful and peaceful, and I felt very moved by being there as this is the home church of the Bishop of Rome, who is of course the Pope. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful Church. One of the BIg Four Basilicas in Rome, this is a real treat. The architecture and art are fantastic. A true treasure and a must-see.

Simply beautiful. It's stunning. Not to miss. The facade and the ceiling are breathtaking.
Rome is full of churches, but this one takes the first place for sure.
Don't miss this beautiful church. Plain on the outside but ornate and magnificent within. In our judgment, This beautiful church is second only to St. Peter's in all of Rome.
Glorious...Magical... When entering this church you can easily thing of how the people build it...Really spectacular...I loved it..!

You have to go. This is one of the special Seven. Have been here so many, many times. I love the approach (walking up to the church), and knowing that it's just across the road from the Scala Sancta. I love knowing that it's the seat of the Holy Father. I love seeing the Jubilee doors and reminiscing. I love the quiet inside, and praying at the main altar. Then I love to look up and left... waaayyy up and left... and see the slab that covers the "original table of the Last Supper".

A beautiful church and one of the oldest in Rome. A beautiful and important church among Catholics in Rome and well worth a visit.You don't get the crowds that you do in the Basilica of St Peter's or the Pantheon so you can really take in the beauty at your own pace.
The most beautiful church in rome. By far the most spectacular church in Rome, its even more beautiful than St. Peter's Basilica.Must be visited
Total surprise. Gorgeous - no crowds - very important church in Rome that most visitors are not aware of. If possible walk by at night to see it illuminated - simply beautiful.

Well worth the effort - not so far out of Rome centre. I am actually staying near the Spanish Steps and it took me about 45 minutes to get to S.Giovanni in Laterano. This is a majestic church. What I found particularly interesting was that the entrance appeared to be a series of very average wooden doors. They open up the the most beautiful basilica in Rome. As beautiful as the Vatican is it has become such a procedure to get in and often incredibly busy - I do understand that as it is the centre of Christianity - but please don't miss S. Giovanni. A must see.
Beatiful Basilica. Beatiful and peaceful place to visit, but the area around is full of emigrants and a bit scary to walk at nights
Yet Another Beautiful Church!. Try to find time if you are in Rome to go to Laterano to see this magnificent church. The interior is magnificent!
Amazing. There are many tourists because it's not really in city centre, so you can enjoy the peace and silence in this beautiful church.

S Giovanni in Laterano. Beautiful, majestic and UNCROWDED jewel of a place to see and easily accessed on the Metro A line. Often overlooked, but this is not to be missed and it is highly recommended! Access also is free of charge.A must see if in Rome...amongst many!

Stunning. Many of Rome's churches are worth visiting in their own right, even some of the smaller ones that are a bit off the beaten track. This is one of the bigger churches and you will not be disappointed by the majesty of the surroundings.Being some way out of the city centre, it is not as busy as some other churches but well worth making the journey.

Excellent and majestic!. Is very different from St. Peter's. The white architecture strikes one's attention. Quite bare compared to St. Peter is charming nevertheless. One should remember that this is the cathedral of Rome and so the see of the pope. Has lovely exterior view from all directions.
Beautiful church in Rome. We visited this very beautiful church, and went to Sunday Mass there. It is huge but very spiritual and well taken care of.
Beautiful & Inspiring!. A great site of ancient Rome. Magnificent artwork. Very impressive! I felt like I as in ancient Rome & prayed for all the saints and martyrs.

free entry but a bit ott. The 'mother church' is worth a visit but be prepared to wonder why the church hasn't done more to help the impoverished. The ceiling is covered in gold and there is so much marble...we left wondering whether offerings that are meant to help the poor actually do or if they just go towards a new sculpture!You can take photo's here but depending on the staff you may be asked to leave if your knees and shoulders aren't covered.O and they have a gift shop - in a church - because they need extra money....

Just great. Superb experience and not to be missed. From the entrance to way out it is breathtaking. Not crowded as St.Peter basilica even it is being the oldest and ranks first among the four Papal Basilicas or major basilicas of Rome.

Stunningly beautiful basilica. Quiet and majestic with soaring ceilings and art. Free to enter and be sure to do the Holy Steps. Catholics will feel their faith here, there is a reverence in the air. This is well worth seeing
Magnificent.. A little "off the beaten path" by way of Roman attractions but the "Cathedral of Rome" and the "Pope's church" is really magnificent. Check out Constantine's baptistry next door.
Worth the effort of getting there. This church has amazing history and internally is quite stunning. Be prepared to be dazzled by everything inside.

Beautiful pieces of work. Basilica di san Giovanni is in honor of St. John and is one of the oldest churches in the world. The main entrance has the 12 apostles on the roof and this is considered to be the tallest statues of Apostles ever created. The side chapels and the main altars are all adorned and done in beautiful pieces of work ranging from statues to paintings. The entrance is free and you could reach the place by metro and getting down at san Giovanni. The place has massive amount of relics and works but only to be overshadowed by St. peter’s. San Giovanni Basilica is among the four most cathedrals of the Rome and with free entrance it is a must visit. You could also grab a picture postcard from the post office near by
An amazing place. This church is just gorgeous and so is the cloister. We just loved it. We also shared a great experience: a mass with people from all over the world.

Loved the doors. The most interesting thing about this church is the ancient doors taken from the curia (old Roman Senate) that now hang at the entrance. Otherwise it's your typical baroque pomp and circumstance. The floors were amazing too. The opulence and over the top baroqueness of it all left a bad taste in my mouth given that the church has lost its true intended focus. It all seems a bit hypocritical.

Excellent. 1. Don't forget the La Scala Stairs beside the church (cross the road on the left when you get out of the church)2. If you acquire Roma Hop on and Off bus, their office is nearly beside the church also. If you get out of the church, its just on the left, no need to cross the road. Believe me, it took me 45 minutes to find, and unfortunately, nobody knows where it is (even the police). I finally found it after asking the security guard of the Basilica.

Wonderful. What a beautiful place this is. We did the audio tour including the Holy Steps. Definitely enhanced our experience. One of the four "biggie" Basilicas in Rome. This was the most impressive -- until we got to St. Peter's.A must see if you are Catholic and visit Rome.
Beautiful edifice. Magnificent structure with soaring ceilings; I have seen most of the important churches in Rome and this one is definitely worth the effort.

Visit to Laterano. This was an unexpected surprise for two reasons it was free to view the church and it is magnificent inside the church. There was a 5 euro charge to visit other parts which if you are really into the history of the religion and church would be worth it.
Holidays in Rome. A huge cathedral which is the home Church of Rome. Well worth a visit. Easy to get their on Metro at San Giovanni station.

the cathedral. Quiet and peaceful the cathedral has interesting relics and a beautiful cloister. The interior is impressive though on a much smaller scale than St Peter's. There is Vatican postbox for any postcards you have to send and a small gift shop.

Amazing. We almost missed this Basilica. We decided at the last minute to visit and it was amazing. It is a must see. While we were there is was much calmer than many of the other sites. It had a more reverent feel.

my favorite church. Some places (not always churches) just 'speak' to you and St. John Lateran does that for me. I've been to Rome a number of times and always make sure I attend at least one service there during my visit. I love the whole ambiance of that particular basilica.
The Marble Basilica. Wonderful Basilica, very large, standing on it's own with the most beautiful marble from floor to statues. Worth a visit.

Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano. This is one of Rome's major basilicas. There are a total of four. It is imponent and majestic at the same time. There is no fee for the admission. If you enter from the right side like I did, the first thing you will see it the big altar. The central nave is very wide and there are two smaller naves on its side, which is typical of the old churches architecture. There are tombs of popes along two smaller naves and 10 feet statues of important saints along the main one. There are chapels, frescoes, paintings and other statues of religious subject on its side. Each one of these masterpieces could be one of the main pieces of art in a smaller museum. The ceiling is decorated in a complex way with carved elements and gilded. Light comes from the above windows. I got there around 4:40 pm and there were some people gathering, then a cardinal arrived and at 5 pm he started to celebrate a mass. You should spend at least an hour here.
One of many Beautiful Churches. One of the many Basilicas each worth a visit for the very impressive paintings therein. It would be hard to pick one from the many we visited as the best
Basilica. Take a tour guide around so that you can appreciate everything and avoid queues. We learnt so much from a very funny narrator.

Roman cathedral. This, not the saint Peter, is the Roman cathedral. And it is worth it. Simple, but magnificient, standing alone against the wind (not a metaphore, it's very windy around it). Inside, statues of 12 apostles (6 on each side) lead to the altar, where every Roman bishop, e.g. the pope, starts his pontificate. It is actually 11 apostles (they didn't include Judas, naturally) and st. Paul. If you go to Rome mostly for its religious importance, this is an absolute must-see.

Just as impressive as St. Peter's Basilica!!. As the Basilica of the city of Rome, the Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano is magnificent and is within walking distance from the stairs which Jesus climbed to have his ultimate fate determined (devout Catholics climb these stairs on their knees - praying all the way).Back to the Basilica - Rome's Cathedral, is either a truly wonderful location for quiet and peaceful contemplation and prayer or a place to simply find inspiration. As the Basilica is a little outside the 'normal' tourist zone, it does not attract the same volume of visitors as St.Peter's Basilica and this fact alone ensures that a visit is not generally spoiled by having to wait in a queue to gain access.Early morning visits are, in my opinion, nonetheless best (especially if you want to also walk around the Basilica's garden without Rome's searing summer heat!). As a continually returning visitor to Rome (having previously been a Roman resident for a few years), I always ensure that a visit to San Giovanni, is on my list of 'must do's' during each stay.I hope you enjoy your visit!!
San Peters little brother. A very beautiful church with a similar layout to San Peters. The floor in particular was nice as was the little garden.
Beautiful, worth the trip. Beautiful church, stunning. My husband and I are not religious but we were hugely impressed. If you are soon to head out to Rome, add this to you itinerary!

It's a special place. Beautiful and tasteful. One of those places you wish you had allocated more time. We went to the stairs across the street which were taken from Jerusalem which Christ climbed. You have to do it on your hands and knees. I passed. Bad knees. But it was still inspiring to see so many people devout enough to do it and pay 5 euros for the privilege. I'm glad to say that even though it was a bit out of way there were quite a few folks visiting. There are many must see sights in Rome and what you actually see depends on how much time you have there. If you have 3-4 days, fit it in.

AMAZING AMAZING CHURCH!. I wish more people knew about these amazing places to see in Rome.. they would be there years before they finally make it! This Basilica was one of THE most gorgeous churches I (can't still believe that I) got to go into!! So many naves - and then the holy steps across the street? This is simply mind-boggling!! To think you get to be ON the steps where Jesus was condemed to die? Thank you St Helen! wow.

more beautiful than St Peter's?. if you found the baroque over the topness of Bernini's interior at St PEter's a bit much go to St John Lateran instead - still magnificent and monumental but not quite so over the top
Wonderful!. Beautiful cathedral to visit! Location was close to our hotel. Audioguide was very helpful during our visit here.

good holy place, easy to visit. this place locates very closed to San Giovani metro station. Morever, after you are done visitting this Basilica, don't forget to visit the holy stair which stands inside the building on the other side of street, just walk across the road, and you will be there. Both of these holy places, I really recommend to visit, when you are in Rome. Nice, beautiful and peaceful place !
Great!!. You can't imagine! Rome is full up of incredible places even in very hide locations. It's not this case, this church is located in an huge square and it's wonderful!!

One of the most important churches of Rome. Another beautiful church in Rome and one of the most important ones being the church of the bishop of Rome . The facade is very impressive and the artwork in the churck , the statues , the marble and fresco's are outstanding . Don't forget also to go to the cloister and museum behind the church and the Baptistry besides the large church , they are an important part .

The Pope's Church. This is definitely a must see while in Rome since it is the actual Archbasilica of Rome. Aside from that, it is a magnificent church. The cloisters are also worth the 5 euros to enter and see the historical pieces. It is a quiet place in a busy city.

Impressive. The Mother of all churches. Really impressed by this church that was once the equivalent of San Pedro. The Claustro has very impressives antique pieces like the one that tells how tall was Jusus Christ.

Magnificent church. This church has mozaics going back to the fifth century and is the Pope's church. It is magnificent in every respect and a must visit church in Rome. Nothing more need be said about it.

Beautiful Classic Basilica!!. Wonderful, spirit moving church! Treat this Holy Place with reverence please!! There were American tourists running around, laughing and being Jerks!! I was embarrassed to write in the visitors book!!

Must always visit here. I have visited Rome annually for the last five years and I always make it a point to visit this Basilica. I urge everyone to read up on the history and art associated with this Basilica. It is after all THE mother church of Roman Catholicism, not the more visited Basilica of St. Peter. San Giovanni doesn't have the distracting crowds of St. Peter's Basilica, and there is plenty to see. Equipped with some knowledge about the place, I can spend a good two hours there every time I visit it.  The Basilica one sees today is a great example of different reconstructions, modifications, and additions, rather than a building reflection one style of architectural design. It is a grand lesson in Roman art/architecture and possibly some of Morromini's great designs for a building of this size. Not to be missed are the Baptistry and Cloister. Take your time but go prepared ahead of time so you know a little about what you are seeing. The more you know, them more you will see and understand and appreciate.

Great Basilica, Buy your souvenirs from here. We visited this great Basilica and were impressed by its beauty. Could not stop taking photos. We were told that this church was build before the Vatican and that St Peter was modelled on its structure. It resembles St Peters but on a smaller scale. We accidentally found a small souvenir shop inside the church (towards the middle) and noticed that the souvenirs were cheaper (even half the price) here from the other shops near the vatican. They have a large selection and as I said, half the price. The lady and the gentlemen at the souvenir shop were really helpful. My recommendation is to buy all your souvenirs from here as you get genuine products and you will not pay from your nose.

Great find!. This was not far from our hotel and we made a detour on our way to the Colosseum and were glad we did! From the outside the building was really impressive, and we were just as impressed when we went in!
five minute walk from the milton roma. amazing building not allowed in wearing shortswatch out for all the street vendors outside as they are a bit pushy
Well worth the time and taxi (7euro). This was so wonderful; we did not know there were Vatican basicllica's outside the walls of the Vatican; do your research and see all four.

magnificent. probably the best church in Rome.. anyway the one that surpised me the most. You don't know where to look at.. it is outrageously beautiful!!! take your time. sit down and breath. the magnificence of this place will fill you!
Another beautiful basilica. Like St. Peters, having all the elements including the centrally placed baldacchino, only smaller and somehow more accessible.
Original doors of the Curia Romana. If for nothing else, this beautiful basilica holds the doors that once stood at the Curia Romana, probably from the 3rd century AD.Definitely worth a visit.
A big surprise. From the outside it looks like nothing, but once inside and into the catacombs, it is so much more than it seems on the outside and it is not mentioned in many guidebooks.

Beautiful-Cathedral of Rome. Stunning Basillica which is the Cathedral of Rome and in the 14 Century was the main Popes Cathedral before St Peters. Has the original Roman doors from the Senate Building in the Forum. Well worth a visit.
Great Architecture. Solemn surrounding even if lots of tourists visit the place. Great architecture just like the other churches in Rome.
Beautiful church. The paintings in this church ar fantastic and you can stay there a long time admiring all the interiior
Beautiful. This is a must see in Rome!! There are tourists there but it is not so overrun by them that you can't enjoy yourself while taking in all the artwork and statues.
The Original Vatican. St John in Lateran was the primary basilica in Christendom before St Peters. That plus it's location in the centre of Rome, makes it a must for many visit to Rome.

Beautiful Basilica. Everyone should visit this historical basilica which is the cathedral of the Bishop of Rome- the Pope. It is the first of the four major basilicas of Rome built in the fourth century by Constantine the Great.

beautiful church!. they are numerous churches and basilicas in Rome, but San Giovanni is one of the most impressive ones.it's easily accessed when you visit Colosseum.don't miss it as the oldest christian church in the world!
always worth a return visit. Its just a beautiful place to visit , we have now been each time on our last 3 visits to Rome . Easy to reach by metro and plenty of local places to eat

This a most see church. it is a bit out of the way furthermore you can walk from Santa Maria Maggiore straight forward about 10 minutes the statues of the apostles are just impressive as well as the ceiling artwork. Just impressive.
Wow. The magnificence of this building is incredible. Well worth a visit. The vastness and incredible frescoes make this a must see location.

An important church not to be missed. A bit off the beaten path but close enough to the coliseum for a side trip. We had the pleasure of being there for two services, one in the chapel and the second in the main church.

Magnificent Basilica. If you are in Rome, this is a must, it "s av amazing and beautiful place.You can use your Rome card and catch an open top bus to there. Beautiful church with 3D sculpture and a couple of impressive organs. Make sure to take time to see this basilica!We saw many churches in Rome and this one was one of the best.

Amazing Basilica. Nice church, one of the most beautiful in Rome. San Giovanni in Laterano can be easily accessed by Rome metro or if you have good legs you can walk from Colosseo to here without problems. The Basilica has an incredible papal altar. The Basilica visit is free but for cloister and baptistery visits you need to pay tickets. Combo tickets are available inside the church.

Well worth a visit. This was the first place we went to in Rome since it was close to our hotel and we were tired from our flight. As soon as you enter you are overwhelmed with the magnificence. It takes your breath away.

St. John Lateran is Magnificent. Very interesting basilica and it is huge. Was not aware of this church but has interesting history and should be visited for sure. Great sculptures and paintings inside. Beautiful church and is highly recommended in interesting area as well.
Beautiful Basilica!. This is an incredibly beautiful and historically significant church. Constantine was baptized in this church. It serves as the Bishops church for the Diocese of Rome.
Seat of Rome. Very beautiful and historic Church. Baptismal site of Contistine and the actual Seat of the Bishop of Rome (Pope)

Officially Rome's cathedral. The basilica is open from 7-6:30. For centuries, this was the main papal residence until the Renaissance era. Earlier most Romans were pagans so this church was tucked away from the center of things. Today, it is the home of the bishop of Rome.To the left on the outside of the church is a large statue of Constantine. He marched to this spot, trashed their pagan gods and dedicated this spot to Christ. The central doorway is the original door from ancient Rome's Senate House in the Forum.The nave is Baroque and built after the 1600's. Notice the relief panels of the Old and New Testament.In the back of the chair is a large white chair which is entitled the Bishop's Chair. The pope is required to sit in this chair within a month of being elected.We walked from the Colosseum but it took us about 20 minutes.Visit the Scala Santa (Holy Stairs) which is the building across the street.
Largest church. Massive and ornate church. Almost as blown away as when I first saw St Peter's. Don't miss it if you are interested in churches
Important church. This is a very important church in the history of Rome and should be visited before leaving. Ignore the beggars they make more money than you do...

Massive church on outskirts of Rome. I was surprised by how enormous this church really is. It was the HQ of the Roman Catholic Church before St Peter's was built at the Vatican. The metro station is close by and you walk just outside the old city wall, which is why the original church was built here back in the day when Christianity was not widely accepted. The approach is impressive with statuary of early saints on the roof top, then I was astounded by the cavernous quality of the interior. It really must be one of the biggest churches in Europe. Well worth the trip out on the metro and you may be able to also visit the Lateran Palace next door (predecessor of the Vatican).
Big, beautiful. Very nice church with lots of details. Also the little cloister garden is very attractive (even has a toilet).

Most important church apart from St Peter's. Beautiful architecture with amazing domes that are so well balanced that during an attempted explosion by terror groups in 60s, , the bomb blew the dome, but because it is so perfectly balanced it dropped right down again into position. Beautiful giant statues of the apostles.It is the church for Rome. St Peter's is for the whole world.

Too Rich and beatiful!. too rich and too beautiful to describe it in few words.
it's a smaller Vatican church, but big and amazing.
Easy to reach by Metro S. Giovanni.

Church is beautiful and cloister is amazing. Church is wonderful and it is worth to borrow audioguide. We visited also cloister and it was really amazing. There is beautiful Medieval corridor with absolutely stunning columns.

Amazing. I recommend purchasing your tickets ahead of time to the Vatican. The line is extremely long. We bypassed the line since we entered through the Vatican and Sistine Chapel. They have catholic service every hour. We were so privileged to have had the opportunity to have mass in this magnificent church.

a great big church. My beloved and I traveled to Rome to run the marathon but we also came to enjoy the treasures found in it's many churches. The advantage to touring churches is seeing art in the place for which it was commissioned. The soaring vaults and huge side chapels really allowed for big works to have room.St John Lateran was easy to get to (we walked everywhere we went) with no lines and not crowded.

ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. Awsome, We paid extra for the guide well worth it, so much more info and places non paying guests dont get to see. Our child did get board after a while as this was 2.5 hours long and he had to be quite !!!!!

A masterpiece!. We decided to visit this basilica after driving past it several times on our tour bus. Once you enter the space you cannot fail to be impressed. I recommend using the audio/visual guide. We purchased a joint ticket for the cloister and Scala Santa for 8 euros. Unfortunately we were not told that the Baptistry and Scala Santa closed for a few hours at 12.30 so we were not able to see them. That being said it was worth every penny and was not filled with noisy tourists who seem unable to keep their voices below shouting pitch! They were also strict on dress code too.

Spectacular -- do not miss. You will be captivated once you enter. Stunningly beautiful. Definitely get the audio guide, which is free, though they accept donations. You can spend hours learning a great deal about the history of the basilica and of the papacy. There is a 5 euro charge for visiting the cloister, but if you combine that with a ticket to the Scala Sancta across the street (don't miss it!) you get a 2 euro break (so it's 8 euro to go to both instead of 10). The basilica is open all day, but the Scala Sancta closes from 12:30-3:30 (at least currently; that may change during the year).Oh, and free bathrooms! (pretty rare)
Big and Beautiful.. The statues of the apostles are amazing.Stands out among the many churches we visited.Including St. Peter's.
very big. massive basillica near the station and apparently the Pope's church. Statues of the 12 apostles on the roof.

Beautiful. The paintings & architecture were beautiful. Thankfully, we didn't have to queue, as we visited in March, midweek. Well worth a visit - remember to dress appropriately (no shorts etc) as we saw several tourists turned away.
Amazing place. There is nothing to dislike. From the mosaic floor to the sculpures, everything is beautiful. The size of it is unbelievable. A most when visiting Rome.

Beautiful and historical cathedral. When I was in the security line to enter St. Peter's Basilica earlier in the morning, I was chatting with a nice Canadian man who suggested that I visit this basilica if time allowed. He mentioned that this was the true papal church in Rome, and that the skulls of St. Peter and St. Paul were actually within the memorials in the church. So, I added it to my list. The bit of history is what I found to be the most amazing, but the church inside is gorgeous. There are many statues and vignettes within the church, and a lot of small chapels inside. The tiling on the floors is even beautiful. Definitely worth the visit to have a look around, or even sit in on a mass if you are there at the right time. It is about a 15 minute walk from the Colosseum, and a bit off the beaten path. You could also easily take the metro from Colosseo to San Giovanni (I think?), and it's only a few minute walk in the other direction from there. If you can, though, I would walk from the Colosseum, as it's mostly back a little side street that is very charming and a nice quiet walk.
Beautiful unique church. This is the Pope's main church as the Bishop of Rome. Well worth a visit.A must-see on a visit to Rome

Seriously nice try to save the time for visit. Very nice church main Rome cathedral with very nice clauster.Worth paying extra money for audio guide and clauster .Definitely worth visit (you need cca 2 hours to admire all the beauty of the church and Sanct Sanctorum.We enjoyed it more than St Peter. Not so many tourists like there.
A Gem. A bit off the beaten track but is not over run by tourists because of its location. Well worth a visit.
Stunning cathedral. A match for St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican. Beautfully decorated with a number of small chapels to the side. Wonderful choir during mass. Well worth a visit.

Breathtaking. As all the other reviewers have said, this magnificent basilica should be on everyone's itinerary when they visit Rome. It is a 15 minute walk or short bus ride from the Colosseum. The outside is impressive enough, with statues of Jesus and the the 12 Apostles on the roof, but the inside will take your breath away. Every surface, ceiling included, is covered with beautiful frescoes, imposing statues and intricate gold work. Make sure you take the time to just sit down and drink in the serene atmosphere while admiring the stunning canopied alter where only the Pope can celebrate mass.We were lucky enough to be there during a special Spanish mass for some clergy and it was very special to be able to sit and listen to their chanting. Even those who are not religious cannot fail to be impressed.It is also well worth paying 5€ to have wander around the cloisters, such a contrast to the opulence inside.

Papal magnificence. If you didn't know, this is were some of the Popes used to be crowned, and what a setting. Gold and colour galore. There are 2 enormous bronze doors on the entrance which have been around since Roman Emperor times, so you will able to touch the same doors as people did 2000 years ago.€5 charge for the cloisters but worth paying - they need to pay for the maintenance of this giant somehow.

A Wonderful Basilica!. The immensity and beauty of this basilica is amazing! It is about a 20 minute walk from the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore to here. Pope Martin V is below the altar, and the church has other papal tombs. This is the Pope's main church as the Bishop of Rome. Well worth a visit.
Vast and magnificent. It was our first landmark to visit and it was hard to leave... We really didn't expect it to be so big from the inside. It was our first clash with the roman art and culture.

wonderful. we have been more times in Roma, but this was our first visit there. Wonderful and without many visitors! You can spend time to understand all the secret of the church, without worry and hurry!

Breathtaking. The façade is stunning, but once you get inside the interior is breath-taking. Take a look at the Corsini Chapel and its mosaic altar, the Papal Altar where only the Pope can celebrate mass, and the mosaics in the Chapel of San Venanzio which is attached to the Baptistry. Note the Baptistry is only open 8am to noon and 4 to 7pm daily. Otherwise the Cathedral is open from 7am to 6.30 pm. In the main square of Piazza di San Giovanni stands the oldest Egyptian obelisk in Rome and nearby are remains of the old Porta Asinaria, one of the minor gateways from the Aurelian Wall from 3rd century, and Nero's Viaduct from the 1st century AD. Just across the road is Scala Santa. The door at the top of the Holy Staircase leads to the Sancta Sanctorum (Holy of Holies). No foot may touch the holy steps so they are covered by wooden boards and may only be climbed by the faithful on their knees.
Wow. If you are in Rome, this is a must, its an amazing and beautiful place.... Rome is a place of Churches, which all have History, and a story to tell, but this one has the wow factor....

Don't miss the original church. A must-see on a visit to Rome, as the first church and one that is still actively used as the original. Amazing history that is available on a donations-basis (with ID retained while using the equipment), from within the basilica.
great place. We recommend you visit this Basilica, its a bit of a walk from the colluseum but well worth a visit. one of the best we have found

Rome Holiday. We visited this church in February and it wasn't too busy.The only problem we had was that we couldn't find where the audio headsets were to buy so we walked round without and info which is a shame as the place is filled with thousands of years of history.The souvenir shop has some lovely gifts and this was where I bought all of mine from even after visitinf the Vatican(prices obviously rise there because of the amount of tourists) but the San Giovanni is known as "The Mother of all churches" around the whole world.Definately worth a visit.
Stunning. Amazing statues the Bastillica is huge and has so much to see, you must allocate at least 30 mins when you walk in it will take your breath away
Beautiful. Just beautiful. Listening to Mass was a lovely experience and worth taking the time to listen even if you are not Catholic. Nothing to dislike :-)

worth the journey away from the centre. This magnificent site can be reached easily by tram and buses using the roma card and is well worth venturing away from central Rome. Allow about 2 hours round trip.

A must see. We had missed this Basilica as it was not on our route, but when we went in it was as good if not better than some of the rooms in the Vatican the 3d ceiling was wonderful, it is a little difficult to find out whats things are as not many translations into English. Well worth a visit.
Out in the Sticks but well worth the journey. You can use your Roma card and catch an open top bus to here. Beautiful church with 3d sculptures and a couple of impressive organs.
Find 15 min to visit. Even if situated a bit far than other sightseeing, but it's 1 min from S. Giovanni metro stop. It is beautiful and calm, not so touristic packed

Cross the street and visit Santa Scala (Holy Stairs). When you will visit Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano, just cross the street and visit the building which keeps Santa Scala.It is said that stairs were brought from Jerusalem to Rome by St.Helen and they are the steps Jesus Christ walked during his Passion on his way to trial conducted by Pontius Pilate.The stairs lead to the Sancta Sanctorum (Holy of Holies) which is the personal chapel of the early Popes in the Lateran palace.Climb the stairs on the knees in order to obtain indulgence.About Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is a masterpiece. A must to visit during visit in Rome. It is also the most important church for Catholicism because is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is the Pope.Also visit the Lateran Obelisk in front of the Lateran Palace. It is the largest standing ancient Egyptian obelisk still standing in the world.
worth the visit. try to get there early in the morning to avoid the long line, definitely worth the visit, really impressive, and a must place to visit while in Rome
Beautiful Church. Make sure to take time to see this one! We saw many churches in Rome and this one was one of the best.

Opulent yet moving. This was the Pope's church until St Peter's was built in Vatican City, and it still belongs to the Vatican. You can tell that it's not an ordinary church, because everything is so opulent and ornate, the whole church is stunning.

A often neglected Must See. This church is often neglected because it is located in the southern section of the city but it is a must see. As one of the four papal basilicas it is impressive for its beauty and historical significance. In the niches of the naos are representations of the twelve Apostles (St. Paul instead of Judas) and many contain the instruments of their martyrdom. This is the mother church of the city and the world and is the seat of the Bishop of Rome (the pope) since the Vatican is not in Rome! Enjoy the church and don't forget to pause and offer a prayer. Praise be the Lord.
A piece of history. I very like this kind of medieval buildings. Therefore Rome is my favorite Europian city! Wonderfull!

Unbelievable. Places like these are the places you can't believe are real until you see them. It is beyond words and a must see for anyone travelling to rome. The architecture is honestly incredible, my jaw was on the floor most of the time seeing this place.

A truly great church. An imposing and impressive basilica, seat of the Bishops of Rome (the Popes), dating from AD324. Everything is on a massive scale, the spaces, the pillars and arches, the sculptures and paintings. Most of the Popes are here, chiselled out of marble, painted in giant proportions, buried in choice locations...Take the Metro from the Termini area and walk a short distance to the Basilica. There are two shops inside stocked with different and interesting items if you want souvenirs to take home. Look for the less obvious: the side aisle archways of angels lit in alternating gold and silver, visible only when you face the door.

Wow, that was unexpected!. My dad had been to this place before and told me that it was almost as spectacular as St. Peter's Basilica and I was like yeah, we can go there. Let's see!When we arrived, it looked impressive from the outside. Nice! But especially when we went inside, I was very pleasantly surprised. I found this place JAW dropping. This was one of the most beautiful churches I've seen on Rome. And I've seen a lot of them.And my dad was right, it felt like as if it was the little brother of St. Peter's Basilica. What I also liked was the fact that there were not that much visitors. A hidden gem!

This is a stunning edifice built over hundreds of years. It is an over =whelming edifice with a charming cloister.The monumental statues of the Saints leave us in stark wonder. The ancient Baptistery (octagonal in shape) has become the model for all baptisteries since its design and construction over the centuries.

An endless history here unfolds. The emperor Constantine gave his private inherited family villa to the Church on this edge of Rome. This is the cathedral of our faith; not the St. Peter's of common belief. You have not been to Rome if you have not been to San Giovanni.

A Must Visit. This church is beautiful. The marble sculptures of the 12 apostles are just so beautiful, with so much detail, you can really spend some time just admiring the mastery of the sculptor. It is not overrun by tourists and the students were not here, either. April is not a good month to go to Europe as all the students are off and they all travel. They were all over Italy and the high school students were noisy. Some sights were hard to enjoy because they were literally crawling with tourists and students. The Scala Sancta is located here. These are the marble steps that lead to Pilate's palace where Jesus walked on. They claim that His bloodstains are on the steps. The steps have been encased in oak for centuries. Where Jesus' blood fell can be viewed because this part is glass. However, the glass part is so small and the glass is cloudy, you really cannot see anything. A plenary indulgence is granted to those who go up these stairs on their knees, providing they have met the criteria for a plenary indulgence. Whether you want a plenary indulgence or not, you can only go up these stairs on your knees.

The Basillica you shouldn't miss when in Rome. Wow, we have been to Rome 10 times and never made it to the Basillica di San Giovanni in Laterano...but this time we made the effort, by way of taxi from our Hotel. The Basillica is breathtaking from the very moment you arrive with the sheer size of the building and the absolute splendour of it's architecture.The frescoes are some of the best we have seen in entire Europe with the Cloisters in there original condition......gorgeous.We gave ourselves 2 hours there but on arrival decided we needed much more time to appreciate this stunning building.If you go please don't miss the Baptistry next door, as many people miss it and it was the very 1st Baptistry in Europe and it's also where Constitine is buried.......the first Emperor of Rome.I can't rate the Basillica high enough.....when you go you will be spellbound. A Must when in Rome.

A Beauty. This beautiful basilica sits atop a hill a hill near the Colosseum. We spent a morning at the Colosseum before touring this church. The artwork and ornate details are lovely. The huge statues of the Apostles are impressive. The Baroque balanced nicely with the gravity of the Coloseum.
Amazing!. What an amazing basilica. We went here several times. Was not crowded during the week, very peaceful. Simply Beautiful!!

The Pope's original church. This was a beautiful Basilica. The statues of the twelve apostles were really impressive! Not as crowded as some of the other sites in Rome. They have audio guides you can purchase, we decided to explore without it and enjoyed our time.

Set aside some time here. I loved this church.A very lovely place to visit. It is peaceful, serene and lovely. The angels on the ceilings were beautiful - make sure you look up. The prayer chapel is worth a visit, to sit in quiet reflection. Make sure you cross the road and enter the very plain church that has the steps you walk up on your knees.Catch the Metro A line to the San Giovanni station.

A must see for anyone visiting Rome. This is simply the most beautiful basilica I have ever visited - and that includes St Peters! Get the metro to San Giovanni and the basilica is only a short distance from the metro station - stunning!
Amazing. It has amazing atmosphere and it is a must see place. This Basilica is my favourite among all of them. Moreover, it is very easy to reach as it is very close to metro station.
Beautiful Church. My family decided to visit the Basilica of St John on the last day of our stay in Rome prior to our cruise. Its a beautiful church. Not to be missed
Don't miss it. I think this was among the most beautiful churches I have ever seen. It's spacious with several sections, a huge organ, and a pious atmosphere.

Wonderful. Near the Holy Steps this is another must see. So, so beautiful. We took the subway over and stopped in after a quick bite to eat across the way. There weren't crowds and we could study the interior with leisure. Gift shop on site.If you're into visiting churches put this on your list. We didn't get to see it all as we ran out of time but we will definitely return someday.

Absolutely a must when visiting the Colosseum area. Not sure why this is not always included in all tours, but the basilica is an amazing trip through the various ages of Rome. Don't miss the catacombs and nice courtyard.

Stunning Beauty. Absolutely gorgeous Basilica. The ceiling and sculptures are a must see. An epiphany service was taking place when we visited, so we didn't get to see everything but what we did see was truly breathtaking.

Stunningly ornate. We entered this beautiful church at such a perfect time of day - the sunlight that shone enchantingly through the windows was even more beautiful than the building we were visiting and will be my overriding memory of San Giovanni in Laterano.The church itself oozes wealth and majesty. The sheer ornateness of the decoration is impressive and imposing and you really get an idea of the vast wealth and power of the Catholic church. Mosaics galore and an ethereal atmosphere made this a highlight of my day in Rome, and I would wholeheartedly recommend visiting.
Beautiful. Truly very beautiful, even the kids were impressed. Couldn't take enough pictures. Not very crowded in December.

deserves a visit. The church is very famous (although less than vaticans) so really deserves to be seen as there are a lot of historical events which took place here. It is very well kept and has a beautiful Chiostro in the back which is a place of incredible quietness and peace. The audioguide and entrance only costs 5€. really worth visiting. If you are a real catholic you might want to also experience the stairs on the external right hand side building to be climbed with knees!

Most Majestic And Beautiful Outside St. Peter. This Basilica of Rome is a must see, outside of the Vatican.It is most majestic and beautiful with superb ceiling. The nave is huge and there are 2 vaulted aisles on each side. The 12 statues of the Apostles in niches are impressive, and a beautiful altar, and amazing mosaic floor.Drop 2 euros in the narrator at the back of the church to listen for 20 minutes to the history.

worth a visit!. Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano was the biggest basilica before San Pietro was built. Is surely worths a visit because it has some nice pictures and statues. Outside of the church begin some buses which go to the catacombes through a nice route. You must go!

Simply Beautiful. The art work in this church is incredible. There are over 900 churches in Rome alone so visiting everyone of them can become a little redundant. This is one of the 900 churches I would put on your list simply because of its size, beautiful art work and historic significance.
Must see. One of the biggest basilica's we saw in Rome, very nice from inside with a lot of statue's also the arena is so huge & really nice to see once you exit from the basilica

A visit to St. John in Laterano Basilica. This tour was facilitated by the Dark Rome Tours group, one of only a few groups that conduct their tours in English. Our tour guide, Mr. Peter, explained the history of this impressive structure and how it came to be.
