He took us through the of the historical artifacts, sculptures, etc. contained within and explained the reason for the name, St. John in Laterano. It was an excellent tour!

The other beautiful basilica. In addition to Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore, you'll want to visit the Basilica of Saint John outside the Walls (built outside the existing Roman walls to conform to Roman laws at the time which prevented Christians from practicing their faith inside the city). There are 12 statues of the Apostles, in addition to a beautiful altar. As with the other basilica, drop 2E in the coin box at the back of the church to listen to the history.

Worth seeing if you're in the area. My husband and I visited to appreciate the artwork and architecture which are both very impressive and beautiful. It's much more peaceful compared to other churches with less visitors (no line-ups - at least when we arrived in the afternoon) and the entrance is free with a 4 Euro charge for the cloisters. The basilica is a short and comfortable walk from the Colosseum, is across the street from Santuario della Scala Santa and is also next door to one of the Omnia Vatican & Rome Card pick-up locations - so very handy to visit all 3 places at once if purchasing the card.

The most impressive cathedral in Rome!. This is a well kept secret. The interior is more impressive than the hyped St. Peter's in the Vatican, but the decorations and Organ are magnificent. Do not miss this fine surprise.
Awesome mosaic floor. We stopped here as part of a walking tour and I really enjoyed hearing about the origins and history of the church. The mosaic floor is amazing.
Impressive!. Amazing to see from up close, much different feelings rush in, imagined different from what I seem on TV. Much better and outstanding in real life!

San Giovanni in Laterano-historic, bright, bueatiful. Very bright interior during daylight so you can see the treasures.Most large churches, like St Peter's are dark.This was the Pope's church before St Peter's and the area surrounding the church still seems to belong to the Vatican. A lot of work and money went into this church over the centuries.No lines and few people.High doors taken from the Roman Forum outside. Golden columns from a Roman Temple to the left of the white chair for the Pope at the far end. Endless large marble statues what were all worth looking at for a while.There are chairs and benches to sit on. Useful when old like us or when you wish to contemplate the beauty around you.I think there is a WC in the Sanctuary but that costs money. It is not worth paying to go in otherwise. We did. If interested, it is on the left side at the far end from the main entrance.We went in 3 times during a month in Rome. Great each time. Bus #117 starts across the street from the Baptistry.That route takes you past the Forum and close to the Spanish Steps among other tourist sites.There is a Baptistry around the back. I believe it was the template or all other baptistries. We did not go in. Closed.The is an Egyptian Obelisk in front of the baptistry. I believe it is the highest in Rome and is covered with Egyptian hieroglyphics. Worth looking at.Scala Santa is near the front and to the left if facing AWAY from the church. It is small, unmarked,it seemed, and worth going in even if you don't believe in a Christian God. It contains the stairs Christ is said to walk up before he was sentenced to die and is a major pilgrimage stop.
impressive to see the different floor. It was impressive to see the different churches, each on one floor, built above each other. Each representing an era. Really A Must See!
the first vatican. i ve been told that this church was the first vatican . is a huge church just outside the centre.about 3 or 4 stops by subway.
Michaelangelo's Moses. One of Michaelangelo's sculptures in an uncrowded church, also displaying chains reported to have been used on disciple John.

beautiful and interesting. Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano was amazing and very interesting but unfortutately the information about the relevant historical things was missineg. the personnel was not really helpful and the visiting schedule of all the attracting things in that location was not adapted to every tourists' needs
Magnificent. I meant to pay a visit here for a long time and finally managed. Worth the visit. Very nice, big church with lots of history.
Brilliant. Best church in Rome, First seat of Papacy well worth the visit, not crowded and beautiful setting, our best church Go see this one!

Amazing. church is far from the center ... I actually got on a bus by mistake...I arrived at noon, during divine service...was a delightful experience: the sun shone through the windows.Cathedral is huge, with the saints aligned like monumental,expressive statues,but the atmosphere is warm, welcoming...definitely worth a visit

Very large church. About 15 minute walk from Holiday Inn Express San Giovanni. It is an impressively large church with beautiful architecture. The Holy Steps was across the street. This Basilica was a little away from the main attraction area of Rome, but nice to visit and see. If you are not into church stuff and architecture, this can be boring.

Can't believe I almost missed this!. I only found this church because I missed a tram stop……one of the highlights of Rome…….it rivals the Baslilica of St. Peter. If you are Catholic it will be especiallly meaningful It is gorgeous and so meaningful. Don't miss this!

Amazingly Beautiful. This huge, gorgeous church should not be missed. It was easy to get to on the Metro and well worth plowing through the scarf (or umbrella) vendors out in front. Inside the church is spectacular and much more serene than St. Peter's with all of its crowds. We spent a couple of hours just looking at everything in amazement. Highly recommend.

A must see in Rome. This was our first stop after dropping our bags off at our Hotel. The church is amazing. If you are a history buff or your religious and want to experience a beautiful church, Basilica di San Giovani in Laerano is highly recommended. If you are a Catholic, I recommend visiting the holy steps across the street from the basilica.

The mother church of christinity for over a thousand years. This is the Mother Church of Christanity. Some argue that it remained the most important Church until St Petres was built.It is argued that Constantine was a shrewd politician, when he won victory to become Roman Emperor with the support of the Christians. He allowed the christians to build a church of this place just outside the walls of Rome on the site of the Barracks of the Imperial Guard who have supported his defeated rival . In doing this he did not offend existing religious practises

A Roman Holiday. It is worth while making the trip away from the centre of Rome to St John Lateran, which and not St Peter's is the mother church of the Roman Catholic Church throughout the world. It is also much less crowded than St Peter's and you do not have to book or queue, and can wander round at your leisure. The sanctuary is both unusual and magnificent and generally worth spending time there.

Another find. Again, taken on tour by Dark Rome, Ltd. to this major basilica which we would never have heard of or seen. Our tour guide imparted an abundance of information. There also was less tourists here than at St. Peter's Basilica.

The Popes Church - as good as St Peters but quieter. We enjoyed a lovely walk through the streets of Rome to see this magnificent church. We were staying at Campo de Fiori, so this was a little out of our way, but well worth seeing. The statues of the apostles were huge, and each was an amazing piece of artwork. The Basilica is just huge, and would easily fit some of the smaller Roman churches inside a single wing. This is often referred to as "The Popes Church", and you will see it is the equal of St Peters at the Vatican, without all of the crowds, and football crowd mentality. Far more peaceful, just as beautiful, a little less showy, and a must see when in Rome if you like churches.

Beautiful art. All of Rome is an art gallery and this basilica is no exception. Gorgeous statuary, wonderful mosaic flooring, beautiful paintings and the original Pope's church. Well worth a visit. If visiting the cloister, the artifacts are fairly mundane other than the beautiful tapestries. They are lovely.

Low traffic, high art. It was a less crowded and more peaceful version of the Vatican; visitors treated this space with the respect an iconic religious venue deserves. See this, for a breath of true revelation.Within easy walk of the Coliseum.

So Beautiful. One of the most ornate and beautiful Basilicas. It takes a while to get there by bus but it is definitely worth it. Across the street is another church which contains the steps from the Roman Praetorium where Jesus was condemned.

Rome’s Cathedral is Magnificent. Roman's call it their church. The church of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope) was very majestic with its stunning architecture, arches, chapels, and naves. The ceiling itself is a remarkable work of art as well as the line of intricately beautiful statues of all the apostles that leads to the main alter. And, the floor has an amazing decorative inlay of marble throughout.This elegant detail from the floor to the ceiling is just as awe-inspiring as St. Peter's but without the crowds, a much more peaceful experience. The Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is easily accessible by metro (stop San Giovanni), has free entry, and photos are allowed. Definitely a must visit. We combined it with a visit to several of the catacombs (just a bus ride down the road) for a very enjoyable day.

San Giovanni in Laterano. First built by Constantine - although rebuilt since - this church was Rome's most important through the middle ages. It's the church of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope) and all popes were crowned here until 1870. It has the doors to the original Roman Senate house. With all this history you know it's magnificent inside and it is. There is a building beside it that houses the Holy Stairs - supposedly the stairs Jesus walked up on his last day. However, today pilgrims and worshipers do it on their knees - fortunately you can look without doing that.

Grand and impressive!. Huge statues of the Apostles stood spaced out, high above, along the top of this grand Basilica. Its interior was baroque-styled and stunningly striking, especially the high ceiling. Every inch was intricately built and decorated with beautiful paintings. Men in olden days were indeed remarkable. Gazing up above was like seeing Heaven.What touched me most were the Holy Stairs. These were the very steps which our dear Jesus struggled up for His trial with Pilate. There were even bloodstains along some steps.The seat of the Papal Throne was simple yet majestic. We went to venerate St. John's tomb and also to ask him to pray for us.What an impressive, unforgettable place!

Gorgeous cathedral. This is not "another cathedral". It is one of the most ornate with gold and arches and chapels and naves that I have ever seen. It is the cathedral where in times past, the popes were inaugurated. Well worth a visit.

Popes Own Church. The buliding contains the original doors to the Forum over two thousand years old.The interior of the church is breath taking - the ceiling is an amazing work of art as are the line of staues of all the saints that leads to the main alter.You can visit the garden that was completed by Pope Leo XIII - his tomb is contained in the church to the left of the main alter.Many people do not know that this is the Popes own church as he is also the Bishop of Rome - St Peters is the main church of the Vatican.Over the road from San Giovanni are the 'Steps of Christ' - the very ones that he climbed to be judged by Pilot - very special place, you can only climb these steps on your knees,try and arrive early as the place is always packed. The doors of the Forum are at the rear of the church - massive and impressive - as is the entire complex of the Church - its a must see on your trip to Rome.

So much history, so much art!. The Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano is the Bishop of Rome's (Pope Francis) Seat. This normal size church located in the midst of busy Rome is amazingly beautiful. We used the audio guide which opened us to the wonderful art history of this building. The giant sized marble statues of the Apostles surrounding the central part of the church are works of art to behold. So much history, so much art!
Interesting with audio guide. We used the Omnia card audio guide services which brought it to life. A shame you had to pay extra for the cloisters (which we did not).

Don't miss this church. Everyone goes to St Peters but if in Rome make sure you get to Saint Johns in Laterano. It is right off the Red line metro and is well worth the visit. You will find a grand church with fewer visitors and a much more peaceful experience in a palatial atmosphere.

Wonderful church. The rain subsided as we headed for the Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano, one of the largest in Roma. This is a beautiful church, filled with ornate decorations and many religious artifacts. We learned about the jubilee years which happen every 25 years and saw the lovely doors that are only opened for this occasion. Next one happens in 2015.

a most interesting church in a city that has so many. An amazing basilica in a city that boasts almost innumerable other churches. The whole history of the Papacy is encapsulated in this church with its many different styles. The cloisters are very much worth a visit, as is the nearby Scala Santa, where the faithful have to climb the staircase on their knees.
Gorgeous and unexpected. My son and I stumbled upon this amazing structure while walking our first day in Rome. Stunning, gorgeous, not too be missed!
Don't miss this Basilica. Not big but impressive and I enjoyed the ancient feel as well as nice sculptures. Have a close view at the Bothic Baldacchino, it is beautiful.

Mother and head of all the churches of the City and the world. It's the first and the oldest of the papal churches in Rome. I wanted to visit the "Archbasilica" for this reason alone. It's almost as stunning as St. Peter's Basilica. There's a lot of intricate detail from the ceiling to the floor. The ceiling's panels are gilded in gold. The floor has this decorative inlay on marble that was done beautifully in the Cosmati style. There are also beautiful life-size sculptures of the apostles lining the nave. There are just so many different parts of this church that are interesting. You just have to see it to understand why it is ranked in the top 5 of all attractions in Rome.

Don't miss the cloister. After the overwhelming grandeur of the basilica and its side chapels it was an unexpected find. The cloister is accessed next to one of the information desks. It survived the earthquake that damaged the basilica and seems to belong in a rural monastic setting. The iphone video-guide for the basilica was quite good.

One of the my favorite churches. To say you have a favorite church in a city of churches is really saying something. There are statues of each of the 12 apostles lining the center aisle, and each statue is incredibly intricate. Definitely worth the visit!

great. What can you say. The table from the last supper. The communion table of St Peter. The columns from the temple of Jupiter. Columns made from the bronze of ships that belonged to Cleopatra and Mark Anthony. Constantine's obelisk, the door from the roman senate, the skulls of St Paul and St Peter and a magnificent church.
Before Avignon and the Vatican. Where the seat of the Pope was before Avignon and the Vatican. An other lavish place for people who are supposed to live in a simple fashion.
Worth the walk. Really beautiful and interesting basilica. We actually came upon it while we were looking for vinyl records shops. Glad not to have missed it.
Stunning. Amazing statues and details throughout the church. Roman's call it their church, and it's no wonder why. Amazing to see and to experience. Beautiful gold work everywhere.

beautiful church. It is very lovely and interesting. The day after our visit, we walked through and there was a huge protest going on all around the church, barricades and signs and Police everywhere. Apparently it was some Communist group wanting a revolution, I don't know why they chose that spot for the rally. But about 30 Polizia vehicles flew by us with sirens wailing, and when we walked back by later, all that was left was a couple signs.

Stunningly Ornate & Beautiful. This was more impressive than any other church or Basilica (except St. Peters) that I saw, and it has an important place in Catholicism. The sculptures are beautiful. The marble work is amazing. The ceilings were unbelievable... I mean - I personally was more impressed by the ceilings here than the Sistine chapel, but I shouldn't really say that... I mentioned it to a tour guide, and they said I shouldn't compare "apples and oranges" since this ceiling was made in workshops and basically applied to the ceiling in sections...still, it was incredible. The whole place was just stunning. I was there on my first day (and hadn't slept on the plane over at all) so I didn't get the whole emotional experience of being in a place so beautiful... but it is really beautiful! It's free too....except I think there's an outside section you have to pay for but I never went over there.
Stunning. This place is well worth a visit, it was trek for us but we were glad we made the effort. Stunning architecture. Watch out for the street hawkers outside, they are quite persistent.

Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano. We went to see the beautiful apse mosaics. The priests do not make it easy to see them. You must insert one Euro coins in a box at the BACK of the basilica to turn on the lights, which stay on for only two minutes. They are ready to go out by the time you get back to the apse. Bring your own Euros--on one will give you change.

impressive. This was another must see in Rome, what made this awesome is the beautiful and large statues in and outside of the church. The Church was closed due to the attendance of the Pope and the cardinals at a Mass, but our tour guide was not informed and the vatican police in attendance were very abrupt with both the guide and the public. We were able to see only the facade from auite a distance and were constantly hassled by the officious guards.It s well worth to visit it.
Great Church. not very famous on the tourist list, but diffidently a great church to see it was the old papal seat in Rome before the Vatican very nice building and sculpture

Truly amazing. The mother Church of Rome. Just awe inspiring inside and very impressive from the outside too. The side chapels are lively. Avoid all the usual nuisance sellers outside and concentrate on the building.
Beautiful. This is another Catholic Church to visit while in Rome. It is very popular and many tourists found their way here. Always fun to photograph these gold filled edifices.
Amazing church. The history and the detail inside the church along with the history . Impressive outside as much as inside

One of the most beautiful churches in Rome. This is the cathedral of Rome (and not st. Pieters basilique). Very big statues, very nice ceilings. Really impressive. Very reachable by metro (stop San Giovanni).
Magnificent. The church was absolutely worth a visit and is spectacular both inside and outside. It was a little hard to get to but well worth a visit. The mosaics were incredible.

Beautiful basilica. This was just as awe-inspiring as St. Peter's. It is a beautiful church; we went on a Sunday afternoon and were able to walk right in. This church has what I call the Pope Chair - until the Pope sits in it he is not yet considered the Pope. The churches in Rome are gorgeous; you think you've seen the best then you wander into another and think - this one is better. They are all amazing.

The Pope's Church and Rome's Cathedral. Through medieval times, San Giovanni was home of the popes and the center of Catholicism until the new St. Peter's opened at the Vatican during the Renaissance. It is a beautiful church and I loved the history. The Holy Stairs (Scala Santa) are next door! Not to miss when in Rome!

Fascinating. The mother church of Catholicism, and it contained everything we expected, plus some. Personally, I wound up with more pictures and a better experience here than at St. Peter's. A bit more intimate and entertaining.

Rome 2013. I am a Catholic and had no idea this church was the actually older than St Peter's and was the home seat of the Pope. My daughter and I toured this beautiful church and were impressed by the overwhelming beauty and craftsmanship. We were disappointed we didn't make it into Santa Scala as the hours it was open were different.

The most beautiful church in the world. I can't do the Basilica justice in words. You must just go and see this most beautiful church. It's a bit of a trek - past the coliseum but it's well worth it. Call into San Clemente on the way and get a double whammy!!
A must see!!. By far one of my favorite and best place to visit in Rome!!! The church is superb and it is an unbelievable experience. It is close to public transportation and definitely a must see.

Don't miss this church. An important church in Rome you should see. This is the church of the bishop of Rome (ThePope). The exterior is fairly plain, but inside is truly magnificent. Easy to find in Central Rome and we'll worth a visit.

Beautiful big church. This huge church is full of statues and other beautiful decoration. The artwork by itself is incredible, but it is definitely worth listening to the audio guide at one of the little machines - great value at ?2 with 2 earpieces and you learn more about the church. It's not as popular as some churches but is worth a visit as you can walk there from the Colosseum.
Quite beautiful. A lovely place to visit. Beautiful interior with lots to admire. Located next to the building that houses the Holy Steps so worth a visit.

Historically Artistically worth the trip. This is a lovely basilica which is actually more important than St. Peter's Basilica to the history and current Catholic Church in Rome. It is the home church of the Bishop of Rome...in other words the Pope. The available audioguide is somewhat interesting, but if you read up on the church, in advance, you can probably do without it. It is worth paying a little for access to the central courtyard. The audioguide and access are included in the Omnia Roma pass from Roma Cristiana.

Not so well known but worth a visit.. This attraction is easily reached using the Metro (which has only got 2 lines). It is well worth the visit and then it is a comfortable walk up to the Collosseum or you can catch the bus to the catacombs and Apian Way.

Amazing basilica, interesting history. If you don't have a guide, take the time to sit at one of the automated "tour guide" machines near the huge bronze doors at the back (which once stood at the Senate in Ancient Rome and witnessed the murder of Julius Caesar). This church, home to popes for centuries before St. Peter's was built, impresses not just for its history but for the stunning beauty of its statues, frescoes and architecture.

Beautiful!. We were staying only a few block from this church. We walked by it many many times. Do not make that mistake. We finally decided to stop. It is unbelievable. The interior from the walls decorated with frescoes and paintings to the marble floors and the stunning ceiling.
Our hotel was close to this church. This is another amazing church. When in Rome just go into any Church and you will be amazed and even overwhelmed. This is another beautiful church.

Stunning. So breathtaking. Extremely crowded, but seriously take your time. There is so much to see and admire. I feel like I could have stood there forever and still not have seen and really absorb anything.

We almost overlooked it.. Easily the second-most spectacular church in Rome behind St. Peter's Basiica. One of the surprises on our trip. This was the center of the Catholic Church before St. Peter's was built, and where the throne of the Bishop of Rome still sits. Don't miss it.

This has to be the number one Basilica of Italy. The pope has St Peters but also in his role as the Bishop of Rome he has this Basilica. Here the bishop gives mass to the people of Rome it would have to rate as number one of all the Basilicas of Italy. With its breathtaking statues and murals and no lines to stand in it is a must see for all. It is located very close to the Coliseum and Forum, this is an easy site to see. I recommend you pay the 5 euros and get the voice guided tour ‘idevice’ to learn the full history of the church and it surrounding. This is available inside the Basilica.
Beautiful Church. If you have visited many churches, dont miss out on this one because you are tired. It is worth the trip. The Holy Stairs are just across the road as well.

Better than St Peter's!. As majestic or more than St Peter's but much less crowded. It was an awesome experience. Very serene. I connected to this church much more than to St Peter.......you really cannot miss it. After all, it is the church of the Pope, he becomes a real Pope only after he has given Mass in this church.

Unbelievably beautiful on the inside. Breathtaking murals. I think it is more beautiful than the Vatican. No lines to get in and located very close to the Colosseum and Forum, this is an easy site to see. Right across the street are the Scala Sancta ( the steps that led up to the praetorium of Pontius Pilate in Jerusalem, which Jesus Christ stood on during his Passion on his way to trial.)
really pleased to have visited this church. Beautiful ceilings and floor. Lovely and airy. Interesting to see the statues of saints NB San Bartolomeo and his flayed skin!
We didn't know. Totally unaware this was the original vatican. Church doesn't look like much from outside, but the inside is worth the time.

Unbelievable. For a church built in the fifth century..looks like new..very nice... Must visit...it was the first church built in Rome in the fifth century...the altar is very rare to see..very nice church with extremely large marble statues....

St. John Lateran. A MUST see. This is a beautiful church, baptismal building, and the Holy Steps next door. Located a bit away from other sites - recommend a short taxi ride, but well worth the visit.

Great. It's not so easy to find this church, actually nobody tell us about it, but this is a very beautiful church! I think it must be in must see list! this church looks simple outside but it;s awsome inside!

another amazing church in rome. even tho it's a bit out of the tourist path, it's great to get to another area and this massive church..amazing. interesting neighbourhood, excellent flea market behind the church

A must see!. Beautiful basilica. For a small donation we got headphones for a self- guided tour, very interesting and well worth it.
We used the subway to get there, very easy and inexpensive.

Second best to St. Peters' Basilica. Majestic from the inside and the outside. Believe it is similar to St. Peters', though at a smaller scale but then you can appreciate more its architectural features...so nicely decorated at the outside and inside. Though on the other side of Rome, its just 2 stops by metro from Termini station. The Scala Santa just opposite this Basilica is worth visiting.

Lavish Laterano. Yet another lavish , ornate church filled with sculptures, statues and wonderfully painted ceilings. Visit the Cloisters for an extra fee to see some of the oldest relics. Again words can't describe the beauty. Be sure to get at least a postcard or pamplet as photos , if allowed with never do it justice
Nice. Big square near the Basilica. And inside everything is beautiful. But that is too dark to take good photos.

best church in rome. the scultues, the decor, ceiling were wonderfulnot packed with queus like st petersquite with seats to look at the ceiling and just drink in the atpospherethe extrance with its massive sculptures on top plus portico facing was very impressive.

Size is impressive. Not too far to walk to from the Colluseum up the hill. A large church - the second inside Rome city I think, but is spoiled by its surroundings. Based in what could be impressive gardens and a pallazo, is now an area for down and outs and alcoholics sadly

very nice. we have been told that this church was the first house of Vaticano.
is a huge church,could be a main one,is free of entrance and has also a wide yard. the metro station is quiet near,with the same name.
Beautiful. Magnificent basilica, a must-see in Roma. Only negative point is the guys outside trying to sell out their scarves and stuff. Watch out for your belongings.

Simply.... A must see on any trip to ROME.... This cathedral is impressive. It is free to visit but you can also get an audio guide. Get there at least an hour before closing time or you cannot get to the courtyard.

We went twice. This cathedral is impressive with a lot of history. It is free to visit but worth the 5 euro to get the audio guide. We actually visited it twice in 5 days and the second time we visited the holy stairs across the road which also has a terrific history and is renovating the staircase which was bought from Jerusalem many years ago. Climbing those stairs is only allowed on your knees and a prayer is to be said on each step. There is another staircase for those who want to see the piece of Christ's cross upstairs but can't go up on their knees.Well worth a visit.
Beautiful. You cannot imagine the beauty in this church. So much history, so much detail. You'll never see another church like this.
Very impressive, great history. The décor and architecture of the basilica is very impressive with a long history. Recommended for a visit but check opening hours.

The nicest church. In rome. Wow, impressive. This church is one of the cost beautiful churches I've ever seen. Big, a lott of paintings and sculptures. A pitty there was a celebration in the church. But wow this is beautiful.

I regret NOT going inside!. Unfortunately, I didn't realize how small Rome was prior to going on our voyage and didn't prepare for visits in this part of the city. The exterior (front and back) is quite lovely but I didn't realize visits were permitted to the interior. Upon arrival home, I noticed the web-site with camera views... it seems absolutely stunning.

Huge impressive church/cathedral. This church/cathedral used to be the residence of the Pope until the 14th century. It is a huge building with magnificent art works and impressive internal grandeur. I'm not personally religious, but this place is not to be missed.

Incredibly ornate. It is a wonder to look at, though after a while seeing this and so many other churches and Basilicas I was a tad tired of the sheer amount of wealth possessed by the Catholic Church in Rome. It is a beautiful building, the decoration is superb, the statutory excellent, I recommend going if you really love churches and want to see some fine art.I am sick of the adoration of men and the complete lack of female representation, despite the long history of many great women in the Catholic Church, and this church continues the trend with no great women being memorialised.
One of the prettiest churches in Rome. Definitely check this out if you can. It is a vatican church and one of the most beautiful ones. I actually thought it was nicer than St. Peter's.
Lovely. Perfect end to our own tour of Rome. Lovely little gelato stand around to corner; try the strawberry & cream flavour...it's oh so good!

San Giovanni in Laterno. The cathedral of Rome - well worth a visit. Quieter than some other churches in Rome. Easy to reach by bus and metro. Wonderful atmosphere and art. Don't forget to visit the Scala Santa across the road!
lovely church - away from crowds. A great contrast to St Peters. Full of history. Must see holy stairs - they leave an impression on you. Great to get away from the crowds!

Unfriendly treatment after a Holly Mass. I like this church very much. It's a beautiful place, so I went there for a Holly Mass on Sunday at 18:00. The mass finished around 18:45 and I wanted to stay quietly and pray for 5 more minutes. This turned out to be impossible, because the guards started to throw people out of the church (very impolitely by the way), including those who were in the middle of a prayer. I understand that the closing time is 18:30, but in this case the last mass should be early enough, that pilgrims can stay and pray in the church for at least a few minutes. This is what churches are for, as far as I know... This experience made me very bitter.

Our most pleasant surprise of the day. This was a surprise find for us. We were advised to stay clear from using the Metro because it is full of pickpockets so we thought that's the end of our plan on visiting this basilica. Little did we know it's a twenty-minute walk from Santa Maria Maggiore Basilica! This basilica has its own charm. Notable too is that it wasn't as strict as the other basilicas wherein you have to cover your shoulders and knees. The decors were ornate and it houses the tomb of Pope Martin V. It is worth the visit.

The most important. This is the most important CHurch in Rome because the the Church of the Pope is this...In fact S.Peter it is known in all part of world but the main is Sn giovanni il Laterano.In the church you can see one of the four holy Doors.Behind the Church there is also a little baptistery very very nice...And ig you have time look also University near baptistery, there are also there many interesting pictures...
Amazing church. It's a bit away form the city centre but if you enjoy such places it's definitely a must see :) Beautiful paintings, sculptures... Remember to cover your shoulders and knees :)
Amazing. It is amazing place. Church is very nice. It is logical, pope’s residence was there in the past. So, behind the St. Peter’s Basilica, it is the most significant church in Rome.

Beautiful. We didn't spend our time going in many churches- But we were told by one of our servers early on if we were going to go in a Church- this was the one to put on our list! and it did not disappoint! It was breathtaking! And we are so glad we made the walk from our hotel.
Well worth a visit. Very highly decorated and the most important cathedral in Rome, although that is not well advertised. Not at all crowded. A memorable visit.

Great statues line this church. The oldest of the papal basilicas is an outstanding architectural building lined with some of the most amazing statues. The decorations and altar area are worthy of a papal building. The small side chapels are ornate and worthy of spending some time viewing. For an additional charge (5 euro) one can enter the cloister area with a museum holding some interesting artifacts, but I would question its value to the average tourist. If you want to get the most from your visit get and audio guide to let you understand the history of the church. The audio guide is compartmentalized in that it allows you to listen to the part about the church, but the cloister component is only activated once the additional fee is paid. There are other components on the audio that are not accessible which was frustrating.The church requires people to have their shoulders covered and to be wearing near knee length clothing. If you do not comply then you will be denied entry. Shawl sellers do a good trade outside the venue as a result (be prepared to pay about 5 euro). This policy is enforced at most churches we visited.The site is easily accessed from the metro stop at San Giovanni.Time to allow would be about an hour for just the church, but a bit more if you want to include the cloister.

Wonderful. We visited this basilica as part of our day long tour of the Vatican (and associated properties) with Dark Rome Tours. It was quite beautiful and completely covered in gold (or what looked like gold). The ceiling was intricate and the sculptures were notably lovely. It was interesting to find out that there was a supposed piece of the table from the last supper located above the sacramental altar. I was also surprised to find out that this church is the seat of the bishop of Rome and therefore of the pope. So when the pope gives mass he mostly gives it here. I would not have expected that, as we had just come from the more popular St. Peter's Basilica and I would have expected that instead.We visited in January and it was not very crowded. Overall, beautiful church and worth the visit.
Stunning, and peaceful.. Breathtaking artwork, especially the altar & the huge statues of the apostles. A bit of a hike to get there, but well worth the effort.

Huge church. This is the second largest church in Rome, after San Pietro. It is not so easy to access by metro. You might find some buses to get you there, but going by foot might reveal some of the less touristic areas of Rome, where you can see the daily life of residents.

A beautiful cathedral with ornate decorations. This Cathedral was the original Papal Seat prior to the consecration of St Peters. The church has an audio-guide that you can purchase which gives a good history of the church and the intrigues between Borromini (the main designer here) and Bernini

A multi-faceted experience. Like others in Rome, this cathedral is stunning, but we found it a more moving experience when combined with the simplicity of the Holy Stairs across the piazza. After taking in the grandeur of the cathedral's architecture and art, we felt something holy about the sight of people like us, bowing their heads in prayer, moving slowly up the stairs on their knees. And then there was a young priest who lowered himself to one knee in order to speak kindly, face-to-face with a toddler who seemed dubious about the darkened surroundings. We photographed the cathedral's treasures, but we couldn't capture the humanity we experienced across the street.

Breathtaking. The beauty of this church is hard to describe, but it simply leaves you stunned. Sadly we got here a little late in the afternoon and had to rush through our visit, but would definitely return.
Great one.. Girls, you need to cover your shoulder to get in. If you really forget to bring sth to cover it, DON'T buy from the sales in front of the church. You can borrow it from the front counter.
Wow. Locally this building is known as the "Mother of All Churches" once seen never forgotten, it is well named & beautiful !!

This is second only to St Peter's. Opulent but in much better taste then even St. Peter's. Many people enter the church from this piazza - note that it is the back door, and you will get a very different impression of the church if you enter from the front. Read up on the history. Top 5 for Rome and not to be missed.

Nice church. This cathedral is large and the artwork is amazing. I really like the atmosphere here. It is older than St. Peter's but has been remodeled. Now it looks grand. The ceiling is very beautiful. It is free to enter and there is a restroom inside which is convenient.

A marvel to rival St. Peter's. St. Peter's always has the immediate spiritual pull when visiting Rome, however on our 3rd visit (first with kids) we visited San Giovanni. Just as impressive as St. Peter's and very similar in structural style, however a much better experience due to the lack of crowds and ability to soak it in and enjoy in your own time. The ceiling, ancient entry doors and sculptures are to be seen. An added bonus is the Scala Sancta across the road and the holy steps - truly a sight and concept to behold.

A must see at Rome. We like this cathedral better than the St. Peter, less crowded, and giving more time for meditation. The building is impressive with the golden ceiling and the beautiful altar. Don't miss the cloister.

Beautiful and imposing. The Cathedral for the Diocese of Rome - as impressive as you see it on EWTN. They had Masses going on almost continuously, but this did not disrupt seeing things from the tourist standpoint. Across the street is the Scala Santa, or Holy Steps, which is something to definitely go see while here.
The Pope's Cathedral. This is a beautiful building, full of many statues. Also, as Rome goes, it's comparatively easy to visit by car and park up nearby.

Worth the trip. A little off the beaten path, but well worth it, and much calmer than many of Rome's tourist sites. To enter the cloister, which houses some amazing artefacts, costs €5, but it includes a superb audio guide that illuminates the visit.

Beautiful. Probably the most beautiful church I've visited, this is the arch-basilica and the cathedral of Rome. Technically, this is the most important church in Catholicism, and the seat of the Bishop of Rome. The art is exquisite; the icons, the relics of Saint Paul, and the nearby Scala Sancta make this an essential pilgrimage site irrespective of your beliefs.

Must see for the Catholic pilgrim. This is "the" basilica of the Catholic church because it is the diocesan home of the Holy Father as Bishop of Rome. Plan on at least a couple hours here - we were here only about two hours including celebrating mass here; could easily spend four if you try to take in all the majestic sculptures and paintings. This is one of those (there are so many) churches of Rome that practically every square inch, including ceiling, have some significant piece of artwork. It is a must see on your trip to Rome to see sights related to the church and for those not so religiously inclined I still highly recommend you see this for the artistic value alone.

Another impressive example of a Roman Basilica. We visited San Giovanni in Laterano with a tour that also included other sights. This building is huge and very beautiful. It contains two of the famous Holy Doors (only opened once every 25 years) and is very busy with crowds.It is a holy place so shoulders and knees must be covered (there will probably be a hawker outside selling scarves but the larger basilicas usually provide ones you can use).Inside is very big with huge, beautiful statues and an amazing ceiling. The organ was not the biggest we'd seen in Rome though (not important I know but it still came as a little surprise).Definitely worth a visit and a guide can tell you more about it. Very close to the Holy Stairs too xx

Don't miss it. I visited in June 2012. I loved this cathedral and would rank it 2nd to the St. Peters when in Rome. Definitely put this one on your list of places to visit. It's much less crowded as well.
amazing. this is a must see!!! very beautiful and bright. take a walk across the street after your visit and go to the holy steps. A very memorable place

Basilica with Cloister. Well worth the bus ride from Via del Corso. Here one can find various works of art including a fresco by Giotto. The nuns also have a gift shop with lovely souvenirs at very good prices. When visiting the cloister there is also a small museum which one should not miss. Audio guides are available for free. The many statues which line the church add to the beauty of this extremely important church in ecclesiastical history.

Breathtaking. We arrived here on a hot day and found the cool air inside wonderful and then we started to look yes it is one of the four main basilicas of Rome and it has the most fascinating history. We used the headphones with the video before we started to enable us to have a really good idea what to look at well worth the time, as it was not that busy, maybe the heat or maybe as it is so big there did not seem to be a crowded as some places we would definitely suggest to go.

Stunning and lovely. Got lost looking for the Holy Stairs, Found a huge Basillica nearby w/awesome artwork - everywhere. While pleasantly lost, we wondered onto the pontificant university area, and we were not chased away, even when we were beyond the gate. Finally found our Holy Stairs, prayed & climbed, then cooled off w/Gelato. It was not crowded, no one bothered us, never got picked.
Huge, overwhelming. Worth a look. Very large and impressive, and a good place to get out of the sun on a hot day of course!

Do not miss this church!. It had the best audio guide (on iPods!) complete with history and art information. Borromini put the final touches on the church’s architecture. It houses enormous sculptures of the saints along the main aisle, frescoes on the walls near the altar, and an ornate baldacchino over the high altar.

One of the wonders of Christian Rome. A very impressive Basilica that even if at first glance seems to be stark then one realises that it has wonderful monuments inside like the memorial to Leo XIII and the tribune in the apse
Historical Church. Worthwhile visit of a very historic church in Rome. Much to see in this beautiful church and the surrounding area. Would recommend some research of the church prior to a visit.
Beautiful!. It is amazing how much was spent on Basillicas back in the day. This was very nice and this is actually the Pope's Basillica.

Don' miss this marvelous church. Yes, we know that there are many churches in Rome and you can not visit all so, do not miss this one. Its interiors are amazing and you can walk from the Colosseum or use the San Giovanni metro station. Reserve at least one hour to enjoy it.

Place to stay with yourself.. You can read a lot about it in travel guides, and be surprised by inner decoration, but if you are in, go through the main building to the inner yard, the door is on the left hand side if you facing the altar (you'll have to by a ticket). Thats the really place to go. Unfortunately you can't enter the yard itself, but you can walk the perimeter of it, just looking around. In you want to visit&feel the Scala Santa (3 minutes from Basilica), please note that it opens in the morning (approximately 8.30-11.00) and in the evening (15.00-18.00).

So peaceful and grand. It's the church of the Popes, the Papal Throne is there. I am partial to St Francis of Assisi and so I love visiting the statue outside. It's incredible the art and architecture.
GIANT BASILICA. Magnificent basilica, once home to the Vatican and home of the popes. Statues, paintings and intricate inlaid stone floors.
Saints staring down at you. Beautiful achitecture, peaceful church, send a postcard from here! Close to the Colosseum and all other attractions. Awe inspiring.
Beautiful. Oh my ...this basilica is well worth the trip. It is not far from the old city center and beautiful to see.

A Nice Place for Families and Couples Alike. For any visitors, keep in mind that this is the designated gay neighborhood in Rome, so if you have any problems with people of the same-sex openly expressing their affection, I'd stay away. My family has no problems with any of this, and we found our stay very pleasant. All of the locals and store-owners were kind and friendly, and we had no problems with noise or anything at night. The party area is closer to the front of the street, though, and we were staying towards the middle, so be mindful of that if you're staying in that area and wish to get a good night's sleep. Prices are fair, location is convenient, company is good...I would highly recommend and stay again!

breath taking. one of the best in Rome ...Loved it !!! the paintings were amazing ...I went there on Sunday so they had some ceremonies which was interesting ...women should cover their shoulders ...entree its free but for the garden they sold ticket for 5 Euro !!
Amazing architecture. Not the biggest fan of churches, but this is an amazing building that has to be viewed first hand. Te cloisters hold a lot of artefacts and the history is fascinating.
More "wow" than St. Pete's. Older and layered in more, history and adornment than St Peters even. If I have to choose between visiting one or the other, I tend to go with St John Laterano.
Nice church. great architecture, good service, very historical and a lot of nice and big statues.... not far there is also the sacred steps

Good. This is no St. Peter's basilica but it is a beautiful church and had fantastic artwork. Inside the church was this pope buried in a tomb who had died ages ago. The ceilings were also amazing and the whole structure was massive.

Most grand Church in all of Rome (St. Peter's is not in Rome). Well the reviews were not wrong: San Gionvanni in Laterano is very, very grand. Scale, artwork, gold, number of chapels, statutes, etc. It's almost obscene its so lavish. But then the Pope is the Bishop of Rome, and when in Rome this is his church, so go figure. The statutes are awesome, especially the one of St. Thomas. It was worth the journey from our summer home in Trastevere, so good call reviewers.
WOW. A well kept secret in Rome. Don't miss it. Can't believe there were hardly any people there. Like having your own private cathedral.

Beautiful and one of the most historical churches in Rome.. This church is definitely a must see. Too many people are clearly shallow in their expectations. It is not the biggest church, nor is it the most gaudy, but it was the FIRST church built around 312 AD. It has gone through several remodels over the years, but each attempted to keep the church true to its original heritage.It is replete with historical significance being commissioned by Constantine shortly after Christianity was allowed to be practiced in the empire.It has many fantastic archaeological features as well and was first seat of the Pope. Not being catholic myself, it was a fascinating journey through the beginning of the catholic faith during the reign of Constantine. If you love history (and some cool art) this is a must see place. It actually has a ton of character that makes it much more interesting than many other churches in Rome.

Beautiful!. Personally, I am not a huge fan of looking at cathedrals, having seen quite a few in Europe. However, San Giovanni Laterano was unexpectedly beautiful, and one of the more beautiful ones I have seen in Italy, but then again, I have not been to St Peter's, so I am not sure. From the floor, to the walls to the ceilings, everything was decorated and well designed. Knowing the history of this cathedral is highly recommended.

Not bad, but that's all. It's not bad, but it's nothing as important as they say. It's beautiful on the inside, but small. A little bit of wasted time for me, as i was far from it and had to take the metro and foot to get there. Like that church there are many more in Rome, so don't bother unless you're in the area
Beautiful church-- my kids' favorite. Gorgeous cathedral-- even my 9 and 11 year old boys were blown away. They liked it more than St. Peter's.

Off the beatten path and not included in most tour but well worth a visit.. If you have time, visit what was the original Cathedral of Rome and papal residence before St.Peter or the Vatican existed. It was just a few blocks from our hotel and not far from the Colosseo so we decided to visit one morning before our scheduled city tour. You can get a free audio tour at the entrance. You need to leave an ID, and donations are suggested. Do a little research on the history of the basilica on-line and you will not be dissapointed. If you have time I recommend you pay the few euros to do the self guided tour of the cloister. We did not have time, but wish we did. We only saw the pictures posted outside and it looked very appealing. Oh well.... we need to go back to Rome then :-)
A place to visit.. It was awesome. This is where the Pope actually becomes Pope and it will not disappoint. The interior is amazing and you will take lots of photographs.

Massive yet beautiful. Huge church. It was as grand as St Peters. We walked there on the walking tour of the 4 major basilicas. The tour was a great way to see 3 of the 4. We did the Vatican as an entirely different day.
St John Lateran. The first (legal) Christian church in Rome. It is a grand and imposing edifice, full of history and artifacts, e.g. the bronze doors from the Roman Senate house and lots more.
Amazing. Another beautiful papal basilica with 12 life-size sculptures of the apostles. The octagonal baptistry next door was also worth the visit.

surprise!. We went because it was stormy and wanted to escape being outside after the Colliseum. While St Peter's is what it is, the scale is not as appreciated because everything there is at scale. in SanGiovanni in Laterano, the home of the Popes before St Peter's, it not as built to scale and so you appreciate the enormity a bit more. Also the side cloisters are very interesting. Well worth a little trip up the hill. Stop at San Clemente too.
A must see sight. Great stuff inside and out! I have seen quite a few churches in Italy but this one is certainly among the top few. The intricate artwork inside is truly amazing.

The statues, the statues. Fantastic and impressive sculptures fill this grand Cathedral ("The Pope's Cathedral"), and make it a great stop for lovers of marble art. Part of the Vatican as per the Lateran Treaty, so as stated by others: dress accordingly or bring a (long) scarf or two.
Amazing. The sculptures are unbelieving amazing , the space it's huge, and the structure of cathedral is imposing.

Beautiful and imposing. This is the Cathedral of Rome and has the atmosphere to match. Beautiful ceiling, huge imposing statues and some stunning artwork. Free to enter but please respect the environment you are in; dress accordingly.
Beautiful. Beautiful nearly as stunning as St. Peter basilica. Visited as part of Roma/Omnia card with head phones etc to tell you all about it

aka Rome's Cathedral. Absolutely stunning site, with beautiful interior, with nearby the Sante Scala, the Holy Stairs. Interesting to see, with queues of "the Faithful" waiting to ascend the 28 steps on their knees. This is claimed to be the staircase that Christ ascended on his way to his trial.

Felt like i'm in Heaven!. As soon as i entered this church, i burst down and cried! Sooo beautiful and unexplainable experience! The architecture and all of what there is it was perfect! Its a place which u highly recommend and when ever i come back to rome it will be another visit for sure. The member of staff was also helpful and sweet!

An important site in early Christianity. We had a great tour in Rome on the history of early Christianity and it was very interesting. It's church was a stop and while a fast visit, interesting to see the different styles inside. And this church had bathrooms! Always a plus.
Relic. The original table from the last supper can be found here! You'll have to ask the staff to point it out for you!

San Giovanni in Laterano - Stunning Church - not to be missed!. We visited numerous churches while in Rome. Before our trip we thought that St Peter's would be the highlight church. St Peter's is over the top amazing but also packed with tourist and cameras and noise. By contrast, San Giovanni in Laterano was quiet, festooned with amazing art, from the golden pillars to the Pope's chair. There is a beautiful tranquil air about the church. It is located just a few blocks from the Metro stop, which was also nice.

Very Large Cathedral. This cathedral is extremely large. It is worth seeing because of it's history and it is the official ecclesiastical seat of the pope. It is the oldest Basilica in Rome. It is older than St. Peter's Basilica, it just does not look like it. Earth quakes and fires took it's toll on the old church. The interior of the new church was designed mostly by Borromini. I'll just say it is very grand!
Great Place. Must see if you are in rome. We had passed by a few times but avoided it as a few coached had just off loaded a lot of people

Overwhelming. Have seen many churches in Rome and this is overwhelming, to think of all the hard labouring that man did for the construction. Went to Sunday mass there just beautiful. To think our new Pope said his first Mass there just weeks ago, and we were there. Make this church a must see. MB & Frank Ohio

Pompous and overpowering. Vast, gold, pompous... Nowhere else can one see what power the church had in its time than in this particular Basilica... It's almost overwhelming in its splendour. Definitely worth seeing, but one is relieved to get outside.
Top Ten churches to see. Great up there with the best Churches in the world as must see. Also check out the Scala Santa across the street and the pilgrims who cover it.

Breath taking. This little known church is simply amazing. The history of Christianity is swelling inside. Don't miss a trip across the street to the church that holds the "holy steps" those crawled up by Jesus during his suffering. No lines, few crowds, must see.
Great Spot with majestic views. Great side trip from Florence. The town is in the hills and has most of the original buildings preserved and the streets are cobble stone.
In awe. Rich in history and ornamentation, San Giovanni in Laterano is a must see for the faithful or simple art appreciation.

i love this place. go there you will not regret it. i took my entire family. heaven on earth
i will go go back many times

Special place. San Giovanni is ome of our favourite memories - its stunning and there is a beautiful peace there. Not crowded and people just seem to have respect for the history. Free to enter but worth paying to view the Laterno exhibition and cloisters - crazy, wonderful pillars surrounding this small oasis of peace in the city. Fantastically ornate ceilings, walls and floors and everything really but staffed by people who clearly love it. Audio guide available but you need to leave some ID as despot and I was nervous about leaving our passports in an unlocked drawer and a frequently unstaffed stand so we couldnt take advantage of this so worth taking some ID that is slightly less precious if lost! Beautiful and awesome and definitely highly recommended>

San Giovanni in Laterano. It's a little off the beaten path maybe, but this was our favorite church in Rome. The main hall of the church has incredible sculptures of the apostles and evangelists (old testament on the left, new testament on the right). The Catholic Church calls this "the mother of all churches" and they're right. Really awe-inspiring.
Mother of Church. IF you want to see a beautiful church, you would have come and visit. You could take a metro to get there, but beware of pickpocket in the subway!

One of the most beautiful basilicas in Italy. Really worth a visit. Breathtaking marble statues all over the basilica. Even without any audioguide, the basilica is still very interesting to just walk around and admire.This is definitely one of my biggest impressions from the whole Italy trip.

The Pope's Church. Marvelous place to visit...especially given that this is the Pope's cathedral (not St. Peter's!). We booked this tour as part of a general tour package that took us through all the major basilicas in Rome. The art and history here is something that should not be missed.

Don't miss this basilica. Having been to Rome four times I have done the big sights before, but somehow missed this one. It is monumental inside and outside. Very muched enjoyed the bronze doors from the Curia in the Roman Forum as well as the breathtaking sparkling mosaics inside.

Awe-Inspiring Experience. I was actually traveling with friends and left them to see a couple places that I'd already been to in order to see San Giovanni in Laterano. The exterior of the building is nice but nothing special, certainly not in Rome.However, once you go inside everything changes. I was lucky to be there when it wasn't crowded (maybe a couple dozen people), and just sat alone in the large hall and looked around. To me the experience was awe-inspiring. Everything in this church is a work of art, the hall is huge and there is so much to look at. I sat there for about half an hour and didn't want to leave.Basically imagine St. Peter's Basilica, only with more statues, no noise, a lot less people, and places to sit. You can imagine how even for a non-religious non-Christian like myself, the experience was amazing.
Suddenly you feel a presence!. My first introduction of "monumental" statues of Rome and the inspiration they must have imparted to the believers as they made their pilgrimage to Rome.

One of the Pope's Churches. Rome is filled with churches, and it's mind-boggling...just walk into any random one you pass and you'll find artistic miracles within. St.John Lateran is one of the largest and most important...and one of the most beautiful. Don't miss the baptistry in an adjacent building.
walked outside. lovely building, indian men selling scarves outside are rude and pushy, would suggest to avoid them! very beautiful area
INCREDIBLE!. There is no way to describe this Papal Bascilica. It takes your breath away. A MUST SEE Take the Hop On and Hop Off bus which drops you right by the church.

You need to visit it!. IF you are in Rome and you dont visit this Basilica, you make a big mistake! This place is simply WONDERFUL! A lot of history on the wall (and the roof) and You will really good in it! You must GO!

Must Go. When you are in Roma you will have the possibility to visit All kind of monument and churces but, as you go to San Pietro, you must go to San Giovanni in Laterano Basilica. Impossibile to give you 1 reason, you'll discover 1000 when inside.
Well worth the trip. San Giovanni is a beautiful church. It is quiet and less busy than other churches, with much history to take into account. Make sure you take time to visit the cloister.
Very Nice Church. This is actually the Popes seat NOT Saint Peter's. Go to this church if you have the time it is nice to see.

Arch Basilica of Catholic Church. What a surprise to find that this church (not St. Peter's) is the highest church (Arch Basilica) in the Catholic church and was where most of the popes were crowned. Beautiful church with fantastic dynamic statues of the 12 apostles. Not many tourists come here but it is incredibly important.
Great church to visit. The statues that line the main isle are unbelievable and the main altar of gold is beautiful.. Of course it is smaller than St Peters but more beautiful in many ways...

A Must See. The Church is unbelievably gorgeous -- statues are stunning. DO NOT MISS the Santa Scala across the street -- these are the steps from Pontius Pilate's palace. You are only allowed to climb them on your knees -- a prayerful experience.

Off the main beat well worth the walk. Yet another stunning church in Rome. Great that it is a little more peaceful and less touristy than some of the other attractions. Marvelous art and statues inside.
Beautiful Cathedral. I found out about this while visiting St. Peter's. It is actually the Pope's seat in the Catholic Church. Amazing architecture.
beautiful!. This is such an impressive visit. Unbelievable beauty. Hard to imagine how this construction happened so many centuries ago.

Amazing scale, and a neighborhood different from the center. I wanted to see this church because of the historical nature of the site, so hopped the Metro which stops very near. I did not see historical remnants (maybe I did not stay long enough), but the church that stands there is awesome in size and the interior is almost overpowering. I am not saying whether I liked the way it was done, only that I am certainly glad that I saw it.

Bronze doors. To rival St Peter's. The big feature here for us were the bronze doors. Huge and so very old, from the old Roman Senate if I remember correctly, and they still work. Lay your hands on them and feel the history vibrating. Need to be on the inside to appreciate them.

Beautiful church.. Can get there directly by metro and its free. Large and amazing to see how the wealthy even in death had statues of slaves and servants on their crypts.From there take the bus 218 to the catacombs.

Buy gifts here. This is a holy place. It is much cheaper to buy any gifts here than anywhere else we visited. The statues were humongous. There were fewer people around so we just sat and enjoyed the quiet.

Worth the trip!. This is a magnificent Church, the original build around 318 by Constantine. It has 30 ft high bronze doors from the Roman Forum. See this before you see the Vatican to truly be able to appreciate it.
must see. take a tour Tree basilica . You can really see amazing art . Our tour guide was very informative and make all so intresting

Some of the best sculpture work anywhere in Rome.. Go for the 12 or so 12 ft+ sculptures along the main run of the basilica. The relief work directly above each is stunning. Pictures do NO JUSTICE to this place.

One of the most beautiful churches I've ever been to.. I can't say enough about how stunning this church is. I wanted to see as many churches as I could and when we walked in to this one, my breath was literally taken away. If you are in Rome, please go see this church. It's beautiful.

Stunning. An incredibly beautiful place to visit, you may have a stiff neck by the time you leave or a sore jaw from walking around with your mouth open but it is worth it. Walked there from our place near the Termini was an enjoyable wander through the surrounding neighbourhood. Put it on your list.
Worth a prologed visit!. Take time for your tour inside the church, you will learn a lot if you use the special audioguide. Every chapel has an history, you will marvel
Impressive doors and statuary. The statue of Constantine on the porch was quite impressive. Unfortunately, the nearby Holy Stairs, which we were told were worth seeing, were closed.

Amazing experience. This cathedral is a must if you visit Rome. The history will leave you in awe. The Pope's chair sits on the altar..the steps that Jesus crawled carrying the cross are on the grounds of the church...so many artifacts of the church are there. What an wonderful feeling you get just walking into the cathedral..it stays with you. This was the Vatican before the vatican was built according to our guide. Wow,that's some history.

Must see. Most tourists put the Vatican on the must see list, understandably but this is the first Christian church that was built by Constantine. It is the mother of all Christian churches and dates back way before the Vatican - across the street is a building that holds the holy steps that was said to have been taken from Israel and has drops of Christs blood on them. The church is the burial place of Pope Martin and contains many works of art. There are bathrooms, a museum and gift shop
beautiful. Beautiful place to visit, dont miss it! Many churches in Rome are beautiful. this one is exceptional, I can compareit only to St. Peters cathedral

just gorgeous. how ignorant can certain tourists be to rate this masterpiece with less than 5 stars?! REALLY???I suppose some people just lack good taste....they should rather visit las vegas...We loved this basilica. every corner of it. most people don't visit the baptistry right behind the church. it is even more beautiful than the church itself!!!!!

Magnanimous. It was a bit of a walk, but worth it! We escaped some of the crowds and were very impressed! I would recommend going later in the day around 5pm when things thin out. Not sure if it is more crowded earlier, but we were thankful to escape the noise and chaos at that time.
Wonderful building. A very spiritual experience. The audio-guide is excellent. The cloisters are a an oasis of peace in this hectic city.

A gem often missed by tourists in Rome. This is in effect Rome's cathedral and a very beautiful church. It was the first building of public worship erected in Rome and in the entire Christian world - it's beginnings in the reign of Constantine the Great. Tourists flock to the Coliseum but miss this wonderful building with its amazing history.

Sooooooooo Gorgeous!. My daughter pulled me in and I think I can say that this is one of the finest churches I've ever been in. It was bright with light, had awe inspiring statues of the saints, fabulous columns from the Temple of Jupiter and the most amazing brass doors from The Senate House in the Forum. Well worth the visit.

Amazing first basilica in Rome. It was quieter to visit with less tourists, masses were conducted regularly, it is absolutely beautiful, and its the popes church as bishop of Rome. Bronze doors on the front were brought from the Forum. Constantine had the basilica built. St. Peter and Paul relics are there. So much to see and easy to get around.
THE most impressive. Ok, ignore my previous review... this is the most impressive church, after the vatican. Unreal ceiling, paintings and huge, huge statues right down the middle. A must see!

Beautiful Basilica. This was a beautiful cathedral, lavishly decorated, an impressive and inspiring place to visit. The mosaic floors containintricate patterns, the golden ceiling is beautiful. The ciborium over the altar is a work of art in itself.
visiting rome. overall beauty and magnitude of the basilica. Side chapels were beautiful and the variety of the art work was astounding
Great cathedral!. Very beautifull cathedral inside and also you can find here great silvered sacred pictures (icons) of Jesus! I advice this place to all who goes to Rome at vacations!

A must-see for Catholics visting Rome. San Giovanni in Laterano is the Bishop of Rome's cathedral and therefore the mother church of all Christianity. San Giovanni is magnificent in its beauty and importance, and it is much less overrun than St. Peter's. A good time for silence and prayer. Don't forget to visit the Scala Santa (Holy Steps) across the street.
I love san giovanni!. It is THE PLACE to get a feel for how christianity got adopted by the romans thanks to the audioguide which free, but donations accepted and passport etc to be left as security.

A Beautiful Basilica. The Basilica of St. John Lateran is the oldest Christian church in the world and was commissioned by Constantine the Great. The cathedral was dedicated to the Savior on November 9, 318. Pope Sergius III added John the Baptist to the basilica’s dedication in the 10th century. Pope Lucius II added John the Evangelist in the 12th century.Pope Innocent X decided in 1646 to restore the cathedral and assigned Francesco Borromini to repair the church. He put 12 niches, which today contain large statues of the Apostles that were made by sculptors in the beginning of 1700. The main façade is the one facing east and was the work of the Florentine Alessandro Galilei and is dated 1732-1735. It was inspired by the work of Palladio. It is the seat of the bishop’s residence and considered the Cathedral of Rome, since the Pope is also the bishop of Rome. The church has one nave flanked by two aisles and ends in a semi-circular apse to the west. There is a 14th century Gothic ciborium created by Giovanni di Stefano. Under this ciborium (at the end of the central aisle, in the transept) is the papal altar where only the Pope can give mass.There is an apse bowl which has a mosaic with God appearing on the upper part. Below is the Virgin Mary. To her left are the figures of Paul and Peter and St. Francis on a small scale. To her right are St. John the Baptist, St. Andrew, St. John the Evangelist and St. Anthony of Padua on a small scale.
great space. beautiful space; interesting area to walk around. much less touristy than St. peters. free audio guide useful

Excruciatingly ancient. For Christians this a must-see pilgrim church with relics that include the heads of Saints Peter and Paul; the Holy Umbilical Cord; and wood from the table used during the Last Supper and in an adjacant building, the Holy Stairs (Scala Santa) which were taken from the palace of Pontius Pilate where Jesus walked on the way to be crucified (drops of his blood can still be seen on them). As non-Christians, we found it all a bit gruesome but interesting and worth seeing.

Great (with one reservation). One of many great basilicas in Rome, this one is the city's cathedral and great both inside and out. Unfortunately, whilst Rome is fairly litter-free, the grounds of San Giovanni were unloved and litter-strewn.
Don't miss this just because it is a little outside the main tourist area.. A truly amazing basilica with an outstanding ceiling. Huge in size, even if it is dwarfed by st Peter's.
many thanks and god bless you.. to the kind person who found my red purse in the church thank you thank you , there r some honest people in this world. rose
Another fantastic church. Our second visit, had to return to show our daughter what a fantastic place this is!!! The cathedral for Rome , the Pope's church and truly magnificent!!!

St John does well. Awesome church, you need to go to experience it. Thats all I can say. From standing outside and thinking how did they get those carvings up onto the roof, to thinking how could so many brilliant artists be in one place. Better than the Vatican
Gorgeous. Amazing church with such elaborate decor. Lots of gold, huge statues. Truly a gem. Perhaps even more beautiful than St. Peter's and definitely not as crowded.

Ridiculously overdone. This church was very close to our appartment, so we made sure to pay a visit. The church has an incredibly heavy baroque style, somehow managing to seem overdone in a city chock-full of massive (baroque) cathedrals.

The Pope's Cathedral!. My husband and I recently visited this cathedral on our last day in Rome. It is a very beautiful cathedral with a gorgeous ceiling and many interesting paintings. They allow you to visit during the Mass but you must stay away from the central area (it is roped off) if you are not partaking in the mass. Please remain silent and do not distract the congregation by taking photos. Remember to dress appropriately, covering your knees and shoulders.
Add this to your must see list. This church is one of the first where a new Pope holds mass. The building is really impressive and on a level with St Peters for amazing statuary.

The oldest Cathedral of Rome!. I liked interesting to know that Popes lived in the Lateran Palace, until the Vatican was build. I liked beautiful decorations! Also the façade of the Cathedral is Baroque look.
Beautiful. This was the first of many churches and basilicas that we visited while in Rome. The detail and artwork are beautiful. Make sure that you visit the cloister.

of great historical importance in catholicism. entrance is free and you only pay an audioguide for 6 euros. It's very good! You can also see when priests are doing mass there. At the end in the main altar there is a "throne" were the pope sits. I think only the pope can do mass in the main altar in this church.
Seat of the Pope. This is the Popes's official Cathedral so it has enormous meaning to Catholics around the world. The plaza infront has recently been renamed to John Paul II

Pretty and cool to see the Senate doors. We enjoyed this church. It is considered the first Vatican. When Constantine legalized Christianity he had this church built. He took the doors off the Senate building and put them here where you can still see them today.
St John Lateran. Not much to say for the Pope's official church. As awesome as St Peter's. If you are looking for the majesty of renaissance Rome, you have to stop there.

not to be missed. This beautiful huge church is often ignored by the open topped bus tours due to it's unglamourous location near part of the old city wall. Yet it is the cathedral church of the Pope's Diocese and quite stunning. Particular features are the frescoed Tabernacle and the lovely Cloisters. I'm assured that the faithful climb the ourtside steps on their knees but we gave that option a miss !
Nice Church, beautiful frescos. We spent a day to visit most churches in Rome. This is one of nicest churches there. You need to know visiting hours of churches in Italy.

Best Bascillica in Rome. In my humble opinion, with the exception of St Peter's, this is the finest church in Rome. The original Papal Church, the first Christian Church in Rome, and still Rome's official Cathedral, and the Popes seat as the Bishop of Rome.
Sort walk from the Colosseum, definitely go take a look.

The Mother of all Churches. This church did not disappoint. Although off the main tourist area of the map it was well worth the detour. We thought that most of the treasures would have been removed to St Peters, when that became the new Vatican, however there are some amazing sights to see in this beautiful church. The vastness of this building, the statues of the apostles in the main aisle and make sure you go out into the cloisters, worth a few euros extra.

One of the most impressive churches I have ever been in!. There is absolutely nothing I did not like about this basilica. It is free, it is beautiful, and welcoming! You have to visit my friend Sylvester in the gift store! He is the nicest person I have ever met. I have gone back at least four times to see him and of course, the basilica. See you soon Sylvester! Ciao!

Amazing. This basilica was beautiful and overwhelming to walk through. I highly recommend this stop. I also recommend heading across the street to the Saint John of Lateran basilica and the Holy Steps.

THE MOST SPIRITUAL BASILICA ON EARTH!! !!. My husband and I decided to visit Europe for our honey moon. We spent 1 week touring parts of France, and 2 weeks mainly in northern Italy...3 weeks were not enough. There is so much culture and history there..not to mention the breathtaking art and glamorous churches and basilica's! The Scala Sancta (the Holy Stairs) are the wooden steps where Jesus Christ walked on his way to be sentenced to death by execution orded by Pontius Pilate in Jerusalem. You can go up the stairs by kneeling, not walking up them. The steps are extremely hard,..so our knees decided to only make it about half of the ways up! There is definitely an opportunity to feel a spiritual presence while praying on those steps!!

Big and beautiful.. Big and beautiful. That's how you can summarize this church. Not as busy as the st peter basilica but as beautiful. The Lateran Basilica, is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome. Definetly worth a visit!

St John Lateran. Just a beautiful church to visit. very interesting, busy but yet peaceful visit. Lovely little souvenir as well. We walked from the Trevi Fountain area and it didn't take that long. Well worth a visit
Easy access!. So called Pope Basilica!It is beautiful and free. The cloister is nice but it not worth 5 Eur visiting it!
As good as St Peters. We enjoyed St; Johns as much as St Peters. The art is stuning. Also, the "Holy Steps" were the most moving experence we had in Itayl.

Great surprise. This church wasn't on our itinerary, but it was near our closest subway station, and was absolutely magnificent. The imposing statues of the twelve apostles were stunning (I especially loved the statue of Saint Philip), and the large front doors, entrance area and marble work were terrific.
So glad that I didn't miss this sight!

Just jaw dropping.. On the last morning of our trip to Rome, we needed one more thing to do.Thank goodness we went here, it is certainly one of the largest and most beautiful of chuches we have ever visited.I hindsight this should be the place in Rome you visit first!This had to be good-it is the Popes church as Bishop of Rome
