My favourite church in Rome. Absolutely breathtaking, you could spend hours here. Opposite the church, there is a building which houses the Holy Steps and also the Sancta Sanctorum (Holy of Holies) Chapel. The church itself is a must see for everyone just for the sheet opulence and Catholics will definitely want to make the Holy Steps a stop.
stunning. A magnificent church. It is 20minitues away from Colosseo. There is a metro station near. You should also visit Santa Scala, which is across the street
Well worth a visit!. A lovely Church, almost as fabulous as St. Peter's. A very ggod shop for religious items reasonably priced.

Incredibly Beautiful. Incredibly beautiful and full of history. I highly recommend visiting this beautiful facility. Be sure to take time to peek in to the side chapels as they offer as much beauty as the main cathedral.

Wonderful Experience. An absolutely beautiful church. Hard to take it all in during one visit. #1 on next visit list. Rome visitors should check the schedule for potential Sunday Papal Mass at San Giovanni.

a mini St. Peter's. This is the Pope's church as bishop of Rome. Definitely should be included in any itinerary. Beautiful architecture and statues. Certainly has the feel of a mini version of St. Peter's Cathedral.
Huge Statues of the Apostles. Loved the huge statues of the apostles. The entrance is an easy incline with short steps which also lead your eyes to the church.

Unknown Beauty. I had never heard of San Giovanni but was taken there on an organized tour. It is an extremely beautiful church and we were told it is actually the Pope's church even though it is outside the Vatican City. The side altars are an unending reveal of beauty. Find this building and immerse yourslef.

Breathtaking. Loved visiting this church "The Pope's Cathedral" - it was beautiful and awe-inspiring, and historical being the first church to be built in Rome. That fact, all by itself, makes it worth visiting! Easy to find from the Metro stop, and definitely worth the side trip when visiting the Colosseum.
Dont Miss. we were stunned by the beauty of this church. The size and history really conect you with the past. The side altars are as beautiful as the nave.
It is amazing church!. This roman church is with amazing interior! So opulent and magic!!! I visited it 2 time for 2 days :-)))
Beautiful. This is a beautiful church that a 15 minute walk from The Coloseum and San Celemente. I really enjoyed visiting this church. It's worth visiting on the day you plan to visit he Coloseum.
Don't miss!. One of the places off the tourist track that is definately worth the effort!! It is one of the great Cathedrals of Rome and is under appreciated!
What a ceiling. In one of Romes basilicas the visitior finds a beautiful ceiling and a stunning mosaic. If You are into churchhistory and art - San Giovanni in Laterano is a must.

Don't forget to look at the floors!. The Medieval Cosmati work in the basilica, cloister and baptistry is exceptional. Go for that if nothing else. I really enjoyed my English-language tour of their museum (entrance on the right off of the narthex--if you enter the church you've gone too far). The museum is only open via guided tour. I was the only one there for the time I chose, so had a private tour. The museum is officially called the Museo Storico Vaticano (Palazzo Apostolico Lateranense). Guided tours at 9:00-10:00-11:00-12:00, and last just under an hour. A small cafe/bar is nearby if you need to sit while waiting for the next tour. There is a long, shallow flight of stairs (no elevator). You can see a complete set of a knight's armor (they were very short back then), Mussolini's signature, miniature cannon. You don't have to be a Catholic or an historian to enjoy this museum.
Beautiful church!. This church is amazing! The outside is beautiful but walking in takes your breath away! Highly recommend a visit. Other churches in the area worth seeing- St. Clemente

Humbling experience. This was probably my favorite place that I visited in Rome. There are many cathedrals around and in Rome, but this one was my favorite. The Holy Stairs will take your breath away. Do not leave Rome without visiting this cathedral.

A work of Art. The building holds so many secrets and such history that I spend hours just observing and enjoying the work. I suggest going with a tour group, there is a lot of information that you would not want to miss.

Off the beaten path but worth it. This church used to be the Papal Basilica before it was replaced by St. Peter's. Extensive use of gold and every color of marble makes for a dazzling display. Small shop to right of altar provides good variety of religious items at good prices. Didn't go into the Baptristry or climb the nearby Santa Scala.
A very impressive cathedral. The San Giovanni is a large and rich cathedral, without the kitch. It's worth taking the metro to visit there.
Impressive church. For us maybe the less beautiful of the 4 Papal basilicas in Rome, but nevertheless worth wile to visit.
Place to confess. Church is beautiful and majestic. If you are in need to confess, place provides access to "the service" in many languages.

The Basilica of Rome. This church is an impressing monument. It is the main church of Rome (San Peter is not technically the church or Rome). Has an impressing Mosaic and the Apostolis statues that dominat the main space are of impressing proportions.

Amazing. One of the most impressive church in Rome and seems to be more important than San Pietro Basilica, being the residence of the bishop of Rome, who is also the Pope.
The picture looks pretty much the same like in other catholic churches but the sculptures are not from this planet, for sure.

The crown jewel of our trip. I'd never heard of this place before our trip Easter weekend, and after reading up on in post-visit, I'm a little shocked and kind of embarrassed that I wasn't aware of a place with this much history in Rome. Every part of the interior takes your breath away; can't say enough about the architecture and grandeur of the whole church. It gives you chills just taking everything in; was especially moving being there for mass Easter morning. This is a must-see for any trip to Rome.
Laterano dept.is good!. Very interesting place,worth to see it and read about it. Great spent time.Close even by foot to city centre.

St. Peter's lite.. I stayed here for around about an hour and a half. I'd intended to get Mass for Holy Thursday, but was informed it wasn't taking place. Having time to kill, I decided to explore it a bit, and was taken aback at the beauty of the place. I got Confession instead of Mass, got a good dose of Catholic culture, and discovered somewhere as important (if not more important, as an arch-basilica) than St. Peter's, without the lines. Nice souvenir shop staffed by the loveliest nuns, too!

So many churches so little time...but this one you should see. This is a great church to visit and should definitely be on your list. There are so many to see but this is one that I highly recommend. Sometimes all these churches start to look alike but if you take the time to understand the history that makes each one more interesting. But if you can only visit 5, make this one of the five. Buon viaggio.

Wow! Plus so many attractions nearby. I hadn't been here before and loved it. It is huge inside and the design and sculptures added under the redesign by Borromini are majestic. It is a huge church with wonderful history and is impressive from both entrances. I spent a lot of time inside marvelling at the size, architecture and artworks. It is also close to other great attractions - the Lateran Palace where the popes lived until the early 14th century and the Scala Santa (Holy Stairs). The large city gate Porta Maggiore is also close and worth a look.I caught a bus there and then walked back past the Colosseum and Roman Forum as the sun was setting which was a lengthy but easy walk and the views magnificent - well worth including in your plans (even if you don't get to the church)!
beautiful and impressive. on my first trip to rome i didn't have time to see thi basilica, but i came now and i'm glad i did it.make time to visit it, you will not regret

Impressive and beautiful. This cathedral was awe inspiring. The guildings and the art inside was beautiful. I have a very special link with this church as it was the first that we visited in Rome and I had lost my wallet on the flight over. Upon arriving in the city, I went straight for a church, stopped at the door and said a little prayer. Before leaving the church the airline called and told me that my wallet was located by a member of the cleaning crew and that they were holding it for me. So, I will always return to this cathedral any time I am in Italy.
Very nice building. There are any number of beautiful religious buildings in Rome but this one is pretty special. A lovely building in a lovely area.

scala santa & basilica. my first time at the basilica i was making a bus connection to the catacombs of san callisto. i didn't realize that the 'scala santa' was in the non-descript (on the outside) chapel of san lorenzo across the st from the basilica. so i went a 2nd time to see the steps. i was very moved although i could only kneel on the first two steps (bad knee). it was worth the trip. took bus #85 getting off before the basilica.

Very impressive Catholic cathedral of Rome. I am not a Roman Catholic or even a practising Christian, and generally prefer English cathedrals that are more understated, but this was a very impressive example of a Roman Catholic cathedral. Brilliant mosaics on the floor of the nave.
Beautiful. One of the four Major Basilicas in Rome. Gorgeous, with Mass on most days. Also near the Holy Stairs and Santa Croce in Gerusalemme.
Stunning...worth the time. Other than St. Peter's San Giovanni is the best church in Rome. The statues of the saints are spectacular
Breathtaking. Enter this church and all around you is gone. Unbelievable. The beauty of this church is, so I think, greater than San Pietro. Beautiful paintings in harmony with the church.

Very nice church. The church is very big, it is built in the baroque style, and it hosts the statues of all Apostles, with beautiful symbols related to each. Beautiful mosaic on the floor, and a very interesting and very old door (really huge). The image of the church also appears in the movie Roman Holiday. it is definitely worth visiting!
A definite must visit. The ceilings have recently been cleaned, and are absolutely stunning. The church had some amazing statues and art work, you can spend hours on here just looking...
Beautiful!. The church was amazing. We spent an hour just walking around taking in all the art! Our second favorite church of our vacation...second only to St. Peters!

Huge and beautiful. San Giovanni in Laterano was one of the first churches I visited in Rome, and certaily one of the most beautiful I've ever seen! I think I liked it even more because there weren't many tourists around, no lines or fees to get in, and a very calm and meditative atmosphere. It was build over the remains of a Roman fortress dating the second century AD, and today is the Pope's seat as Bishop of Rome. The main nave is the most impressive, with twelve huge statues of the Apostles. There are also six popes burried there. Take some time to admire the ceiling and the beautiful gothic baldacchino!
Yet another amazing church in Rome. Very interesting because of the close links with the nearly elected Pope. The Papal Altar is very impressive.

The Poverty of the Church on full display.. Ok so, you've been to St Peter's, the most important church in Christendom.....except it's not number 1....it's number 2....THIS is the number 1 church in the world....they say so over the door and it is the Pope's personal church.....what makes it number 1? it is consecrated to Christ himself......that makes this the world's only Arch-Basilica....it was known as the church of gold and is still pretty impressive...not as big as St Peter's...but it's got the best relics in the Sancta Sanctorum...including the actual stairs Jesus walked up to see Pilot....[no joke]....When you'r at the colosseum look down Via San Giovanni....there will be an obelisk punctuating the end....it's a quick 10 minute walk....when you get there you won't be impressed....you have to walk into the church to get the full gist. The Sancta Santorum is across the street and the Baptistry is an octagonal brick affair to the right of the church..they close for a very long lunch!
Popes church as the Bishop of Rome.. Very impressive statuary.The church is large and easy to get to via the Metro. Very historic church.Lateran Conference held here.

AWESOME!. This is one of the most excellent church's in Rome when it comes to statues, beautiful floors, paintings and gold ceilings. It is situated in a nice area and you can shop just around the corner at Mercato Via Sannio.
Huge statues. Larger-than-life statues of the 12 apostles make this church all the more impressive. This is the most important church in Christianity as well.

Favorite Church in all of Rome. Absolutely stunning sculpture and so much history. I believe that each new Pope must say a mass in this church within a certain time of being elected. This is the Pope's (Bishop of Rome) home church. Hoping there is media coverage when new Pope Francisco visits. There are some relics located here - including pieces of the table from the last supper and some bones of some saint - can't recall but remember reading in the Rick Steves guide.The humongous main doors to the basilica are worth a trip in themselves. They were originally taken from the Senate building in the Roman forum. I enjoy visiting this church more than St. Peters which is always so crowded and hectic. You also won't be constantly hounded by street sellers as you are around Vatican City.
Historic site. The interior was amazing and we visited during a service which was moving. Marble statues, stain glass windows, tiled floors and art work all interesting to see.

Well worth a Visit. This building was the seat of the Popes for approximately 1000 years before moving to Avignon in France. Entrance is free but there is a charge if you want to visit the Cloisters / Crypt.

Even after you are sick of churches, this one is worth a look. I saw this church on my last day of a 23 day vacation in Italy. After seeing so many churches, I did not think I could take one more but this one was worth it. I didn't have time for the audioguide but would definitely go back on my next visit to Rome. It was lovely to sit in the church and take it all in after what was a busy last day in Italy. And as another posted commented, the church is in very good condition.

Visit the Apostles. This used to be the headquarters for the popes and is an impressive church with an impressive area of statues and, it is believed, relics of St. Peter, St. Paul, and the Last Supper table. Across the street are the Holy Stairs that Jesus may have climbed.

Put a day aside!. About a 10-15minute walk from the Coliseum is this beautiful Basilica, as the title suggests, i would defiantly put a day aside to visit, hands down one of the best attractions on my trip!After walking around the various Chapels, we strolled across the road to the Scala Santa and Sancta Sanctorum, and seeing the 16th century crucifix was a highlight!Finally again a short little walk away is the Baptistery, a must must visit, (personally my favourite part of the whole day), beautiful artwork tells wonderful stories! (see picture)I'd recommend getting the audio guide sometimes they're a bit hit and miss but this was a iPod with earphones and was by far the best audio-guide i experienced in Rome!No wonder The Catholic Church call it "The Mother of All Churches"....

Another Basillica !. When you think you are all "churched out" and do not want to visit another, then take a break and go visit San Giovanni in Laterano. The architecture and paintings are amazing. And you get to see some Caravaggio's too! Take some time to sit and contemplate in one of the many side aisles. It is spiritually uplifting.
Lovely cathedral to visit. About a 10 minute walk from the Colosseum, well worth the visit. Large and beautifully decorated, it's a real sight to see
Cathedral of Rome. Easy to get to, we caught the Metro to San Giovanni.You must place this on your must see list, make sure you spend time in the cathedral of Rome, very well worth a visit.
Sue J. The size completely blew me away, beautiful, easy to get to using the hop-on, hop-off buses. Well worth a visit.

Yes, you can see one more church!. This is Rome's Cathedral. It has been rebuilt many times and is a splendor to see. The church offers "free" audio guides (donation required) and I do recommend them as there is so much to see. This church also has the relics of Sts. Peter and Paul. Really... go see this cathedral!
Beautiful!. This is one of the most beautiful churches we saw in Rome. Bronze doors on the church are marvelous! It has amazing paintings and mosaics, its just astonishing. Must see!

Fantastic Bassiclica. This is a bit out of the way but the buses do reach here from the Colloseum (you have to buy tickets before getting on-finding a machine was not that easy). It is well worth the trouble as it is on a grand scale and exceptionally beautiful-in my opinion. It is also the first church in Rome-although it has been rebuilt on a number of occasions.

Must visit, close to Colosseum. This is the most beautiful church building I have ever seen, and there are many gorgeous ones in Rome and elsewhere. It seemed every available inch was decorated with painting, marble, gold-effect or polishing - all to glorify God. If you decide to only visit one church, then choose this one; however, I would urge visiting more as they form such a huge part of Rome's history and life.The front is peaceful and awe-inspiring. The roof peers over the top of the work-place buildings as you step away from the metro station towards the old walls. Toilets inside. We walked from here to the Colosseum, calling in at San Clement's en route; it is really not as far as some other reviews suggest.

Beautiful church, and don't miss the Santa Scala.. This church is beautiful, and the 50 foot bronze doors that used to be at the entrance to the roman forum are on the front of the church. The large section of the original city walls are next door, and the Santa Scala directly across the street should not be missed.

Beautiful and convenient. Easy to get to as it is the center of Rome and deservedly it is the cathedral of Rome. Be sure to check out the statues of each of the apostles. Each got there by winning a contest set up by the pope.
Amazing. Well worth a visit, physically hard to do the steps but emotionally worthwhile.Get there as near to 3.00 as you can

The cathedral of Rome. This church is really, really big. It alone of Rome's churches can be called a cathedral, meaning the seat of the bishop. It is also really, really old, but there's very little visible here that's pre-Baroque. (Evidently the earlier history of the church is more evident in the cloister, but I wasn't able to access it.) Borromini was involved with one of the 17th C restructurings of the building, so you'll find his cherub motif tucked into spandrels in the side aisles, but this wasn't the best fit for his talents. The late medieval ciborium is interesting, there's a badly preserved bit of fresco by Giotto, and the 18th C statues of the apostles are impressive, but there are no real first-rate works of art here.
Better than the Vatican!. Definitely felt more like a church and less like a temple to power. Lots of interesting things to look at most certainly and a nice walk as well.

Amazing over-the-top basilica. It's like so many ancient churches in Rome, but moreso. It's full of memorials to dead popes and cardinals, and everything is decorated in an incredibly ornate style. You can also make confession in multiple languages!
Beautiful church. We did not allocate enough time to view properly as we found it by accident one to go back to on another visit

Don't miss. This is my favourite church in Rome. A lot of people miss it because it seems to be out of the way but its really close to the Coliseum. It's absolutely BEAUTIFUL! And never seems to be crowded. It was the Popes church before St. Peter's was built. Please go see it.

Awesome and empty. We just stumbled across the Basilica of St. John Lateran after visiting the Colosseum.There was no fee to access and we also picked up a free audio guide. I would recommend the guide as it gives you lots of interesting facts.WOW fantastic inside, and it was empty just a few people. Once you have finished here go across to Il SANTUARIO della Scala Santa Which contains the steps believed to have been climbed by Jesus on his way to trial before Pontius Pilate.When inside be very quiet as there are many people on their knees climbing the stairs Wgmac

huge church,interesting visit.. this is the first habitation of the Pope,before he moves in Vatican.is a huge church,free charge of visit,is very interesting and not so popular as the others.we liked it a lot.

Very impressed. We had nod read nor heard about this magnificent basilika. On a day when we got a bit lost in the tram we ended up in front of it. We decided to go in and we were not disapointed. We were especially impressed by the very large statues of the 12 disciples. While we were there on a rainy day in january there weren't to many tourists but quite a few catholist men a women who prayed.
spectacular. Pray here and feel so close to Jesus, beautiful church, dont miss the relic believed to be the manger where Jesus was born
Wonderful Church and worth a visit. Beautiful Church. Easy to get to via metro. This is the pope's church and the church of the people of Rome.

Nice church, convenient transit point. Stunning indoor photography is possible there -- well lit at night and easy to reach via Metro, bus and tram. Road construction in the area is a little unsightly. Maybe just because of the off season.

Don't miss it. Exquisite architechture and artwork. It is the home church of the Bishop of Rome and a visit to La Santa Scala (believed to be the Holy Steps that Christ mounted for audience with Pontius Pilate) across from the church is well worth it too.

Amazing spiritual experience. The art and sculpture contained in this masterpiece of a church is second to none! It is one of the most exquisite cathederals is the world. We also happened to recieve the best Sacrament Of Reconciliation that we have received in living memory. This humbling church is not to be missed when in Rome !!
Big church. Big Church located in S.Giovanni area and near "Scala Santa" ("Saint Stairs"). the area is full of shops, market etc...Many paintings, columns, mosaics, statues....
another Gem of a church in Rome. this was another must see in Rome, what made this awesome is the beautiful and large statues in and outside of the church

Breath taking. What a wonderful surprise this was, it wasn't in my lonely planet guide as a top 10 but it should be. Another amazing Catholic Church of Rome, once again the art work and sculptures were beautiful.

The Seat of True Roman Catholicism. St. Peter's is in Vatican City, which is not ROME. Every Catholic Roman we met sees this church as their spiritual home. It is the seat of the Bishop of Rome, who also happens to the Pope. It is a church of sweeping majesty and beauty. Much more simple than St. Peter's but grand in its own right. One can feel a true sense of spirituality here.

The most important church in Christendom. This may not be one of the top ten tourist attractions in Rome, but it is Christendom's most important church. This building complex includes a Roman Era baptistry and the former Pope'palace. Built by Emperor Constantine, it has survived to this day in spite of earthquakes, wars, Papal schisms and renovations. When the Papacy returned from Avignon to Rome in the 13th century, the religious complex was in poor shape, opting to relocate to the Vatican area. A short wakl from Santa Maria Maggiore - another of the main christian pilgrimage Basilicas - With important works of art and impresive relics for the morbidly curious, San Giovanni in Laterano is surely worth a visit.

Check that the basilica is open!. We visited as part of a Green Line Christian Rome tour.The Church was closed due to the attendance of the Pope and the cardinals at a Mass, but our tour guide was not informed and the vatican police in attendance were very abrupt with both the guide and the public. We were able to see only the facade from auite a distance and were constantly hassled by the officious guards.

Just Amazing. there are so many cathedrals in rome but i found it simply other than others. it's ceiling is stunning. from outside it looks very ordinary so definetly must to go insid to explore it. it s well worth to visit it.

the Holy relics. This cathedral is compulsory for visiting for all the Christians such as a lot of cathedrals and churches in Rome. St Paul's and St Peter's heads are storaged here. Besides it is a really beautifull and rather big cahedral with a lot of sculptures and ancient mosaic.

Wonderful ceiling. Nothing special from outside, the inside is particularly impressive with paintings, sculptures and a ceiling which definitely has the "wow" factor. If you're not "churched out" - there are so many in Rome - this is well worth a visit.

Superlative in a town of superlatives. This place is just stunningly beautiful. No big dome to 'wow' at from the outside, but plenty to wow at inside. An absolute must. Such art, such sculpture, such marble, such contrast of plain white marble, then intricately frescoed ceiling works. Wished I could lie on my back looking straight upwards to take it all in.

Nice historic church. If you want to see something alternate to the St.Paul's glory, head to the San Giovanni in Laterano.You will avoid the Vatican hordes and you will see a very beautiful and historic catholic church.

Awe-inspiring and so beautiful. This is so beautiful and well worth visiting.Just near to the Scala Santa - the Holy Steps - so please visit as well. This church/Cathedral is absolutely stunning.The apostles stand on the roof with Jesus. Wonderful!The wooden table at the alter is said to have been used by St Peter to celebrate the eucharist and there are still some historic remains visible dating back to the 14th century and also hosts Jesus, blood which was brought to Rome by Centurion .
Beautiful. A beautiful church filled with arty treasures. Not near the main sights, it's well worth a walk to visit.
A surprise find. We happened upon this church by accident but it was stunning and well worth a visit. If you are happy wandering around Rome there are many opportunities to 'drop in'

Not one of my favourite Basilicas...... San Giovanni does not have anything of the original ancient Basilica built by Constantine in the IV century AD. It is coldly grandiose. The only thing that really deserves to be seen, is the central door, which originally was the Roman Senate's ancient door. The Giotto painting portraing Bonifacius VIII opening the first Jubilee in 1300, is hidden away on the right aisle. All in all, it not worthwhile a visit, unlsess you happen to stumple upon it.
Flea market. Across the street is a great flea market for clothes, shoes, leather goods and watches. Great buys and one can bargain.The church is magnificent.
very beautiful. there are hundreds of holy buildings in Rome, but this one was expecially moving and extremely well preserved

do go. it's a magnificent place. it's so unusual - it's the cathedral of Rome, the 'other' Vatican. It's just out of control. Skip the sacristy/cloister - it's a bit of a letdown after the drama of the actual church.
Fabulous. One of the most beautiful cathedrals I've seen in Rome. Impressive statues, gold ceiling, showing the richness of the church. It's definitely worth seeing.

Wonderful church. Statues and pictures inspiring respect, also full of art. St John Evangelist's picture on the right (see photo), roof decoration, statues of Apostles are impressive, as well as what we thought was a big pulpit. We stayed long time inside to observe all these.Concerning nearby monuments outside, my wife liked "Scala Santa". I liked the statue of St Francis of Assisi, having read a book by N. Kazantzakis about his life.

Must Sees in Roma. This is a must see for anyone interested in church architecture and history. It is one of the four patriarchal basilicas in Roma. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds and to see the morning light coming through the windows.

Opulent and airy. This basilica is located a bit out of the city center, but is more than worth a visit. Its opulence, size and open-air feel are remarkable, even by Roman standards. It is located next to the remaining fragments of the very first Christian church in Rome.

Great Church. So, if you are on pilgramage you will no doubt come to this church. It's history is well documented, and the nearby holy stairs are a must. I did want to mention though, that this basilica has a tremendous gift shop! It is run by nuns and they will have a priest bless anything you buy. Perfect! So don't spend all of you money at St. Peters!

One of the most beautiful churches in the world. Italy--and Rome specifically--is full of churches. They really are some of the most beautiful buildings and sights in the country. This one has to be up there as one of the top churches to see. It's actually the church of the Pope, not St. Peter's Basilica. Its enormity and sheer presence will blow you away. There's not much to do but take your time admiring this amazing church. Enhance the experience by reading up some history on it before you go in so you could appreciate the significance and symbolism of every aspect. Also, across the street is the Sancta Sanctorum, which used to be the pope's personal altar/church. I went into it with a class, but I'm not sure if there's a way for the public to get in. It too is beautiful. You'll also see the Scala sancta which are said to be the stairs that Christ walked up in order to appear before Pontius Pilate before his crucifixion. It is believed that if you climb these steps on your knees, all your sins will be forgiven. Regardless, just seeing the amazing churches and steps and their significance in history is well worth the visit!Only downside is that it's quite a trek to get there. It's near the walls of the city and so it's not near most of the other tourist attractions. But it's worth it. Take Bus #3 and check it out!

Imposing church. The church has an imposing structure and beautifully sculpted apostles. The iron(?) door is huge. The chairs in the church are a bit plasticky, thereby spoiling the centuries-old feel, but other than that, everything else takes you back a few centuries.
Breathtaking. The most beautiful, spiritually uplifting church I have ever been in. You could just sit & soak up the ambiance for hours.

Don't miss the older part, just outside.. The current church is very butifull and interesting but the main interest we had is just outside . There you will find the remains of the first church in rome. being almost 1800 years old it's amazing.

Amazing!!!. For me the Basilica San Giovanni in Laterano is even more impressive than San Peters. Together with the Holy Steps right next door you could spent a whole day there, if you are interested in all the amazing details.

Another Must see when in Rome. There are 5 papal basilicas in Rome, and San Giovanni is one of them and is deemed to be the oldest papal place - for long time the popes even resided nearby in Lateran Palace. Huge basilica, the mixture of styles, enormous number of details and decorative elements. Beautiful cloister (upon extra fee). Huge, spacious interior, sometimes a little crowdy, easily accessible (metro, station San Giovanni or some buses (e.g. small electric bus No. 117 - it stops close to Colosseum, a walk from there takes 15 minutes, there is St Clemente Basilica on the way as extra bonus ;-)A must see - also the sourrounding is veru interesting: the Holy Stairs Chapel across the square, the Roman walls and Egyptioan obelisk.

The Awesome Apostles. The apostles lining the main hall have memorable expressive faces, their flowing robes in stone a tribute to man"s sense of what is beautiful. Outside, the statues of st. francis and his brothers are not to be missed.
What to say? Heaven!. Been there, twice now, and still not "satisfied" - how many times can ... Lookin' forward to next visit!
Magnificent!. We stumbled upon this amazing Basilica quite by accident, absolutely mind blowing! We spent over a hour looking at the amazing sculptures, architecture and art.

Beautiful Ceiling. The ceiling here is different in style than most churches I've visited. Interesting, full of detail, and gorgeous colors! There were a few very detailed sculptures that I also enjoyed.

"A must see, often overlooked". After having seen all the major attractions such as the Vatican, Roman Forum, Coliseum upon passing I decided to walk in. I came in through the back of the church which appears small and humble. Can I say, "WOW"! The inside is spectacular. The statues are absolutely breath taking and I am so glad to have had accidently walked in because it quickly became one of my favorite top five places in Rome. Whenever someone tells me they are going to Rome, I tell them to please take it upon themselves to check this place out because the art and architecture are both simple but extragavant at the same time.
top sightseeing attraction, overlooked by many. Historically one of the most interesting sights, three different god's places from three different eras.

Worth the visit. I had been to Rome many times and always hit the same sites. This time I was on my own for a day so chose to see things off the main path. First stop was St. John Lateran. This is the pope's parish. The high church of Rome. It is a beautiful structure and profoundly moving place. The beauty. the awe-inspiring art and architecture take your breathe away. A must see!

Accidental Wonder. Didn't know the history or importance of this church. It is the Archbasilica of Rome and is MORE important to the church than St Peters. The pope MUST officiate church here before he is considered the "official" head of the Catholic Church. Beautiful and impressive.
Amazing. The original Vatican. Amazing. Its not a main tourist attraction but should be. The area and the Vatican is a place where you can admire the art and just spend a quiet day.
Huge!. A massive and wonderful church. Catch it during the lunch periods or early mornings to avoid the crowds and photo takers!
Very old, Very big, Impressive. This was just about the first church in Rome in the 4C and the size and grandeur reflect the early popes living here. Lots of memorable features and beauty to admire.
Incredible. It's huge and full of history... Even from the outside as well as inside...a definite must see while visiting Rome

Huge and religious. This is what I really like in Rome: you walk around and than go in a church and than you find there things like the Moses from Michelangelo or a part of the holy boose. Here you cant find this things but you can feel how religion lives and complete everyday life.And everything is huge and keeps you thinking how people could build anything like this.

Huge church on an amazing scale. I like this church because of the scale and the wow factor. The silhouette against the sky was amazing with statues of holy people on top of it.
A draw back was people trying to sell you bracelets and scarves outside. Ignore and avoid.
morning visit. lovely, peaceful atmosphere. Stunning artwork. Easy access. A local person who spoke some English told us some of the history. A memorable visit

fab. it was sooo great and its so untouristy, the place used to be the vatican, the local bus stops close by. would recommend to anybody that does not want to stand in line to see the vatican that is open to public

Statues of Apostles make this a worthy stop. The official Cathedral of Rome. It's big and beautiful but really only worth a stop for the statues of the Apostles (St. Thomas was my favorite but St. Bartholomew is also very cool). The heads of Peter and Paul reside over the altar. But, after seeing St. Peter's San Giovanni feels overly large, poorly scaled and kind of empty. Don't miss the Sancta Scala (Holy Stairs) across the street.

The most important cathedral in cristendom. The Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano is a very important cathedral because it's the Papal Archbasilica and it's a very old one (dating from the 4th century). The exterior is great (The facade is neoclassical and on the right side of the facade you can find the Lateran Obelisk) and the interior is quite amazing (the church gives you the sensation of greatness, making every visitor to feel small).

Beautiful Church, Peaceful Atmosphere. One of the most important churches in Rome, San Giovanni in Laterano is also one of the most opulent. Constructed in the basilica style, its gorgeous, high ceiling is breathtaking. Because there are powerful statues across Rome, those here won't stand out, but the biblical stories recounted in marble are of interest. I wouldn't bother with the cloister (for which there is a fee), but do check out the Scala Sancta and the Baptistery. Also, be sure to take in the front of the church--there's a side entrance you'll use if you walk up from the Colosseum (15-20 minute trek) and miss the grand facade.

Interesting and opulent. I visited San Giovanni's on a Sunday when a church service was in progress, so I only stayed briefly and quietly saw what I could without disturbing those in prayer. The church is beautiful with ornate ceilings, huge sculptures of the apostles, paintings, crypts, and numerous side chapels. It was only after visiting that I read some of the history of the cathedral. To fully appreciate all I was seeing, I should have read about it prior to my visit. It was only later that I found out that the massive bronze doors were once located in the Senate in the Roman Forum. This church certainly merits a visit, but if possible, do it at a time when a religious service is not being conducted so that you can see all that it has to offer without distracting anyone. I walked from the Coliseum and it took about 15-20 minutes.

SO CROWDY YOU MAY LOOSE THE ATMOSPHERE. This is really the cradle of christianity in Rome. The baroque apparel (from Bernini) hide the ancient glory of this church. But you'll find it sooo crowdy that you can miss the authentic atmosphere. This is a real shame. Go and visit the SCALA SANTA too, in order to see devotes climbing to the top on knees! Keep silence and respect!
Another wonder of Rome.. Every church you visit in Rome is filled with treasures. San Giovanni in Laterano is no exception. Add this one to your list of places to visit.
Saint Johns Lantern. First Home of the Popes. Many art treasures. Amazing how they built these buildings without modern tools

Go and be wowed!. As a Christian but not a Catholic I am not a great fan of all the gold and ornate decorations but I defy anyone not to be blown away by this. It is so intricate and opulent you cannot fail to be wowed. It is not as large as St Peter's but it is still pretty big by most standards and no where near as busy which is interesting as it is the Papal seat for Rome. It costs 5Euros to visit the Cloisters.

The real Vatican. This is what early churches and Vatican history is all about. The pope is Archbishop of Rome and this has always been his church. Was the center of Christianity long before St Peters was build. Fantastic monastery garden behind the church.

More impressive than St. Peters. This is the most beautiful church and you can see it all without the crowds of St. Peters. There are many beautiful sculptures, but the ceiling is outstanding. Just a beautiful experience.
Scala Santa. The Scala Santa or Holt Stairs where you go up 28 steps on your knees as a form of penitence. This is the original hq of the early pope.
Very beautiful church. We found this church just as mass was starting. The statues are amazing, love the interior as it was really beautiful. Definitely worth a visit.

One of the great churches of Rome. The building is vast and there are very impressive sculptures of the 12 apostles. This was also the site of the first great basilica built in the early Christian era.

Amazing in its size and detail. The basillica is easy to reach by subway. It is well worth the visit for its history, its rich detail which is a feast for the eyes and its sheer size. As the basillica of the Bishop of Rome, it is well worth visiting on the way to visiting the Vatican.

Gorgeous. This wasn't on our list of things to see but we had a little extra time so we walked a few blocks and went in. So glad we did...it was the most beautiful church we visited. And there was a mass with organ music and singing while we were there. Made it all very special.
Very impressive. Less tourists than St Peters so more spiritual. Lots of history here as everywhere but this is the Pope's church as Bishop of Rome

Thanksgiving Mass for the Canonization of Kateri Tekakwitha. My sister and I found this beautiful church just as the thanksgiving mass was starting. There was a full orchestra as well as the choir from St Peter's Basilica. it was sheer coincidence that we were there at this time. There were approximately two thousand pilgrims from the USA and Canada so we were told. The day before at St Peters there had been the Canonization of seven new saints, one of which was St. Kateri. The first North American saint.The church is beautiful. Well worth visiting.

Awesome. The Cathedral of Rome was inspirational. Well worth the walk, yet metro reasonably close too.
The art work was powerful.
Beautiful. Amazing statues, beautiful church. Went twice during my stay. Off the beaten path. Definitely worth a visit
St. John latern Church. Such a beautiful Church, architecture is fantastic. We loved all the paintings and statues in the Church
superb. I almost liked this one more tham the Vatican/San Peter. Impresive. Not sure what to add so I can reach 50 characters :-).

Fantastic Basilica after St. Peter Basilica. Stopped here with John in Romelimousinebyjohn.com we arrived around 11am. Inside great carved statues of all appostles..created by Borromini. Obseved the Obelisc from Egypt . The Lateran was were the popes lived in the very beggining. Saw the holly door too.

How do you not give a Roman chiesa a five-star review?. This is a monumental structure full of classic delights, especially if one tunes out the Catholic Christian static and appreciates it on a humanist basis. The painting and statuary are on par with any church in Europe, for sure. Just be quiet, please -- travelers can get so noisy.

Breathtaking. We have seen many churches and cathedrals in Europe, but this would rank 2nd, right behind St. Peters at the Vatican. Take time to visit the Baptistry just outside and a side entrance. We happened to visit during a baptism, very touching.

Easily as good a St.Peter's, but no queues and no crowds. Very spectacular, both inside and out and, best of all, no crowds. You can gaze down the aisles admiring the reflections in the marble floors because they're not jam-packed full of people! The ceilings and statues are all stunning, in particular the twelve huge statues of the aposles that line the nave.Make sure you walk around the East side to see the frontage in all it's glory (this is the side you'll see first if you come from San Giovanni Metro) and see the needle in the piazza NW of the basilica.It's easy to get to, either by walking less then 2 mins from San Giovanni Metro station on line A or do as we did and walk from the Colosseum along Via di San Giovanni in Laterano wich takes 10-15 mins and has the added advantage that you can stop at San Clemente on the way!
Just Incredible. This is the original Vatican! The basilica is smaller than St Peter's in the Vatican, but just as impressive. This is a place with so much history. Worth the visit.

A quiet less-crowded alternative if you don't have the time or the inclination for some of the other places.. Oldest church, redone on the inside around the 17th century I think. Worth a visit just to see the gigantic doors which came from the Roman Senate. Adjacent to a pleasant crowd-free neighborhood. Nice walk from the Colosseum.

Wow. Only came here because it was a 10 minute walk from our hotel. Until we visited we were completely unaware of it's importance, but the building itself is amazing. Certainly on a par with St Peter's Basilica, but more from its statues, where I think St Peter's beats it for the artwork. Definitely a must see whilst in Rome.
Breathtaking. This is a must if you enjoy visiting churches in Rome. Go and see for yourself. Whatever I say won't do it justice. Beautiful. Huge. Amazing.

Beautiful church near the Colosseum. It was impossible not to be moved by the atmosphere in this church - we visited on a Sunday and there was a service taking place, with young children singing - it was truly beautiful. The church itself is beautiful - ornate carvings and paintings. Well worth a visit
Just amazing!. Do not miss San Giovanni. We went to mass there. Very special. We were not expecting to see this level of spendour and art. Amazing!

Worth seeing . I must admit that I had never heard of this church until it came up on Trip Advisor, but I genuinely enjoyed my visit. It's quite large and impressive and while there are churches with more impressive artwork I genuinely saw something quite different in the bold architecture here.
Beautiful. Kind of out of the way, but simply one of the most beautiful Basillicas in all of Rome. I highly recommend visiting. Very easy to get to if you are close to a metro, too.

So fascinating!. Do not miss the visit!
i was in the group of 13 and the guide was great,although she was hard to hear because she whispered more than talk...
had i known i would have gone myself with a guidebook
i visited the Sancta Santorum and it was so touching
recommend to go whether you are religious or not
Amazing sculptures!. Very close to the main tourist track, you shouldn't miss this church... recommendable................

Beautiful church. This is worth a visit, a lovely place, peaceful in a bustling city, stunning setting and interiors, watch out for sales touts outside, they can try to push bracelets etc at you and demand money.
Interesting. Interesting but not the best church to visit if you're short on time. The interior was less decorated than other churches in Rome.

St. John's Lateran. St. John Laterans was one of four major churches that we toured in the afternoon after touring the Vatican in the morning. It is massive, yet has an intimate feel. I enjoyed these major churches just as much or more than the Vatican. I also found out that one can get a plenary dispensation if you visit all four churches in the year 2015

The Cathedral of Rome. Many people think that St. Peter's is the pope's church in Rome,because the pope now lives at the Vatican, the location of St. Peter's. However, the pope lived at the Lateran Palace at the church of San Giovanni in Laterano (St. John's at the Wall) formany centuries. It is a spectacular church and the cathedral ofthe diocese of Rome. It has most ancient baptistry in all of Christianity, which is located in a sperate medieval structure behind the cathedral. The mosaic above the altar is magnificent. The church also has a beautiful cloiser, which is open to the public for a small admission. And, there are publicrestrooms available in th cathedral and cloister area, which is a very rare and precious gift to tourists. This church is also the burial site of Pope Leo XIII, the social justice pope, and the greatRenaissance architect Berninni. The central doors of this cathedral are the actual doors to the ancient Roman Senate.How's that for history?

A total lovely surprise- Dont miss. A truly lovely church which is really the official Cathedral of Rome. The audio is free, they really dont tell you that they are free, but be sure to pick up a set when you enter. You can give a small donation. Be sure to go next door to see and even experience the Sacred Steps that pilgrims climb on their knees. These steps were brought by St. Helen (Constantine's mother) from Pontius Pilate palace-- the ones Jesus walked up. It is quite humbling.

Notes on visiting Rome’s cathedral (and the Scala Sancta!).. Founded in the early 4th century by Emperor Constantine, San Giovanni in Laterano is considered one of the oldest churches in Christianity and rivals only St. Peters for historical bragging rights in Rome. The church also functions as the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of the city, who in this unique case happens to also be the Pope. I visited the area with a small group through Context travel. We started at the Scala Sancta (Holy Stairs) which according to the Christian tradition are the steps that Jesus climbed on his way to trial. Located opposite the Basilica in a building that used to house the Lateran Palace, the stairs themselves consist of 28 wooden steps that you can ascend (on your knees) if desired. There is a small museum on top that contains older Christian relics. A tour of the Basilica proper followed. Like many historic churches there are seemingly endless levels of appreciation for the statues, artifacts, and paintings inside. In this case highlights included a fresco of Boniface VIII (possibly by Giotto), the Papal Altar, the tomb of Innocent III, and the impressive façade by Alessandro Galilei. We finished with a tour of the Lateran Baptistry (for years the only one in Rome) with its associated art works. Our guide did an excellent job of explaining the infinite intricacies of the church and providing context with present day history and religion. There was an audio guide available as well for those who do not have the means/desire to join a guided tour.In summary, if you visit one church in Rome I would suggest St. Peters. If you visit two please include this one. An overall worthwhile journey.

A beautiful Church in Rome. My wife and I visited this Church in September 2012. The sacle of the Church is amazing both inside and outside. Inside there are marble statues of the 12 Apostles. There is also a beautiful statue of John the Baptist. As a Christian site, this place is a must see. Enjoy.
special church visit. Seeing so many churches on a single trip you don't expect to be so impressed as I was by San Giovanni di Laterano. The light and inner courtyards were very impressive.

Best looking church in Rome!!. We went to San Giovanni after visiting Vatican City via the underground train. Even from afar, the outside view of the church was astonishing with the angels on the rooftop & huge doors. Once we were inside the church, the view was even more remarkable with richness of hand crafted art on church ceiling & statues on each pillar. We could not believe such an old church is still in a marvelous condition just as it was built recently. We sat there for 2 hours to enjoy the beauty of this church. It is truly an unforgettable experience just to be there.
beautiful church. this is a must see. St Peters is not the only significant church building that should be on your list

Beautiful. San Giovanni is the largest church in Rome. St Peters being in the state of the Vatican City. It was once the home of the popes before they moved to St Peters and thus has all the beauty you would expect. Unlike St Peter's you won't have to queue to get in.

Rome's second stunning basilica. The Basilica of St John Lateran is known as the Cathedral of Rome, and is one of my favourite places in Rome, but you do need to read up a bit about it to get the best out of a visit. Taking along a decent guide book is well worth it.First, there is a huge Roman statue of Constantine, outside the basilica, in the porch. Secondly, do not miss a close look at the huge doors before you enter. If they look old, its because they are- they were the original doors to the Curia in the Forum. Inside, pay particular attention to the beautiful ceiling, and statues of the apostles by Borromini, lining both sides of the nave. The frescoes and decorations in the centre of the Basilica are hugely impressive, and as if that was not enough there is one of Rome's loveliest cloisters to walk around too.Outside in the large piazza,you can walk around to the historic Baptistery, originally dating from the time of Constantine. Unfortunately it was closed when I was there. It takes about 30-40 minutes to walk to the Basilica from the Colloseum. Down Via S Giovanni in Laterano. There are a number of cafes along here for a coffee and snack. You might want to visit the church of San Clemente whilst you are around this area, the famous church with its underground excavations. You will pass it as you walk along the Via S Giovanni, but its easy to miss it.
Another great church to visit in Rome. Situated in a nice Piazza, the church has spectacular fresco's and statues worth a view on the way to or from the Colloseum.

The 1st Church of Rome. Few people know that this Church surpasses even St Peters in importance....I love Rome 1st Church...the Mother of all Catholic churches....altho I am not Catholic one can truly appreciate the history...the story...the splendour of this churche....a definite place to be seen in the Eternal city!
Great bascilica. It's beautiful and huge. The fresco's are beautiful. We were there during a mass. The italians sing beautifully, it's stunning when you are there.

One of the most beautiful churches in Rome. Huge and beautiful church, statues and pictures impressive, holy and quiet atmosphere.
It is recommended to ride the Metro.

Stunning!!. We were lucky enough to have our hotel fairly close by, so we visited twice. Just an absolute masterpiece. If you get a chance, walk down Viale Carlo Felice towards the church. It is a tree lined street that leads you straight to the front of the church. At first, you can tell the church is large, but it is incredibly deceiving. Everything from the statues, to the pillars, to the arches are all in perfect proportion so that it is difficult to judge how far away you are from the entrance. Only when you get very close do you realize how immense the facade is. The inside also has stunning proportions, with statues about 15 feet tall lining the view towards the altar. The details are amazing and every corner has some intricate design. Definitely worth visiting if you are in Rome.

Popes original Church. This is a fascinating church with a lot of historical meaning regarding the Popes. The doors leading into the church are from the Roman Senate! Way cool place to visit. Make sure you get the facts before going.
Magnificent Statues!. It collossal statues of the holy saints (apostles). The St. John the Baptist tomb area. You walk in awe of one of Rome's most beautiful churches!
Most interesting of the 3 holy see properties we visited.. Fabulous art and architecture. It is an interesting mix of styles that all seem to blend harmoniously in one ancient structure.
Masterpiece. Very fine design, easy to reach by public transtport links. It's masterpiece, what else could I say. It's worth to travel there.

Most People Miss This One. This is the "granny" and most people miss it. Probably because it is a bit out of the way.But it has plenty to see. I would not miss it if you have 3 days or more to spend in Rome.
A real gem. Here is a church with beautiful artwork, sculpture, etc and without the big crowds. The cloister ($$) has some nice sculpture gathered from other sites to preserve them.

breathtaking. It's a big beautifull church not as crowed as St.Peters. You can take a self guided tour of the museum,not that impressive. It is located in a wonderfull piazza with benches to sit on.Worth finding.

Rome's Cathedral. you must visit rome's cathedral which is imposant and has a special atmosphereyou must visit rome's cathedral which is imposant and has a special atmosphereyou must visit rome's cathedral which is imposant and has a special atmosphere

marvelous, but poor loan system for the audio guides. we liked the big statues of the apostles best. Very impressive! the loan system of the audio guides was not wel organised. We had to give our pasport to get an audio guide. But we left our pasports at the hotel and only had a copy with us. They would not except the copy for an audio guide; Finally they took 50€ witch we got back at the end of our tour. We would have chosen to visit the basilica without an audio guide, but you could not enter the convent garden without one (why not ???). The audio guide also includes the Holy stairs.
Beautiful Church. We attended a wedding there and it was beautiful. The paintings and sculptures were astonishing. Highly recommend it!
What a surprise..... Here's the real Church of Rome, and to be honest way more interesting than most - really worth a visit

blessed...... the architecture itself is just amazing, amazing, looking up to the ceiling is almost unbelievable. we just sat in the church admiring how little details are done almost perfect. coming here as a catholic i call it very lucky and it just touches your heart. love this place, one of the places i will definitely come back and visit again.

Don`t miss this!!. What a place..From the amazing bronze doors almost 30 feet high that were taken from the roman forum to the guilded ceiling inside ,,this is a place not to be missed in Rome.. Surperb...

Great Church-much less crowded than St. Peter's. One of the four great basilicas in Rome. East accessible, from the San Giovanni Metro station, it's a short walk (about 5 minutes) to this basilica. Audio guides are available (for a fee of course) in front of church entrance.Just before you enter into the church, you'll see the statue of Constantine (4th Century) and central doorway with tall green bronze doors. These are original doors from the Senate House in the Forum.In the church you'll find larger than life statues of the Apostles and Evangelists on the nave pillars,the Baldacchino with two statues of St. Peter and Paul, said to contain their heads as well as the golden columns from the Temple of Jupiter.You'll also see the Pope's cathedra and beatiful mosaic in the dome of apse.There is no cost to enter and best of of not a large crowd. A wonderful, moving experience.

Saint John Lateran - Don't Miss this Gem. I've been to Rome twice and have been to St. John Lateran both times. Many people, especially non-Catholics, do not realize that this is the "official" home parish of the Bishop of Rome - in other words, the Pope. Whenever the Pope officiates in his capacity as the Bishop of the Rome diocese, it is at St. John Lateran - not St. Peter's. What I appreciate most about this enormous church is the light - most of the churches in Rome tend to be pretty dark inside, but not St. John's. The openness and light allow one to appreciate the marvelous gold leaf and art work on the ceiling. Enormous statues line the church. It has beautiful side altars and the organ is beautiful to behold - can't imagine what it must sound like. Check out the web site for St. John Lateran for yourself - words can't do it justice. It is located a few blocks south of the Colosseum (an easy walk) and there is a subway stop (Redline) for St. John's. You can even catch a bus across the street from the Church and go to the Catacombs.
will blow you away. It was one of the most amazing churches to visit ,do not miss it!!! The architecture and art on view was just outstanding and will last in my memories fr a very long time

Absolutely amazing!. I walked in and was really overwhelmed with the ceiling, sculptures and painted walls. I highly recommend a visit here. Be sure (ladies) not to come dressed in shorts and a tank top.

Beautiful and much quieter than St Peter's and Vatican. I preferred San Giovanni to St Peter's and the Vatican, perhaps this was in part due to the significantly smaller amount of people. It really was beautiful and awe-inspiring. I am not a religious person but I still really enjoyed the deep sense of history and all of the art here.
The finest church in Rome. Much more impressive than St Peters Basilica, this is the cathedral of Rome The statues are most interesting

The Mother Church of the world.. Rome's Cathedral with the Sancta Scala adjacent.
The relics of the Apostles in a glimpse of heaven.
Read the history. Easy from Metro.
Exceptional.. Fantastic church, in some ways better than St. Peter's. Smaller, beautiful. The Senate door and jubilee doors were awesome.
A Wonderful and Worthwhile Visit. Off the main track, but absolutely fabulous! Also, not nearly the crowds you'll encounter in central Rome.
One of the best. This is one of the must see basicalla's on your Rome journey. You could spend a day there trying to see all of the art work and learn the history.
One of the most beautiful churches in Italy.. The original St. Peter's. Less ornate but a beautiful church. We were so glad we got to see it. It should be a top sight to see in Rome.

Better than St. Peter's Basilica. No crowds but very beautiful with an interesting history. We were able to stroll up to the amazing front door of this cathedral and quietly walk inside and revel in the amazing interior, No crowds, unlike St. Peter's or the Vatican City. Go early however, as everything becomes more crowded after 10a.m.It is right near the S. Giovanni metro station set on a beautiful piazza.

We visited this church after the vatican...we wern't disappointed..worth the metro ride. Avery interesting church,built for the popes before the vatican,vist the cloisters and the church across the road
Beautiful, grand church. Beautiful church, be sure to make it before closing time though. Also visit the Holy Stairs in the building across it.

Really worth a visit whilst in Rome. Beautiful church to visit and staying in a nice 2 bed apartment in the Laterano area two stops further out on the metro stop, Furio Camillo, it was located at Via Appia Clelia so we only had about 20 minutes walk on the Via Appia to get to the gates of Rome and the Church of San Giovanni is just yards to the left. Fantastic treasures of paintings and even old confession boxes and can be cool as a respite from the rome heat but going in late October, early November is a much better time to explore the city as it is like a cauldron in the summer months. Metro is around 3 Euros for a day journey to the Vaticano area but be particularly careful around the Trevi Fountain area in particular as we witnessed the police apprehending a guy with a big fat wallet he has stolen from some unfortunate tourist. Angelo's restaurant at the Piazza Navona is good and he is particularly welcoming and will send free champagne to your table courtesy of his charm. Do stay in the laterano area if you want to experience a real taste of an Italian neighourhood and not too many tourists. In fact, I reckon that we were the only ones there. I can speak some Italian but don't worry, the locals will help you out and are really polite.

a bit far but really wort it if you have time. we walked from S Maria Maggiore in a very hot august afternoon so it was a delight arriving at this beatiful basilica. Always better when yo ahve a nice guide book to mak you appreciate it all.we took the bus ti return to near Republica(there are public washrooms in the church)
Lovely. We only got to view this from the bus, but it was a great building. Easy to find, apart from the steps.

Wonderful place in wonderful. During our 5 day long stay in Rome me and my wife tried to visit as many historical spaces as possible. This beautiful city is full of incredible monuments but basilica of San Giovanni in Laterano positively surprised us the most. The church is outside the city centre but not so far to be unreachable by walk. In contrast with other famous sights like Pantheon or St. Peters basilica it is not crowded with tourists at all. There is enough daylight inside to enable taking pictures and it really makes sense because interior is very impressive - huge and full of valued paintings and statues. The basilica played very important role in the history of Roman catholic church. As this charming place is quite close to Colosseum, Palatinum and Forum Romanum we decided to visit all these places during one day and we really enjoyed it as the rest of our stay in one of the best places in the world which Rome definitely is in my opinion.

emotionally moving. I found myself in tears and thought this basilica was more beautiful than St. Peter's. The statutes of the twelve apostles are over 15ft tall and the paintings and gild through our move you to tears.

my favorite site in rome. this church was incredible - the original doors from the roman senate, church in existence since the 300's. i was really blown away by this site. my favorite sight in all of rome!

Beautiful and without the crowds. This cathedral was extraordinarily beautiful. It's magnificent architecture showed off the impressive statues and frescos. There was no cost and no crowd. A wonderful experience.

A Must See!. Beautiful architecture, art, and history! You cannot go wrong when visiting this basilica. As one of the main Vatican basilicas, it is a must to visit this beautiful church. Not far away are the Holy Stairs. Both of these are free of charge and are truly inspiring. You will come away from this experience with a new perspective and respect for life. Will visit again when in Rome!

St. John in Lateran. This was one of the six churches that we visited as part of our Christian Tour. It's a beautiful church and I was mesmerized by the Scala Santa...It can only be climbed on one's knees. Wow...

Worthwhile If Only To See The Front Door!. As Rome's cathedral church, San Giovanni is an impressive structure both inside and out. Erected under the rule of Constantine, whose giant statue watches over the entrance, this was the first great Christian church ever constructed. Having said that, there are a lot of amazing churches in Rome, full of renaissance masterpieces and melted down Aztec gold. This is a great example. The most notable feature though are the great bronze doors taken from the Imperial Roman Senate which are still used as the main entrance to the church. It is quite something thinking you have just walked through the same door that Caesar, Nero and Hadrian walked through all those years ago.

Found this gem when we saw it from the top of the War Museum. Found this by accident and it should be rated higher then it is. Impressive and not crowded. Maybe I just loved it due to low expectations, but worth a visit. .
The Cathedral of Rome. This is another of the stunning large churches in Rome. Although outside of the Vatican, it is considered to be the seat of Papal authority in Rome.

The Cathedral of all Cathedrals. A glorious building to the glory of God. The quality of the workmanship is awe inspiring. We were in a party of pilgrims from Birkenhead on a bring your own priest basis and we had our own mass in a side chapel and this added to the experience.

The True Cathedral of Rome. As the seat of the early Popes before the Vatican this is a church you must see. It is beautiful and steeped in religious art without being OTT as some Roman churches are. From the impressive marble entrance hall, housing a large effigy of Constantine, to the series of beautiful statues of the twelve apostles, each holding either a symbol of their role, or martrydom - including the macabre statue of Bartholomus holding his flayed flesh! Don't miss the baptistry behind the church which is older with its glimpse of earlier Christian worship in the mosaics and fresco's.
St. John. One of the biggest cathedrals in Rome. Magnificent, quite place in the morning. Best for visit for all people

Beautiful beyond words.. My eyes could not get enough, my senses could not absorb the magnitude, beauty and serenity of this church. It is magnificent beyond words and should not be missed on any itinerary.
Snowwhite. Beautifull marble church, white as heaven! The statues are placed very tactfull, the sun plays with the church as if god is playing with us. The most beautifull cealing in Rome!
A haven of beauty.. Off the usual tourist trail but well worth a visit. Only 10min walk from Colosium. Beautiful interior.Allow photography.
Amazing! A must see. Staggering!. If you are going to visit one church, consider this one. It defies description. A most humbling experience.

wonderful place, unbelivable freskos.... Spent almost an hour in San Giovanni in Laterano and was not enough to cover everything... Lots of paintings that deserves a longer visit. Also please allow some time to visit souvenir shop to see amazing things...

Exquisite. Don't miss this cathedral. We walked there easily and were awe struck. There are a lot of magnificent churches in Rome (of course the Vatican is the most spectacular in the world), but S. Giovanni is right up there.

Beautiful church- surrounding grounds not well-kept. The church itself- Rome's official cathedral- is beautiful, and Holy Staircase across the street is a must for pilgrims. Exterior grounds are not well-kept though, unfortunately, in stark contrast to St. Peter's in Vatican City.
Beautiful!. Lovely art and unusual church. Market nearby. Various buses stop outside.No queues and free entry.Plenty of pictures to be had at this location.

Wonderful surprise. Found this on our daily walks and didn't realise this was the Cathedral of Rome. It was absolutely amazing, really busy but so big the crowds seem to disperse easily. There is so much history and wonderful things to see.
Beautiful. This church is similar to St. Peter's, just a smaller scale. It has a canopy that is lovely. It is well worth visiting.
Beautiful facade!. Look up and see the beauty of this 4th century church. Detailed statues on the top of the church. A must see!
Bernini's tomb. You can find the tomb of Renaissance artist & sculptor Bernini in the altar steps. Also, the tombs of six popes is visible, in a carved out "basement" just in front of the altar.
Beautiful Basilica. Beautiful Basilica, not far from Colloseum, definitely worth seeing, especially for the ceilings and the hall of statues.
Fabulous!. We happened to visit just as a parade was beginning and a festival was going to be held. What a lucky moment! I believe this is one of the oldest Catholic churches in Rome.

Beautiful Basilica and well worth a visit. Just a five minute walk from the coliseum takes you to this beautiful basilica. It is the oldest chuch in the world as the original building was started in 314 and was the seat of Popes until St Peter's was build in the Vatican City State . In its present form St John's in Lateran looks very similar to St Peter's and is considerd to be Rome's largest cathedral. The interior will take your breath away as it is just spectacular and the ceilings are fabulousEntrance to theChurch is free

Highly recommended.. I love visiting European Churches in general but Rome really has some of the best ones in terms of historical importance and architecture. The Arcibasilica Papale di San Giovanni in Laterano is one church you should not miss. It is apparently the oldest and first among the four major basilicas of Rome, and it stands in all grandeur with spectacular architecture on both the exterior and interiors of the church. I like the inscription on the façade, Christo Salvatori.. which indicates the church's dedication to Christ. When you step into the church one may be simply overwhelmed with the intricacy of the walls and ceilings, and of cos the baroque sculptures lining the centre of the church.

The pre-Vatican. Although much was seriously destroyed during the wars, this still gives you a sense of where the popes lived from antiquity until the building of St. Peter's. Impressive interior and beautiful colonnades.

The Vatican church outside the Vatican. The church is massive. It is so Beautiful. It has a wide Path leading you to entrance , which itself is very WOW. Then you enter the church and that is like WOW WOW WOW. It is so Grand. We have been told that it was the 1st church that was built in Rome , and acts like the Vatican church , but outside the Vatican walls. This is where the bishop of Italy resides. The ceiling of the church is unlike anything that we have ever seen before. Grandness on a major scale. This is a defiant must see when in Rome.
Lovely church. Beautiful basilica, a little out of the way. It is worth seeing if you love Baroque art. However, if you are pressed for time, there are far more interesting churches to visit in Rome.
Too little time to view this lovely site. It is really a must for visitors to Rome. The architecture, the figurines, the chapels, the floors,all was very beautiful and very informative.
impressive Cathedral. I liked the quiet location in an amazing city. Compared to other places and churches, it was rather quiet. Unfortunately there was a restoration activity in the wing.
Interesting. I did not realize what an important church this is - thoroughly enjoyed wandering through here and learning more about the building and the history.
Nice and not crowded. Extremely nice and not too crowded. This is considered the most important church in the sense it is the arch cathedral
Worth a visit. Very ornately decorated and a quiet haven in a busy city. It did not have the crowds of St Peters so you colud spend time looking at the beuty of the church without having to rush.

The Mother of all Christian Churches in the World!. All the beautiful adjectives in the English vocabulary would not be enough to describe this amazing Church which is the very first Church (older than St. Peter's Basilica) built in Rome. One has to see this Church to understand it's grandeur and significance in the Catholic World. This is the Church that became the model for all the churches that followed.
early morning mass. loved looking at the frescos and all the lovely altars the gold around some of the altars are lovely

Hugely interesting, way less crowded.. An easy walk from the Colosseum and Forum, this is Rome's first cathedral, and the Mother Church of the whole world. Often overlooked by tourists, it's a hugely interesting edifice having included the residence of the Popes prior to their exile to Avignon. This is the Cathedral of Rome, where the Pope performs his day-job as Bishop of Rome.The old Papal Palace contains the steps from Pilate's house in Jerusalem, a pilgrimage site. Another Christian "relic" of dubious provenance, of which there are thousands in Rome. This one claims to have the bloodstains of Jesus embedded in the steps.The cathedral is full of intricate sculpture, excellent marble floor-work and Papal tombs, and contains a High Altar at which only the Pope can perform.Walking from the Forum, you will arrive at the entrance on the northern Nave. Don't forget to go round the front of the cathedral and see the facade! The first thing you'll see is the obelisk of Thutmoses III, the oldest in Rome dating from 15thC BCE. Pinched from Egypt by Constantine, it was originally in the Circus Maximus.A short walk away from the eastern facade, in the direction of the Metro station, is a part of the Aurelian wall containing the Porta San Giovanni.Entrance is free, apart from the cloister area which currently costs 3 Euros. Remember - as for most Italian churches - to take a shawl to cover your shoulders and have your knees covered too. Or you won't get in. I cart around a pair of tracksuit trousers and a T-shirt in my day-pack specifically for this prpose!

Awe-inspiring!. We took the Metro to San Giovanni in Laterano (St. John Lateran) - about a five minute walk from the metro station. It was magnificent! Walking up the long pathway to the church gives you a sense of what is in store inside. The sculptures, the paintings, the ceilings, the chapels - the size! - unbelievably beautiful, incredibly breath-taking! This is the official church of the bishop of Rome - the pope. We learned that the pope must actually sit in the "cathedra" chair in this magnificent church sometime during his first year after being elected in order to be formally named The Pope. After spending several hours inside marveling at its beauty, we walked across the street to the Scala Santa (Holy Stairs). We saw many people on their knees, climbing the main stairway while engaged in their prayers. We took another stairway to the second floor, saw the chapels, and read the history. Beautiful. Very moving. Both places are worth the visit. Give yourself enough time - at least a couple of hours - to really see and experience San Giovanni's.

It's a Square.. It was very pretty, but is just a piazza. Not too sure why it's listed as a major tourist attraction. However, just around the corner is the Archbasilica of St. John Lateran, which is an amazing building to visit. Girls, just keep in mind you have to have your knees and shoulders covered (because you know how tempting those knees and shoulders are) so if you haven't dressed 'appropriately', you can get a scarf off the hawkers (at a price).

One of the Top3 churches in Rome!. Rome has hundreds of churches (900 I have read) but if you need to choose only a few, San Pietro, San Pablo Fuori li Mura and San Giovanni in Laterano are, for me, the Top3. San Giovanni is currently the Cathedral of Rome (residence of the Bishop of Rome). It is in fact a Vatican Church outside Vatican City. Residence of the Pope from the 4th century (until 1309) San Giovanni is also an icon of the Catholic history. The fact of being the most ancient church in the world is another reason to visit it. The buiding was destroyed and rebuilt serveral times.It is a huge and amazing building but much less crowdy than Sain Peter's Basilica. From the main altar to the right side you will see a huge church pipe organ made in 1598.Please keep the Vatican dress code here although controls can be a little bit relaxed.You can access here by metro (metro station San Giovanni of the Red Line is only 100 mts from the Church) or bus. It is not very far walking from the Colosseum.
A solem & bright beauty. It was such a beauty. My 9 year old daughter couldnt stop taking picture. It was solem yet bright, didnt give one a creepy feeling like some dark gothic church did.

An obligation. What can i say more than my fellow scribes? Nothing, it is worth the visit and every minute spent considering it as a magnificent work that is, far beyond its historical value that is enormous.
Superb. Thought this cathedral was more peaceful than St. Peter's Basilica. It definitely has a more human scale. Definitely worth a visit; doesn't have the hordes of tourists.
Is a must. Is a beautiful Cathedral very close to the Holy Steps, two sites you cannot miss specially if you are a Roman Catholic.

Beautiful place. The best and more beatiful church in Rome in my opinion. This Church shows power of Catholicism during the period that they command Rome. In general, experiences visiting the churcil in Rome are amazing.
Make the effort.. All the things we read about this beautiful cathedral were true. Take the time to see for yourself. :)
