SO worth it!. After visiting the Via Appia Antica, we took bus 218 to San Giovanni in Laterano (luckily, someone else rang the bell and we saw this was the place to exit). What an amazing site this is! The adornment in the Roman churches is unparalleled. Huge statues of the saints line the nave and there are seats so you can sit and contemplate their grandeur. Don't miss trying to "walk" up the 28 holy stairs on your knees--I couldn't believe how painful this was! Pilgrims come from all over to do this. The holy stairs are in a little pinkish building across the side street to the right of the cathedral as you are facing the cathedral's front (come out of the front of the cathedral and turn left).
St. Johns. What an amazing beautiful place to visit. You can see where Bernini is buried and look at the beautiful art work, sculptures, and marble work.
serene church. very different than others we saw. much more plain, in a good way. we took a walk under the archways, too. lovely atmosphere.
Beautiful. Very pretty church. Worth a visit. No one said anything about my shorts and tank top. :) it was nice and had plenty of things to photograph.
Impressive. Great stop to be in awe of over-the-top gold and glitz. Stop at the front desk and make a small donation for the fee audio guide.

Interesting large church off the beaten path. It's a bit far from the other major attractions, but it's well worth it. The pope used this church before moving to St. Peter's. It is very ornate and large. The holy steps are just across the street from it.

Breathtaking.. Besides St Peter's this is one church not to be missed in Rome. The beginning of Christianity started here and the history surrounding it is overwhelming. Get some info on the church before you go, or pop 1 EUR into the electronic information booths dotted in a few places around the church, its worth knowing the importance of what you're looking at. Across the road is the Sancta Sanctorum where the Holy Steps are housed. Make sure you get there early as they kicked us out to close up at about 1pm.
very interesting. Plenty of nice and not expensive bars and restaurants and ice cream shop- see the bear ice creams...- just beside Collosseum
Beautiful church. Beautiful church. Breathteaking statues of the apostoles. When we went they gave a free audio guide which was nice.

Beautiful, like all churches in the area.. We took the subway here because we had some time to kill one afternoon. It's easy to find, and absolutely beautiful. It was free (donations accepted), and quiet. I enjoyed getting away from the main part of the city, too.

Beautiful, historical church!. The "first of all churches of Rome and of the World" was well worth the time, with so much to try to see in Rome. We found a concise booklet with colored photos for sale in the gift shop for around 3 Euros that helped make the visit more meaningful. We used it for a "self-tour" and had it as a souvenir to take with us. The Holy Staircase is in a building across the street... we felt also very worth the time to visit and be inspired.
Yet another church. Typical richly decorated Catholic church - so many in Rome that after a while they merge into each other.

One of the kind. Its like the mother of all churches! Breathtaking and spectacular. Not too far from the Colloseum, but much calmer, less crowds, and many Bernini sculptures to see. Girls take some scarf to cover your shoulders, and guys do not wear shorts. Amazing staff in gift shop. There is also museum, and possible to take audio guides.
Beautiful Church. Thete are hundreds in Rome but this is truly a beautifful one, very much something to see when in Rome, considered one of the 5 major churches in the city
Baroque & historic. Main Catholic Church and Pope's residence until the 1300s. That means that it served that purpose for a longer period than San Pietro has.

San Giovanni is a Gem. The basilica of San Giovanni in the Lateran is definitely a must see on a trip to Rome. It is the pope's home cathedral as bishop of Rome. Besides being immense, it is full of beautiful sculptures, artwork and tradition.
eery. in a good way. so silent, a real place for contemplation. loved the courtyard.
Beyond Spectacular!. I would highly recommend going inside the San Giovanni. Words cannot express how beautifullydetailed the inside is.
Beautiful Church. This church had all of the artwork and history like St. Peter's, but no one is there.

One of the best. Huge church - but took ages to get to on foot! The scala steps were just across road on left from entrance but were closed during lunch hours when I was there. Would definitely recommend having a look at this church though for the size of it!
Beautiful!. Beautiful.. and free! The church was very close to the B&B we stayed at. Lots of homeless people hanging out around the area, though...

Grand Statues looking down on me. I remember my first visit in January 2005, when I moved to Rome and had stayed for a night in a B&B up the road. Going back to my longer-term booked place, I passed through the church and felt dwarfed by the marble men... fascinating, as I contrasted it with the sense of Royal Palace in BKK, which had been equally overwhelming at an earlier time in my life, though in a very different way.

A MUST. The Pope 's church. Really remarkable in so many ways from the entrance doors to the relics of Peter and Paul. Don't expect the nuns running the gift shop to speak English. Check the calendars before you go to assure that the Holy Steps across the street are also open the hours you intend to visit
Gorgeous church. Despite to a be poorly known, when we compare to the other churchs, this church is a great example of grandiosity. Incredibly beautiful, and well preserved.
gorgeous.. Really amazing gift shop - my boyfriend spent 65 euro on catholic statues and there were plenty more he would have liked too. the architecture of the building is literally amazing.

Beautiful and peaceful. Beautiful building, much less crowded than other major churches and well worth a visit. Not so far off the beaten track - if you're visiting Santa Maria Maggiore, continue on down Via Merulana. Also, buses to the San Callisto catacombs and Ardeatine caves leave from just down the street. Confessions available in multiple languages.
Stunning Basillica. Inside it is just impressive. In my opinion, this is even better than St Peter Basilica. It is a master piece art inside.
San Giovanni in Laterano. A tour guide told us it would be worth the subway right when compared to St. Peter's Basilica and it was.
masterpiece. This basilic is a work of art. Only negative point on the visit is that visitors have to respect dress code strictly
Great Basilica. One of the four major basilicas in Rome - a must see.
Quiet and beautiful. The ceiling is amazing. There were not many crowds which added an aura of reverence and beauty to the exploration of this historic church.
A beautiful church. There are a lot of beautiful churches in Rome, this was one the loveliest.
beautiful. After visiting St. Peters this was a refreshing change. Its a beautiful church. Kind of crazy being in the original Vatican after going to the current vatican

Beautiful Church. When we went there in the early afternoon there wasn't much of a crowd. We got to admire the shear beauty and awe of this place without having to fight them. This place deserves more recognition and should not be missed.
Beautiful church. Large, spacious, beautifully decorated and not as overcrowded as San Pietro with no queues to get in. Read about its history before visiting.
Astonishing. Lovely church. It's a must for every visitor in this lovely town.

Very nice church - a bit of the beaten track. In theory San Giovanni is not really of the beat track as it is directly in the city centre. But compare to other famous churches in Rome there were much less tourists. I really enjoyed the Audio Guide (you can rent it against a donation) which was really interest.
25 Foot Statues of the Apostles!. Amazing, grandiose, worth the visit. My wife liked it more than Saint Peter's.

Amazing cloister. Because the basilica of St. John Lateran has been rebuilt a number of times (fires, etc.) since its 4th century founding, it has a less cohesive feel than many of Rome's other ancient basilicas. However, there are some wonderful things to see, including the bronze doors that were originally on the Curia or Roman senate building, and the divinely wonderful cloister (pay the extra few euro and visit for a completely peaceful and very interesting visit).
Rome. Beautifull church, in some ways more impressive than St.Peters Church!
It's huge. It was the most sober of the Vatican City. Lost of tourists. It's a must see
San Giovanni. The church was very impressive, and beautiful. It's a little out of the way, but I think it was worth being able to say we saw the original vatican!

Easy access, interesting. I have nothing to add to the previous reviews, except that this church is very easy to go to (metro station St.Giovanni Laterano) and is also on your way if you want to visit the Via Appia catacombs by public transportation (bus starts very near the church.)Plus, it is magnificent, do not miss the various papal coats of arms all over the church (floor and ceiling)

Beautiful & Stunning. Having passed this a few times on the sight seeing bus we decided to go in one night at 6. It is a beautiful chapel which is breath taking and stunning. I had spent the previous day in the Vatican museum and Sistine Chapel and to be honest I was pretty disappointed when I was in the Sistine Chapel as it was nothing like a traditional chapel and had thousands of people crammed into it. So when I went to San Giovanni I was over the moon to have found such an amazing chapel that was actually like a chapel! Because it was 6oclock we were there we went to mass which I would recommend going to if you are religious. Unlike the Vatican which charges to get in this is free and if I had the chance to go back I certainly would.It really is a beautiful chapel and the service was lovely.

Stunning. This is one of the 4 major Basilicas in Rome. Upon reading some of the reviews have realized that I can add very little to what was already said. It doesn't matter what your belief or religion. The architecture alone is awe inspiring. I was particularly impressed with the enormous statues of the 12 apostles on either side. If you are in Rome, do not miss this. Well worth the visit.

One of Rome's major basilicas - Beautiful!. Also known as St. John Lateran's, San Giovanni is one of Rome's major basilicas and is the official seat of the pope. It's beautiful - a must see.The Scala Santa, or Holy Stairs, are across the street - a place that pilgrims visit and ascend on their knees while praying.

Just as good as the Saint Peter.. Amazing and completely underpromoted cathedral of Rome. The only reason is it not wordfamous is that Rome also offers the Saint Peter church. In any other city, this would be the nr1 attraction. No entrance fee, no long cues. A "must visit" when in Rome
Cathedral of the Diocese of Rome. Beautiful Cathedral of the 4th century which was established by Emperor Constantine. Was the main papal residence until the 19th century.
My favourite of Rome's churches. There are many churches in Rome, this one in particular is not too be missed due to its stunning interior and history. The marble and gold statues are fantastic.
Bishop of Rome. This church is the seat of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope) and it is extremely beautiful. The statues of all the apostles are absolutely amazing. Very peaceful and historical.
Majestic. Hugh spaces,nice decoration.The church of the Bishop of Rome,the Pope.

worth a visit stunning interior. we took the metro which was very easy and cost only 1.50 euros per trip per person. Stunning beautiful interior. The Pope who is also the Bishop Of Rome says mass here at certain times.

One of the 7 Roman basilicas. One of the main cathedrals in Rome. It is architecturally perfect and if you stand facing into one of the arches in the side aisles and have someone else stand facing the diagonally opposite arch and you whisper into it you will be able to hear then as if they were standing next to you speaking plainly. The paintings are magnificent and the side chapels are beautiful. It is well worth the visit.

How have I missed this?. I've been to Rome a half-dozen times before, but never visited this beauty. It is a gorgeous church! It is easy to visit by taking the Metro to the nearby stop. We saw it in the morning, then walked to the Colliseum from here. Well worth the stop! You will need about an hour to see it, though thirty minutes would do if you can't spare much time.

The first church to be built in Rome!. San Giovanni in Laterano was the first church to be built in Rome. The facade is admirable: Large statues of the saints and the Christ top the facade and the size just takes your breath away.

Should be on your places to visit and easy to get to.. This is the premier basilica of the Christian faith. Opposite are the Holy Steps which Christ is said to have climbed into the house of Pontius Pilate. Free entry and can be reached by bus 117 or metro A to San Giovanni.
fabulous. The Popes church. A must visit, the statues on top of the church can be seen from the centre of Rome.
Better than St. Peter's!. We thought this church was fantastic, beautiful decoration. The nearby steps where pilgrims ascend on their knees was also very moving.
A must see Church. Absolutely breathtaking - a must see. The frescos, mosaics and history leave you wanting more.
Impressive Basilica. It's a great church, It's definitely worth visiting and I was not disappointed at all. Neither will you be.

Yes. Look at the large bronze doors, originally from the Curia in Ancient Rome. Walk around the place and notice the decoration; and the scale. Compare the white and tan color of the marble and carvings to the mosaics. Now look at the relics in their gilded cage. Interesting to see what people believe; and what they venerate, eh?

A significant stop for history and Christians. This is the church of Rome where the Bishop of Rome is seated who is always the Pope. it is considered the most significant Basilica in all of Christendom. Beyond that, it is quite a beautiful place to visit, just inside the old walls of Rome, and across the street from the Sacred Steps.
Beautiful well kept church. The wonderful baroque style of the church and its wonderful statues were spell- binding

Impressive basilica. Everything about this basilica is BIG - the sculptures that surround the center are huge and impressive. This said, I don't think it deserves to be on top 5 places to visit in Rome.
Great history !!. Very interesting. Must get a tour to get most out of history of the place. Lots of pictures to be taken

Awe Inspiring Basilica. This basilica is the archcathedral, the mother of all Roman Catholic churches and it certainly has the characteristics of one. Gorgeous works of art, sculptures, mosaics... I spent a lot of time just marvelling at the decorated ceiling. Words cannot convey the beauty of the place and the serenity. If I had more time, I would have spent a lot of time praying and meditating. However some may not be happy at the numbers of people walking around with their cameras and whispered comments. There were also small shops off to the side of the basilica where one could purchase religious articles. Very important for pilgrims. And of great import was the Scala Sancta (Holy Stairs) just across the street for us to do our devotions.

Gives St. Peter's a run for its money. Well, what would you expect. It's 2nd to St Peters but it has such a peaceful, real, operating church feel in a glorious setting. We were fortunate to visit on a day when there was a chorale service, astounding tenor solo, and the archbishop offer the service. The art is wonderful and the golden mosaics remind me of those in the Ravenna church - gorgeous.

One of the most beautiful Churches in Rome. In Rome there is no lack of churches, that is certain, but San Giovanni is the one we both liked probably the most. It is huge without beeing dark and oppressive ( like St.Peter for example ).
If you only want to visit a few churches, do not miss out this one!
wonderful. We visited this wonderful church called the mother of all churches, and its size and beauty make it beautiful. We bought a lot of cards that we sent to all our friends

Beautiful Church Definitely worth seeing.. Dont miss this church even though it is a little off the beaten tourist routes. The neighborhood is a little sketchy but not dangerous. This church is actually on the site of the very first Christian Church and is actually the Cathedral of Rome. The chapels are beautiful and the nave is very impressive.

Great church!!. We were there between 23-24 of June when they had a big fiesta with traditional food and crafts. We also saw the orchestra and the operetta performing. It was a really nice night just outside the central Rome.

Best part are the doors. The doors from the Senate are fabulous but the rest is unimpressive unless you can get a permit to visit the excavation under it. The scavi are fascinating and the best part. You can arrange an underground visit through Roma Sotteranea. I'd skip what is above ground.

WOW!. We took in the Sunday morning service complete with chorale service and the Archbishop delivering the sermon. So what if it was in Italian and we couldn't understand anything. So what if we're not Catholic. It was astounding to see this brilliant cathedral operating as it was designed to do.
Shame that the place lost its former splendour. It is still the arch basilica, so a must for any visiting catholics

Beautiful. This church is absolutely outstanding. The paintings on the walls and ceiling are incredible and the marble pillars - wow! We thought this was among the loveliest of the churches we saw in Rome.

Beautiful!. What a beautiful place. Well worth the visit particularly if you are interested in architecture and art (and of course religion!).
It's near a tube station too so easy to get to. The sacred stair in the building across the road are also very interesting.
Very nice but far out. Buses not well marked and this wasn't on our map, took us quite a bit of time and overall, wasn't that impressive.
do not miss it. Its the most important church in Rome considered the mother of all churchs of the world. Its more important even than the San Petrus Basilica at the Vatican.

I loved seeing the Curia doors. San Giovanni in Laterano is a lovely church--actually it is the first Vatican and the first Christian church to have been built. The interior is lovely to see (and, it is a free attraction--a rather rare thing in Rome). For me the highlight was seeing the doors that were moved from the Curia (Roman Senate) to the church in the 300s. I really felt the symbolism of that--that the Romans took the doors off of what had once been the most important institution to them (the symbol of their "free" government) and moved them to the church (the institution destined to become the most important institution in the region for 1000 years). Very fortuitous. At any rate, I enjoyed the church and the doors.
Don't miss. to go to the Lateran. Probably the best place in Rome - except Trastevere!

Real gem a bit oustside of Central Rome. We rent a flat in front of San Giovani and the view was really stunning. The basilic is really worth a visit if you stay more than 3 days in Rome as it looks really like a small St Peter. The palazzio on the side is also really worth it as for 5€/person you've got a visit by a guide that tells you a lot on the vatican life and history. Really recommended!
No fees enter!!!!!. Nice place and a very historic site. You can visite this church, near Metro station San Giovanni. Beside this place you can find the Holy Stairs.

Very beautiful church. Everybody thought that because the Pope is in the Vatican that St. Peter's is the Cathedral of the Diocese of Rome. It is not (don't feel bad) I found that out too, recently. It is this beautiful church San Giovanni.The interior is so intricate. We chanced upon this church because they were one of the very few who offers confessions in English. It has certain time each day that they offer it so be sure to check first before going. Otherwise, you can also admire the church on the inside. Here's a sample picture. Enjoy.
Skip the Vatican crowds! Come here!. Beautiful church. Almost no one here. Loved the Cloister

Never miss this when in Rome. You go to rome for the Colosseum of the Vatican, but you really can't miss this one. It's the actual HQ of the Pope and it's overwhelming in it's history and beauty. Must-see
Cathedral of Rome. Separate to the Vatican, this is the official cathedral of Rome and it is a beautiful building inside and out.
nice church. The church is worth visiting as it has a very nice architecture and paintings
Don't miss "The Pope's Church". If you've only been to St. Peter's then you really haven't seen the most important church in Rome.

The Pope's Cathedral is magnificent.. This is the Cathedral of Rome (St. Peters is a Basillica), and is a beautiful Church. The Church has some strange visiting hours, but is still a church and has a Mass schedule to follow.

Beautiful Church!. Stunning church, also away from the city center, so not full of a lot of toursts. Be sure to check out the Santa Scala right next to it if you are a Catholic, it's a pilgrimage for them.

The previous Vatican. This is so awesome!!! Keep in mind that this is the previous Vatican with corresponding art and decoration. Definitely worth the journey and just take 30 minutes to behold one of the most beautiful churches in Rome.

San Giovanni in Laterano. For the history, first church. A little off the beaten path, thus not as crowded. Easy to reach by bus. I believe it was the 17, but there are others. Go the the sacred steps after or before, and then San Clemente
Beautiful. Not far from the city centre this church is well worth the visit. It is beautiful inside. Was the original Vatican, so to speak :)
Wow!. Truly an amazing feat of architecture and art. You must see this old churchM
Breathtaking. Make atrip to visit the Popes church. This is catholic splendor at its most bling!!

Amazing cathedral.. This amazing cathedral is a bit far from the center of Rome, but trust me - you MUST get here. It's a 5 minute metro ride, and it is so much worth it.Enter the San Giovanni gate to Piazza San Giovanni and the cathedral would be to your left. You cannot miss it. It is HUGE.Walk by Porta Asinaria (Gate of the Donkeys), which is one of the minor gateways in the Aurelian Wall.This incredible cathedral was the residence of many popes, and one can see why - it is almost as impressive as St. Peter's basilica.The cathedral is beautifully decorated with dozens of statue, gilded ceiling, many small chapels, and beautiful altar and in incredible looking apse.The acoustics in the cathedral is simply superb, although we did not get a chance to attend a ceremony in it.Don't miss it.

The Pope's Cathedral. Great Roman Church. It is the only Cathedral in Rome. St. Peter's is just a basilica. The pope's church as Bishop of Rome is St. John Lateran. It has its own feast day in the calendar of the Church. Baptistry next door is a wonder, and the Sacra Scala - brought from Jerusalem by Emperor Constantine's mother is right across the street. Climb it on your knees! Easily accessible by bus. Five minutes (or so) from St. Mary Major.

Beautiful church. We saw more than a dozen churches during our trip to Italy. San Giovanni stood out as one of the most beautiful-just stunning. It's a bit out of the way, but absolutely worth a visit.
beautiful church. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome - the cloisters were definitely worth visiting too.
Magnificent. We almost skipped this church, since it is a bit out of the way, but were very glad we didn't. Fantastic. The 12 apostle statues were particularly stunning.
An incredible and historic church. You must visit this church to put the entire history of Christianity and the Vatican into perspective.
Attended mass here. Beautiful Basilica! Huge. Inside is incredible! Worth a stop!
San Giovanni in Laterano. Absolutely beautiful. Worth visiting. Recommend the audio.

Gorgeous Cathedral. Rome is not at a loss for beautiful cathedrals and basilicas, but this one, "The Pope's Church" is not to be missed! Beautiful architecture and masterful sculptures! It's a must see while in Rome. Also there is a great trattatoria across the street - - Silvo - - for some excellent food afterwards!

Rome's City center is the largest of Europe. There is something for everyone in the center, it is a multi-centric city, there are poles of attraction all over the center, take time to walk all around, or take a guided tour.

My favourite place in Rome. This was totally unexpected, but the moment I stepped into San Giovanni, I was in love.
Even though smaller, it's not as touristy as St Peter's in the Vatican and IMHO better. The decorated ceiling is fantastic.
Entrance is free, but the cloister costs 3 euros extra.
Impressive and beautiful. This is a must see on any travellers visit to Rome. An immense and ornate church, the central aisle is lined with more-than-lifesize white marble statues of the apostles.

Cathedral of the Pope. After a guided tour through the Vatican museum and St Peter I was not expecting the big hit you get when you enter the Cathedral. Clearly a landmark to visit in Rome. Still a functioning church thus the atmosphere is respectful. A must-go.

Beautiful and peaceful. Beautiful, not as touristy with less people just standing around taking photos. Really moving! Especially the Baptistry. Have to be willing to appreciate the holiness and quiet beauty of the place. The cloisters are small but have beautiful mosaic columns and roman gravestones.

Forget the Vatican queues and head for somewhere quieter and equally historic and interesting. Magni8ficent church. There was a long wait to see the Vatican so we opted for St John Lateran instead. As in all Italian churches there was no entrance charge it was uncrowded and quiet and the art and sculpture was magnificent. The saying "Peter's Pence" originates here from the practice of throwing change down onto the tomb of St Peter which is housed here. There is a small gift shop tucked away in a side chapel where we bought a calendar illustrated with ancient maps of the world. Well worth a visit, allow a couple of hours and the tourist buses all stop nearby.

the basilica of Rome. This is an enormous church, which you can enter from the side or front. It has been on this site since the 4th century, but most of what you see is Francesco Borromini's Baroque remodeling, which ramped up the scale of everything. For 3 Euros you can visit the much earlier cloister which is peaceful and charming. It's columns and arcade walls are fine examples of the tiny mosaic work done by the Casmati family and thereafter referred to a "cosmatesque." There is also a large octagonal baptistry reached by its own entrance behind and to the right of the apse. One of the chapels contains a lovely early mosaic apse wall. There are no visitors except the occasional priest or seminary student.
Beautiful!!. Absolutely one of my favorite churches in Rome!!!!

The world's first church for Catholics. Not only is this the first Papal church given by Constantine to the reigning Pope when he legalized the Catholic Faith, but was a palace before that with a stunning history. The Laterani family was martyred and the Palace stolen because of their faith and how ironic that it should then become the greatest of churches. The statues of the Apostles are some of the greatest art in the world and unlike Florence, all free to see! My husband counted the dime sized triangular tiles in the mosaic floor (The same pattern found in The Holy Cross in Jerusalem Church which was also a palace) and calculated that one circle alone contained over 2,400 tiles each cut and laid by hand. This is mind boggling when you realize that there are thousands of these circles in the entire church. The Table of the Last Supper is enshrined here as well as the relics of both Sts. Peter and Paul.

Buying Pendants. My husband and I just recently visited San Giovanni in Laterano, it was absolutely gorgeous and yes a refreshing taste of a somewhat unknown religious place in Rome. The Scala Sancta was just so touching to see and watch the people climb up on there knees. A very emotional site to say the least.On a side note I was wondering if anyone knows of a place where I can purchase pendants online from San Giovanni? I purchased a few when we are there and now realize that I was supposed to buy more for family and friends. I know it might be quite far fetched to expect there to be some sort of website that I can purchase these on, but I figure it doesnt hurt to ask. Thank you for all the replys!

Beautiful church. It wasn't planned as a stop but thanks to a delayed plane it was time to freestyle and Rome around well Rome. Unfortunately I didn't know much about this beautiful church prior to arrival so I didn't know what a lot of stuff was but I took a lot of pictures and looked it up afterwards and wow. My only regret was not getting over to the scala sancta which is must and will be the first stop on my next trip.

Simply Gorgeous. San Giovanni in Laterano is THE official Cathedral of Rome. The architecture is truly breath-taking. The statues make you feel like you are in the presence of greatness and the mosiacs are just OUT OF THIS WORLD. The Scala Sancta (Holy Stairs) right across the street and are truly a humbling experience. If you have the time definitely climb the stairs on your knees in prayer.
Must Visit. One of the Roman churches you must visit. A very large but superbly maintained church. A lot of gold glistening in the afternoon sunshine

A Must See. A beautiful church. Rich in history. I think this is where Constantine established the first Christian Church and where previous Popes stayed (before the Vatican/ St Peter's). It's called the Mother of Churches. One of the highlights in our trip. Highly recommend

Pay to see the courtyard. This church is amazing inside but check out the beautifully preserved outer courtyard (small fee) to see some of the best medieval architecture this side of The Alhambra in Granada, Spain.
most beautific basillica in rome. This basillica is amazing and beautiful. We enjoyed our visit very much.

Statues of the apostles are wonderful. The church is the one the pope attends on holidays. It is large and grand looking but the 12 statues of the apostles are what is worth seeing. We walked from the Colosseum(about 20 minutes).

The Original Vatican. A must-see for Catholics. It is the site of the original Vatican and contains (maybe!) the skull bones of St Peter and St Paul, and the Holy Stairs nearby are testament to faith. Its location, inside the old city walls, is also interesting.
OK. We know it is a very significant church and quite beautiful, but the primary reason for our trip was archaeology of Rome.
The first catholic cathedral, wow!. To attend a mass in this wonderful church was a mystic experience! And I´m not a religious person!

Very Historic Place!. It is so much larger than I thought and very beautiful. The altar holds the skulls of Peter and Paul. It is a little far from the city center but not from the Colisseum and there is a taxi stand just outside to get back.

One of the best churches in Rome. If I were to recommend 5 churches to see in Rome,Lateran would definately be one of them. The Pope's Church,as it is called, has some of the most amazing statues of the disciples,with the symbolic items that identify them. Generally a beautiful and large church,and slightly off the beaten path, but not to be missed if you are wanting to get a good sampler of Rome churches under your belt
Lovely church. For a christian this church is something you must see in your lifetime! What a beautiful statues and colors.

A special place to visit. This is a special place to visit. Take the audio-tour which is free with a donation to learn about the church and it's history.Be sure to get there before noon and leave enough time to see everything as the church closes at 12:30PM for several hours.

Gorgeous cathedral but couldn't climb the holy steps. The cathedral is unique with the statues of the apostles in the interior and it's history as the original home of the Pope. The steps moved here for pilgrims were locked up taking away one of the important experiences of this location. Easy public transit.

impressive cathedral. We visited the cathedral Monday in the afternoon and it was not crowded at all. The facade is very impressive and the interiors as well. I am not a religious person but I was impressed by the architecture , the sculptures and the beautiful mosaics . Don't forget to admire the floor mosaics , they are very beautiful.
WOW!!. As a papal basilica, this place is incredibly large and beautiful. A masterpiece not to be missed if you like old churches!

Very beautiful, well worth a visit. Can be easily reach by Metro.
It is a beautiful church and I am glad I made the effort to go and visit.
Beautiful church. Loved the cloisters - so pretty. Great facade and beatiful inside the church, a lot quietr than the Vatican and just as memorable. Well worth a visit!

Kind of boring. San Giovanni is a big duomo, of course, but it isn't really impressive or interesting compared with the other sights in the city. The only thing you might want to check out is the attached baptistry, which has some interesting 4th-century mosaics. Otherwise, you might want to skip this church.

Rather Serene. So manyt of Rome's churches are overwhelming and in a sense this is too; but there's a humanity to this church that has drawn me (a confirmed atheist) back for a second time. On balance I think its the cloister - its so beautiful, calm yet nurturing.
mother of all churches. beautiful mozaieks.Its octagonal chapel stood as an example for the next chapels

Beautiful and worth the trip. We visited as part as an private tour, so we had transportation to site.
Church was very beautiful and it was wonderful to learn more about it from our guide. It is a must see when in Rome.
The mother church of Cristianity. The first, the number one church. Amazing place. Beautiful. It is a place of prayers for all nations.

The real cathedral of Rome. The basilica is very pretty in the inside with enormous statues of the apostles and it's grand in the outside, with lots to see both inside and out. The entrance door in the left there is a bronze madonna holding a baby that lots of people touch and even get very emotional - you will notice that the foot of the child and one of the fingers of the madonna is shiny and not green like the rest. There is also the Scala Santa, supposedly the real stairs from the house of Pilate in Jerusalem used by Christ when he was condemn to crucifixion. Outside there is the oldest bapstistery and the oldest obelisk of Rome and other ruins that I'm not very sure what they represent. These collection of buildings are also part of the Vatican (despite the fact they are not within the VAtican grounds). San Giovanni is not far from the Colliseum and in the way it's worth stopping to see the church of S. Clemente.
Fabulous. This was a glorius church and has been incredibly decorated within

Monolithic. The church of St. John Lateran is gigantic, a bit far from our hotel which was beside Piazza Navona, but well worth the trek. You can reach the church from the Coliseum in about 20 minutes.
Alot of fun. Central with parties on may,great bars and fun in the centre
church I like best. The guide was excellent and our group loved seeing this most beautiful part of histoty
Don't miss. San Giovanni in Laterano is a beautiful church and well worth the visit. Its history is as impressive as its architecture.

A very powerful and holy basilica in Rome. This was the only basilica where one has to climb up the steps leading to the main church on one's knees and while inside, one can instantly feel the vibes. It's an experience to treasure while one is in Rome
excellent to visit. excellent to visit, beautiful church we went in April/May 2012
Gorgeous Site. We took the tiny city bus here after visiting the Coliseo. It is far enough away for the center of activity in town to be a relatively chill location.

A magnificent basilica!. San Giovanni lies a bit outside the main historic area, but is well worth a visit. The small electric bus Nr. 117 goes directly to San Giovanni from the Corso. My favourite part is the basicila's facade - it is an outstanding example of perfectly proportioned classical architecture exuding a sense of calm, elegance and grandeur in equal measure. It is even more remarkable that the facade is hemmed in by other wings, yet its power beauty shine through undiminished.

Amzing Church and monument. This was the initial Vatican if I am not mistaken ..before the Pope moved to Avignon ( France )From Avignon moved to the Vatican use the subway to reach it station Laterano ( of course ) Amzing monument .. doors from a roman temple Across you willfind the most amazing gem..the Holly Stair ..the stair that Jesus walked in Pontius Pilat house .. stair was broght to Rome and covered in wood .. we walked in our knees to the top praying ,,, amazing place .. ( you are not allowed to walk on it I mean you can .. but it would be a sacrilege )Beware they break at lunch so check the hours Cannot miss it is in a nice building in a plaza across San Giovanni Church ..entry is from the left Enjoy Bobby
Overwhelmingly beautiful. The statuary and art are fabulous. Don't miss the baptistry across the street.

Rome´s Cathedral. Fantastic Church full of history and ceiling of gold !The ancient bronze doors of Curia, the roman senate house, are here !!!In front the basilica is the first pope´s palace with the Scala Santa, supposed from Poncio Pilatos house.An devotion act to go upstairs on your knees is a silent pray of houndreds.....mistic !

Most beautiful church ever. This was a hidden jem, an accidental find in our last 2 hours in Roma, i was very moved, it seemed a very holy place with the most lovely nuns staffing the giftshop. From the outside it looks a little ordinary & the begger on the stairs may turn you off, but it is well worth a couple of hours of your time. Simply Stunning holy place.

Beautiful Church. Our daughter got married in the chapel of this church and it is a gorgeous church. Lot of history in the place. If memory serves me right, I think it is closed from 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. daily.
beautiful large church. you see the richiness of the Roman Catholic church

Worth a stop. On our last day we ran out of sites to see and turned to our guide book for suggestions. We ended up here and were surprised that this church had been so overlooked. Very nice, grandiose, good photo op, but dress appropriately - no shorts.
A real must see. A stunning and beautiful must see. IT has a lovely peacful cloister that you can ivist with extraordinary twisted marble pillars.

The Archbasilica of Rome. Built by Constantine the Great in the 4th century, it is the oldest and ranks first among the four major basilicas to be built in Rome. The size of this basilica is not as big as St. Peter but that does not make this basilica least important as it is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome, and the official seat of the Pope, where he acts as the bishop of Rome and the head church in the world. The highlights are: i) the two-storied portico that makes up the facade of the basilica and the large statues of Christ & the saints on top of the façade dating from the 18th century;ii) the central bronze doors from the Curia (Senate House) in the Imperial Forum;iii) the Roman statue of Constantine the Great (at the left end of the portico) which was found in the ruins of the Bath of Diocletian;iv) the Cosmatesque pavement in the nave dates from the 14th century;v) the statues in the nave depict Apostles and Evangelists. Closed doors painted on the wall behind the statues represent gateways to Heavenly Jerusalem. Above the statues are relief panels with Old Testament scenes on the left and related scenes from the New Testament on the right, all these dating from the 17th century;vi) the cloisters date from early 13th century;vii) the mosaic in the apse dates from 800, the year Charlemagne was crowned in Rome. It depicts Christ with the Apostles in the center, Christ with Constantine and Pope Sylvester I on the left and St Peter, Pope Leo III and Charlemagne on the right. Pope Leo II has a square nimbus, showing that he was alive when it was made.viii) the Scala Sancta (Holy Stairs) nearby and the baptistery (the oldest in Christendom). Access to the basilica is free but a minimum admission fee of €2 is applicable for access to the cloisters. Personally, I love to visit this basilica more than the St. Peter because there are fewer crowds here compared to St. Peter and I could take my time to slowly admire the whole basilica, the cloisters and the Scala Sancta as well as the baptistery nearby.  On a side note, there are two shops in the basilica, I bought a lot of souvenirs from one of the shops (at the side in line with the back door) in this basilica instead of those shops scatter around the city and the Vatican (I think the quality is about the same but price is at least cheaper than St. Peter, just make sure you inspect every item as some stocks may not be very new) as my small contribution to support this basilica. I allocated a full day to visit 4 basilicas (except the St. Peter), the Trevi fountain, the Spanish Steps and end the day at Piazza del Popolo. Send message to me if you are interested to know the details (provided that if you can walk a bit)!
Don't miss this amazing church. One of the oldest & most beautiful churches in Rome. Beautiful paintings and statues. Definitely worth a look.
One of the most beautiful basilicas in Rome. Wonderful cathedral with beautiful paintings and statues, typical catholic basilica,
worth the walk. We walked from the Colosseum and found thsi nto be very worth while, using Ricks book really heled too but they have audio guides there if you need them

City on a Monte. Beautiful countryside drive to the city. Parking was easy and close to the walled city. There are many shops inside the walls. Goole history of the city before you go so you know a little more about the history.

The Pope's church. This looks like a mini St Peter's from outside, it's the official parish Church of the Pope. While you're there; Directly to the left is the Santa Scala and a hundred yards in front of the main door is the Chapel of the Holy Relics which contains the crown of thorns and the sign Pilot had put on the Cross.

Not quite like the Las Vegas wedding chapel. The Archbasilica of Rome, the seat of the Pope's Church (no, it's not St. Peter's), and Boromini's greatest triumph. Didn't think I could be moved by my 6th day in Rome, and at least 10 church/basilica visits, but this is the mover and shaker. There is a free audio guide, but come befor 3 PM so you can have some time to see this gigantic place. Not counting the 11 or so Popes buried in this church, the scale and finish of the building is awe inspiring. Not to be missed.

Beautiful basilica. While St. Peters is jammed full of people, St. John's is not nearly as crowded and still a joy to visit. The statues of the apostles lining the main corridor and the small chapels off to the sides are quite beautiful.

The most important church in Rome. Many people don't know that San Giovanni is technically, the "home church" of the Pope--the official seat of the Bishop of Rome. It's impressive to see, if only for the massive statues of the apostles inside, as well as the huge Egyptian obelisk in the square--purportedly the oldest and tallest in Rome. If you go, don't miss visiting the nondescript building across the street, which houses the Scala Santa, supposedly the actual steps from Pontius Pilate's palace in Jerusalem where Jesus was tried. Pilgrims come from all over the world to climb the stairs on their knees. Very moving, whether you are Catholic or not.

Beautiful Church. loved the grandness of the church and the stairs that was supposed to be where Christ walked on. as with all churches in Rome, I wish they could have provided us with a little leaflet pointing to which are the key attractions on the church rather than make you sit by a booth and drop 2 euros to hear a commentary about the church.
Fight for the best church. The church is beautiful and the stories behind it are fascinating. I recommend taking the audio guide to learn more about it.

Romes other Basilica. Amazing basilica - look out for the ancinet bronze doors at the rear that came from the original Roman Forum and go across the square to the sacred steps purported to have been the ones Jesus climbed with the cross.
The most Spirtual place in Rome. 2nd only to the Vatican,to the most spirtual place in the world,and kneeeling and doing the Sacred stairs is a must
tremendous church. it is the most important church in Rome after basilic if Saint Peter. Worth seeing
Vatican Property. Do do the Vatican full day tour and see 4 properties. This is a wonderful Basilica with lovely art. I highly recommend this one.

Another overwhelmingly beautiful church in Rome. We spent a day walking from one church to another in Rome. Each of these are so overwhelmingly ornate that it became a case of sensory overload after a while. Bring your wide-angle lens and some Euro coins to illuminate the artwork. Your best bargain in Rome
Wow, must see!. Very historical. We had a guide, so she told us all about it. Lots of things to see in the area too.

Nice church, papal altar etc. worth a look but won't take more than 10 mins. Papal altar on view.
Don't forget the holy stairs across the road
Nice altar. As many churches in Rome, it makes no exception: it's beautiful. Plus you have a special altar and the 'holy stairs' are close by which makes the trip worthy.

Pope's Church, Rome's Cathedral. When visiting Rome one must see the 4 main Basilica's. San Giovanni in Laterano was in fact the first to be built and is the Pope's home church. The imposing statues that are adorned on the top can be seen for miles. Inside is a sight to behold and take time to take it all in. Many so called ' relics' are kept here. Near by are the Santa Scala (Sacred Steps) and the Baptistry (oldest in the world). Although the Basilica is open ' all day' the Santa Scala and the Baptistry are closed for siesta from 1230 until 1530. Another Basilica is Santa Maria in Maggiore which is about 15 minutes walk straight up Via Merulana from Piazza San Giovanni.The other Basilica's are St Peter's which needs no introduction and St Paul's Outside the Wall's. This is well worth the Metro ride to see as the cloisters and front facade which are like no other.

Gorgeous and historic.. San Giovanni in Laterano was the first openly Christian basilica built in the city of Rome. The 18-th century facade is impressive, with large statues of Christ and the apostles at the summit. The tall bronze green doors were moved to this church from Rome's ancient Senate building in the 1650s to remind everyone that the church was Europe's lawmaker. The church is huge and impressive. No wonder, as it's where the pope occasionally holds mass. The mosaic half dome over the apse glistens, and the bishop's chair beneath is where newly-elected popes must sit before the can officially become pope. (Methinks the ceremony is likely timed so that the shaft of light entering the window above left falls squarely on the bishop's chair.)It's a good idea to combine a visit to this church with a visit to the Holy Staircase, which is right across the street. It's also not far from San Clemente, another fascinating religious site.
Glad we went. I was as impressed with this smaller basilica as I was with St. Peter's.
Worth the trip. Easy access via the subway. This Church is gorgeous and was not at all busy when I visited. You can really explore without the throngs of people like at St. Peter's
what a place. one of the most beautifull churchs of Rome.....and you can go to the holly staris....right next the churc
St. John Lateran. Beautiful church and artifacts, well worth the visit

The First constructed Christian Church in Rome. Its historic importance makes it a must but add the immense statuary of the 12 Apostles plus the tombs of important popes plus the abundance of gold plus the sacred staircase plus the museum and you cannot miss this Church. It is on a direct walk from the Coliseum

One of the top church visit experiences available in Rome. Having visited Rome on numerous occasions, we consider San Giovanni in Laterano a top two or three church visit experience in the city of Rome. Combined with the Scala Santa attraction, just across the street, this makes a 'must-see' visit, even on the shortest of trips to Rome. Only a visit to the Vatican and St. Peters could be considered a higher priority if you don't have time to see both. Visits here are free and you can take photos inside. There is much to love about San Giovanni. It is not only the ArchBasilica, even higher in the pecking order than St. Peters, but it is also considered the Mother of All Churches. Its history is outstanding, being founded by Constantine himself, it was the papel residency until 1309 and Popes where coronated here until the 19th century. Thus, while St. Peters grabs most of the attention today, it is San Giovanni that was the Star of the Catholic World for most of the past sixteen hundred years. But San Giovanni is not just about history. It is a magnificently decorated church with many beautiful things to see. The square in front of the church is nice and large allowing excellent views of the Basilica's classic Baroque facade, one of the finest in Rome. Inside, you will also find a huge nave lined with massive and beautiful statues of the twelve apostles. The marble floor tiles and the decorative ceiling, round off one of the most attractive nave areas in Rome. You will also find a huge, gorgeous alter, lined with attractive artwork as well as very nice mosaics present in the dome and chapel areas. The huge church doors and beautiful outdoor Logia area outside the church are also well worth finding while at San Giovanni. Overall, the beauty found inside and outside San Giovanni is really only matched by St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican. There are no other rivals to San Giovanni in this regard. To visit San Giovanni, you can the San Giovanni (Metro) stop to visit the church but it is still quite a walk so you might want to just take taxi to this location if you plan to start your day visitations at this location. In addition to a visit to San Giovanni in Laterano and the Scala Santa across the street, you can walk up Via Giovanni in Laterano to the very good Basilica di San Clemente and onward to the ancient Coliseum and Forum areas, making for a great 1/2 day or more of attraction visitations in Rome.

A beautiful Basilica. We nearly missed seeing this Basilica as it was not one that had been recommended to us. It is beautiful and we spent ages there.We rented headsets which is not something my husband usually likes to do but we were very glad we did as we learned so much about the history.Next to the Basilica is a building which houses the Scala Sance (Holy Stairs)............."The Scala Sancta (Holy Stairs), wooden steps that encase white marble steps, are, according to Roman Catholic tradition, the staircase leading once to the praetorium of Pilate at Jerusalem, hence sanctified by the footsteps of Jesus Christ during his Passion. The marble stairs are visible through openings in the wooden risers. Their translation from Jerusalem to the complex of palaces that became the ancient seat of popes in the 4th century is credited to Saint Helena, mother of the Emperor Constantine I. In 1589, Pope Sixtus V relocated the steps to their present location in front of the ancient palatine chapel (the Sancta Sanctorum). Ferraù Fenzoni completed some of the frescoes on the walls". (Copied from the information on St John of Lateran).When we were there the Scala Sancta was closed and unfortunately we did not have the time to go back.If you are planning to visit any churches in Rome you must see this one. Well worth the visit.
Very nice basilica!. The church is in the same style of St. Peter's and is very nice inside!

Gorgeous church. This is a gorgeous church.We were lucky to arrive when there was a special mass for pilgrims in progress. We entered through a side door and were able to observe. The cloister garden in the center (small fee) has some ancient objects.
The Pope's Cathedral. This cathedral is one of the most beautiful in all of Rome. There is a wonderful cloister that has, gorgeous mosaics and beautiful frescoes. It is a short walk from the Metro.

FIRST CHURCH OF POPES 1309. We did a church walk from our hotel near "REPUBLICA" but you can take m1 metro till San Giovani stop -4th stop and walk from there . In same area you can see other beautiful & interesting churches such as the ''Basilica S. Croce in Gerusalem, Giovani Lateano and Scala Santa (sacred stairs)

Beautiful. This Basilica is very beautiful, the ceiling is magnificent as are all the statues and paintings. We were taken their as part of a guided tour and our guide pointed out all the interesting things and gave us information which we would probably have missed if we had visited on our own. This church is certainly worth a visit.
great church. it was a very special place it was very peacful you felt a part of history there is nothing i didnt like about it

Magnificent. One of the papal churches of Rome, San Giovanni in Laterano is a grand dame. Truly huge. I love the ancient Cosmati mosaic floors as well as the renaissance tile floors that provide visually challenging perspectives and one moves about them.
Love this church. What a beautiful church this was!!!!! I would love to go back and see this again.
interesting although big and "heavy"!. Interesting but obviously not a MUST on a first trip to Rome!
S. Giovanni. Worth visiting. We learned at the Vatican that it is the second location used by the Pope.
Popes Church. This is a beautiful Church, striking statues of the Apostles in the Nave Aisle, a place of peace and tranquility.
One of the Four Main Basilicas to See. This is a must see. Truly breathtaking. The inside is probably the second most beautiful cathedral in Rome.

Worth the stop. All the churches start to look a little bit alike after awhile but this one is worth the stop as it features awesome statues of each of the 12 apostles and is just across the street from the Holy Steps which you will also want to see.
Beautiful Church. Fantastic church with an impressive ceiling. Make sure you visit the very beautiful cloister.
Beautiful Large Church!. We were lucky to have this beautiful Church include on a tour we took. What a surprise, so many statues and works of art, very impressive!
Worth the walk. A bit away from main attractions but worth the walk - has more soul than St Peters - amazing cloisters dont miss them .
Worth a visit. One of the four Vatican churches. Lots of history and beauty. Worth a stop/
A small wonder worth a look. Probably overlooked by most but actually a really nice find.
Large Cathedral. A very large cathedral with many different architectural styles. A lot of extra fees for various guides
Very beautifull church and a highlight of our trip. everything and the easy transport links from the metro san giovanni 5 mins walk or if weather is nice you can always walk arnd 20 mins from centre
Awesome. This is the first cathedral in Rome - one of the 4 of the Holy See - astonishing and dazzling in its decoration and history.

The cathedral of Rome. Most people seem to think that St. Peter's is the cathedral of Rome but it isn't. The Pope is the bishop of Rome and San Giovanni is his cathedral. It is a placed steeped in history, of the church and of Rome. Well worth a visit.
Well worth the visit, easy to get to on the bus or metro. Worth taking the audio so that you can get a really good understanding of the different areas, especially round the cloisters
Sacred Steps. I climbed the sacred steps on my hands and knees. It was a wonderful experience.
My favorite church in all of Rome. Fantastic sculptures of the 12 apostles, the artwork was superb and the gift shop was pretty good too!

Absolutely wonderful.. Don't waste hours queuing for the Sistine Chapel. Visit this marvellous ancient building instead.
After all it is the cathedral church of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Bishop of Rome, i.e the Pope!
Can't speak highly enough of San Giovanni.
Must see. Such a beautiful, breathtaking place. It is a little out of the way, so take public transport. Don't try to walk it from the Coliseum

Forgotten Cathedral that should not forget to see  . This is my favorite cathedral in Rome. It was the original main cathedral before San Peters Basilica was built. All the detail, art, and status are worth seeing. There are several attractions nearby like the Scala Santa among others.

Roots of Christianity really beautiful don't miss it. I had to convince my family to go because we walk form the Coliseum to the church by it was worth looking at this great church found it by Constantine before the separation of the church

Fascinating architecture and history. Check out each of the niches along the corridors; look down the enclosed stairway at the statuary. The vaults overhead are positively stunning. If you exit the cathedral after dark, be sure to take photos of the green-lighted buildings across the street. I took several on automatic exposure with my camera held very steady and still against the building (to avoid a blurred result from slight movement while the shutter clicked), and they are some of the most interesting photos of the city.

The Pope's Home Base. An incredible church, this is the Pope's "home base" in Rome and the first legal Christian church in Rome. It was founded by Constantine way back in the day, so there has been a church on this site for something like 1700+ years.The architecture here is truly incredible, with a massive nave, a beautifully coffered ceiling and frescoes everywhere. The side chapels are filled with beautiful works of art and offer a quiet place to sit and rest.Cool fact: the massive center bronze doors are the original Roman Senate house doors. Think about all the people that passed through them...many popes, kings, Julius Caesar, Cicero, and you...if they are open. Next door is the Lateran palace - home to the popes until they moved to the Vatican, and now a museum with limited hours. Visiting this basilica is taking a trip back to the earliest history of the Church and to me, sometimes feels more accessible than St. Peter's.
Gorgeous. Its amazing!. Even more in a sunny day because its enlightened and you can appreciate the work done on the ceiling.

A church worth visiting. This church is massive and beautiful. When you first step inside, the huge, sculpted statues of Christ and the Saints line the center walk to the altar. The entire area is full of decor, from the floor to the ceiling and the cloisters.If you need to purchase some religious items (rosaries, pendants, crosses, etc), their souvenir shop has the best prices. The church is quite far from central Rome so it is best to take the metro to get there.
Impressive and not very known. It's a small St Peter!! A must for visitors, right in the Bus connection to Catacombs
Great art. One of many churches not to miss, very ornate and the oriiginal official church of the Pope

One of the hearts of Catholicism. Everything. The architecture, the sculptures and paintings but especially the atmosphere that truly inspires meditation and prayers without the circus that Saint Peter's has become.

Out of the way but worth the visit. Finally made it to San Giovanni after many trips to Rome. This church is gigantic and very impressive. A great place to sit, rest and take in the grandeur of this lovely church.
Ex residence of popes. Beautiful cathedral outside and inside with magnificent doors and statues. Get yourself a guide book to be related the lonf story of this place.

The most beautiful church. the most beautiful church I have ever seen in my life . it is amazing , the design , the drawings . everything . even outside , the square is so beautiful with the Egyptian Obelisk . a place that worth visiting
The Pope's Cathedral is worth a visit. The baroque is nice but it is more soothing and easy on the eye than St Peter's
Mind Boggling. This building is a beautiful work of art and praise.
Beautiful Church on a Very Large Scale. The detail, the sculpture, the pillars, the side altars, the extraordinary history of the church. The Pope is the Pastor. This is his church!
For a cathedral, not that impressive. Maybe I had seen enough churches, but this one didn't do it for me.
Wonderful Art. The basilica is superb, also try and visit the little local antica basilica next door
Saw this church twice. Once with a tour group and then again on our own. it was better when we were on our own.

Beautiful Church, but be sure to check out the Vatican Museum Attached. My husband, daughter and I visited during a trip to Rome. We toured Basilica, and then saw that their was a Vatican Museum attached. We tried to enter, but was told to come back at noon - it was around 11:30. We went to Santa Scala, and returned about 12:10 and it was empty. We saw a sign that had posted opening times at hourly intervals, and asked if we missed it. We were told no, paid about 5 euros each and went through security. The Security Guard asked us if we needed an English guide and we were given a guide who took us through the museaum, giving the three of us a personal tour, which was facinating. The funny thing was, the guard followed our 'tour' and had to keep turning lights on and off as we went. Not sure why he was there, maybe he was afraid we would knock our guard unconscious and sit on the Papal Throne, but it was a wonderful tour and I highly recommend it.

The Cathedral of Rome. You can't miss this amazing church, huge and magnificent! What drilled me was the inner part, where you have the sacresty: beautiful 500 wooden cases and a small chapel to pray in private.Try to discover who was buried in the cript under the main altar and whose pieces are buried on the top of the main altar!!
Beautiful church. Try to get a tour of the adjoining museum. They seem to allow visits only by the tours and in January these ran on the hour.
Beautiful. Sunday morning masses almost continously, but the tourists can walk around - this is a big basilica. The statues are really, really spectacular, amazing!

Must See- Better than Colosseum. This is the second most impressive Basillica in Rome- St. Paul's is the first. Inside is statues of the twelve apostles with each statue something like 15 feet tall on a 7 ft tall pedistle. This is a must visit. The artwork in the ceiling and the sheer size of the Cathedral is breath-taking. My wife and I saw the major sites in central Rome and the Colosseum and we were most moved and impressed by the Cathedral.

Near Metro stop - beautiful - worth a visit. Rome has soooo many beautiful churches. Without having seen ALL of them, I can't say if San Giovanni is THE most beautiful one. But it certainly is fantastic and being not far from the metro stop San Giovanni, it is a good one to visit especially for people who do not wish to walk too much. We approached from its front facade and thought it was closed with its gates shut and luckily wandered over to its side and found the inconspicuous entrance there. It's a pleasant walk (maybe 1/3 mile?) from here to the colosseum.
Really nice church!. Really important church in Catholic world. Popes used to be in this one. It's really really nice.

Church of Rome. The bishop of Rome officiates at this gorgeous church. All of Rome's churches are incredibly beautiful, but this one happens to be the principal church of Rome, apart from the Vatican.
A lovely basilica!. Near our hotel. A number of busses will take you to various sites from around the basilica. See review.
The first Vatican!. This church was the first Vatican and is absolutely beautiful! It's worth the walk. When you leave, cross the street and do the holy stairs as well.

go to the cloister!. The basilica is not the best in Rome, but has fine mosaics and a fair smattering of relics. The cloisters are well worth visiting and may be free - nobody stopped me. The baptistery next door also has excellent relics.
Better then St. Peters. This is the original Christian Church provided by Constantine. Less crowded, very interesting. We used the MP3 files from Rick Steves.
Amazing. Read up before you travel to take it all in and arrive as early as you can ion the morning to miss crowds.
Cathedral. Huge until you really step into St. Peter's Basilica. It is also the cathedral of the Bishop of Rome - the Pope.

Fantastic!!. Take the metro to get here; it's a pretty quick trip and then a short walk. The inside of this church is beautiful and very bright (a lot of white on white). Try and count all of the cherubs; they are everywhere!!
Maybe our favorite church in Rome. Didn't expect such a wonderful building inside. A WOW factor when you walk in. Statues of all the disciples. Simply beautiful inside. A must see.
San Giovanni. What a magnificent church. This church has some features of the vatican.
A very important place for a church historian. Many interesting things encluding Scala Santa and the Sancta Santissima wher we also could go.
Worth visiting. Beautiful architecture, impressive statues inside. Next to the Basilica don't forget to visit the Scala Sancta.
Basilica. Christmas time market outside on the street, was also lovely. Beautiful Basilica. I always like to visit when I'm in the city.

Also see the Scala Sancta. St. John Lateran church is worth a visit. I would suggest renting the audio guide which is quite informative. Do not miss the Scala Santa - the sacred steps - which are in a separate building across the street from St. John's Basilica. Devout Christian ascend the 28 steps on their knees. This stairway was brought from Jerusalem to Rome by Constantine's mother in 326 a.d. These stairs are supposed to be the ones Jesus climbed on his way to his trial before Pontius Pilate.
Gorgeous architecture. One of the four basilicas with a holy door. From ceiling to floor this is amazing.

Exceptional Church. This church was a surprise. We had not expected such a large well preserved structure. This was a great find. Highly recommended. Take the Metro from Terminii and get off at the San Giovanni stop.
latran. the president of france is the chanoine of this church also prayers for many saints
a site not to be missed. speechless........................it's feeling of history and who walked before you in this Holy structure
My favorite "church" in Rome. It´s amazing, huge, and a kind of museum...a lot of statues, monuments, etc. You have to go there. The "Scala Santa", a place near the Basilica is one "must".

beautiful building. This is one of the four basilicas on the Rome pilgrimage. Very beautiful interior much of what you expect from any basilica, you could spend a good hour or more here. If you go make sure you cross the road and visit the Holy Steps. These steps are believed to be steps that Jesus walked on , they are covered but you can see through in parts and see the wood. You can only go up the steps on your knees reading prayers as you go up this will take you some time.
Powerful experience. I visited many many churches in Rome and this was one of the most majestic places of worship I have been in.

largest church in rome. beautiful. there is a market right outside and the "Holy Steps" to the left. A must see Church, the second best out of all the 10 or so churches we visited in Rome (best being St Peter's Basilica).
Rome's Cathedral. Most people think that St. Peter's is Rome's Cathedral, but it's not. Don't miss the cloister; pay the entrance fee.

The Pope's Church - Beautiful inside. From outside, you might not realise this is actually a church - the front sort of looks like a grandiose government building, but the inside is beautiful. Well worth a visit if you are in that area of the city.
As beautiful as the Vatican. The church architecture is amazing. If you have the time, it's worth while to visit.
Bascilica di San Giovanni. It was great seeing the arcitecture and history of the building

semi- hidden jem. Beautiful church and stunning sculptures, on a par with St Peters. Very few tourists, as only catholics seem to know significance of pontif's formal seat and visit, but results in no crowds. Dress code is no shorts, sandles, skirts above the knee and no bare shoulders.

Basilica. Yes, we wanted to go in here. The lighting in the Galileo exhibition was poor without any good reason as most of it was modern text explaining various things and photographs of historical items so the lighting could have been better without doing any damage. The information was very enlightening and contradicted what I had thought the church thought about Galileo. Good reading,and all translated into English too.

St John Lateran Basilica. Truly a wonderful experience to visit and have Mass on Sunday morning with 3 bishops and 25 priests on the Altar of this Incredible Basilica. The tour of the Basilica goes back thousands of years. This is a sunday morning, I will never forget.
fair. no entrance fee. the condition of the church is excellent.
Should not be missed. nice walk to get there..and well worth it...then you can walk just outside the old Roman walls and pick up the Metro
The Church across the sreet. We stayed right across the way from here 2 yrs ago and didn't realise the history behind this magnificent Basilica until later. Go there.

Beautiful !. I've visited alot of churches in Europe. San Giovanni in Laterano is one of the most beautiful I have seen. The free audioguide is a must if you enjoy knowing more about what you are seeing. It is rich with information and I stayed for almost one hour listening and walking around.

The first Catholic church. One of the only four major basilicas in the world and the very first one built after the emperor Constantine declaration of Christianity as legal and official religion of the Roman Empire. Visit the tomb of Innocent III, the most powerful medieval pope.
Fantastic. Not one of the most immediate places you would think of going but absolutely worth the visit. Wonderful inside. Just go and see!

After Basilica do San Pietro, thats number 2 within most amazing churches in Rome.. Magnificent... The most important church of Christianity ever. Its beauty is ... speakless. You have to see it, On the other side of the road there are Holy Steps, which Jesus was using. A must see!

Beautiful Church, definitely worth the trip. This church is SE of the Colosseum and a little far from the center, but it's worth every step you take to see it. Not only is the church beautiful, but across from the church/piazza is the Scala Santa, or Holy Staircase. This is one of the four basilicas in Rome. The ceiling, the enormous statues of the 12 apostles, the chapels inside, etc. all make it one of the must-sees of Rome.The Scala Santa is amazing; the steps are marble encased in wood, so it's easier on the knees of those who climb it. There are 3 staircases; the middle one is the Scala Santa (28 steps) to be climbed only on your knees; the other two are for climbing up or down and for those who climb on their knees to go down. It is said these stairs were in Pilate's house in Jerusalem, and were the same that Jesus climbed when He was going to be judged/sentencedthe stairs were brought by Constantine's mother Helena, to Rome in the 4th century.

Basilica di San Giovanni. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome. Offers confessionals in all languages, which I thought was very considerate. The artwork is exquisite and the sculptures impressive.
Fabulous church!. Although not very close to the old historical centre, I would definitely recommend it. Magnificent interior and atmosphere !

See the Pope's church. The best thing about this church to me was the original doors of the Senate, monstrous castings of bronze, used now as the doors to this church, which is the church which the Pope is priest of. St. Peter's is too big for me, and here you have great beauty but also a sense of the spiritual in the interior. Perhaps it's the simplicity of the long rectangular nave, with it's golden ceiling, with giant statues of the 12 Apostles or perhaps it's the amazing golden Basilica at the end, with it's mosaics, or perhaps it's the 18th century facade by Gallilei which is tranquil despite the statuary popping out of the roof or perhaps it's the cloister with its twisting inlaid marble columns. But there's a sense of age and purpose in this church, sometimes called the oldest or mother church. What can you say about a building which was restored for the first time in 460 after the Vandals sacked Rome. You can get there by Subway or bus. The bus back to town leaves from the front.
Fantastic. Everything, wow what a place to visit. we felt very moved in here and overawed. A beautiful place to visit.
Fabulous!. Loved the ostentatiousness, hated the scaffolding!

Not on the main tourist trail, but if you are in the area.... Similiar to St. Peter's Basilica, but smaller. Very well appointed and designed inside. I woudn't make a special bus or taxi trip to just see "another ornate church", but if you are in the area you should definatly stop in.
San Giovanni in Laterno - Must see. This is Rome's cathedral ! Worth the visit. Awesome. Beautiful.
Great. Impressive, especially if you catch the ceremony. We went in for a while and stayed a few hours.

Beautiful church, out of the way location. This church is in my top 5 favorite of Rome. It's stunning and in close proximity to other great sites: Colosseum, Roman Forum, and the Scala Santa. If you're into checking out all the obelisks, this one is one of the most ornate of all. I can't fathom why, but there are few visitors here compared to other churches. If you are a believer, it's perfect for a quiet reflection of one of biggest cities in Christendom.
Dull Basilica. This is probably heresy but this is not the most interesting of the Basilicas

A fascinating building. Wonderful apse mosaics at the end of an enormous basilica with large than life statues of the twelve apostles. Don't miss the wonderfully ornate ceiling! Well worth a visit.The only down side is that it's at a horribly busy crossroad near the city walls.
excellent. A must regarding the religious history of Rome and this I believe predates St Peter's.

The Laterano Bascilica is exceptional!. The bacilica is breath taking, The art and statues and colors used make it exceptional. The side alter areas are also beautiful. And even the last ancient door to the Roman Senate serves as a door there.

History at its most beautiful. If you love to wander around beautiful buildings with an abundance of history, this is for you. Climb the Holy Steps, reputed to come from Pilate's palace and view the basilica to get your fill of what makes Rome so beautiful.

remarkable; usually a missed opportunity. The church that was really the heart of the beginnings of christianity; forget St Peters- an overblown commercial process to enrich the papacy; this has the benefit of being the first church built for the popes by constatntine; its 9th century facade is still there; the heads of St Peter and Paul are in reliquaries on the altar; the doors are roman; there is a fresco by Giotto; then- the tallest obelisk in rome is in the square; the baptistry and associated chapel are roman imperial at its best; then the scala sancta is across the other side of the square; there are the walls; the legionary ampitheatre; the fragments of the true cross in St Croce- a remarkable church itself; the palace of constantine's mother- Helena behind, and of course Porta Maggiore and the bakes tomb just 5 minutes away- all this and no crowds.

A Magnificent Bascilica. WE took a private car so that we could easliy access many of the Churches...St. John Lateran, St Paul outside the Walls, etc. This Basilica was outstanding and if you have an I-Pad there is an App for a wonderful tour.

Worth visiting to see the obelisk. The obelisk in the square is the tallest standing obelisk in the world. It is magnificent. It was also a pleasure to visit a site that was not swamped with tourists.
Beautiful Basilica!. A really beautiful Basilica.....u will see a lot and discover a lot!
Worth seeing it. this is one of the main Basilica's in Rome. The Basilica of the Pope

This Place is a Wonderful Tribute God. Very beautiful, large yet not ostentatious. Magnificant statues and sculpture. A real work of holy art yet comfortable for prayer. We chose to renew our vows there. I could easily spend a very long time here enjoying communion with the Lord in the "Pope's other church". Art enthusiasts will appreciate their visit.
beautiful basilica and piazza. this was a bit far from our hotel (near termini) but well worth it, beautiful place, great to photograph all the angels above it.

Old and Impressive. A lovely little Basilica that is worth the visit if you haven't already visited a 100 just like it already. Take time to have a sit and take in the ambience of this basicilica it is something special.
Very simply but great church. go from the frontside and wait a while when you are entering the church, you will be impressed by the greatnes
Amazingly beautiful basilica. Found it beautiful and well worth a visit. The side chapels are interesting as well.
Amazing Church. This is a sight to behold, well worth exploring and the ceiling & walls are amazing!!

Out of the way but worth the effort. A 1Euro bus ride from Via corsa, this is an absolute gem of a church. home of the papacy before it moved to the vatican, it's a massive, marble floored, huely ornate church. noy quite St Peter's but without the crowds and tourist traps
Awe inspiring. Loved this church...less busy that St Peter's so you get to appreciate all the artistic marvels
it's huge. it is absolutely amazing inside a must see! It is a bit of a walk from the Colosseum though and most of it is up hill.

A Surprise. We actually went to San Giovanni in Laterano to see the Holy Stairs across from it. From the outside San Giovanni was not impressive but inside...oh my goodness. It was well worth the hike (we got lost) to see this splendid church. I highly recommend it to all who visit Rome.
Gorgeous Bascilica. This was truly a must see. Could have spend much more time viewing all of the statues and beauty of this basilica. Truly an inspiring visit.
Beautiful, beautiful. can be reached by metro and worth the trip. Quite huge.
Basilica. It is beautiful. Even if you don't appreciate visiting churches, this is a must see.
Awesome. The oldest church in Rome - well worth a visit. Combine it with a visit to the Coliseum and Trajan market
