San Giovanni in Laterano. Fantastic Basilica. Best seen with a tour guide I think. Get to touch the Holy Door and ask for a blessing. Really close to the Holy Steps (if you want to go up the Holy Steps, know that it must be done on your knees with prayers said on each step, so leave enough time to do that - usually around 1 hour is quoted)
THE BEST ONE.. Dont miss this one. More spiritual than St Peter's which is treated by visitors as a museum. An incredible group of nuns run the fabulous gift shop inside (with GREAT prices too!)
Impressive. Well worth a visit; cloisters are being renovated but the museum is still accessible with the highlight of my visit- a copy of a Monteverdi Mass.
What a place!. You need a good few hours to really appreciate the splendour of this place. The architecture and history is amazing. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful. This was an abslutely beautiful place and a place not to miss although I feel that way about all of Rome no matter where you go you will find beautiful churches like this!

Bishop of Rome's Church. This church has a great history. Many people don't realize that the Pope is the Bishop of Rome also. So many people think that St. Peter's is his church but as bishop it is St. John's. It is well worth the visit to see all the beauty and to hear the history of Christianity in Rome.
Superb Statues.... Beautifully proportioned building with many huge statues inside & a breathtaking ceiling... the small shop inside is definitely worth a visit for gifts too !
Next to Scala Santa. If you are in a luck day, you'll see a wonderful classic music concert.
Wouw!. This church is more beautiful than the church San Pietro.
Wow of a scale. This basilica in comparison with others is not about ornamentation but about the sheer size of it that gets you wonder on the humbling of the soul as man looks upward

An Exceptional site. Part of traveling in Europe is experiencing the historical aspects of it's architectural treasures. This is one of the most important churches in Rome and played a substantial role in the history of the Catholic church. That notwithstanding, I find this to be an exceptional place to spend time. One can never have enough time to really know a place such as this but the beauty of its architecture and the adornment of its interior is enchanting. Even before that, the multi-statued exterior is a clear indication of what's to come. It would serve any traveller to review information about this sacred place before visiting to get the most from it. I loved the large mosaic on the interior dome. Take time to feel the place. Breathe with it. Enjoy another living historical experience here unique among all of Rome's churches.

Cathedral Church of the Bishops of Rome. Not quite as big as St Peters, it is just as impressive. The architecture is a poem of grace and elegance. And no where near as crowded at the Vatican. Absolutely go.

Breathtaking !!. We were so glad we went to see this Basilica. It was a bit out of the way, but since we saw the Vatican on another trip we decided we'd skip the Vatican this time and see this instead. We were not disappointed.

Hidden Gem of the Vatican City State.. Known as the Pope's Basilica it is located around a 5min easy walk from the San Giovanni Metro Station. Located a bit out of the way from most of the other main attractions in Rome means it has far fewer tourists.While quite impressive from the outside (but let's face it, impressive facades in Rome are a dime a dozen) it is only when you enter that you are left awestruck by its sheer beauty. Words can only fail to describe this place so I won't try, suffice to say that everything from the statues, to the frescoes, alter pieces and the architecture itself is sublime.Though still a tourist attraction, it is also a 'working' church and while photo's are allowed in all the main areas, the areas set aside for prayer are off limits to cameras providing a bit off peace and quiet from the normal hustle and bustle of Rome. There are also a number of confessionals with priests providing confession in a number of languages.Entry to the church is free though a donation is appreciated but not asked for. The same goes for the toilets. There is a donation box but it's not obligatory. Audio guides are available at the front door as well as 'audio-points' within for those who want a more in depth understanding of this place.Having seen many sights in this magnificent city, I have to say as far as churches go this was the highlight for me, even topping The Basilica and the Parthenon. I spent around an hour and a half here and left feeling refreshed.Two thumbs up - Highly Recommended.

The mother church of the whole inhabited world. The Papal Archbasilica of St. John Lateran is the cathedral of the city of Rome (not St. Peter's), and is the official seat of the Bishop of Rome, who is also the Pope. Apparently, it ranks above all other churches in the Catholic Church, including St. Peter's. It has the title "mother church of the whole inhabited world" and is the oldest among the four papal basilicas. It also houses the papal throne. To get to St. John Lateran, take the metro and alight at the Manzoni station. The basilica is just a few minutes walk from there.Like all the other papal basilicas, St. John Lateran has a Holy Door which is opened during Jubilee years, when pilgrims enter through the door to gain indulgence. This Holy Door was last opened and closed by Pope John Paul II. The Holy Door has oxidized except for the left foot of the Child Jesus, probably where numerous faithful keep rubbing it for luck or grace. I definitely rubbed the foot of the Child Jesus for both when I visited the basilica, as it was raining then, and I was praying for it to stop. And indeed, it stopped!Although not as big as St. Peter's, St. John Lateran is still massive. It has six existing papal tombs inside. Unfortunately, I only noticed Pope Martin V's tomb, which was pretty hard to miss considering it was located right in front of the confessio. The aisle of the basilica is flanked by niches with huge statues of the twelve apostles.

The Pope's Church. A beautiful church with the Sacred Steps across the street. I climbed all 28 of them on knees while imagining the pain that Jesus suffered on the Way of the Cross and His Crucifixition. I am in awe of what this church offers.Be wary of the beggars and gypies hacking their wares, especially scarves, around the perimeter of the church. If you do happen to see something you like, offer them less than the asking price and negotiate. Or, nod your head and smile or just say "no,"

Mixed messages about the tomb versus the head of Saint Paul. We stopped to visit the tomb of Saint Paul, as previous reviews indicated. We did not find it, and we asked the workers at the church, they declined its presence in this church. Some, helpful! Knowledgeable! Worker said this church contains head bones (skulls!!!) of both St. Paul and St. Peter, and both are on display above the main alter. After some reading, the claim of St. Paul skull may be correct, and the rest of his body may be at a church called St. Paul Outside the Walls (Basilica di San Paolo Fuori le Mura). On the other hand, the skull of saint peter may be not. It happened that two days earlier I had private tour at the Vatican necropolis and the professor who guided us said that St. Peter bones (all 170 found pieces) are present in the graffiti tomb under the Vatican. I saw two bones of St. Peter that were displayed for us to view. Also I read at Frommer’s the following about the steps; which I did not look for in this church: “It's alleged that the 28 marble steps (now covered with wood for preservation) were originally at Pontius Pilate's villa in Jerusalem and that Christ climbed them the day he was brought before Pilate. According to tradition, Constantine's mother, Helen, brought the steps from Jerusalem to Rome in 326, and they've been in this location since 1589. Today pilgrims from the world over come to climb the steps on their knees. This is one of the holiest sites in Christendom, although some historians say the stairs may date only to the 4th century.”I strongly recommend reading some history or even travel books about this church before you visit it (I made a huge mistake by not doing that).

Don't miss this - expecially the baptistry. His is a truly beautiful basilica and in my opinion much more pleasant than the more frequently visited St Peters. There are still quite a number of tourists around the place but it's nothing like the crowds heaving inside St Peters. This basilica also looks less... trashy?... than St Peter's. It's still very elaborate and richly decorated but not in the over the top way that some other places in Rome are. The baptistry is a real highlight of any visit here, particularly the ceilings and frescoes in the side chapels. We had looked forward to seeing the cloisters as well but unfortunately the garden was actually being dug up and was cordonned off behind screens which rather ruined the effect.

Beautiful church outside the Vatican. This church is really beautiful, and much less crowded than St. Peter's. It is close to a metro stop which makes it easily accessible from some of the more popular tourst areas in Rome. I highly recommend making the trip out here, and then across the street to see the Scala Santa. However, make sure you check the opening times because the Scala Santa is only open I believe in the morning and then again from 3:30-5:30. We got there right at 3:30 and people rushed the stairs, but it was cool to see it with no one on them initially.

Not to be missed. Excavations carried out in the past years have revealed the tomb of St. Paul which can now be seen under the main (papal) altar. A very quite place for prayer since it requires some knowledge to get there since it is about 10 minutes away from the tourist center by metro.

Archbasilica of Rome & First Place of Public Worship in the World. This is a wonderful and interesting church to visit. The audio tour that is available is definitely worth it and the tour is by donation so you aren't charged for it up front. You give what you can and it is definitely worth a few euro to learn the history of this church. Also, don't forget to go across the street to see the Sacred Stairs. It is truly inspiring to see pilgrims making their way up the stairs on their knees and to also see the blood of Christ on the first step.

The Best Basilica in Rome. I was speechless when I entered this Basilica. it was absolutely breathtaking! In my opinion, St Peter's basilica was not as great. It was so good I dragged my wife to see it when we both stopped by Rome.
Beautiful Cathedral of Rome. Many people do not realize this is the actual Cathedral of Rome, one of the our Major Basilicas. ull of history and beautiful sculptures. Highly recommneded

Don't visit only the church!. Although it's magnificent in its own, be sure to visit the beautiful Battistery and the awe-inspiring (due to the faithful climbing it on their knees) Scala Santa (Holy Staircase) across the square.

Wow. On our last day in Rome (before heading to Venice) my wife and I decided that we'd trysomething a bit off the beaten path and I am very glad that we did. This Basilica is outstanding. It is part of the Vatican and it is as spectacular as St. Peter's. It hosts the seat of the Bishop of Rome (the Pope) and the chair a newly elected Pope must sit in after election to make it official. There are many magnificent sculpturs but the biggest treat are the front doors. They are from the original Senate. You can go over and grab the handles that Caesars grabbed, perhaps Cicero. We grabbed a cab to get us there and then walked back to the city centre after visiting the Scala Sacra which are just across the stree from the Basilica.

Awesome Basilica. San Giovanni in Laterano is an awesome Basilica in Rome. It is also the seat of the Pope, since it is a cathedral while St. Peter's is not. Its soaring marble arches are incredible. If you go during December there are some beautiful ceremonies which are awe-inspiring

Not very impressive but a large church. This is the mother of all Roman Catholic churches. It dominates the piazza where it is located. It is easily accessible via metro as the station is just opposite the main entrance. The church is large and the interior is vast. There isn't as much to see as St Peter's Basilica or Santa Maria Maggiore but the large central cyborium and the statues of the apostles are beautiful.

Best kept secret in Rome. I have been to Rome three times, and finally managed to make the trek to San Giovanni in Laterano. I have no idea why it is so overlooked in guidebooks and reviews. This is a VERY LARGE cathedral and it is ornate with some outstanding features. Beautiful and intricate marble floors, frescos, a beautiful apse, exquisitely detailed 16th century Medici ceilings and incredible reliefs and sculptures. St. Bartholomew by Pierre Legros is simply amazing!If you enjoy the cathedrals, this is a MUST SEE place on a trip to Rome. I have seen St. Peter's, Barcelona Cathedral, Duomo in Milan, and a host of others, but this would probably rank second to St. Peter's on my "need to see" list.The outside is very deceiving on this cathedral, and perhaps that is the problem. But when you walk in, it is that much more breathtaking because you aren't sure what to expect and you are going to be impressed.There is a good page here: [--]
